webTitle: Wilkinson's hopes for revenge lost in the mist

fields.headline: Wilkinson's hopes for revenge lost in the mist
fields.trailText: The famous autumn mists of the nebbia were the only winners in England's U-21 fixture against Italy in Monza last night when the match was abandoned after barely 10 minutes of play.
fields.body:
Whoever scheduled England's Under-21 fixture against Italy for a November night in Monza's Stadio Brianteo had reckoned without the nebbia - the famous drifting autumn mists of Lombardy which close Milan's airports for weeks at a time. After barely 10 minutes of play, the referee called the match off, depriving Howard Wilkinson's side of the chance to take their revenge for their defeat at Italy's hands in the European Under-21 Championship finals in the summer.

The mist descended a quarter of an hour before the kick-off, but the Bulgarian referee took advantage of a temporary dispersal to start the match five minutes late. Italy had an opportunity to take the lead after four minutes when Owen Hargreaves, the 19-year-old midfield player currently learning his trade in Bayern Munich's reserves, gave possession away just outside the England area. The ball broke to Emiliano Bonazzoli, who looked likely to score until Ledley King exerted just enough pressure to force an inaccurate shot from the Verona forward.

But when the referee, like everyone else in the stadium, lost sight of a clearance kick by the Italian goalkeeper, he decided that he had seen enough, or rather not enough, and called the players off before cancelling the match altogether a few minutes later.

Wilkinson, the FA's technical director, had picked a side to play in a 4-3-2-1 formation, the so-called "Christmas tree", with the two young Manchester United wingers, Luke Chadwick and Jonathan Greening, supporting the lone striker, Darius Vassell.

Injuries and the youth policy suddenly adopted by England's senior side had cost him the presence of several eligible players, notably Joe Cole, John Terry, Paul Robinson, Alan Smith, John Terry, Chris Riggott and Wes Brown.

"We lost, but we weren't beaten," Wilkinson had said after the 2-0 defeat by Italy in Slovakia, which seemed a triumph of self-delusion. At that time the junior Azzurri were supervised by Marco Tardelli, who took them to the European title and then to a disappointing quarter-final elimination by Spain in the Olympic tournament before moving into club football as the coach of Internazionale and handing over the Under-21s to Claudio Gentile.

webTitle: Jefferies at the head of Bradford shortlist

fields.headline: Jefferies at the head of Bradford shortlist
fields.trailText: Just 10 days after leaving Hearts, Jim Jefferies has emerged as the man most likely to take over at Bradford City.
fields.body:
The former Hearts manager Jim Jefferies has emerged as the man most likely to be handed the task of preserving Bradford City's Premiership status. Just 10 days after leaving the Edinburgh club by mutual consent, Jefferies yesterday travelled to Valley Parade for talks.

Bradford's chairman Geoffrey Richmond believes Jefferies has the necessary experience to succeed Chris Hutchings, who was sacked a week ago five months after being installed as first-team coach.

Although the former Scottish international Stuart McCall took charge of the team on Saturday, when Bradford slipped to the bottom of the Premiership after losing 1-0 at home to Everton, he has no interest in succeeding Hutchings on a permanent basis and has implored Richmond to move swiftly to find a new manager.

The two other men believed to be on Richmond's short-list are Howard Kendall, the three-time manager of Everton, and the former Liverpool manager Roy Evans.

Kendall recently rejected the chance to pick up the threads of a fractured managerial career in Cyprus, while Evans has been out of work since severing his ties with Liverpool two years ago.

Brazil's new coach Emerson Leao will begin his reign in the stand today when his side play Colombia in a World Cup qualifier in Sao Paulo. Leao, who took charge after Wanderley Luxemburgo was sacked in September, is serving a 20-day touchline ban after being sent off in a match involving his club side Sport Recife.

Brazil will be without Romario. The 34-year-old striker, who has scored seven goals in their last two matches, pulled a muscle in training on Monday and has been replaced by his bitter rival Edmundo.

Despite lying second in the South American group, five points behind Argentina, Brazil's form has been patchy - they have lost to Chile and Paraguay - and, asked if he could make the players perform as a team, Leao said: "Only if I were a magician."

In a bid to secure victory, Leao is giving Barcelona's Rivaldo a free role. "A player like Rivaldo has to play free," he said. "He has a vision of the game when the ball is in motion that few have."

The Premiership's 22 referees were able to breathe a sigh of relief yesterday with the news that the Football Association has declared them all competent at their job.

The announcement came after the first two-monthly review of referees' performances. The reviews were introduced this season in an attempt to make referees more accountable for their actions.

But while no Premiership referee has been "relegated" so far, they would be unwise to rest on their laurels as the FA also announced it would continue to reward promising Nationwide officials.

The first to benefit from the new system are Matt Matthias of York and Gloucester's Clive Wilkes, who will make their Premiership debuts on December 16. Wilkes will take charge of Everton's game with West Ham and Matthias of Coventry's visit to Derby.

However, there is no quick return for the two officials demoted by the Premier League last summer. Both Uriah Rennie and Paul Alcock have been overlooked for a recall.

Rangers have switched the date for the home leg of their Uefa Cup third-round match with Kaiserslautern after Dundee agreed to postpone a league trip to Ibrox. The match will now take place two weeks tomorrow in order to accommodate German television demands.

The switch gives Rangers extra time to prepare for the Old Firm derby a week on Sunday, which under the original schedule was due to be played at Ibrox three days after the Uefa Cup first leg.

Arsenal have signed the 20-year-old defender Rhys Weston from Cardiff City of the Third Division for an undisclosed fee, subject to the player agreeing personal terms and passing a medical.

The former Chelsea midfielder Eddie Newton turns out for Cheltenham reserves today - just three years after scoring in Chelsea's 2-0 win over Middlesbrough in the FA Cup final. Newton, 28, recently spent a month on trial at the Third Division club Barnet.

webTitle: Inter woe a threat to Keane's Ireland place

fields.headline: Inter woe a threat to Keane's Ireland place
fields.trailText: It seems a long time ago now since Ian Rush went to Italy and famously remarked that it was like being in a different country.
fields.body:
It seems a long time ago now since Ian Rush went to Italy and famously remarked that it was like being in a different country.

Robbie Keane, like everyone else, knows what Rush probably meant to say although, in terms of la dolce vita , the Irish striker might well believe he is yet to get his fair share.

Four months after swapping Coventry for Internazionale, his Italian job, like the film of the same name, is coming to a cliff's edge. The question must be whether "Baby Irish" can pull himself back from the brink before he topples over the precipice.

Keane's form has slumped since Marcelo Lippi's sacking and, in a recent poll of 10,000 Inter supporters, only one in five believed the 20-year-old striker merited a first-team place.

More damagingly, however, there are dark rumours in the Italian media that Lippi's successor Marco Tardelli has been considering loaning Keane to one of several interested clubs, headed by Reggina, in Serie A.

Inter have rejected the suggestions but the Republic of Ireland manager Mick McCarthy has seen enough of Keane over the last couple of days to notice a slight dip in the Dubliner's confidence.

"As a footballer you are always trying to improve yourself," said McCarthy. "Well, I doubt if Robbie can improve his contract, or his club. But he will want to get playing again, that's for certain."

McCarthy is happy to stick with the team that drew in Holland and Portugal as his strongest XI but will make changes if those players are struggling in club football. "I will review the situation over the next three or four months," he said.

Keane will be acutely aware of that, as will Manchester City's Richard Dunne and Blackburn Rovers' Jason McAteer and Alan Kelly.

Tonight, against a Finnish side preparing for their World Cup qualifier against England at Anfield next March, the absence of Niall Quinn means Dominic Foley will partner Keane in attack, while Ipswich's Matt Holland will replace Roy Keane, who has a hamstring injury, in midfield.

fields.headline: Hendry's Scotland future in doubt
fields.trailText: Colin Hendry's international career appeared to be shuddering to a halt last night when even Craig Brown, the Scotland manager and Hendry's foremost fan, admitted that he could not select him for any more matches, starting with tonight's friendly against Australia in Glasgow, unless Hendry resumes playing first-team football.
fields.body:
Colin Hendry's international career appeared to be shuddering to a halt last night when even Craig Brown, the Scotland manager and Hendry's foremost fan, admitted that he could not select him for any more matches, starting with tonight's friendly against Australia in Glasgow, unless Hendry resumes playing first-team football.

The 34-year-old Scotland captain is now firmly out of Gordon Strachan's plans at Coventry City, capping a dismal two years in his career. Hendry's move to Rangers in the summer of 1998 for £3m, reputedly to become captain of the club, turned into one of the great transfer fiascos and he has had even less joy since moving to Coventry, having been both jeered by supporters and badly injured.

After 48 caps, Hendry is just a blond forelock away from the 50-cap mark that would qualify him for the Scottish Football Association's hall of fame. Brown, though, has gambled with the player in the past and watched Hendry pay for it. It was no coincidence that he had not played for three months prior to last season's Euro 2000 play-offs against England and, having started both matches, did not appear for another 10 weeks having exacerbated his knee problem.

"I've had to be honest with Colin and tell him that I can't go on selecting him unless he is playing for a club," said Brown. "I hope this is not the end of the road for him with us but he needs to resume playing. He'll be on the bench against Australia but I can say for certain he won't be selected against Belgium in March unless his situation has changed."

Brown will give Brian O'Neil, recently arrived at Derby County from Wolfsburg, a chance again to establish himself at the heart of the Scottish defence. It was Brown who gave him his debut four years ago, coincidentally against Australia in a 1-0 win at Hampden Park.

"We had him in midfield and I think he is more suited to the role he's in now," said the Scotland coach. "He would be the first to admit he is not an international midfielder, but he is an international defender. "

Dominic Matteo will also be given his Scotland bow, probably at left wing-back. Barry Ferguson and Craig Burley will be in midfield while Hendry's absence means a new captain is needed and this looks set to be Celtic's Tom Boyd.

Leeds United's Mark Viduka, the short-lived favourite son of Celtic, will probably be on the Australian bench.

webTitle: Taylor's selection will lead to tears before bedtime

fields.headline: Taylor's selection will lead to tears before bedtime
fields.trailText: Peter Taylor's choices for the Italy match suggest he still has some unfinished business to clear up from his days as the England Under-21 coach. It is a wasted opportunity.
fields.body:
Peter Taylor is famous, in his various changing rooms, for his brilliant impersonation of the cockney clown Norman Wisdom. He intends to play it straight in Turin tonight but there is growing apprehension that there could be trouble in store.

Even our Norm would not have carelessly mislaid so many members of his England squad before a friendly against Italy, though Taylor's choice of David Beckham as captain should at least help prevent yet another withdrawal by a Manchester United player.

But it was the caretaker manager's original selection that was most disappointing. If this was the best an England manager could do, the Football Association clearly did the right thing in turning to Sven-Goran Eriksson.

Taylor is a likeable and impressive young manager. But his choices for this match suggest he still has some unfinished business to clear up from his days as the England Under-21 coach.

It may make a refreshing change from the intense conservatism of his predecessors. But, without wishing to appear youthist, Taylor has gone too far the other way. Friendly or no friendly, Italy is a place for grown-ups.

If he really wanted his callow charges to learn a thing or two he should have pitched them in with a few old sweats. What, for example, can Kieron Dyer possibly learn from Gareth Barry, or Nicky Butt from Emile Heskey? How to lose, probably.

There are also some curious individual selections in the squad. Why Michael Ball, who cannot nail down a place in a struggling Everton side? And, if Taylor wanted us to take his youth opportunities scheme seriously, why didn't he find room when the selection was originally made for the most exciting young player of them all, West Ham's Joe Cole?

But it is the balance, or rather the imbalance, that is the most worrying feature of Taylor's brave new dusk. There is an alarming lack of experience to help the kids through against the streetwise Italians.

English football is not short of young talent. Just look at Michael Owen, Paul Scholes, Cole, Barry and Gerrard. What it is short of is the experience of playing together and Taylor's pick 'n mix line-up will do nothing whatsoever to prepare England for the more meaningful World Cup matches to come. Eriksson must be as bewildered as everyone else.

This is a wasted opportunity and one that means it will be Taylor's wisdom, not his Wisdom, that is questioned in Italy tonight.

It would be nice to report that England's cricketers, who are also in action today, are more thoroughly prepared, but this is hardly the case.

There is, of course, the terrifying possibility that the first Test against Pakistan in Lahore is already a few hours old as you alight upon these trifles, and at this very moment Pakistan could be 63 for eight, but no matter.

England have had an impressive month in Pakistan when you consider what they have been up against, what with unfamiliar conditions, iffy umpiring, injuries, fly swarms, tear gas, thrown bottles and allegations of dodgy dealings with bookmakers.

They have won matches and, with some patience and charm, worked equally hard at bridge-building after the troubles of 1987. Unfortunately, after a good start, their recent efforts have not exactly been in the Isambard Kingdom Brunel class.

If Andrew Caddick wasn't bad enough, with his sledging of a batsman, his show of dissent to the umpire Sajjad Asghar and his disparaging remarks about Pakistan, what followed was even worse.

The captain Nasser Hussain, who at first denied that Caddick had even spoken to the umpire, then appeared to condone the behaviour of his player. The worst thing England can do in Pakistan is develop a siege mentality, something they had wisely avoided until now.

Not content with this, England also dropped a 17-stone clanger when they sent Andrew Flintoff home two weeks ago, as if they couldn't afford the hotel room.

As many observed at the time, Flintoff should have remained. To carry on with just seven batsmen, when there was always a possibility that all would be required, was optimism in the extreme.

webTitle: Manual recount will not be stopped

fields.headline: Manual recount will not be stopped
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Florida supreme court rejects Republican legal block to hand counts in contested counties
fields.body:
10pm: Florida's highest court has rejected a request from the Republicans to delay manual recounts in the crucial counties on which the presidential election result depends.

Katherine Harris, the secretary of state for Florida, and a Republican, had asked the Florida supreme court to order a halt to ongoing manual recounts "pending resolution as to whether any basis exists for their legitimacy."

She also asked that the various legal actions around the state be transferred to the local circuit court in Tallahassee, the state capital, where she asked that all new suits to do with the election be filed.

fields.headline: Italy 1 - 0 England
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Italy: Buffon, Cannavaro, Nesta, Maldini, Di Livio, Albertini, Gattuso, Coco, Fiore, F. Inzaghi, Delvecchio. Subs: Toldo, Adani, Bertotto, Pancaro, Pessotto, Ambrosini, Di Biagio, D. Zenoni, Del Piero, S. Inzaghi.

England: James, Ferdinand, Southgate, Barry, G. Neville, Beckham, Butt, Dyer, Parlour, Barmby, Heskey. Subs: Wright, Carragher, Fowler, Phillips, Johnson, Lampard, P. Neville, Anderton, Ball, Robinson.

1 Barmby kicks off after a minute's silence to mark a tragedy in the Agnelli family, long-time patrons of Juventus. Barely 20,000 people are present to witness the dawning of a new England.
2 Italy have the first chance when a cross from the left results in a corner on the right. Fiore takes but England clear. First touch for David James.
3 Fiore looking lively from the start, and Butt looks to be the man charged with keeping him in check.
5 Beckham tries to put his much-vaunted vision to good use early on whem he tries to release Heskey through the middle - to no avail.
6 Shocking free-kick from Italy 30 yards out to the left - ends up looking more like a pass to the loose England wall.
8 Italy push up in response to England's first meaningful move into the home side's half. Gattuso's cross into the penalty area is headed back by Southgate, but it leaves James with some work to do before the ball can be gathered.
10 Parlour releases Heskey on the right and then picks up the return, but his cross fails to find Barmby on the edge of the six-yard box.
13 Delvecchio has the first clear chance for Italy when, under pressure from a defender, he does well to lift the ball over James - and the crossbar. England win a free-kick despite an apparent shove on Delvecchio.
17 Good chance for England. Beckham finds Heskey on the edge of the penalty area and the big Liverpool striker whacks it first time... into ranks of empty seats.
20 Heskey turns Maldini just inside the area but a perfectly timed challenge by Nesta leaves Heskey looking like he has been mugged.
22 Di Livio has a pop from 25 yards but, despite a bobble halfway in, a calamity is avoided by James in the England goal.
23 England free-kick after a nudge on Heskey by Cannavaro - Beckham repeatedly wafts the ball towards Heskey who is lurking around the area.
25 Substitution Carragher on for Butt. Gattuso, Di Livio and Barry form a pact and conspire to embarrass James by making him scramble to get a loose ball, but to his credit James recovers well and gets there first.
28 Inzaghi cuts inside Neville but his pass does nothing to help Fiore and Delvecchio do anything constructive - Delvecchio resorts to a kind of demi-dive that the ref choses to ignore.
30 Nothing too constructive from Italy so far, and England look capable of playing themselves into this game as the evening wears on. That said, England have so far had no attempts on target compared to Italy's two.
34 Dyer plays the ball to Beckham slap bang in the middle of the park; Dyer continues his run but Beckham looks up, advances and shoots from 30 yards, forcing keeper Buffon to make the save.
36 Great work by Ferdinand after his deep centre finds Heskey 20 yards out, but Heskey's control lets him down and Italy recover ground to clear. Italy respond on the break with Inzaghi through the middle - he finds Delvecchio out on the right but the resulting cross is poor and James claims.
37 England free-kick 25 yards out to the right - Beckham takes towards an on-running head but Italy clear.
41 Italy win a free-kick out on the right after Di Livio goes down like a sack of pasta under pressure from Barry. No worry, it's straight at James.
44 England free-kick from 35 yards out - Beckham takes to the far side of the six-yard box, but, although Southgate is closest, no English player is in position for the chance.
45 England's first corner; Beckham takes straight at Buffon. Half-time - not a bad effort from England's young side, helped in no small measure by Italy not pushing the game too hard.

46 No changes as Italy get the second half underway.
47 Italy free-kick 25 yards out to the right - played short for Di Livio to waste a cross.
48 Italy seem more keen to keep England pinned back but Heskey gets away on the right before seeing his cross blocked by Cannavaro. Corner; comes to nothing.
50 Italy knock it around centre circle before a speculative centre towards James pops out from the throng of blue shirts - still not a lot of invention from the Azzuri.
53 Substitutions Di Biagio and Zenoni on for Albertini and Di Livio. The Italian bench decide enough is enough and try to inject some inspiration to their team's performance.
54 Italy free-kick after Southgate catches Inzaghi 25 yards out - Di Biagio blasts it high over the bar.
57 Barmby races away and finds Heskey deep on the left. Heskey crosses to the far side and Buffon only just manages to block the resulting shot. Referee misses a swipe at Beckham by Gattuso.
58 GOAL Gattuso, lucky to stay on the pitch, winds up his right foot 25 yard out and scores off the underside of the bar.
61 Substitution S Inzaghi on for Delvecchio.
63 A mistake by Nesta almost allows Dyer to get in a shot from six yards; Barmby, on the overlap, cuts it back, but Buffon clears for a corner.
64 Heskey looks to have been pulled down and claims a penalty. Nothing doing.
67 Substitution Adani on for Nesta. England having a good spell since going a goal down and win their fourth corner. Beckham takes but Italy clear.
69 Beckham continues to spray balls out from midfield; he trys to find Parlour on a run down the right, but Italy read it well.
71 James almost has a calamitous moment when he comes for a ball, decides against it and is almost caught 15 yards off his line. In a way, it almost seems a shame he wasn't.
Substitutions Del Piero on for F Inzaghi. Big cheers from the local Juve supporters for that one. Phillips and Johnson on for Heskey and Barry.
74 Substitution Bertotto on for Maldini. Johnson has a goal-scoring chance with his first touch when he gets in a toe-poke from six yards anly to see it go over the bar.
78 Substitution Anderton on for Parlour. Terrible atmosphere in the stadium now as driving rain silences those fans that made effort to turn up for tonight's admittedly meaningless game.
80 Italy free-kick deep on the left. Del Piero takes, decides to go for goal and is unlucky to see a blinding effort skim off the crossbar.
83 Substitution Fowler on for Dyer.
84 England continue to knock balls in to Phillips and Fowler, but all that results is another corner. Beckham takes from the left and Southgate gets up to head over the bar. What good is that, Gareth?
87 It's all becoming quite painful and it almost feels as though the game is being played behind closed doors, bar a couple of horns going off and a ghostly rumble when someone tries something different.
90 Two minutes of extra torture time to play. Curiously, the crowd briefly spring to life at the prospect of a swift finish. England have last stab at the Italy area before the ref calls time. The verdict on the Taylor Experiment? Could have done worse, but none the wiser after a soaking in the shadow of the Alps.

webTitle: RSPB investments linked to TotalFina oil spill

fields.headline: RSPB investments linked to TotalFina oil spill
fields.trailText: The Royal Society for the Protection of Birds is putting its investment house in order after discovering that it holds shares in a company implicated in an oil spill that killed hundreds of thousands of birds in December.
fields.body:
The Royal Society for the Protection of Birds is putting its investment house in order after discovering that it holds shares in a company implicated in an oil spill that killed hundreds of thousands of birds in December.

RSPB found out that an overseas fund, managed on its behalf by Merrill Lynch, has shares in TotalFina, the company that chartered the tanker Erika, which sank off the coast of Britanny. Oil from the stricken ship leaked out, killing between 120,000 and 300,000 sea birds.

A spokesperson from the environment charity said: "We are obviously very unhappy about the situation and trying to put the matter straight. We will be looking to reinvest the funds elsewhere, in a greener home."

The funds are contained in an overseas unit trust that holds shares in almost one hundred companies. "It was part of a basket of funds and was not easy to spot," claimed a charity representative, who confirmed, however, that 80% of its funds are held in the UK and are ethically screened.

A spokesperson from Merrill Lynch said a spread of funds was vital for a charity's investment security. "We provide a product that gives charities exposure to overseas equities."

However, he denied that it was the investment company's responsibility to avoid exposure to media scrutiny. "We are very concerned about adverse publicity, but we provide a product that charities can choose to buy into."

webTitle: Comment: The culture of secrecy that dooms our hospitals to failure

fields.headline: Comment: The culture of secrecy that dooms our hospitals to failure
fields.standfirst: Ignoring embarrassing  problems is at the heart of bad NHS practice
fields.trailText: If health care is to improve the NHS must sweep away the culture of cover-ups and complacency, says health reporter Patrick Butler.
fields.body:
As a snapshot of the state of the NHS, the three reports into failing hospitals published today make disturbing reading.

In particular, the revelations of inhumane, sadistic cruelty at North Lakeland NHS trust, where mentally ill patients were tied to their commodes, almost beggar belief.

But the Lakeland case - assuming, hopefully, that it is a rare, extreme occurrence - is probably the least useful in gauging the problems facing the health service as it begins to implement the NHS plan reforms.

It is the relatively less shocking findings of the Oxford Heart Centre report which go to the heart of why the NHS is commonly perceived to be uncaring, unresponsive and incapable of raising standards of care.

That report detailed a culture where poor care went largely unchallenged, and if it was, it was ignored or pushed under the carpet. It depicts an environment where staff felt intimidated into not raising the alarm over bad practice.

These failures reflect a deep structural fault in the collective NHS psyche, an endemic fear of "rocking the boat", of questioning powerful individuals, particularly doctors, out of fear of retribution. This encourages in turn a pervasive, and perverse, culture of secrecy.

When health minister John Denham called the management at Oxford "dysfunctional" he meant there was an institutionalised culture of non-accountability in which professional interests were protected at the expense of patients.

At Lakeland trust, student nurses first raised concerns about abuse on the wards in 1996, but no action was taken. A clear lesson of these reports is that if standards are to improve, the culture of "omerta" in NHS institutions must be swept away.

The NHS and ministers must lead by example. It is easy to implore NHS staff to blow the whistle on abuses and failures. But staff take their lead from the top, and there are few organisations more sensitive about "keeping up appearances" than the government and the Department of Health.

Which brings us to the commission for health improvement (CHI), whose investigations accounted for two of the reports. Billed - not by its own members - as the "Ofsted of the NHS" its appearance on the NHS scene has sent shivers of apprehension across the NHS.

Managers and doctors worry that they will be "named and shamed" in the same way that the office for standards in education has pointed the finger at schools. Such worries can quickly create a climate of paranoia and, yes, secrecy.

Reputations and careers are at stake. As CHI prepares to assess every NHS body over the next four years it must tread carefully. It will have failed if it merely creates a new culture of secrecy among senior health staff prepared to conceal and dissemble in order to prevent the inspector calling.

fields.headline: Lythgoe goes to Carlton
fields.trailText: 6pmThe man behind some of LWT's biggest entertainers including Cilla Black and Barrymore is off to join arch rival Carlton to make Survivor!.
fields.body:
The man behind some of LWT's biggest entertainers including Cilla Black and Barrymore is off to join arch rival Carlton to make Survivor!.

After weeks of wrangling over terms, LWT parent Granada has allowed controller of entertainment and comedy Nigel Lythgoe take up the temporary residence as executive producer on the new reality game show.

Only a week ago, executives at Carlton were complaining that Granada were trying to block the six month secondment.

It is understood LWT were looking for compensation of up to £200,000 to cover his salary, pension and bonuses.

The deal marks the first big collaborative deal between the two ITV rivals and could be the start of a new era.

webTitle: In brief, 6pm: Fast Show suits Johnny Depp

fields.headline: In brief, 6pm: Fast Show suits Johnny Depp
fields.trailText: Plus: Minnie Driver joins the Gwyneth Paltrow club of warbling actresses, Paltrow gets hot with baked beans heir, Will Smith swears off gambling, Tom Jones to croon at Douglas-Zeta-Jones wedding, and pictures from Jurassic Park 3 now available
fields.body:
 Johnny Depp (pictured) has filmed a sketch for the BBC comedy programme, The Fast Show. The star, who lives in Paris, is a big fan of the show and managed to slot in some time with Fast Show regulars, Mark Williams and Paul Whitehouse, whilst filming in England. Depp will appear in the sexually provocative 'Suits You' sketch which will be shown on BBC2 at Christmas. To have a look at a photo from the sketch go to the BBC website.

 First we had Gwyneth Paltrow warbling alongside Huey Lewis in her latest film Duets. Now, Minnie Driver announces that she is to release an album with singer-actor Chris Isaak. The pair recently performed together at Toronto's House of Blues club, said music website Music365, and plan to release an album next year. Driver apparently recorded an album back in the early 90s which was never released, whereupon she dropped the idea of becoming a pop star and concentrated on acting. Sam Slovick, Driver's co-producer on the project, said of the music: "The idea is to make the record she wants to make and not succumb to any external pressure, because the reality is she is really, really good."

 The British tabloids are today full of the budding romance between the aforementioned Gwyneth and the heir to the Heinz Baked Beans empire, Chris Heinz. The pair were spotted dining in New York recently and the 27-year-old Harvard Business School student then flew Paltrow to London for a romantic break. A 'close friend' of Paltrow's told the Daily Mirror: "She says he's a breath of fresh air after all the showbusiness boyfriends she's had."

 Will Smith has admitted to losing $60,000 in 20 minutes whilst filming The Legend of Bagger Vance in Las Vegas. News website Ananova reports that Smith, shocked at losing so much money in so little time, told his golf coach Ron Del Barrio: "I guarantee you this - you will never see me gamble again." According to Del Barrio, the Men In Black star has kept his word after claiming: "That's how I am, I learn a lesson and I don't forget it."

 Gossip site Peoplenews has reported that Welsh crooner Tom Jones is to sing at the wedding of Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta-Jones this coming Saturday in New York (see our earlier story). Tom is expected to sing in his native Welsh although it is not clear exactly which song he has been asked to sing.

 RefreshMagazine has some 'exclusive' pictures from the set of Jurassic Park 3. Universal Pictures had kept the set firmly under wraps until now, but found it difficult to hide the man-made mountain for much longer.

webTitle: Woodhead under fire for degree attack

fields.headline: Woodhead under fire for degree attack
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The recent criticism of "vacuous degrees" by the outgoing chief inspector of schools, Chris Woodhead, was "ill-informed, ill-considered and unconstructive", the head of the government's universities watchdog claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
The recent criticism of "vacuous degrees" by the outgoing chief inspector of schools, Chris Woodhead, was "ill-informed, ill-considered and unconstructive", the head of the government's universities watchdog claimed yesterday.

The latest counterblast against the head of the office for standards in education came as officials at the Department for Education and Employment considered the need for a damage limitation exercise in the run-up to his departure from the post at the end of the month.

They fear that Mr Woodhead may use the publication of two reports to launch a final, devastating attack on government education policies before he starts his new job.

Yesterday John Randall, chief executive of the quality assurance agency for higher education, broke his public silence on the issue to criticise Mr Woodhead's foray into higher education - an area outside his remit.

In a newspaper article in August, Mr Woodhead accused universities of devaluing the sector by offering a "plethora of quasi-academic courses", such as media studies and beauty therapy.

Speaking yesterday at a con ference unveiling new criteria for degree standard in universities, Mr Randall said: "A few weeks ago the now departing chief inspector of schools launched an attack on what he described as vacuous degrees. I found that an ill-informed, ill-considered and unconstructive comment.

"It is not sensible to dismiss glibly whole fields of academic endeavour."

Mr Woodhead was questioned by MPs on the Commons select committee on his public comments on areas outside his reponsibility two weeks ago, the day before he announced his resignation after six years in the post.

He is leaving at the end of the month to take up a new career next spring as a columnist for the Daily Telegraph and as a public relations consultant. The MPs referred to private correspondence from Mr Randall to Mr Woodhead in which Mr Randall made clear he was furious at the chief inspector's comments.

webTitle: Harrison attacker detained in psychiatric hospital

fields.headline: Harrison attacker detained in psychiatric hospital
fields.standfirst: Audio: Steven Morris from outside Oxford crown court
fields.trailText: A deluded fan who tried to kill former Beatle George Harrison and his wife was tonight ordered detained indefinitely in a secure psychiatric hospital.
fields.body:
A deluded fan who tried to kill former Beatle George Harrison and his wife was tonight ordered detained indefinitely in a secure psychiatric hospital.

Michael Abram, 34, was found not guilty due to insanity of two counts of attempted murder after the jury of six men and six women at Oxford crown court heard he was a paranoid schizophrenic who did not know he was doing wrong at the time of the attack.

Mr Justice Astill described the incident as a "horrifying attack" and ordered Mr Abram be sent to the hospital "without time restriction".

Armed with a knife, an electrical flex, a table lamp and a pole from a broken statue, Mr Abram rampaged through the millionaire's mansion in Henley-on-Thames, Oxon, claiming he was on a "mission from God" to murder Mr Harrison, 57, and his wife Olivia on December 30 last year.

The court was told how he stabbed the guitarist at least 10 times before battering him with the table lamp and threatening to kill Mrs Harrison, 52, with the flex.

Yesterday the jury was told in Mr Harrison's own words how he feared he was about to die as his blood-soaked wild-eyed attacker plunged a knife into his chest puncturing his lung.

Mr Abram believed he was the fifth Beatle and his victim was a witch, the court heard earlier today. Psychologists had told the jury there was clear evidence Mr Abram was insane.

The jury took one hour and two minutes to return its verdicts after hearing that the former heroin addict believed he was possessed by Mr Harrison.

Mr Abram thought he was being conspired against by a host of celebrities including members of Oasis and the Beatles and Madonna, the court heard.

The blond-haired 34-year-old had denied two counts of attempted murder. The jury had been told that there is no dispute over whether Mr Abram committed the offences, but that it was a case for them to decide whether he was insane at the time of the attacks.

Dr Phillip Joseph, a psychologist, said that at the time of the attack Mr Abram was clearly mentally ill. Dr Joseph said he believed that when Mr Abram was stabbing Harrison "he was suffering from such a defect of reason that he did not believe it was wrong."

"He believed his actions were justified. The actions were ordained by God, justified by the Bible and he needed to kill George Harrison because he was possessed by George Harrison,"Dr Joseph added.

Not only was Mr Abram obsessed with the Beatles but he believed the group Oasis wrote lyrics about him. "His life was falling apart, he was living in squalor. He was looking for a meaning to his life, but he was preoccupied by his mental illness," Dr Joseph said.

Dr Jenny McCarthy, a consultant psychiatrist who had been treating Mr Abram said the defendant had been suffering from mental illness, particularly schizophrenia, for a number of years, but doctors had failed to diagnose a condition.

Dr McCarthy said Mr Abram was not a naturally aggressive person and had responded well to treatment. She believed it was not necessary for him to be locked up indefinitely in a mental hospital, but that he could be rehabilitated into society.

Mr Abram's mother had been particularly supportive of her son, the jury heard.

Mr Abram was consumed with persecutory delusions and believed he was possessed by a phantom menace, an event which he thought Nostradamus had predicted, Dr Joseph said.

Mr Abram's condition deteriorated after the solar eclipse in August last year, and he became convinced he was on a mission from God, Dr Joseph told the court.

Dr Joseph said Abram would sit on a upturned plant pot in his bare flat in Huyton, Merseyside, listening to songs by John Lennon, Bob Marley, U2 and the Beatles, which would feed his delusions.

Dr Joseph added: "He was trying to make sense of what was going on in his mind. "He began to realise that the person behind this was George Harrison and realised that he was the phantom menace.

"He was aware that John Lennon had previously said the Beatles were more famous than Jesus. He thought for a time it was Paul McCartney that was the phantom menace."

It was only an apparently imaginary belief that his ex-girlfriend had stolen £80,000 from a drug dealer which convinced Mr Abram that Mr Harrison was the phantom menace. He developed this conviction after listening to the refrain "it's gonna take money" taken from the George Harrison 1987 solo hit Got My Mind Set On You.

The jury heard yesterday how Mr Harrison shouted "Hare Krishna! Hare Krishna!" in a bid to confuse his attacker before trying to disarm him on the landing of the Victorian mansion.

Dr Joseph said: "George Harrison spoke something backwards to him. He (Mr Abram) thought he was cursing him in the devil's tongue.

"He realised it was all true and George Harrison was shouting at him, he was a witch. He thought that if George Harrison had talked normally to him at this point he would not have gone through with it because he didn't want to."

Dr Joseph added: "George Harrison ran at him. The thought of killing Harrison went through his head. He stabbed him in the area of the heart with the intention of killing him.

"As he was stabbing he realised it was George Harrison but he also realised he was a witch who had possessed him. He was killing him to make it all stop."

Mr Abram was said to have expressed considerable remorse to the psychiatrist and wanted to write a letter to the family.

Dr Joseph told the court that father-of-two Mr Abram, who he said was of average intelligence, started to go off the rails after his relationship with his girlfriend, Jeanette, broke down.

webTitle: Local government power lies behind the scenes

fields.headline: Local government power lies behind the scenes
fields.standfirst: Bureaucrats and think tankers, not politicians, wield the real power in local government
fields.trailText: Bureaucrats and think tankers, not politicians, wield the real power in local government.
fields.body:
You might expect a list of the most powerful people in local government to be dominated by local politicians. Instead, our panel went for bureaucrats and think tankers, leaving Sir Jeremy Beecham, chairman of the Local Government Association as the only councillor in the top five.

If this list is to be believed, then the real power to affect the future of local government is firmly centred on Whitehall. Two representatives of the influential think tank, the New Local Government Network, are included here not because they have any direct power, but because they have the ear of ministers. The inspectorates, too, gain their power from ministerial patronage, and have won three entries in the top 15.

There are, of course, power bases outside SW1, and it is good news for local government that the LGA takes the top two spots in this list. The Convention of Scottish Local Authorities and Association of London Government are also represented. But it is only when local government speaks with a collective voice that politicians seem to have any real influence.

The two notable exceptions to this rule are Kent county council leader Sandy Bruce-Lockhart and Birmingham council leader Albert Bore, both in charge of large local authorities and both grasping the government's modernisation agenda. These two men are strong, independent voices, but this list makes it clear that neither has the power to be gained from attending court at the palace of Westminster.

Feedback: what do you think of the Power 90 panel's choices? Please send your comments to editor@societytheguardian.com

fields.headline: Managers blamed for hospital failings
fields.trailText: Health managers are blamed for a catalogue of serious failings in the quality of care at three NHS hospitals criticised in official reports published today.
fields.body:
Health managers are blamed for a catalogue of serious failings in the quality of care at three NHS hospitals criticised in official reports published today.

An investigation into problems at the Oxford Heart Centre, one of Britain's leading coronary units, discovered poor standards of clinical care and under-supervision of inexperienced doctors. North Lakeland NHS trust in Cumbria is criticised by health service standards watchdog, the Commission for Health Improvement (CHI), for degrading and cruel practices, including the strapping of mentally-ill patients to their commodes.

Officials at Carmarthenshire NHS trust in Wales came under fire for failing to tighten procedures quickly enough in the wake of a blunder in which the wrong kidney was removed from a seriously ill patient.

The government is expected to ask CHI to formally investigate the Oxford Heart Centre, part of the John Radcliffe Hospital. Health minister John Denham today described the management team at the centre as "dysfunctional".

The Lakeland and Carmarthenshire reports are the first to be issued by CHI, which came into being in April. CHI has been dubbed the "Ofsted of the NHS" - a reference to the formidable education inspectorate which has "named and shamed' failing schools.

Mr Denham ordered an immediate turn-round in performance at the Oxford Heart Centre. He said: "It is a very worrying report. It paints a picture of a dysfunctional team and, more than that, a failure to deal with problems when they were first raised."

He told the BBC's Radio Four Today programme: "What we have to do is tackle the management failings, the failings of people to work on the team and get it back on the road."

The study was ordered in March this year - before CHI was set up - after staff raised concerns over operational practice.

Fears included the quality of pre and post-operative care, claims that junior doctors were not properly supervised, and allegations that there was a culture of intimidation preventing staff airing their worries.

The hard-hitting CHI report into North Lakeland NHS trust in Cumbria blames "whole systems failure" for a catalogue of degrading, unprofessional and cruel practices at Garlands Hospital in Carlisle.

The CHI inquiry report confirmed allegations that patients were tied to commodes, sworn at and denied food, clothing and blankets. The trust chairman and the director of personnel have been dismissed, while the chief executive has been suspended pending a disciplinary hearing.

Other senior managers have received warnings. CHI chief executive Peter Homa said: "The abuse of elderly people was appalling. At the time of our visit to the trust, we could not be sure that it could not happen again.

"The culture of this organisation needs to change fundamentally, so that the rights of patients are understood across the trust."

The CHI report into failures at Carmarthenshire NHS trust stemmed from the case of Korean war veteran Graham Reeves, who died in February after surgeons at the Prince Philip Hospital in Llanelli removed his healthy kidney by mistake, leaving him with just his diseased kidney.

CHI said that the trust had drawn up an action plan to address the problems, but had been slow in implementing it.

It also found there was still confusion in the minds of some staff about the handling of critical incidents.

CHI chief executive Peter Homa said: "While we cannot be specific about the failures that led to Mr Reeves's death, we can say that the trust's action plan addresses the right issues, but is taking longer to implement fully than it should."

The Royal College of Surgeons and the trust, which runs the hospital where the mix-up took place, have already carried out investigations into the incident, but their findings have not been released.

webTitle: Deadlocked rivals turn to supreme court

fields.headline: Deadlocked rivals turn to supreme court
fields.trailText: George W Bush and Al Gore both turned to the Florida supreme court today to resolve issues critical to the state's contested US presidential election, seeking rulings on the legality of continued manual recounts sought by the Democrats.
fields.body:
George W Bush and Al Gore both turned to the Florida supreme court today to resolve issues critical to the state's contested US presidential election, seeking rulings on the legality of continued manual recounts sought by the Democrats.

Mr Bush, clinging to a 300-vote lead in a state that will settle the election, requested permission to join in a suit by the Florida secretary of state, Katherine Harris, seeking an order to block further manual recounts.

A short while later, former secretary of state Warren Christopher said Democrats would ask the court to take jurisdiction over a burgeoning number of election-related lawsuits.

He said the papers to be filed would ask the state's top court to rule "whether hand counts are appropriate under Florida law and if so what is the deadline for their completions".

The legal manoeuvring continued as officials in Florida's Broward County changed course and decided to grant the Gore campaign its request for a full recount by hand.

David Boies, a lawyer recently added to Mr Gore's legal team, set out the types of issues that Democrats would like to see addressed. He said: "What kind of manual recount? When do you terminate it? What are the standards? Can you have a manual recount in some counties and not in another?" It was not clear whether by his comment he was suggesting Democrats might seek to expand manual recounts beyond the four counties where they have requested them - Volusia, where it has been finished; Broward and Palm Beach where they are pending, and Miami-Dade where officials voted last night not to continue. Mr Bush made a one-page submission to the Florida state supreme court, saying he was entitled to join Ms Harris's case because "initial vote tabulation and the statutory recount tabulation resulted in a majority of votes being cast for George W Bush".

Ms Harris, a Republican, gave all counties until 2pm (1900GMT) today to justify to her why they should be allowed to conduct further counting past yesterday's 5pm (2200GMT) deadline.

Counting of overseas ballots is due to be completed by midnight on Friday. In her petition, Ms Harris said local canvassing boards should stop any effort to hand count ballots "pending resolution as to whether any basis exists to modify the certified results after the statutory deadline for submission of returns". She also asked that the flurry of legal actions around the state be transferred to a court in Tallahassee, the state capital.

"Without question, this court must make it clear that the election of the president and vice president is not a matter of local pleasure," the petition said. "It is, at the least, a statewide matter of concern. This court must assume control over this litigation to preserve its ability to establish standards and to protect the voters of the state."

In an additional filing today, Ms Harris said that the state supreme court should step in and stop the Palm Beach count "to protect the integrity of the process and ensure the application of a uniform rule of law". The court has seven members, all chosen by Democratic governors.

Palm Beach County election officials decided this morning to postpone manual vote counting until a judge rules on a Democratic party lawsuit demanding that the canvassing board consider ballots that were previously rejected as incompletely punched.

Meanwhile, five other states had close votes, forcing county-by-county examinations of the totals and raising the possibility of other recounts.

 New Mexico: Gore leads by 375 votes out of more than 571,000 cast. Gore regained the lead on Tuesday after picking up 500 votes in Dona Ana County, where officials had misread an absentee total. Election workers misread a 620-absentee total for Gore in one precinct, mistaking the figure to be 120.

 Wisconsin: Gore leads by 5,385 votes out of 2.5m cast. Officials in heavily Democratic Milwaukee County were investigating a number of reports of questionable voting, including allegations that at least 174 Marquette University students voted multiple times.

 Iowa: Gore leads by 4,048 votes out of nearly 1.3m cast. County officials continued to count absentee votes and ballots that were challenged on election day, a process that was set to conclude next Tuesday.

 Oregon: Gore leads by 4,233 votes out of nearly 1.4m cast. Gore's margin was shaved on Tuesday as officials continued counting the state's postal ballots. About 10,000 ballots were left to be counted, and officials expect to be finished by the weekend.

 New Hampshire: Bush leads by 7,211 out of more than 578,000 votes cast. A review of votes on Monday found proofreading and computer errors, which trimmed Bush's lead by 958 votes. But this result is expected to be final.

In an additional filing today, Ms Harris said that the state supreme court should step in and stop the Palm Beach count "to protect the integrity of the process and ensure the application of a uniform rule of law". The court has seven members, all chosen by Democratic governors. Palm Beach County election officials decided this morning to postpone manual vote counting until a judge rules on a Democratic party lawsuit demanding that the canvassing board consider ballots that were previously rejected as incompletely punched. Meanwhile, five other states had close votes, forcing county-by-county examinations of the totals and raising the possibility of other recounts.  New Mexico: Gore leads by 375 votes out of more than 571,000 cast. Gore regained the lead on Tuesday after picking up 500 votes in Dona Ana County, where officials had misread an absentee total. Election workers misread a 620-absentee total for Gore in one precinct, mistaking the figure to be 120.  Wisconsin: Gore leads by 5,385 votes out of 2.5m cast. Officials in heavily Democratic Milwaukee County were investigating a number of reports of questionable voting, including allegations that at least 174 Marquette University students voted multiple times.  Iowa: Gore leads by 4,048 votes out of nearly 1.3m cast. County officials continued to count absentee votes and ballots that were challenged on election day, a process that was set to conclude next Tuesday.  Oregon: Gore leads by 4,233 votes out of nearly 1.4m cast. Gore's margin was shaved on Tuesday as officials continued counting the state's postal ballots. About 10,000 ballots were left to be counted, and officials expect to be finished by the weekend.  New Hampshire: Bush leads by 7,211 out of more than 578,000 votes cast. A review of votes on Monday found proofreading and computer errors, which trimmed Bush's lead by 958 votes. But this result is expected to be final. webTitle: The film star and the bandit

fields.headline: The film star and the bandit
fields.trailText: The most sensational crime to have convulsed India for a generation ended today when film megastar Rajkumar was freed from captivity by an equally celebrated brigand, Veerappan, reports Derek Brown.
fields.body:
The most sensational crime to have convulsed India for a generation ended today when film megastar Rajkumar was freed from captivity by an equally celebrated brigand, Veerappan.

The matinee idol, at 72 somewhat faded but still idolised by India's film-obsessed masses, had been in the clutches of the country's most notorious outlaw for 109 days.

The saga of Rajkumar and Veerappan - like most south Indians, they have only one name - has stirred riots, political crises, and an outpouring of emotion. It also injected new bitterness into the traditional rivalry of the two biggest south India states, Karnataka and Tamil Nadu.

Only this Monday, Tamil Nadu chief minister M. Karunanidhi accused the neighbouring state for mismanaging the extraordinary crisis. Karnataka ministers returned the insult with interest.

Rajkumar was abducted from his remote Tamil Nadu farmhouse home, close to the Karnataka border, on July 30. He was released in Karnataka today, reportedly in reasonable health.

There is as yet no word of what, if anything, Veerappan has won in exchange for his celebrity hostage. He had been demanding the release of 56 jailed associates in Karnataka and Tamil Nadu. The state governments, mindful of the repercussions on the streets should any harm have come to Rajkumar, agreed to free the men, but the national Supreme Court blocked the move.

The luxuriantly-moustached bandit has entered modern Indian folklore after a 40-year career of violent crime, much of it centred on the smuggling of precious sandalwood. To some downtrodden Indians, he is a hero who defies authority and looks after his own. In reality, he is a ruthless serial murderer who kills and kidnaps with apparent impunity.

He has frequently captured armed police and paramilitary units, usually releasing them unharmed but never hesitating to kill when in danger. He is accused of no fewer than 120 murders.

Rajkumar was by far his most celebrated captive. The actor has made around 210 films, mostly in the Kannada language and, though now retired, he remains one of the brightest stars in the pantheon of Indian movies.

As word of Rajkumar's release spread, overjoyed crowds began to assemble in Bangalore and other south Indian cities in raucous celebration.

Delighted crowds are gathering in Bangalore to celebrate the release of India's film megastar Rajkumar, reports Luke Harding. (1min 57)

webTitle: Special advisers, mandarins and lobbyists hold public sector power

fields.headline: Special advisers, mandarins and lobbyists hold public sector power
fields.trailText: Unaccountable ministerial special advisers, lobbyists, regulators and civil servants are the most powerful and influential individuals in the public and voluntary sectors, according to our survey.
fields.body:
Unaccountable ministerial special advisers, lobbyists, regulators and civil servants are the most powerful and influential individuals in the public and voluntary sectors, according to the Power 90 survey.

It is a list of the most influential individuals in NHS, local government, social care, housing, and charities, and reveals that power in these areas is heavily centralised and dominated by white, middle-aged men.
Of the 90 places, just 20 were taken by women. Most of these work in social services. In the NHS, where 80 per cent of the workforce is female, just one - Royal College of Nursing general secretary Christine Hancock - figures in the power list.

The list, compiled by SocietyGuardian.co.uk journalists after consultation with around 50 professionals, analysts, trade unionists and academics, specifically excludes ministers.
The list includes several peers, including Lady Dean, chair of the housing corporation. But the only MP to make the list is Ken Livingstone, the mayor of London.
He is seen as influential in local government, housing, and regeneration.

Just one ethnic minority figure makes the list. Private care homes tycoon Chai Patel, an influential new labour adviser, ranks highly in both the NHS and social care lists.
Although the lists contain service regulators such as Denise Platt, chief inspector of social services, and Peter Homa, chief executive of the commission for health improvement, there is no consumer presence on the list.
Instead the lists are dominated by producer interests - professional groups such as the British Medical Association, and lobby organisations such as the Local Government Association.

Two of the most influential figures are special advisers: Robert Hill, Tony Blair's health adviser in the Number 10 policy unit; and Ed Balls, chief economic adviser to the Treasury, and chancellor Gordon Brown's right hand man.

The most powerful individuals in each sector are:

&#149 NHS: Robert Hill

&#149 Social care: Denise Platt, chief inspector of social services

&#149 Local government: Brian Briscoe, chief executive of the local government association

&#149 Housing: Lady Dean

&#149 Voluntary sector: Stuart Etherington, chief executive of the national council for voluntary organisations

&#149 Regeneration: Moira Wallace, head of the social exclusion unit

The relatively little-known Hill, who was quietly instrumental in a range of policy initiatives including the NHS plan, is perceived to be the most influential in the NHS - ahead of Nigel Crisp, the NHS chief executive - despite having virtually no public profile.
Hill is also seen as the second most influential player in social care. Ed Balls is regarded as an influential player in housing and regeneration, reflecting the perception that power is increasingly wielded by the Treasury.

Civil servants from the Treasury also feature in the NHS and housing lists. Other powerful individuals include: Lord Richard Rogers of Riverside, Sir George Alberti, president of the royal college of physicians; and Sir Jeremy Beecham, chairman of the local government association.

Feedback: do you agree with the Power 90 panel's choices? Please send your comments to editor@societytheguardian.com

webTitle: The Commission for Health Improvement explained

fields.headline: The Commission for Health Improvement explained
fields.standfirst: The Commission for Health Improvement, an NHS inspection service, resents suggestions that it will "name and shame" hospitals in the way that education inspectorate Ofsted has attacked schools, but NHS staff fear the worst, writes Patrick Butler
fields.trailText: The Commission for Health Improvement, an NHS inspection service, is determined not to "name and shame" hospitals in the way that education inspectorate Ofsted has attacked schools, but NHS staff fear the worst, writes Patrick Butler
fields.body:
What is the Commission for Health Improvement (CHI)?
An "arms length" health services inspection body set up in April 2000 with the aim of increasing standards of care across the NHS in England, Wales, and (by invitation only) Northern Ireland. Scotland has its own body, the Clinical Standards Board.

CHI carries out investigations into "major system failures" (or "failing hospitals") and plans to inspect every NHS trust, health authority and primary care group by 2004 as part of its programme of clinical governance reviews. These reviews inspect each body for quality of patient care; whether clinical staff are up to date in their professional practice; and whether safeguards are in place to prevent clinical errors.

Is CHI similar to Ofsted, the education inspectorate?
No. While both aim to raise standards at the organisations they inspect, CHI resents its reputation as "the Ofsted of the NHS", feeling that this gives it a reputation as an intimidating "hit squad" out to punish recalcitrant NHS organisations. It wants to be known as an assessor rather than an inspector and sees its role as developmental and collaborative. It says its methods are "very different" from those of Ofsted.

Does the NHS believe CHI is a bit like Ofsted?
Yes, so far. A recent survey by the Health Quality Service and trade magazine Health Service Journal discovered that most NHS chief executives and senior quality managers were "fearful" of inspection. They worry that it will adopt an Ofsted-style "name and shame" approach, that staff will be made public scapegoats, and that CHI investigators will "relish wielding a big stick". Like school teachers with Ofsted, NHS managers believe CHI inspections will be costly, stressful and distracting.

Does it have the power to close failing hospitals or remove the management?
No. But it "will report serious findings" to the health secretary or to members of the Welsh Assembly who may take action. According to health secretary Alan Milburn: "(CHI) is uniquely placed to respond quickly to and investigate thoroughly, with extensive powers to gather information and interview individuals. Using these, it will identify the source of problems and develop fast and effective solutions. It will not take over the provision or management of services."

Is it independent of government?
Technically yes. Its aim is to publish the truth as it sees fit, regardless of how uncomfortable this may be to government, NHS bodies or the public. But some NHS staff are sceptical about how independent it will be. An internal CHI report in October 2000 admitted: "We need to convince the NHS that we are the developmental body we claim to be The NHS audience is reasonably aware of what we aspire to be, but is cynical about what we will be allowed to be."

Who decides which NHS organisation will be investigated by CHI?
CHI investigates individual health services "when required to do so" by the secretary of state for health. In addition, "anyone within or outside the NHS" can ask it to conduct an investigation, although in these cases it is a matter for CHI to decide whether or not to proceed.

Who runs CHI?
It is chaired by Dame Deidre Hine, former chief medical officer for Wales and co-author of the seminal "Calman-Hine" report into UK cancer services. The chief executive is Peter Homa, a former trust chief executive and head of the NHS waiting list task force. Board members include two prominent Labour-supporting doctors, cancer specialist Professor David Kerr and London GP Sam Everington. When it reaches full strength, CHI will employ more than 300 people. Its budget for 2000-01 is £12m.

fields.body:
Methodology: The information in this patent research was compiled by searching the Derwent GENESEQ database (www.derwent.com). This database includes all the DNA sequences (partial and complete gene sequences) which have been recorded in patents from 40 patent authorities worldwide, including the US, European, World, Japanese and German patent offices. The database includes information on which organism the gene sequence was obtained from, its characteristics and uses. GENESEQ is a commercial database which can be used to determine whether a particular gene sequence has been patented; follow competitors' work and reveal if a patent has been infringed.

Additional data was obtained from the UK and European patent offices' searchable databases: www.patent.gov.uk and ep.espacenet.com.

The number of patents which include gene sequences is growing exponentially as progress in genetic research becomes more rapid. A patent may cover one or many (50 or 60 in some cases) partial or complete gene sequences. One patent may also cover many variants of the same gene. Because there is a delay of some 3-5 years or even longer in the assessment of patent applications, the majority of patent applications included in this research (approximately 60-70% depending on organism) have not yet been granted. The European Patent Office currently has a backlog of some 15,000 biotechnology patents applications.

Research for this supplement was specially commissioned from GeneWatch UK, a policy research group based in Derbyshire which evaluates the science, regulation and control of genetic technologies. GeneWatch UK personnel who carried out the research were Sue Mayer, Ben Ayliffe and Becky Price. To find out more about GeneWatch UK, its publications and online database, visit their website at www.genewatch.org or send an e-mail to mail@genewatch.org.

webTitle: The best eyeball scene: Pitch Black

fields.headline: The best eyeball scene: Pitch Black
fields.trailText: Having crashed on an alien planet, convicted killer Riddick (Vin Diesel), his eyes coated with a strange metallic sheen, addresses Captain Fry (Radha Mitchell) and the rest of his terrified companions in a darkened cave.
fields.body:
Having crashed on an alien planet, convicted killer Riddick (Vin Diesel), his eyes coated with a strange metallic sheen, addresses Captain Fry (Radha Mitchell) and the rest of his terrified companions in a darkened cave.

"All you people are so scared of me. Most days I'd take that as a compliment. But it ain't me you got to worry about now."

Unbeknownst to the others, the teenage Jack (Rhina Griffith) has wandered in from the planet's exterior.

"Where the hell can I get eyes like that?"

Nonchalantly, Riddick turns to the kid.

"You got to kill a few people..."

"OK! I can do that."

"... Then you got to get sent to a slammer where they tell you you'll never see daylight again. You dig up a doctor, and you pay him 20 Menthol Kools to do a surgical shine job on your eyeballs."

Jack steps back, awed.

"So you can see who's sneaking up on you in the dark."

"Exactly."

Enraged, Fry turns to Jack.

"Leave!"

Looking irritated, Jack shrugs sullenly and wanders outside. Riddick nods approvingly.

"Cute kid."

See also: Un Chien Andalou, A Clockwork Orange, The Evil Dead

Don't see also: An American Werewolf In Paris

Pointless trivia: Vin Diesel formerly worked as a nightclub bouncer in New York.

fields.headline: NHS inspector praises whistle-blowers
fields.trailText: Staff who blew the whistle on poor standards of hospital care have been praised by the government's health standards regulator for their courage in attempting to alert the authorities to care abuses.
fields.body:
Staff who blew the whistle on poor standards of hospital care have been praised by the government's health standards regulator for their courage in attempting to alert the authorities to care abuses.

Peter Homa, chief executive of the Commission for Health Improvement (CHI), criticised North Lakeland NHS trust in Cumbria for not acting after abuses were reported by staff in 1996, and blamed that failure for further alleged mistreatment of patients in 1998.

Mr Homa today praised the "courage" of whistle-blowers who battled to expose mistreatment of elderly mentally ill patients at North Lakeland.

The trust was slammed in a CHI report for failing to prevent abuses which included tying patients to their commodes, and feeding patients while they were on the toilet. Homa described the management's failure to prevent abuses on elderly mental health wards at North Lakeland NHS trust as a "very sad, depressing situation". He said the trust had become too obsessed with meeting its financial targets.

Dr Linda Patterson, CHI medical director, said: "The culture within the trust was that all staff were not absolutely informed of current clinical practice and were accepting of the fact that abuse had occurred. We found that very disturbing, but we think it's a sign of the corporate culture. We had a team who were experienced in the field and they were appalled, as were we."

A nurse who exposed failings at Oxford Heart Centre suffered "extensive bullying and harrassment" after raising the alarm to managers in 1998, it emerged today. Christine Hancock, general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing, said it was "shameful" that it had taken more than two years to investigate concerns raised by Colette O'Keefe, a senior nurse at the centre. "She has had to face extensive bullying and harrassment because she had the courage to speak out," said Hancock.

Oxford Heart Centre was criticised by an NHS Executive report after an inquiry found evidence of serious management failings, a failure to monitor inexperienced staff, and a culture of secrecy and complacency.

webTitle: Clinton: 'Somebody has got to quit shooting'

fields.headline: Clinton: 'Somebody has got to quit shooting'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel & Middle East
fields.trailText: Angry funeral processions, rock-throwing and gun battles marked the twelfth anniversary of the symbolic declaration of Palestinian independence today.
fields.body:
Angry funeral processions, rock-throwing and gun battles marked the twelfth anniversary of the symbolic declaration of Palestinian independence today.

Six men were killed by Israeli army fire in confrontations on the West Bank and Gaza strip and 36 more were injured.

Two died at the Karni crossing between Israel and Gaza, two in the West Bank town of Tulkarem, one in Hebron and one in Jericho. In addition, a Palestinian died in Gaza of his wounds.

Yasser Arafat, the Palestinian leader who declared independence while in exile in Algeria, said today it was the world's responsibility to get the peace talks back on track. Unlike previous independence days he will not be making a public address.

Mr Arafat had said a Palestinian state would be established in 2000 but after seven weeks of Israeli-Palestinian fighting he is no longer under pressure to deliver.

"We are not disappointed because we are continuing our struggle and the struggle needs some time," said Marwan Abdel Hamed, a Palestinian legislator.
