fields.headline: Charlton's 'hair', Redknapp's 'violin', and Petit's 'sanity'
fields.trailText: IF ALL AROUND YOU ARE SCORING GOALS
fields.body:
IF ALL AROUND YOU ARE SCORING GOALS

Ever since he was named caretaker England coach, Peter Taylor has talked a good game. Tonight, in the Stadio Delle Alpi, his young team will have to play one. But the omens don't look promising: the last time England won in Italy was way back in 1961 when Elvis was in the charts and Bobby Charlton had hair. But Charlton - and his counterparts Johnny Haynes and Jimmy Greaves - knew a thing about scoring. They managed to unlock the catenneccio three times that night. Most of us would be grateful if Heskey and Barmby did it just once.

Furthermore, England will be up against a near full strength Italy side. Francesco Totti misses out because of injury, but the other big names from the Euro 2000 squad are there, ready (as the tabloids might say) to tear Taylor's young lions to shreds. And what young, inexperienced lions they are: England are without five almost certain starters in Brown, Owen, Smith, Gerrard and Scholes. In their place comes Parlour, Butt and Neville - not exactly the names that tripped off the nation's tongue when Taylor announced that he was giving youth a chance.

And yet, and yet England really do have every chance of scrapping a draw. For a start, the Italian players and public often regards friendlies as an irrelevance. Giovanni Trapattoni - like Svennis - hardly knows which players England are playing, and most Italian people barely care. And with only 20,000 likely to be in Stadio Delle Alpi tonight, the atmosphere is likely to resemble a deserted church. If England can hold out for the first ten minutes, then twenty and thirty, the game will start to drift. And the prospect of another tedious - sorry, creditable -0-0 draw will become a distinct possibility. Sounds good, doesn't it?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

HARD HAT

East End legend Harry 'The Hat' Redknapp likes a laugh as much as the next man. You only have to look at the state of West Ham's goals against column to see that. But we've all got to draw the line somewhere, and the Hat is no exception. Shortarse admirers of Mussolini get his goat in particular, especially when they suggest that top West Ham prodigies are not yet ready to play for England and "must prove themselves, match after match, for a long time, not just a few games".

"Enough is enough," growled the Hat after hearing Paolo Di Canio question whether Rio Ferdinand and Joe Cole really have what it takes to succeed. "I can't allow this to go on," he hissed, slowly removing his fetching pig leather car coat (with shearling collar). "I know Rio has been sickened by this. I have a terrific bunch of lads with a wonderful team spirit and will not stand by and watch somebody wreck it."

"I'm so angry," the obviously livid Hat pointed out unnecessarily after a short pause. "I don't care who he is or how much talent he has, Paolo cannot get away with this time and again. I don't want to sell Paolo, but there comes a time when you have to do something about it and take action." Whether this "action" will involve renegotiating with Lazio - who had a bid for the player turned down earlier this season - or fitting Di Canio with a slightly heavier set of trendy red boots, we don't know. But the future isn't bright for Paolo whatever the plan is, because Hat wants a word: "We've got some very straight talking to do." Look after him, sweet Jesus!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"There shouldn't be a problem - it's a football pitch and you go out there, 11 against 11, to get on with the job and play to the best of your ability. That's all I want our lads to do" - Bryan Robson reveals his top secret plans to rescue Boro's home form. And mighty canny they are too.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

HE WAS HE IS A RIGHT NUTTER

To be honest, the Fiver was scratching its head a little bit today. As fascinating as Pierre Njanka's trial period at Bolton will undoubtedly be, it failed to grab the Fiver's imagination in a half-nelson. "What can we write about?" we pondered, while idly flicking through this evening's copy of Le Parisien (first for news in the French capital and surrounding arrondisements). What on God's earth could we possibly come up with? And then we saw the interview with He Was He Is Emmanuel Petit.

"I wish people could live on the moon so we could send all the crazy people there," was the remark that first caught our attention. You see, HWHI's pal Youri Djorkaeff withdrew from the French squad to face Turkey this week, a state of affairs brought about by death threats sent to the Armenian-born forward by unpleasant Turks. This, of course, is not on, but it has left the former Arsenal legend a tad disturbed. "When I was on the plane to Turkey I started thinking about Youri and I said to myself: 'I'd like to be a dog'. Dogs are nice. They can sleep anywhere, they wag their tails and on top of that they get stroked all the time."

Now, it's not the Fiver's place to suggest whether HWHI is getting enough stroking at home, but it does appear that it is not just poor Youri, dogs, and astral satellites that are on his mind. Returning to a familiar theme, the Barcelona substitute also attacked the number of games in Big Cup (which Barca, in case you've been in a camomile tea-induced coma, have been knocked out of). "Considering the number of games we have to play, I wouldn't be surprised if we were soon forced to take drugs," HWHI said, repeating an incisive point he also made last year at Arsenal. "And more and more footballers' wives will cheat on their husbands because they are never at home!" Paranoid, lui?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink will be a winter transfer target for Barcelona. According to reports in the Spanish press, coach Llorenc Serra Ferrer would like to partner Hasselbaink with Patrick Kluivert. But Hasselbaink told Marca this morning: "Barcelona is a phenomenal club. But I cannot say anything at this moment because it is not a possibility, since I do not think about leaving Chelsea."

Arsene Wenger wants Coventry's Magnus Hedman as the long-term successor to David Seaman. According to the Mirror, Arsenal are ready to offer the Sky Blues £5m for their Swedish international goalkeeper. Planet Football suggests that the Gunners have also made an enquiry after Juventus striker Darko Kovacevic.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Cameroon international Pierre Njanka has joined Bolton on trial from Strasbourg. The 25-year-old defender had a brief but unsuccessful spell at Huddersfield last month.

Manchester United defender Wes Brown could make a surprise comeback from his knee injury in time for Saturday's derby against Manchester City.

Peter Enckelman has signed a new long-term contract with Aston Villa that ties him to the club until the summer of 2005.

Peter Withe is yet to sign a 12-month extension to his contract with the Thai FA. "I have some problems that I have to deal with in [Britain] before I can make that decision," Withe said without elaborating.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

BBC 1: Match of the Day (10.35pm) Joy at the Beeb as they secure broadcast rights to the highlights of a friendly that could see Seth Johnson getting a game.

Sky Sports 1: Scotland v Australia - Live (7pm) Meanwhile Sky pull out all the stops at Hampden Park. Who will spit most? Find out with Sky's new interactive greb index.

You're on Sky Sports (10.30pm) Slightly later than usual, as the McCaffs have been busy: "We went to observe the ducklings and found that all the six eggs had hatched. When we saw the ducklings, they were in their pen all huddling together underneath the light to keep warm. They were pecking at each other."

Sky Sports 2: Italy v England - Live (7pm) Measure the roundness of Team England's arse cheeks with Sky's new interactive buttometer.

Sky Sports 3: Republic of Ireland v Finland (7pm) Whilst gauging Robbie Keane's tumbling transfer value with the interactive Lira-lizer.

Eurosport: Turkey v France - live (7.30pm) No gimmicks. Unless you count Archie McPherson.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7pm) "And if it wasn't so cold, windy and uncomfortable I might be able to tell you how round the buttocks on Team England actually are."

webTitle: Britain should market itself more effectively abroad

fields.headline: Grade urges marketeers to sell Britain abroad
fields.trailText: 3.15pm: Former Channel 4 boss Michael Grade today called on marketeers to sell Britain abroad, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Michael Grade today accused British business of "terminal modesty" and called on business leaders to sell their achievements abroad.

Speaking at a Marketing Society debate on the marketing of Britain, Mr Grade, chairman of Pinewood Studios and former Channel 4 boss, said it was time to put aside the notion that gentlemen don't sell.

"Britain has much not to be modest about. We are good at selling our products abroad and we need to transfer that to UK plc," he said.

Ian Davis, managing director of management consultancy McKinsey, said Britain needed to market itself more effectively to foreign talent if it was to remain competitive.

He predicted that the top talent would become increasingly mobile, seeking out the best opportunities and lifestyles.

Chris Powell, chairman of advertising agency BMPDDB, said marketeers should take the lead in the branding of Britain.

"You may sell globally and hire globally but you should ensure your national background is known," he said.

webTitle: Sir Elton John: 'I spent £30m in 20 months'

fields.headline: Sir Elton John: 'I spent £30m in 20 months'
fields.trailText:
Mark Hapgood QC: "£293,000 on flowers alone - is that possible?"
Sir Elton: "Yes, I like flowers."
fields.body:
Pop superstar Sir Elton John's lavish lifestyle was vividly portrayed in the High Court today when it was revealed he once spent almost £30 million in a 20-month period - an average of £1.5 million a month.

In that time he spent £293,000 on flowers and more than £9.6 million on property, the packed court heard as the 53-year-old singer gave evidence in his multi-million pound contract battle.

Sir Elton, dressed in a grey suit, white shirt and brightly-patterned blue tie, and watched in the witness box by his long-term partner David Furnish, said: "I have no one to leave the money to. I'm a single man. I like spending my money."

Details of his spending came as he was cross-examined by Mark Hapgood QC, representing City accountancy firm PricewaterhouseCoopers, one of the two parties being sued by the star.

Mr Hapgood suggested to Sir Elton that he went "spending mad" following a $60 million deal with recording company Polygram in February 1996.

He referred to a report summary prepared by PricewaterhouseCoopers of Sir Elton's personal spending from January 1996 to September 1997. Under the heading of "personal" the accountants had calculated that in that period Sir Elton had spent just under £30 million at an average of £1.5 million a month.

Mr Hapgood asked Sir Elton, who is expected to be in the box for the rest of the week: "Do you have any reason to think that inaccurate?"

Sir Elton: "Probably not. No."

Mr Hapgood: "£293,000 on flowers alone - is that possible?"

Sir Elton: "Yes, I like flowers."

Mr Hapgood: "In the same period, over £9.6 million on property?"

Sir Elton: "Yes".

When Mr Hapgood again put it to Sir Elton that he had personally spent the millions, the superstar replied: "Hmmm."

Mr Hapgood: "Just under £2 million a month on average?"

Sir Elton: "Yes."

The star is suing Andrew Haydon, 45, former managing director of John Reid Enterprises (JREL), which for many years was his management company, and City accountancy firm PricewaterhouseCoopers, which looked after his business interests.

The star alleges that Mr Haydon was negligent in allowing JREL to charge him overseas tour expenses - including booking agents, accountants and producers.

Sir Elton's case is that the "several millions" which he paid out in touring expenses should have been borne by JREL under a management agreement.

PricewaterhouseCoopers (formerly Price Waterhouse) are accused by Sir Elton of negligence in managing his affairs. Both defendants are vigorously contesting the allegations against them.

Mr Haydon denies negligence and claims that everything had been done in accordance with management contract terms and conditions.

PricewaterhouseCoopers say they have looked very carefully at the criticisms made and rejected them, and would be asking the judge to rule that the firm's employees had acted according to the highest professional standards.

Sir Elton has already accepted $5m from Mr Reid in settlement of his claims against him.

The star told the court that he thought he was being "ripped off" by Mr Reid, his former business manager.

webTitle: Analysis: the state of our hospitals

fields.headline: The state of our hospitals
fields.standfirst: Patrick Butler, health correspondent at SocietyGuardian.co.uk, on the damning reports out today
fields.trailText: Patrick Butler, health correspondent at SocietyGuardian.co.uk, on the damning reports out today
fields.body:
As a snapshot of the state of the NHS, the three reports into failing hospitals published today make disturbing reading.

In particular, the revelations of inhumane, sadistic cruelty at North Lakeland NHS trust, where mentally ill patients were tied to their commodes, almost beggar belief.

But the Lakeland case - assuming, hopefully, that it is a rare, extreme occurrence - is probably the least useful in gauging the problems facing the health service as it begins to implement the NHS plan reforms.

It is the relatively less shocking findings of the Oxford Heart Centre report which go to the heart of why the NHS is commonly perceived to be uncaring, unresponsive and incapable of raising standards of care. That report detailed a culture where poor care went largely unchallenged, and if it was, it was ignored or pushed under the carpet. It depicts an environment where staff felt intimidated into not raising the alarm over bad practice.

These failures reflect a deep structural fault in the collective NHS psyche, an endemic fear of "rocking the boat", of questioning powerful individuals, particularly doctors, out of fear of retribution. This encourages in turn a pervasive, and perverse, culture of secrecy.

When health minister John Denham called the management at Oxford "dysfunctional" he meant there was an institutionalised culture of non-accountability in which professional interests were protected at the expense of patients.

At Lakeland trust, student nurses first raised concerns about abuse on the wards in 1996, but no action was taken. A clear lesson of these reports is that if standards are to improve, the culture of "omerta" in NHS institutions must be swept away.

The NHS and ministers must lead by example. It is easy to implore NHS staff to blow the whistle on abuses and failures. But staff take their lead from the top, and there are few organisations more sensitive about "keeping up appearances" than the government and the Department of Health.

Which brings us to the commission for health improvement (CHI), whose investigations accounted for two of the reports. Billed - not by its own members - as the "Ofsted of the NHS" its appearance on the NHS scene has sent shivers of apprehension across the NHS.

Managers and doctors worry that they will be "named and shamed" in the same way that the office for standards in education has pointed the finger at schools. Such worries can quickly create a climate of paranoia and, yes, secrecy.

Reputations and careers are at stake. As CHI prepares to assess every NHS body over the next four years it must tread carefully. It will have failed if it merely creates a new culture of secrecy among senior health staff prepared to conceal and dissemble in order to prevent the inspector calling.

webTitle: Coming to a child near you

fields.headline: Coming to a child near you
fields.standfirst:
First the Teletubbies, then the Tweenies, and now... the Hoobs. Nikki Spencer reports on the latest bunch of Day-Glo puppets to capture pre-schoolers' imaginations - and their parents' purses

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: First the Teletubbies, then the Tweenies, and now... the Hoobs. Nikki Spencer reports on the latest bunch of Day-Glo puppets to capture pre-schoolers' imaginations - and their parents' purses.
fields.body:
It seems like only the other day that we were queueing up to get our hands on Teletubbies dolls but just as we have worked out which Tweenie is the purple one (Milo), our living rooms are about to be invaded by a whole new fleet of cutesy aliens with Day-Glo haircuts whom we will be obliged to gen up on. Welcome to the Hoobs.

If you are a parent of a child under five, it is very likely that, however much you try to resist, by next spring you will find yourself referring to young children as "tiddlypeeps", while words like "hoobledo" and "hoobacious" will be popping up in your conversation. Recent audience research for another new BBC pre-school show, Yoho Ahoy, has revealed that adults with children are more likely to be able to quote chunks of Postman Pat or the Tweenies than any lines from literary classics. This is hardly surprising given the way pre-school television is taking over more and more airtime. Children's TV, particularly for this youngest age group, is becoming an increasingly competitive and lucrative market.

Channel 4 is loath to provide an exact figure for what it has paid Muppets creator Jim Henson's company for The Hoobs, but industry estimates make the deal worth at least £14m. For that money, C4 is buying 250 half-hour programmes which commissioning editor Paul Ashton claims will "combine style and innovation with clear child-development thinking". Besides featuring Henson's signature puppetry, as well as animation and participation from real live "tiddlypeeps", the Hoobs will emphasisediscovery. In every episode, the Hoobs, highly coloured characters who travel the universe in, naturally, a Hoobmobile, will try to find out the answer to a single question; for example, "What things float?" The programme is also aiming to be an early introduction to the internet; the series will be supported by a parallel website "and other educational materials".

All of this is a far cry from the way things were 15 years ago when Anne Wood, creator of Rosie and Jim and Teletubbies, founded her own chil dren's production company. Ragdoll has come a long way from its humble origins at her kitchen table: at the Children's Bafta awards on Sunday, Wood was acclaimed for her "outstanding contribution to children's film and television", recognition of the fact that her style of programming has reshaped the entire industry. When she was starting out, the rule of thumb in television was that the younger the audience, the smaller the budget.

"Young children were ignored in broadcasting for years. Nobody thought these programmes had any significance," explains Wood. "Then parents began to buy videos and children would watch them over and over again. And as soon as other people saw that there was money to be made, they started to take an interest."

This process was accelerated when, in 1997, Wood and her colleague Andrew Davenport won a commission for a new BBC series aimed at one to three year olds: Teletubbies looked and sounded like nothing that had ever been shown on children's television before. But not everyone was immediately convinced of its merits. In a letter to the Daily Telegraph, one parent described them as "weird alien creatures that can't even talk properly". But columnists such as Nigella Lawson found their children loved it and soon leaped to the programme's defence.

Then came the merchandising. By Christmas, there were reports of near-riots in department stores, as parents tried desperately to obtain the dolls for their loved ones.

"Teletubbies changed the nature of the pre-school market," comments Lucy Rouse, editor of the TV industry magazine Broadcast. "Others saw the success and the spin-offs, and realised there was a new target audience in younger children and their parents."

As further Teletubbies clones have arrived, the direction of this expanding market has roused critics. The Pre-school Learning Alliance, an educational charity, has recently endorsed the new GMTV pre-school series MacDonald's Farm, but it still has reservations about the direction of the industry.

"There has always been some mar keting attached to pre-school programmes, but it's more powerful nowadays," says Ann Henderson of the Alliance. "The bottom line is that companies are interested in shareholders, not children.

"It is very easy to tag the word 'educational' onto a package. Just because it has letters and numbers on something doesn't mean it's educational. Parents have got to watch programmes with their children and see what they are getting out of it," she advises. "If they don't like what they see, they should take them for a walk or play a game instead."

The figures for profits from pre-school television sales, and spin-offs such as videos and toys, keep mounting up. In its first year, Tellytubbies made a staggering £23m. Only a few weeks ago, it was announced that the Tweenies had outstripped this record by amassing a £30m profit in its first year. No details have yet been released about the exact nature of the merchandising that will accompany the Hoobs, but Angus Fletcher from the Henson Company confirms that there will be "a lot of activity in this area". Undoubtedly, this will prove an understatement. Channel 4's Paul Ashton says he believes it is naive to think that you can now have an international pre-school series without merchandising: "I think parents do want to buy things for their kids, and the job of people like me is to offer them good things rather than rubbish.

"You can't just wish the whole area away. Henson is a commercial company and we are a commercial company and children do want to hug something they have seen on TV."

Anne Wood says she has some sympathy with parents who worry about the expense and effect of merchandising, but she too concedes that this is now the nature of the business. Most pre-school programmes are not fully funded. The companies that make them are left to recoup some of their costs from spin-off sales.

"It's not a question of whether we like it or not. We just have to deal with it or we wouldn't be making programmes at all," says Wood.

 The Hoobs will be broadcast on Channel 4 from January.

For the children: a history of pre-school TV

1946 The BBC broadcasts its first ever kids' TV programme, inspirationally titled For the Children. A few months later, Muffin the Mule (below) takes his first steps to TV stardom. Many early programmes were broadcast on Sunday afternoon, leading church leaders to express concern that children would be lured away from Sunday school.

1950 Andy Pandy, Looby Loo and Teddy come out to play for the first time.

1952 Bill and Ben appear on our TV screens. Plans have been announced for a revival next summer.

1964 Humpty, Big Ted, Little Ted and Jemima make their debut in Play School. Play School inadvertently became BBC 2's first programme: the previous night's grand opening didn't happen because of a power failure.

1972 Rainbow, ITV's long-running series, makes puppets Bungle, George and Zippy household names. Geoffrey joins the following year.

1980 The title Watch with Mother is finally dropped from the schedules.

1988 After 25 years of Play School, and despite a public backlash, the BBC replaces it with Playdays.

1990 A turning point in pre-school TV: Rosie and Jim chug on to our screens in their canal barge, and producers Ragdoll realise there is a market among pressured parents for videos.

1997 The new Ragdoll products, Tellytubbies, say "Eh-oh". The single goes to number one, and within a year the BBC has amassed £23m in profits from the show and merchandise.

1999 The Tweenies arrive on BBC. This brightly coloured quartet proves to be just as popular as the previous brightly coloured quartet.

2001 The Hoobs say a "Hoobiehello" to young Channel 4 viewers. It will be the first pre-school programme to introduce children to the internet.

webTitle: Parents: Helping dad with his work

fields.headline: Helping dad with his work
fields.standfirst: Ever thought your kids showed artistic promise? Issam Kourbaj did, and now his son's work is hanging alongside his own in a Cambridge gallery.  Andy Martin  reports
fields.trailText: Ever thought your kids showed artistic promise? Issam Kourbaj did, and now his son's work is hanging alongside his own in a Cambridge gallery.Andy Martin reports.
fields.body:
I have several masterpieces hanging on my walls. There is Red Bus, Cow (all black), The Digger, Airs Rock (sic), and - definitely worthy of a spot in the Louvre - Mum, Dad, Spud and Me. They were all painted by my two sons, when they were aged about four. Call me biased if you will, but I also admit that, looking at their later works (they are now aged 10 and eight), there has been something of a falling-off in sheer artistic verve. Or, as Wordsworth neatly put it, "Whither is fled the visionary gleam,/ Where is it now, the glory and the dream?"

The only other picture with a definite dash of gleam and dream is The Village, which looks like a bunch of building blocks that have been kicked over and scattered about, by Issam Kourbaj, aged 37. Kourbaj has given me fresh hope that the fond idea of my kids as infant geniuses (retired) was not totally crackpot after all. "The true artist does not borrow," said Picasso, "he steals." And this is what Kourbaj has done: brazenly plundered and plagiarised the early works of his three-year-old son Mourad, and mounted an exhibition, is/am, in which, to be fair, he has hung the little guy's paintings on the wall alongside his own.

Kourbaj the elder was born in the black mountains of southern Syria. He had the classic artistic upbringing - illiterate, impoverished, selling chewing gum in the streets. His uncle Suleyman used to make things out of unexploded bombs (he died, of course, rather suddenly), and the young Issam was similarly forced to make all his own toys, fortunately out of less lethal debris. This rigorous training took him from the Institute of Fine Arts in Damascus to the Academy of Art in St Petersburg, and finally to London to study architecture and theatre design.

Kourbaj, to my eye, looks like the young Cat Stevens when I go to see him in his studio in Cambridge. To his son's eye, however, he has red hair, green ears, eyes like catherine wheels, a crinkly chip smile, and bits of blue fungi sticking out of his head. And it is that intense, uninhibited, and wildly eccentric vision of the world that the grown-up Kourbaj has appropriated.

After painting a couple of thousand tourist portraits to earn a few roubles in Russia, Kourbaj vowed never to paint anyone's face ever again, fled to Mexico and Cuba, and went into a sustained period of abstraction interspersed with landscapes bearing a strange resemblance to naked women. The British Museum bought one of his sketchbooks, but there is a school of thought which maintains that Kourbaj is almost too cool, ethereal and disembodied, culminating in a recent collaboration with Cambridge University's department of aerial photography. He was floating up to heaven. His son's paintings dragged him back down to earth again.

Mourad had picked up prizes from Kettle's Yard, in Cambridge, and another in a cafe art competition. Like some superhuman tennis prodigy, he was already overshadowing his old man. Dad decided to give up the struggle and join forces with his son to make a great doubles team. "The best teachers are those who do not intend to teach," Kourbaj says. "He is as primitive as a caveman. He is not confined by the rectangular."

Using recycled book covers as canvases, Kourbaj père has extrapolated Kourbaj fils's pre-representational efforts to produce radiant blobs and swirls and squiggles that look like some mad particle physicist grappling with the irreducible elements of the universe. But he has also been softened and humanised by his son's first shots at depicting the world at large, and the exhibition has a separate room dedicated to images of orange cats (with gaping jaws), a doomed bird, impossible machinery, and upside-down trees. "Mourad did not even know he was painting," Kourbaj says. "He is still surprised by everything. I wanted to capture that same sense of surprise."

Was it Plato who first suggested that children have a primal vision of truth that is lost as they grow up and are exposed to adult ideas? He also reasoned that you had to die to recover it. Issam Kourbaj has shown that you don't have to go that far; that parents can have it too, if they only open their eyes to the unconscious art of their children. I don't care how much Tate Modern offers for Red Bus or Cow. They are not for sale.

 is/am, by Issam and Mourad Kourbaj, is at the Artists' Studio, 1a Albert St, Cambridge, November 18-19 and 25-26, 11am-5pm.

fields.headline: Boy soldiers
fields.standfirst: Under-18s in the UK cannot buy alcohol, sign legal documents or vote. But they can fight - and die - for their country.  Richard McClure  reports
fields.trailText: Under-18s in the UK cannot buy alcohol, sign legal documents or vote. But they can fight - and die - for their country. Richard McClure reports.
fields.body:
As wreaths were laid and bugles sounded at ceremonies around the country last weekend, Alan Richards chose to spend Remembrance Sunday away from officialdom and platitudes. Breaking off from his shift as a fitter at Port Talbot steelworks in South Wales, he observed the two-minute silence alone, remembering a loss far more immediate than most.

In March this year, his son Wayne, a Royal Marines recruit, was shot dead during night manoeuvres on Woodbury Common, Devon. Somehow, for reasons as yet unexplained, live bullets became mixed up with blank ammunition. Two shots fired by a sentry hit Wayne, one in the head, the other in his chest. He was pronounced dead at the scene.

Eight months on, Alan is still suffering from weight loss and broken sleep. He firmly believes that his son should never have been placed in such mortal danger. After enlisting in January when still 16, Wayne had spent just nine weeks at the army's commando training camp at Lympstone. He was killed three weeks after his 17th birthday. "Wayne wasn't a man - he was a boy," says Richards. "He should never have been put in that situation."

Wayne's name is the most recent addition to the grim roll-call of under-18s who have been killed during military combat or exercises. Since 1982, more than 90 recruits aged 16 or 17 have died on active service, with a further dozen killed during training. This uniquely British statistic led Amnesty International to issue a report last week, U-18s: Child Soldiers at Risk, calling on the government to raise the minimum age of soldiers taking part in armed conflict to 18.

"In Britain, under-18s are not allowed to vote, sign legal documents or drink alcohol, yet growing numbers are being recruited into the dangerous environment of the armed forces," says Amnesty spokesman Neil Durkin. "We want the UK government to give a cast-iron guarantee that no under-18 will ever be sent into dangerous situations for this country."

While the term "child soldier" evokes images of Sierra Leone's West Side Boys dwarfed by their automatic rifles, or pubescent Karen rebels fighting in the Burmese jungle, the UK also deploys troops who are legally still children. With more than 6,500 juveniles in the ranks, Britain recruits more servicemen and women under the age of 18 than any other country in Europe. (France, for example, has fewer than 500.) The UK is also the only European nation routinely to send 17-year-olds into combat zones. Around 200 minors were deployed during the Gulf War (two of whom died), while in Kosovo, 17-year-olds were among the first K-For peacekeepers to enter the capital Pristina.

The Ministry of Defence is keen to point out that juveniles join up voluntarily and with their parents' permission. "As such, it's not like the African countries with kids hacking off limbs," says an MoD spokesman. "It's a completely different end of the spectrum."

Wayne Richards' grandmother Marion, however, questions the issue of parental consent. "Alan was against Wayne joining up from the start and refused to sign the documents," she says. "But Wayne's mother signed because he seemed so keen. At the very least, both parents should be required to give their permission."

Other parents discover too late what they have actually signed. Once enlisted, under-18s have a single opportunity to leave the army, between the second and sixth month of training. After that, they must serve until they are 22. According to At Ease, a confidential advisory service for military personnel, the army's training contract deliberately sets out to confuse parents and children alike.

"The current system is a form of bond-servitude, trapping 16-year-olds into a contract they don't understand and an occupation they can't leave," says the organisation's Gwyn Gwyntopher. "We actually distribute a leaflet translating the Queen's Regulations into plain English, so that kids and their parents fully realise what they are doing.

"Parents, for instance, still believe they can buy their children out if they are unhappy - but that was abolished in 1991. Also, if their kid goes awol and turns up on the parents' doorstep, they can be prosecuted for taking him in or giving him a meal."

One parent, who wishes to remain anonymous, claims she was assured on three occasions by her local army careers office that no 17-year-old would be sent to fight in the Gulf, only to discover her son of that age had been deployed with the Queen's Own Highlanders. "He hasn't been the same boy since the day he came back," she says. "I expected him to return a man. Instead, he was totally broken."

Not all under-18s suffer psychological scars from active service. In 1995, Steven Cowap, then 17, was among a group of Welsh Fusiliers taken hostage by Serbs and held captive for 10 days. He survived the ordeal with no signs of trauma, but admits he was fortunate. "I wasn't stressed by the situation," says Cowap, who is still serving with the regiment. "But it depends on the individual. Some people at that age are quite mature; others are just kids. Looking back, I was probably thrown in too early."

Steven's mother Bridie is among those calling for the UK to support a United Nations initiative making 18 the minimum age for recruitment and participation in hostilities. "For me, the whole nightmare of Steven's hostage situation was made much worse because, in my eyes, he was a baby," she explains. "He was too young to go to war."

The campaign is also supported by Labour MP Paul Stinchcombe, whose private member's bill to similar effect ran out of parliamentary time earlier this year. "If recruitment into the services below the age of 18 was thought neither right nor necessary at the time of the first world war, how can it conceivably be thought right or necessary today?" he asks.

So far, though, all moves have been vehemently resisted by a military desperately short of men. Despite a recent upturn in the numbers enlisting, the army is currently around 5,000 men below its full complement, while those who have joined up are increasingly dissatisfied with their lot. Last year, nearly 2,000 service personnel went awol - the highest number since the end of national service.

In its efforts to fill the ranks, the army is becoming ever more reliant on under-18s. Despite defence secretary Geoff Hoon's call for an up-to-date army offering an up-to-date career, the recruitment of juveniles has swelled under the present regime to around a third of the total intake, with the number of young recruits increasing twelvefold since 1996.

In February, At Ease, along with other interested parties, will submit its assessment of under-18s recruitment to a select committee as part of the Armed Forces Bill, the five-year review that determines military regulations. Though accustomed to having their views rejected, the campaigners have renewed hope that they will prevail. For the family of Wayne Richards, however, any reform will come too late.

fields.headline: Double talk
fields.standfirst: Leah Wild's IVF diary
fields.trailText: Leah Wild's IVF diary
fields.body:
I was having my hair cut. Michelle, my regular stylist, glanced down at my stomach. "You're pregnant!" she cheered, letting the whole salon know. "When are you due?"

I mumbled something I hoped was indistinct. "Sometime next year... spring... March-ish..." as though it were an insignificant fact that I hadn't got around to checking up on.

She glanced at my stomach again. Michelle has always been blunt. "You're huge!" she told the salon: the woman having highlights whose skull sprouted tinfoil spikes, the elderly lady trying to make a few thin strands stretch over a large cranium.

"It's twins," I muttered.

"Twins! Twins in the family?" Michelle asked cheerily. "No," I said. Tinhead and the cranium waited. I have a phrase I have learned to use in such situations: "They were created by science."

That evening, I recounted the scene to my mother. It was supposed to be a funny story. My mother did not see it that way. "Say you have twin cousins," she retorted immediately; she had obviously already imagined such an encounter. "Say that your brother's a twin." The family secret must not be shared.

The shame of IVF is one thing; at least it rarely runs in the family. But the shame of Preimplantation Genetic Diagnosis (PGD) is quite another. PGD - where IVF is combined with the process of sorting "good" embryos from "bad" - is necessary because of an inherited condition. If you suffer, your whole family is implicated. Your parents, siblings and even your cousins once and twice removed share in the shame. That is why, for many families with such conditions, it is a closely guarded family secret. Miscarriages are unreported, stillbirths soon forgotten. Only they know what lurks in their genes.

Then along come twins and the secret is suddenly out. We are unmasked as other. We can't hide it any more. Either we tell our story, or we are forced to invent further lies.

Since the advent of IVF, there has been a remarkable rise in multiple births. From 1982 to 1998, the incidence of twins increased by almost 50%. There are now approximately 10,000 born in the UK every year. And the more multiple the birth, the more staggering the increase. There were 46 sets of quadruplets born worldwide in the first 50 years of the 20th century. Thanks to fertility treatment, there were 79 in 1994 in the US alone. IVF specifically increases your likelihood of having twins to around one in five.

There are no separate figures for PGD. Technically we are not infertile; we just have many miscarriages (as in my case), stillbirths, or children who die prematurely. Once unaffected embryos have been chosen, our chances of conceiving should be the same as any other woman's. I had two unaffected embryos replaced in my womb; my chance of both being successfully implanted should have been higher than a woman who had straightforward IVF. But there are no statistics to support this, simply because the sample is so small. Few of us are given access to PGD. In the entire country there have been no more than a dozen children born through the procedure I underwent, and those have all been within the last few years. But a disproportionate number of these are multiple births.

'Of course, we always thought it was twins," the nurse told me when the scan showed two furry alien creatures floating around in my womb. Well, of course. It's just that no one had bothered to tell me. The Assisted Conception Unit had confirmed my pregnancy with a blood test. The test had shown the level of my hormones was so high there had to be more than one foetus in there. The nurse knew, the doctors knew, perhaps even the receptionist who filed the results in my cardboard folder knew. But I didn't. I presume the information was hidden from me in order to be reassuring, so as not to raise my hopes. It is now estimated that up to 12% of pregnancies start out as twins, the vast majority becoming singletons before the first scan. But not telling was not reassuring. It only made me concerned about what else might be being withheld.

It is as if all of us - the infertile couple, the wider family, the medical staff - are infected with secrets and lies. As a result, we are all alone. PGD patients - and there are so few of us - don't even nod at each other in the waiting room, as though utterly absorbed in last year's Homes & Gardens, bowed over with shame. Elsewhere, it is impossible to spot each other. Perhaps the woman in the hairdressing salon with the tinfoil on her head was infertile, too. Perhaps she had a condition that caused her to miscarry. Or perhaps she had four uncomplicated children, and regarded me as a medical freak. As we each sat silently, shamefully, protecting our secret, I would never know.

Leahwild@cswebmail.com

webTitle: Parents: The Panel on children switching faith

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: The son of Jewish former home secretary Michael Howard has announced he is to become a Church of England minister. How should parents respond if their child decides to embrace a different faith?
fields.trailText: The Question: The son of Jewish former home secretary Michael Howard has announced he is to become a Church of England minister. How should parents respond if their child decides to embrace a different faith?
fields.body:
Abdullah Trevathan Muslim father of 10

If one of my children did want to switch to a different religion, I wouldn't flare up about it - that would just make things worse. It would undoubtedly be done in a temper or for a reason, and I would try to find out what had really happened. It sounds terribly biased, I know, but when you know the basic tenets of this way of life, it is very difficult to move to some other faith. So I would just try to pour cold water on hot fire. To me, Islam represents a natural, primordial way and those are the values I try and pass on to my children.

Keith Toms Atheist father of three

I'm a socialist and an atheist: I think Marx summed it up well when he said that God is a projection of man's unrealised potential. I believe that the natural potential to be liked and to be good is inside us all. If one of my children said they wanted to embrace religion, it wouldn't bother me because we're all individuals. I think as a parent it's important not to impose any thwarted ambition of your own on to your children. The one thing that would really hurt me is if any of them turned out to be a racist, or came home and announced that they were going to be a Tory.

Kawal Singh Sikh mother of two

Both my children have married non-Sikhs but retained their Sikhism. Because my religion believes in treating everyone equally, I had no qualms in accepting their partners. If they choose a different path, I hope that path will embrace some of the tenets of Sikhism, and that my children will live peacefully, lead an honest life, and contribute to society. That's just as important as religious allegiance, but I would like them to believe in something greater than them. Many religions believe in one God and there are different ways of getting to the same destination.

Lesley Blumberg Jewish mother of three

I have always accepted that, living in a society so open to different beliefs, this could happen. So if one of my children announced they were changing their religious allegiance, it wouldn't come as a shock. However, I think it would be a shame. When life gets tough, I believe it is the rituals and ethics of your own religion that get you through. If my child was planning to convert, I would point out how life would be in the long run and flag up the possible pitfalls. I wouldn't encourage it but ultimately I would accept it. I would never turn my back on my children.

Sally Fox Christian mother of three

If faced with this situation, I would sit down and find out exactly why and how they wanted to change. I would point out why I'm a Christian and how the concept of forgiveness has changed my life. It's something which doesn't seem to exist in the outside world, but I can sleep at night because I know I'm forgiven and that I can forgive. You can never force a child to do anything: banning them from smoking just makes them want to do it more. So I would try to be cool, calm and logical, keeping my emotions out of it. I just hope we could talk it through.

fields.headline: The Bill pays off for ITV
fields.trailText: 3.15pm TV overnights:ITV had a good night in the ratings, helped by an hour-long episode of the Bill which drew 7.9m viewers, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
One of the reluctant stars of Anthony Thomas's award-winning series, Fat, won the hearts and minds of the nation when the series was screened in 1998.

The obese, miserable American woman whose life was so compromised by her 36 stone weight that she had to have a stomach bypass operation was a ghoulish - if sympathetic - symbol for the western world's neurosis about food.

Christie Martin's return last night in Christie's Story stormed the schedule last night, bringing in 7.5m viewers to ITV.

A thoroughly good night was had by all over on ITV, with an hour-long episode of The Bill drawing 7.9m viewers, leading into Peak Practice with 8.5m and then the coup de grace, Christie's Story.

Meanwhile, audiences for The Weakest Link on BBC1 are dwindling. Last night's show was seen by 6.2m - 1.5m down on the previous night.

And nearly 2m viewers have now switched off BBC1's drama series, The Sins, since it started in October. Last night, just 4.7m viewers tuned in to the Pete Postlethwaite and Geraldine James drama.

webTitle: How the Human Rights Act will affect charities

fields.headline: How the Human Rights Act will affect charities
fields.standfirst: The introduction of the Human Rights act to British law may have major repercussions on the way charities do business
fields.trailText: The introduction of the Human Rights act to British law may have major repercussions on the way charities do business.
fields.body:
Tax rules and law changes have kept charities on their toes this year. The recent implementation of the Human Rights Act 1998 brings even more new regulations. But the good news is that there's plenty of advice to help organisations comply.

The act incorporates a limited version of the European Convention on Human Rights into British law. The convention upholds the right to be treated humanely, to liberty, to freedom of expression and to a fair trial. This means people will be able to seek redress through the British courts rather than take cases to the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg.

The act has been applauded and derided in equal measures. Supporters say the measures offer an overdue form of redress for those who have suffered at the hands of public services, but critics predict that the courts will be clogged with people demanding action on trifling grievances.

All public authorities must comply with the conventions, and for the purposes of the act, the term applies to any body - whether it is public or private - that carries out a public function. So, for example, the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children is considered to be a public authority as it has powers to protect children and invoke care proceedings.

Voluntary organisations which work with agencies to provide government funded services must comply with the conventions. So too do the increasing number of charities that are contracted to provide services on behalf of local authorities or central government. These include charities that provide residential care, hospice care, health care and advice, child care, housing associations, family planning and pregnancy advice centres.

The National Council of Voluntary Organisations has drawn up this checklist to help charities gauge how the Human Rights Act will affect them.
 Establish whether your organisation falls within the remit of the act.
 Identify the rights that relate to the parts of your work that are considered public functions.
 Identify whether you are interfering with a convention right or whether that interference could be justified.
 Build a respect for human rights into your organisation's services, employment practices, volunteering policies and procedures.
 Consider the implications of the act for your campaigning, public policy work and communications strategy.

According to the Charity Commission, there are a handful of convention rights likely to have the biggest impact on charities. These include:
 Article 3: the right not to be subjected to torture or inhuman treatment. This could apply to charities providing hospital or residential care.
 Article 6: the right to a fair trial. This might affect complaints hearings, tribunals and appeals, and case reviews.
 Article 8: the right to respect for private and family life. Any organisation that holds personal information might be affected by this convention.
 Article 9: freedom of thought, conscience or religion. This could refer to a care home worker being able to wear a particular form of dress for religious reasons, even if it is out of keeping with the home's uniform.

The Charity Commission suggests that any charities unsure as to whether they qualify as public authorities should take legal advice.

According to the Charity Commission, there are a handful of convention rights likely to have the biggest impact on charities. These include:  Article 3: the right not to be subjected to torture or inhuman treatment. This could apply to charities providing hospital or residential care.  Article 6: the right to a fair trial. This might affect complaints hearings, tribunals and appeals, and case reviews.  Article 8: the right to respect for private and family life. Any organisation that holds personal information might be affected by this convention.  Article 9: freedom of thought, conscience or religion. This could refer to a care home worker being able to wear a particular form of dress for religious reasons, even if it is out of keeping with the home's uniform. The Charity Commission suggests that any charities unsure as to whether they qualify as public authorities should take legal advice.

webTitle: Vote recount: the state of play

fields.headline: Vote recount: the state of play
fields.standfirst: Special report: US election
fields.trailText: 15 November: The latest news from New Mexico, Wisconsin, Iowa, Oregon and New Hampshire.
fields.body:
While the Florida recount battle between presidential rivals George W Bush and Al Gore continues, five other states also have close votes.

Tight margins have forced county-by-county examinations of the totals in these states and raised the possibility of other recounts.

 New Mexico: Mr Gore leads by 375 votes out of more than 571,000 cast.

The vice president regained the lead yesterday after picking up 500 votes in Dona Ana County, where officials had misread an absentee total. Election workers misread a 620-absentee total for Mr Gore in one precinct, mistaking the figure to be 120.

Mr Gore also got an extra vote from another county. Mr Gore led by 6,000-plus votes on election night, but he saw that advantage disappear after officials fixed problems in Bernalillo County that had prevented thousands of votes from being counted. However, this latest change gave Mr Gore 286,390 votes state wide to 286,015 for Mr Bush.

Meanwhile, state police were nearly finished with a court-ordered impoundment of ballots across the state. State Republicans wanted impoundments to ensure ballots were protected in case of a recount or challenge.

State officials will finalise the results on November 28, and either side will have six days to request a recount.

 Wisconsin: Mr Gore leads by 5,385 votes out of 2.5m cast.

The Bush campaign has not ruled out a recount in Wisconsin but cannot request one until all 72 counties turn in certified vote tallies, which are due Friday. The campaign would then have three business days to request a recount.

Officials in heavily Democratic Milwaukee County were investigating a number of reports of questionable voting, including allegations that at least 174 Marquette University students voted multiple times.

 Iowa: Mr Gore leads by 4,048 votes out of nearly 13m cast.

County officials continued to count absentee votes and ballots that were challenged on Election Day, a process that was set to conclude yesterday. The vice president's lead was narrowed during the canvassing that began on Monday.

Challenged ballots include situations where a voter had moved and was not listed on the new rolls. These ballots were not initially counted, and officials now are adding those that are determined to be legitimate to the total.

All requests for a recount must be made to a county within three days of the canvass - either Thursday or Friday. Both sides were monitoring the numbers, and the Bush campaign was considering whether to request a full recount.

If a recount is ordered, each county would have 18 days after its canvass to complete the new tally. A recount could cover the entire state or target specific counties.

 Oregon: Mr Gore leads by 4,233 votes out of nearly 1.4m cast.

Mr Gore's margin was shaved yesterday as officials continued counting the state's mail-in ballots. About 10,000 ballots were left to be counted, and officials expect to be finished by the week's end.

A recount would be required by state law if the margin falls to less than one-fifth of 1%, or about 2,800 votes. Mr Gore's lead is not likely to fall that low, but if a recount is called, it is expected to be held the first week of December.

The Bush campaign, which has sought information about a possible recount, has said it is waiting to see the final count before deciding whether to seek one. Republicans on Tuesday called each county clerk seeking their own information as ballot counting continued.

Counties have until November 27 to finish counting their ballots and at least one county is expected to take that long. The state cannot declare an official winner until then.

 New Hampshire: Mr Bush leads by 7,211 out of more than 578,000 votes cast.

Monday was the deadline to ask for a recount, and none was requested. A review of votes on Monday found proof-reading and computer errors, which trimmed Mr Bush's lead by 958 votes but this result is expected to be final.

webTitle: Government considers all-postal voting for local elections

fields.headline: Government considers all-postal voting for local elections
fields.trailText: The government is considering radical changes to local elections that would see voters choosing their councillors exclusively by post.
fields.body:
The government is considering radical changes to local elections that would see voters choosing their councillors exclusively by post.

Home secretary Jack Straw has indicated to the Local Government Association that he is considering rolling out all-postal ballots, after pilots during this year's local elections doubled turnout in some northern wards.

A report from LGA officers to the association's ruling executive says Mr Straw is "considering the feasibility of either a full or partial extension of all-postal ballots". It adds that the home office is seeking preliminary views on the move by the end of next week.

LGA chairman Sir Jeremy Beecham welcomed the move: "It's quite clear that postal voting is the only likely way of increasing turnout, so I'm much in favour of it."

Although he raised concerns about the security of postal voting, Sir Jeremy wants to see the system introduced quickly. He suggested the home secretary should consider giving all councils the option of holding postal elections as soon as possible.

In practice, this is not likely to happen before the May 2002 local polls. Mr Straw has the power to extend postal voting to any, or all, local elections in England and Wales but, under a bill currently before parliament, he must first receive a recommendation from an independent electoral commission, an election watchdog that will not even be formally established until later this year.

The Home Office has also made it clear that experimental voting pilots will be cancelled if they clash with a May general election.

However, officers at the LGA suggest that even May 2002 may be optimistic, and that further trialling is needed. They point out that all-postal voting has not been piloted in county council or London borough elections, and that it has not been trialled on a council-wide basis.

Few, if any, further all-postal pilots will take place next year. Many councils have been put off experimenting with alternative voting methods altogether because they fear the trials will be cancelled.

The government has only received applications from six authorities to pilot novel voting methods next year, compared with 44 last year. If the pilots do go ahead, Bristol will be the first council in the country to stage an authority-wide postal poll.

Other experimental pilots in last year's local elections covered early or advance voting, weekend polling and mobile polling stations, but a recent report by the LGA concluded that only all-postal voting had a significant effect on turnout.

Report co-author and local elections expert Professor Michael Thrasher said ease of voting was the key to the success of postal balloting. "The easier you make it for people to vote, the more turnout will increase," he said.

fields.headline: Vosper Thornycroft jobs ultimatum
fields.standfirst: Shipyard threatens redundancies unless MoD comes to rescue
fields.trailText: Vosper Thornycroft, the naval shipbuilder, yesterday warned that it would have to start laying off 650 production staff at its Woolston yard near Southampton early in the new year unless the ministry of defence brought forward a key order within weeks.
fields.body:
Vosper Thornycroft, the naval shipbuilder, yesterday warned that it would have to start laying off 650 production staff at its Woolston yard near Southampton early in the new year unless the ministry of defence brought forward a key order within weeks.

Chris Cundy, finance director, said slippage in the MoD's timetable for tendering the contract for five new offshore patrol vessels meant that Vosper would have to begin implementing redundancy notices for more than half its shipbuilding workforce of 1,200 which were issued last month.

The MoD, often pilloried for protracted delays in its procurement process, has put the contract for the vessels to replace ageing fisheries protection ships on a fast-track schedule. But Mr Cundy said a gap in Vosper's otherwise booming order book meant the first of the Woolston staff would have to be laid off in January. "We're looking at time-scales unheard of for the Royal Navy," he said, "but unfortunately there's been a bit of slippage and we need the invitation to tender to be awarded within the next few weeks . . . Our hope is that we get the contract or other short-term work to prevent these people going as the last of the navy's new minehunters is due to leave the yard in April."

Vosper, which yesterday announced a 14% rise in pre-tax earnings for the first half to £18.8m, including an exceptional £1.2m gain on a prop erty sale, said its order book had virtually doubled from £640m to £1.25bn. But three quarters of this is in its expanding support services business, including work and training outsourced by MoD.

Vosper is to build one of the first three new Type 45 destroyers for the MoD in an initial £1bn contract managed by BAE Systems which is to build the other two at its Yarrow yard near Glasgow. This work, due to start in mid-2002, will be carried out in Portsmouth as Woolston closes.

webTitle: Charities call for more state funding

fields.headline: Charities call for more state funding
fields.standfirst: Voluntary organisations want more government funding to allow them a greater hand in delivering public services
fields.trailText: Voluntary organisations want more government funding to allow them a greater hand in delivering public services.
fields.body:
Three out of four charities want to play a greater role in delivering public services, according to a survey published today. But they say they need more core funding from the government to do so.

The government funds 13% of voluntary organisations' income.

The survey by the National Council for Voluntary Organisations found that 65% of charities thought the government should provide them with core funding - with 20% calling for project funding and 15% for start up funding. Over half of the 500 voluntary organisations questioned favoured higher direct taxation to pay for the increased spending.

Stuart Etherington, chief executive of the NCVO, said: "The government has a responsibility to foster an environment within which charities can prosper and fulfil their potential as key players in tackling social exclusion and addressing need.

"For this vision to become a reality the future government must acknowledge its responsibility to the sector and make a firm commitment to core funding for charities and voluntary organisations."

The survey also looked at public spending priorities in areas other than health and social care. The most popular candidates for an increase in public spending were transport and the environment. Conversely, cuts were called for in the defence budget.

 The full details of the survey will be published later this month in the first edition of voluntarysector, the new magazine of the National Council for Voluntary Organisations.

webTitle: Rebellion and betrayal in Japanese parliament

fields.headline: Rebellion and betrayal in Japanese parliament
fields.standfirst: Japan's prime minister is facing calls for his resignation - from his own party. Jonathan Watts reports from Tokyo
fields.trailText: Japan's prime minister is facing calls for his resignation - from his own party. Jonathan Watts reports from Tokyo
fields.body:
In the grey and dusty headquarters of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party the air is thick with the talk of rebellion, betrayal and upheaval.

The building in Tokyo's Nagatacho district is usually the calm control centre of one of the world's most effective political machines, which has held power for all but one of the past 45 years.

But it has plunged into a chaos of accusation and counter-accusation since Friday, when LDP heavyweight Koichi Kato made a blatant grab for power by calling for the resignation of his party boss, the prime minister Yoshiro Mori.

This revolt has stirred up the Japanese political world like few other events in recent years and prompted pundits to suggest that the country could at last be witnessing the beginning of the end of Mr Mori and, possibly, the LDP.

But there is also more than a hint of deja vu about the revolt, which in many respects resembles nothing more than a re-run of the change of government in 1993 that promised so much and delivered so little.

As was the case seven years ago, the nation's leader is spectacularly unpopular and there is widespread distrust of politics. In 1993, it was prime minister Kiichi MIyazawa, who bore the brunt of public anger at bribery scandals and economic decline, with approval ratings of less than 10 per cent according to some polls.

Today, the target of abuse is the gaffe-prone prime minister Yoshiro Mori, who is disliked by more than 70 per cent of voters. His support is shrinking fast. According to a survey released on Monday by NHK, the state-run broadcaster, Mr Mori's approval rating has declined by 7 points in the past month to 17 percent.

As in 1993, the economic outlook is also very uncertain. Last week, the government downgraded its assessment of the nation's growth prospects for the first time in two years. There are also parallels in the recent series of sex and bribery scandals that forced the resignation of several government ministers and weakened the standing of the the prime minister.

In such circumstances it is easy for challengers to follow the golden rule for getting ahead in politics: always kick a man when he is down.

Ozawa did his stomping by leaving the LDP. By contrast, Kato is putting the boot in from within by saying that he needs to take the helm of a party that is currently sinking like the Titanic and dragging the nation down with it.

"If we continue on this way, Japan's economy, its vision of the future and its status in Asia and the world will decline rapidly," he said in a television interview.

He has threatened to vote against Mr Mori in a no-confidence vote that the opposition are expected to submit later this month.

With the support of his own 45-member faction and another group of 19 MPs lead by an ally, Mr Kato could help the opposition to overturn the government's majority in the 480-seat lower house of parliament. If the no-confidence vote is passed, Mr Mori would either have to resign or to call a general election.

It is still far from certain that Mr Kato will win the numbers game. LDP elders have been working feverishly behind the scenes to break up his support. They have also encouraged Kato faction members in the cabinet - such as Kiichi Miyazawa, who is now finance minister - to criticise his disloyalty.

But if neither side blinks in the next two or three weeks, the outcome of the vote is likely to depend on how many urban-based LDP politicians feel that Mr Kato offers them the best chance of electoral survival.

Even if Kato is successful in ousting Mori, there are doubts about whether he is the right man to change the course of Japanese government, which has run up a public debt worth 120 per cent of GDP in a vain 10-year attempt to revitalise the economy.

Like Mr Ozawa, Mr Kato projects himself as a moderniser. He is in favour of small government, deregulation and fiscal rectitude. A Harvard-educated former diplomat who is fluent in Chinese, he can also claim to offer far more of a global perspective than Mr Mori, whose views are widely criticised as insular and anachronistic.

But Mr Kato, who is not known for his charisma or leadership qualities, would not be the choice of most Japanese people for prime minister. He is seen as a product of the status-quo that he claims to want to change. He is a former bureaucrat, a master of LDP backroom deals and no stranger to political funding scandals. When Ozawa left the party in 1993, Kato played a central role in bringing it back into power a year later by helping to negotiate a coalition government.

At that time, he dismissed Ozawa and his supporters as being nothing more than an alliance of anti-LDP opportunists. The criticism stuck: the government of prime minister Morihiro Hosokawa, which started amid such high hopes for reform, soon disintegrated without a shared and coherent vision.

The danger is that Kato will suffer the same fate unless he can distinguish himself from the current administration. He has promised to do this by producing a policy platform by the end of the week. It is likely to include tax increases, which are favoured by the opposition.

This would signal a tightening of fiscal policy - one of three possible fault lines in Japanese politics along with a growing rural-urban split and a long-standing divide between supporters and opponents of reforming the nation's peace-advocating constitution.

Unless Mr Kato can draw clear battle lines on one or all of these issues, he will be labelled a negative candidate who is merely capitalising on the unpopularity of the prime minister. Voters need a lot of persuading that they have not seen it all before.

fields.headline: Managers blamed for hospital failings
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited special report: future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Health managers are blamed for a catalogue of serious failings in the quality of care at three NHS hospitals criticised in official reports published today.
fields.body:
Health managers are blamed for a catalogue of serious failings in the quality of care at three NHS hospitals criticised in official reports published today.

An investigation into problems at the Oxford Heart centre, one of Britain's leading coronary units, discovered poor standards of clinical care and under-supervision of inexperienced doctors. North Lakeland NHS trust in Cumbria is criticised by health service standards watchdog, the Commission for Health Improvement (CHI), for degrading and cruel practices, including the strapping of mentally-ill patients to their commodes.

Officials at Carmarthenshire NHS trust in Wales came under fire for failing to tighten procedures quickly enough in the wake of a blunder in which the wrong kidney was removed from a seriously ill patient.

The government is expected to ask CHI to formally investigate the Oxford Heart Centre, part of the John Radcliffe Hospital. Health minister John Denham today described the management team at the centre as "dysfunctional."

The Lakeland and Carmarthenshire reports are the first to be issued by CHI, which came into being in April. CHI has been dubbed the "Ofsted of the NHS" - a reference to the formidable education inspectorate which has "named and shamed' failing schools.

Mr Denham ordered an immediate turn-round in performance at the Oxford Heart Centre. He said: "It is a very worrying report. It paints a picture of a dysfunctional team and, more than that, a failure to deal with problems when they were first raised."

He told the BBC's Radio Four Today programme: "What we have to do is tackle the management failings, the failings of people to work on the team and get it back on the road."

The study was ordered in March this year - before CHI was set up - after staff raised concerns over operational practice.

Fears included the quality of pre and post-operative care, claims that junior doctors were not properly supervised, and allegations that there was a culture of intimidation preventing staff airing their worries.

The hard-hitting CHI report into North Lakeland NHS Trust in Cumbria blames "whole systems failure" for a catalogue of degrading, unprofessional and cruel practices at Garlands Hospital in Carlisle.

The CHI inquiry report confirmed allegations that patients were tied to commodes, sworn at and denied food, clothing and blankets. The trust chairman and the director of personnel have been dismissed, while the chief executive has been suspended pending a disciplinary hearing.

Other senior managers have received warnings. CHI chief executive Peter Homa said: "The abuse of elderly people was appalling. At the time of our visit to the trust, we could not be sure that it could not happen again.

"The culture of this organisation needs to change fundamentally, so that the rights of patients are understood across the trust."

The CHI report into failures at Carmarthenshire NHS trust stemmed from the case of Korean war veteran Graham Reeves, who died in February after surgeons at the Prince Philip Hospital in Llanelli removed his healthy kidney by mistake, leaving him with just his diseased kidney.

CHI said that the trust had drawn up an action plan to address the problems, but had been slow in implementing it.

It also found there was still confusion in the minds of some staff about the handling of critical incidents.

CHI chief executive Peter Homa said: "While we cannot be specific about the failures that led to Mr Reeves's death, we can say that the trust's action plan addresses the right issues, but is taking longer to implement fully than it should."

The Royal College of Surgeons and the trust, which runs the hospital where the mix-up took place, have already carried out investigations into the incident, but their findings have not been released.

webTitle: Daily Mail agrees to run Queercompany ads

fields.headline: Daily Mail agrees to run Queercompany ads
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: The Daily Mail has decided to carry adverts for a gay internet company despite initial concerns, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
The Daily Mail has decided to carry adverts for a gay internet company, despite initial concerns that they did not fit in with its conservative editorial stance.

The newspaper is running a Queercompany.com ad that shows two gay men, naked to the waist in a passionate embrace under the headline "I'm queer. And by the way, this is not an apology".

According to Queercompany chief executive Wanda Goldwag, the Mail had agreed to run another ad showing two women holding hands alongside the caption "No white wedding. Sorry mum", but refused the rest.

John Teal, the Mail's advertising director, said: "Whenever we are presented with contentious ads, editorial look over them as they have the ultimate say about what runs in the newspaper.

"It seems there have been some crossed wires between the advertising and editorial departments, but from my department's point of view we are running the ads and that's it."

He said today that he had never had a problem with the campaign and that, subject to negotiations on rates, all four of the ads would run.

Ms Goldwag told trade magazine Marketing that the Mail was the only newspaper to refuse to run all but one of the company's risque press ads following objections from the editorial department.

webTitle: Teenage mothers blamed on anti-abortion sentiment

fields.headline: Teenage mothers blamed on anti-abortion sentiment
fields.trailText: Many teenage mothers carry on with unwanted pregnancies because of local antipathy to abortion, according to research for the Joseph Rowntree Foundation.
fields.body:
Many teenage mothers carry on with unwanted pregnancies because of local antipathy to abortion, according to research for the Joseph Rowntree Foundation.

The findings are based on a survey in Doncaster, one of the 50 most deprived local authority areas in Britain, where teenage pregnancy rates are among the highest in the country.

Researchers from York university found that a young woman's decision to carry on with an unwanted pregnancy is influenced by attitudes in her community, and by high levels of teenage pregnancy and hence visible young mothers.

The study found that most teenagers were shocked when they discovered they were pregnant. Although they considered their own views held prior to the pregnancy, they were influenced primarily by the predominantly anti-abortion attitudes and experiences of those around them.

Researchers carried out in-depth interviews with 41 teenagers who had been pregnant and held focus groups with young people and parents.

The young women had few sources of impartial advice and by the time pregnancy was confirmed, had seven to 14 weeks to decide on an abortion. For those who had chosen an abortion, knowing someone who had made the same decision, or was willing to offer advice, had been an important influence.

None had become pregnant in the hope of gaining a council house or financial independence. Families played a crucial part in ensuring that young mothers and their babies became an accepted part of the extended family.

"Our research suggests that information about abortion and early motherhood should be made more available so that young women are better informed," said Sharon Tabberer, University of York research fellow and co-author of the report.

"It also identifies a need for independent counselling, advice and support for teenagers from the time they first suspect that they are pregnant. We welcome the steps that the government's teenage pregnancy unit and the pilot Sure Start Plus programme are taking along these lines."
