webTitle: Few places for women or ethnic minorities at power top table

fields.headline: Few places for women or ethnic minorities at power top table
fields.standfirst: Comment: White, male, unelected, often unaccountable - our survey shows these are the people who matter in the public sector
fields.trailText: Power 90 tells us public sector power is heavily centralised, often unaccountable, and dominated by while, middle-aged men. Patrick Butler examines the list.
fields.body:
No Tony Blair, no Gordon Brown, no Alan Milburn or John Prescott. These are strange omissions, you might say, for a list purporting to identify the most powerful and influential individuals in the public sector.
Their power over the NHS, local government, social care, housing and regeneration and the voluntary sector is obvious - and that is precisely why we left them out.

We wanted to examine how power networks connect to and from the great offices of state. So, no ministers. Their omission is also an acknowledgement that to be useful and relevant, any list of powerful individuals in the public sector has to have limits and perspective. So no mention either for Microsoft boss Bill Gates, or US Federal reserve bank chairman Alan Greenspan.

That is not to say the choices ignore outsiders. In the lists you will find powerful individuals as diverse as governor of the bank of England Eddie George, Daily Mail editor Paul Dacre and James Crosby, chief executive of the Halifax.

Indirectly, their decisions have a profound influence on public sector policy. Who is the most powerful person in the public sector? We have deliberately not attempted to compare the power of, say, Robert Hill (health) with Brian Briscoe (local government) or Denise Platt (social services) with Lady Dean (housing).

But a study of the five sectors shows that some names pop up across the sectors: Hill has influence in both health and social care; while chief economic secretary to the Treasury Ed Balls is perceived to be influential in housing and regeneration policy.

Denise Platt, chief inspector of social services, Ken Livingstone, mayor of London, and Andrew Foster and Wendy Thomson, controller and director of best value inspection at the Audit Commission, and private care homes tycoon Chai Patel also pop up more than once.

So what do the lists tell us about power in the public sector? Each sector has its own particular power networks. But patterns do emerge. Some of the most powerful individuals are unaccountable ministerial "special advisers"; the Treasury's influence on public sector policy is profound and growing.

Gender is also an issue. Of the 90 names here, 20 are women. Three are the most powerful in their sector: Platt, Housing Corporation chair Lady Dean, and social exclusion unit head Moira Wallace.

But aside from social services (where eight of the power 15 are female), women are thin on the ground.

Nowhere is this more apparent than the NHS, where 80 per cent of the workforce is female and yet just one woman, RCN general secretary Christine Hancock, makes the power list.

Power is no respector of hierarchy, or job title. Thus it may seem illogical that Hill, a little-known Blair adviser, is regarded as having more influence on the health service than Crisp; but Hill was scored higher than Crisp by almost every one of our health panellists.

Another factor in compiling these lists is perspective. One could route all Treasury power, for example, through permanent secretary Andrew Turnbull or chief economic secretary to the Treasury, Ed Balls; we have attempted to be as precise as possible in pin-pointing the loci of power.

Thus in our housing list Michael Gahagan, director of housing at the department of the environment, transport and the regions (DETR), is regarded as more powerful than his boss Genie Turton (who is in turn perceived as more important than her boss, DETR permanent secretary Sir Richard Mottram).

Compiling such a list is not an exact science; the rankings are based on the perceptions of our informal panels of advisers, experienced public sector professionals, analysts and academics (most of whom are listed).

Finally, while we believe the lists offer insights into where public sector power lies (repeating the exercise in a year's time, when a general election may have been and gone, will be a fascinating project), the lists are also meant to be entertaining, in the spirit of a parlour game.

Do you agree with our choices, or have we overlooked some obvious power brokers? Please send your comments to editor@societytheguardian.com

fields.headline: Commission for Health Improvement (CHI)
fields.standfirst: The Commission for Health Improvement has a vast task ahead of it. Patrick Butler explains
fields.trailText: The Commission for Health Improvement has a vast task ahead of it. We explain.
fields.body:
What is the Commission for Health Improvement?
An "arms length" health services inspection body, set up in April 2000, with the aim of driving up standards of care across the NHS in England, Wales, and (by invitation only) Northern Ireland. Scotland has its own body, the Clinical Standards Board. CHI carries out investigations into "major system failures" (known in journalese as "failing hospitals") and, separately, it plans to inspect every NHS trust, Health authority and primary care group (known as local health groups in Wales) by 2004 as part of its programme of clinical governance reviews. Clinical governance reviews measure, in each inspected body: the quality of patient care; whether clinical staff are up to date in their professional practice; and that safeguards are in place to prevent clinical errors.

Does CHI see itself as a bit like Ofsted, the education inspectorate?
No. They are both inspection bodies that aim to raise standards at the organisations they inspect. However, CHI resents its reputation as 'the Ofsted of the NHS' feeling that this gives it an unwarranted reputation as an aggressive, intimidatory 'hit squad' out to punish recalcitrant NHS organisations. It wants to be known as an 'assessor' rather than an 'inspector' and sees its role as developmental and collaborative. It says its methods are "very different" from those of Ofsted.


Does the NHS believe CHI is a bit like Ofsted?
Yes, so far. A recent survey by the Health Quality Service and trade magazine Health Service Journal discovered that most trust NHS chief executives and senior quality managers were "fearful of inspection". They worry it will adopt an Ofsted-style "name and shame" approach, that staff will be made public scapegoats, and that CHI investigators will "relish wielding a big stick." Like school teachers with Ofsted, NHS managers believe CHI inspections will be costly, stressful, and will distract attention from day-to-day work.

Does it have the power to close failing hospitals or remove the management?
No. But it "will report serious findings" to the health secretary or the Welsh Assembly (who may take action). According to health secretary Alan Milburn: "(CHI)is uniquely placed to respond quickly to and investigate thoroughly, with extensive powers to gather information and interview individuals. Using these it will identify the source of problems, and develop fast and effective solutions. It will not take over the provision or management of services."

Is it independent of government?
Technically, yes. Its aim is to publish the truth as it sees fit, regardless of how uncomfortable this may be to government, NHS bodies or to the public. There is some cynicism among NHS staff as to how independent it will be. An internal CHI report in October 2000 admitted: "We need to convince the NHS that we are the developmental body we claim to be The NHS audience is reasonably aware of what we aspire to be, but is cynical that we will be allowed to be."

Who decides which NHS organisation will be investigated by CHI?
It will investigate individual health services "when required to do so" by the secretary of state for health. In addition, "anyone within or outside the NHS" can ask it to conduct an investigation, although in these cases it is a matter for CHI to decide whether or not to proceed.

Who runs CHI?
It is chaired by Dame Deidre Hine, former chief medical officer for Wales and co-author with ex-chief medical officer for England, Kenneth Calman of the seminal Calman-Hine report into UK cancer services. The chief executive is Peter Homa, a former trust chief executive and head of the NHS waiting list task force. Board members include two prominent Labour Party-supporting doctors, cancer specialist Professor David Kerr and London GP Sam Everington.

fields.headline: Why the current floods are not all caused by global warming
fields.trailText: There is no river anywhere near, but last week the Brighton suburb of Bevendean was drying out after a flood. fields.body:
There is no river anywhere near, but last week the Brighton suburb of Bevendean was drying out after a flood. Carpets, sodden furniture, washing machines and freezers were being thrown into skips, mud hosed out of houses. People knew what to do; it had happened before. Muddy water, runoff from fields planted with winter cereals, had flowed down a normally dry valley and into the houses. Four small dams meant to protect houses filled and overflowed. But much of the damaging flow resulted from a field that bypassed the dams. In this field, a gully 1.5 metre deep and several hundred metres long had been cut in the early hours of 12 October. It discharged hundreds of tons of mud into houses and roads.

Bevendean, like other sites around Brighton, has a long history of flooding and serious soil erosion. In 1982 the farmer at Bevendean, on being asked if he had an erosion problem, replied no. He later pointed to a field where he had lost a cow in a gully. Bevendean houses were also flooded in 1985 and 1987.

Between 1976 and 1993 there were 60 floodings in the Brighton area. A substantial number will have been added this autumn. In October 1987 at Rottingdean, 3km from Bevendean, around £400,000 of damage was done to about 30 houses. Half of these costs were borne by household insurers.

There is a pattern to the muddy flooding. Almost all incidents occur in the months of October and November, and all involve runoff from fields prepared for, or sown with winter wheat. Because the fields are bare, even moderate amounts of rainfall result in muddy flows leaving the fields by cutting gullies. Farmers often claim that these are 'freak events'. One farmer making this claim was asked when was the previous case of flooding of the nearby village. He replied 'last year'.

Over the hill from Bevendean is the well-known vineyard of Breaky Bottom. The farmhouse, built in a dry valley in 1827, was not flooded until 1976. Then again in 1982, 1987 and last month. The muddy-flooding has increased since the slopes up-valley began to be cultivated with cereals. Under grass there was no threat as there was little runoff and no erosion. A series of October floods in 1987 resulted in considerable damage to house and vines and a long-running legal dispute, resulting in undisclosed damages being paid to Peter Hall at Breaky Bottom. The case sought to prove that cultivation of steep slopes for wheat constituted a predictable risk of downvalley flooding. That it was done in the knowledge of the risk, and that nothing had been done to mitigate that risk, and that therefore, land use and farming practices were more responsible than the heavy rain. Central to the case, and others like it, is the assertion that it is how, when and where the valley-slopes are cultivated - not the fact that it rains hard as the main cause of muddy-flood damage. Farmers thus have a responsibility to manage land wisely, including an awareness of downvalley risk of flooding.

This is not only a South Downs problem. In other parts of the country where houses are adjacent to farmland, the incidence of muddy-flooding has increased since the adoption of winter cereals in the 1970s. Particularly at risk is the Isle of Wight, Devon, Somerset, Kent and parts of the east and west Midlands. In some areas summer storms have also caused devastation to maize, potatoes or linseed crops, flooding houses in towns such as Faringdon in Oxfordshire and Bishopsteignton in Devon.

The Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food (MAFF) have recently published a series of advisory booklets for farmers on 'Controlling Soil Erosion'. The 'Soil Code' also devotes several pages to the risks of runoff and erosion. The risk of damage to properties and roads is clearly recognised and farmers are told how to assess that risk. They are advised if the problems are 'regular and severe' to seek further advice and to consider switching to grass. The approach is voluntary, but at least the advice is now freely available.

There are success stories that show how property can be protected from muddy floods. At Rottingdean, a deal between the farmer and his landlord Brighton Borough Council led to a reduction in the area of cereals and the construction of a substantial dam. There has been no flooding since 1987. At Sompting near Worthing, after several repeated muddy-floods of houses, the farmer constructed small dams and put areas of the catchment under grass using through Set Aside payments. No property damage has occurred since 1993. Such examples of good practice in preventing muddy-floods need to be more widely known. In the southern Netherlands, Belgium and northern France, radical approaches involving co-operation between local communities, farmers, and EU funding have begun to make progress in providing protection.

Recent media reports have linked flooding in southeastern England to climate change. There is certainly an element of storms and exceptional rainfall, but housing developments on floodplains have also contributed to the catalogue of damage. Floodplains are meant to provide a natural service by storing water like a sponge - not be cluttered with houses. With the issue of runoff from agricultural land, it is easy to demonstrate that landuse is critically important. Damage occurs where property is in close proximity to bare cultivated fields, and these sites are quite predictable. Damage will not occur every year, but in relatively wet autumns such as 1982, 1987, and 2000. Farmers at these sites are engaged in a risk-taking activity (commonly called a gamble) and can expect to lose every few years. But the real losers are the insurance companies, the local councils, and the householders. Costs of damage to crops are minimal compared to those associated with the flooding of houses. In the short-term, muddy-flooding of properties is a cost that is borne by non-agricultural sectors of society.

fields.bodyText: There is no river anywhere near, but last week the Brighton suburb of Bevendean was drying out after a flood. Carpets, sodden furniture, washing machines and freezers were being thrown into skips, mud hosed out of houses. People knew what to do; it had happened before. Muddy water, runoff from fields planted with winter cereals, had flowed down a normally dry valley and into the houses. Four small dams meant to protect houses filled and overflowed. But much of the damaging flow resulted from a field that bypassed the dams. In this field, a gully 1.5 metre deep and several hundred metres long had been cut in the early hours of 12 October. It discharged hundreds of tons of mud into houses and roads. Bevendean, like other sites around Brighton, has a long history of flooding and serious soil erosion. In 1982 the farmer at Bevendean, on being asked if he had an erosion problem, replied no. He later pointed to a field where he had lost a cow in a gully. Bevendean houses were also flooded in 1985 and 1987. Between 1976 and 1993 there were 60 floodings in the Brighton area. A substantial number will have been added this autumn. In October 1987 at Rottingdean, 3km from Bevendean, around £400,000 of damage was done to about 30 houses. Half of these costs were borne by household insurers. There is a pattern to the muddy flooding. Almost all incidents occur in the months of October and November, and all involve runoff from fields prepared for, or sown with winter wheat. Because the fields are bare, even moderate amounts of rainfall result in muddy flows leaving the fields by cutting gullies. Farmers often claim that these are 'freak events'. One farmer making this claim was asked when was the previous case of flooding of the nearby village. He replied 'last year'. Over the hill from Bevendean is the well-known vineyard of Breaky Bottom. The farmhouse, built in a dry valley in 1827, was not flooded until 1976. Then again in 1982, 1987 and last month. The muddy-flooding has increased since the slopes up-valley began to be cultivated with cereals. Under grass there was no threat as there was little runoff and no erosion. That it was done in the knowledge of the risk, and that nothing had been done to mitigate that risk, and that therefore, land use and farming practices were more responsible than the heavy rain. Particularly at risk is the Isle of Wight, Devon, Somerset, Kent and parts of the east and west Midlands. webTitle: UPC puts pre-tax losses down to digital expansion

fields.headline: UPC blames digital expansion for pre-tax losses
fields.trailText: 1.15pm: Dutch cable company United Pan-Europe Communications is counting the cost of expanding its digital network. Bu Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Dutch cable company United Pan-Europe Communications, which holds a stake in UK operator Telewest, is counting the cost of expanding its digital network.

UPC said its programme for rolling out television, telephone and internet services contributed to a third quarter pre-tax loss of E639.5m (£387.5m), tripling the deficit for the same period last year.

Sales figures also disappointed, as the E258m (£156m) total was below forecasts, although it more than doubled last year's numbers.

The company said that its losses would continue into next year, though analysts believe the group is right to plough money into its digital programme.

The ambitious combination of television, telephone and internet services over its networks is seen as a potential big earner.

UPC is unlikely to gain any short-term respite from a merger between UK cable company NTL and its rival Telewest, in which UPC holds a 25% stake. Analysts say the companies' combined debt burden makes such an agreement impossible.

Some good news was provided by its ExciteChello internet service provider, which posted a 21% rise in subsciber figures to 264,000.

fields.headline: UBC Media posts half-year losses
fields.trailText: 1.15pm: UBC Media, the radio production company in which Noel Edmonds has a 15% stake, has lost £430,000, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
UBC Media, the radio production company in which Noel Edmonds has a 15% stake, has posted pre-tax losses of £430,000.

The company, which produces the Pepsi Chart Show, Radio 4's Something Understood with Mark Tully and the Richard Allinson show for Radio 2, said that the losses for the six months to October were in line with expectations.

UBC raised £5 by floating on the Stock Exchange in July and today said it had turned over £2.4m in the six months to October.

Chief executive Simon Cole hinted that UBC would use its cash balance to buy small independent companies.

Mr Cole said: "In the first six months we have increased revenues by 21% in comparison with 1999, initiated key acquisitions and have strengthened our cash position through raising £5m at our initial public offering.

"Our public company status ensures we have a strong currency with which to make further acquisitions."

He pointed to the fact that UBC Media has also strengthened its digital radio activity, joining the MXR digital radio consortium, and has signed internet radio content deals.

webTitle: Scottish Radio tunes in to record profits

fields.headline: Scottish Radio tunes in to record profits
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Scottish Radio Holdings has posted record profits thanks to bumper performances from its media businesses. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Scottish Radio Holdings has posted record profits thanks to bumper performances from its mix of old and new media businesses.

The Glasgow-based group combines analogue, digital and internet radio, including the Radio Clyde and Radio Forth stations in Scotland.

Scottish Radio also runs newspaper and outdoor advertising businesses.

The group said that full-year pre-tax profits had climbed 27% to a record £20m, on turnover up 30% to £71.7m.

Despite its enthusiasm for digital and internet services, Scottish's analogue radio operations were the biggest earner, with a turnover of £34m.

The figures were backed up by the latest radio ratings, which showed the group's radio stations were still on top of their regional markets.

Lord Gordon, chairman of the company, said: "With steady further growth, increasing investment in new technology and commercial evaluation of new corporate opportunities, SRH will play a full part in the continuing and exciting developments already underway in the media sector."

Scottish Radio raised £75m through a share placing earlier in the year, which will drive its plans to invest in digital radio and make further acquisitions.

The group is also planning a January relaunch for the struggling Ireland on Sunday newspaper after acquiring the loss-making title in the summer.

Scottish Radio's main focus over the next year will be on expanding its digital radio network, with £1m set aside for investment in its existing stations and for buying more licences.

Digital radio will be a front for Scottish's expansion into England, with licence applications planned for the Midlands and London.

The group is also interested in extending its reach in the Republic of Ireland.

fields.headline: Knowledge Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Send your questions to the.boss@guardian.co.uk. We'll do our best to answer them
fields.trailText: WELL-TRAVELLED FOOTBALLERS
fields.byline: Sean Ingle, Scott Murray and Paul MacInnes
fields.body:
WELL-TRAVELLED FOOTBALLERS

"Has anyone played for a First Division side in each of the big four European leagues (Italy, Spain, England, Germany)?" asks Paul Carek. "If so, who was the last to do it? Who was the most successful?"

Step forward one Florin Valeriu Raducioiu, who like the kid who can manage three Shredded Wheat, boasts a travelling record many players would envy. After playing for five seasons at Dinamo Bucharest, the Harvey Nicks regular spent four years in Italy (with Bari, Verona, Brescia and Milan), two years in Spain (with Espanyol), that season at West Ham and also a year at Stuttgart - before going back to Espanyol and then Brescia. Cheers to Duncan Young for the spot.

Other players have also been suggested - notably Stefan Schwarz (Fiorentina, Valencia, Arsenal/Sunderland and Bayer Leverkusen). However, hats off to Simon Lindberg who, after originally suggesting the Swedish midfielder, decided to phone up "the people at his Swedish club Malmo" to make sure. They confirmed that while Schwarz was at Leverkusen, he was merely a trainee and never played. "I hope I haven't caused any troubles since I am a big fan of Knowledge Unlimited," says Simon.

Meanwhile, Duncan Young points out that several players have managed three clubs in the big four countries, including: Jurgen Klinsmann (Tottenham, Sampdoria, Stuttgart); Allan Simonsen (Charlton, Borussia Moenchengladbach and Barcelona); Savo Milosevic (Villa, Zaragoza, Parma); Karlheinz Riedle (Dortmund, Lazio, Liverpool); Mark Hughes (Man U, Barcelona, Bayern Munich); Darko Kovacevic (Sheffield Wednesday, Sociedad, Juventus); Brian Laudrup (Bayern Munich, Fiorentina, Chelsea); Bryan Roy (Nottm Forest, Foggia, Hertha Berlin); Martin Dahlin (Borussia Moenchengladbach, Blackburn, Roma); Christian Karembeu (Sampdoria, Real Madrid, Middlesbrough); Paulo Futre (West Ham, Atletico Madrid, Reggiana); Alojsa Asanovic (Valladolid, Derby, Napoli); and Mario Stanic (Gijon, Parma, Chelsea).

WHAT A REFRESHING TACTIC

"Can anyone explain the archaic tactic of 'metodo', beloved of the Austrian side of the 1950s I believe?" asks Liam Arthur.

During football's formative years, attack was the name of the game. The barnstorming 2-3-5 formation was king, while the classic W-M formation - used by England after the war - was merely a glint in Walter Winterbottom's eye. But during the 1930s, Italy coach Vittorio Pozzo was formulating an idea which was to become known as the Italian metodo.

Pozzo decided that 2-3-5 was just a little bit too bold and decided to pull his two inside-forwards back into midfield, making a sort of 2-3-2-3 formation. Five men in midfield obviously worked, as Italy won successive World Cups in 1934 and 1938 and Pozzo was hailed as a tactical genius.

Incidentally, before the 1938 World Cup, fascist dictator Benito Mussolini sent a telegram to Pozzo which said "win or die". Fortunately for the creator of metodo, Italy beat Hungary 4-2 in the final.

HOMER - D'OH!

Were Fenerbahce the first team to beat Manchester United in the Champions League at home? asks John Stewart

The Turks weren't just the first team to beat Manchester United at home in the Competition Formerly Known As European Cup. By winning 1-0 in Group C of the Champions League in October 1996, they ended United's 40-year unbeaten home record in all European competition.

The damage was done by Elvir Bolic, who broke down the left wing in the 76th minute of a dull game and walloped a shot which deflected off David May and over Peter Schmeichel into the net.

Sure enough, having lost at home in Europe for the first time in 40 years, United took only 14 days to repeat the feat. A penalty from Allesandro Del Piero was enough to give eventual finalists Juventus a 1-0 win.

PUTTING IT ON YOUR SHIRT

Last week we explained how Kettering Town became the first British club to run out with a company's name emblazoned on their shirts, which - not surprisingly - got many of you reminiscing fondly about those early days of kit advertising.

"I recall when I was with the Daily Express in Manchester, going to a Bolton match (circa 1980) and they were sponsored by the local paper, the Bolton Evening News. Since they used only the initials every player in the team appeared to be named BEN," remembers Len Findlay, who now works in Australia.

This is disputed by the club, however, who can only remember as far back as their sponsors for the 1981 season Knights Security.

Meanwhile, Paddy Dwyer says he can remember an edition of Roy of the Rovers "from some time in the late seventies in which Melchester Rovers were getting ready for one of the invariably vital games they played.

"The company name Gola was emblazoned across their shirts and, as they put them on, one of the players said to Roy: 'What's this, shouldn't it say Goal?' Even at age eight, I thought to myself 'Jesus, what a twat'. It's good to know footballers in comics are just as thick as their real life counterparts."

EMILE "SCRATCH" HESKEY

"So what's that scratching thing that Emile Heskey does every time he scores a goal then?" asks Dr Adam Marshall. "He's not turning his hand to music is he?"

Sadly Dr Adam, our prognosis is that Emile is not the music man. Indeed, according to sources close to Liverpool Football Club, Emile is doing nothing more than an impression of a dance DJ (popular amongst the youth). This impression consists of listening to an imaginary song on imaginary headphones - hence the left hand placed against the ear - while spinning back said imaginary track with the right hand (the rewind, as it is known) for the delectation of the crowd.

However, scholars of the 'rap scene' insist that Emile is 'scratching' with his right hand, the process by which DJs grind their records into dust, and also the means by which 5ive created the "wiggy wiggy" noise on their recent number one hit 'We Will Rock You.'

WOLFSBURG'S WOLFGANG WOLF

Can you confirm that the manager of [Bundesliga side] Wolfsburg is called Wolfgang Wolf? asks Stefan Schnoor (which could possibly be an alias)

It sounds ridiculous. And it is. But it's also true.

CAN YOU HELP?

"Is Raul the youngest player to score a hat-trick in the Champions League?" asks John Stewart.

"What percentage of the games that Chelsea have lost over the last three seasons have they been without Marcel Desailly for? Surely he is the key link to this teams current success?" reckons Gavin Gray.

Anyone who knows can mail their answer to the.boss@theguardian.com. And you can use the same address to send your questions: we'll do our best to answer them.

webTitle: The 15 most powerful people in housing

fields.headline: The 15 most powerful people in housing
fields.trailText:
1. Lady Dean of Thornton-le-Fylde
Chairwoman, Housing Corporation
The Housing Corporation
Former boss of SOGAT, the newspaper industry print union, Brenda Dean is now in charge of a £650m investment budget for new social housing at the Housing Corporation. A front bench Labour spokeswoman when the party was in opposition, and a member of the Wakeham commission on House of Lords' reform, she is a player with influence.
fields.body:
1. Lady Dean of Thornton-le-Fylde
Chairwoman, Housing Corporation
The Housing Corporation
Former boss of SOGAT, the newspaper industry print union, Brenda Dean is now in charge of a £650m investment budget for new social housing at the Housing Corporation. A front bench Labour spokeswoman when the party was in opposition, and a member of the Wakeham commission on House of Lords' reform, she is a player with influence.

2. Michael Gahagan
Director of housing, Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions (DETR)
DETR Housing site
The key housing policy person. A pivotal role as the key sifter of housing policy ideas, and a gatekeeper to the minister. Chaired the DETR review of the Housing Corporation, and a number of other departmental housing committees.

3. Richard Best
Director, Joseph Rowntree Foundation
JRF Online
Head of the largest social policy research charity in the UK, and guardian of probably the biggest housing research budget in the country. Expert at wielding the power that knowledge brings.

4. Eddie George
Governor, Bank of England
The Bank of England
Interest rates drive all sectors of housing. Differential regional economic performance is the cause of the two biggest challenges for housing policy - sky-high prices in the south and lack of demand for social housing in the north.

5. Lord Rogers of Riverside
Chair, Urban Task Force
DETR Urban Task Force site
High-profile architect (Lloyds building, Millenium Dome) and key influence on prime minister Tony Blair. His Urban Task Force sought to find the housing holy grail - a way of meeting demand for new homes without concreting over the countryside.

6. Moira Wallace
Director, Social Exclusion Unit
The Social Exclusion Unit
Crucial role in defining where housing sits within the social exclusion and regeneration agenda, which is currently transforming the activities of council landlords and housing associations.

7. Ed Balls
Chief economic adviser to the Treasury
HM Treasury
Gordon Brown's special adviser, and effectively the second most important person at the Treasury, with influence over every area of economic policy. If he said investment in social housing was important, things would really change.

8. Genie Turton
Director general, housing, construction, urban and rural policy, Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions
DETR Housing Directorate site
A key position in the DETR in terms of housing, and boss of Michael Gehagan.

9. Peter Williams
Deputy director general, Council of Mortgage Lenders
Council of Mortgage Lenders
Important policy influence on mortage lending and well beyond. Housing Corporation board member and all-round networker.

10. Paul Lautman
Head of housing, Local Government Association
LGAnet
A powerful influence largely through command of the detail of local authority housing policy.

11. James Crosby
Chief executive, The Halifax
The Halifax
Lends money for house purchase to roughly one in ten households in the UK. The commercial lending arm has a major influence on which new social housing projects receive funding.

12. Chris Holmes
Director, Shelter
Shelter
Highly influential both at political level and on the detail of policy - well known and respected not least for having run a large local authority housing department.

13. Mavis Macdonald
Permanent secretary, Cabinet Office

webTitle: Boo.com could face legal action from Camden Council

fields.headline: Boo.com faces legal action from council
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Boo.com could face legal action after an urban ad campaign backfired on the trendy fashion house. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Boo.com could face legal action after an advertising campaign backfired on the trendy fashion website.

The US-based dot.com has covered the streets of Camden in north London with stickers promoting the website's recent relaunch.

The move has angered Camden council, which is now planning legal action against Boo as part of its campaign against illegally posted ads.

A Camden spokesman confirmed its intention to prosecute. He said: "Boo.com have been illegally advertising around Camden. The only reason we haven't yet taken legal action is because of the trouble we've had getting hold of them.

"They don't have a London office so there has been no one to serve a writ on."

The spokesman said that nine out of 10 cases like this end in legal action since it is almost impossible to take down the offending stickers.

He added that everyone connected with the offence would be implicated in the lawsuit - from the ad agency to the company responsible for putting up the stickers.

Under the Town & Country Act this kind of offence carries a fine of up to £1,000 per offending poster - or in this case, sticker.

Diabolical Liberties is understood to be the agency responsible for the campaign.

fields.headline: Marketing Society hears Tory lambasts Labour record
fields.trailText: Former Asda boss Archie Norman has accused Labour of dragging the country down at today's Marketing Society conference, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Former Asda boss Archie Norman has launched a scathing attack on the Labour party's record in government, accusing it of dragging the country down to third world standards.

The Conservative environment spokesman likened the nation's infrastructure to that of Russia or India and said that while Britain's private sector was thriving, the public sector was in crisis.

Hijacking today's Marketing Society's conference, Mr Norman said: "The revolution in quality is purely a private sector revolution. Our roads are always being dug up, our railways are in crisis and our flood defences are failing. All that adds up to an impression of a country that is failing."

He argued that the NHS was being run in a way that would put any equivalent private organisation to shame.

"The NHS is the third biggest employer in the world after the Indian railways and the Russian army and it is run in much the same way," Mr Norman said, holding up the Dome as an example of what happens when politicans get too involved.

fields.headline: The race to buy life
fields.standfirst:
Carve up of the human heart: private firms, universities and charities are rushing to isolate and patent human genes before it is even understood what they do
Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Carve up of the human heart: private firms, universities and charities are rushing to isolate and patent human genes before it is even understood what they do
fields.body:
The race for commercial control over the essence of life is threatening to spiral out of control with private firms, universities and charities claiming exclusive development rights over natural processes in the human body at the rate of 34,500 a month.

For the first time, research commissioned by the Guardian reveals the awesome scale of the gene rush, as investors, scientists, entrepreneurs and lawyers use powerful new technology and obscure new laws to isolate and patent the genes which make us what we are - before they even understand what the genes do.

Biotech firms say they need patent protection to recoup their investments. But the risk to society is that future medical researchers - private and public - will have to hack their way through forests of patents, paying out hefty licence fees to a host of gene-squatters, before the miracle drugs of the genetics revolution reach the market.

"It's like someone buying a street and taking a toll from everybody passing through," said Thomas Schweiger, of German Greenpeace, which is campaigning against gene patenting.

Sue Mayer, head of GeneWatch UK, the independent watchdog body commissioned by the Guardian to analyse the gene patent rush, challenged the basis on which gene patents are granted - that genes, or bits of genes, are "inventions".

"What's striking is the speed and the scale at which patent applications are being made," she said. "It's impossible that this is caused by a sudden outbreak of creativity and inven tiveness. Unless people look at the issue seriously, unless the rules are changed in a few years time we will find very basic knowledge and information has been privatised."

Alongside human genes, patents are being sought by organisations, overwhelmingly from rich countries, on hundreds of thousands of animal and plant genes, including those in staple crops such as rice and wheat.

Patents are already pending or have been granted on more than 500,000 genes and partial gene sequences in living organisms.

When GeneWatch UK began its database search last month, patents had been granted or were pending on 126,672 whole or partial human genes. As of this week, however, that number had rocketed by over 34,500 to 161,195, an increase of 27%.

The Guardian's research found that

 One firm alone, Genset of France, has applied for patents covering 36,083 human gene sequences

 Patents are pending on genes controlling processes in the human heart, teeth, tongue, colon, skin, brain, bone, ear, lung, liver, kidney, sperm, blood and immune system

 The US department of health is the world's fifth biggest recorded gene patenter, with applications pending or granted on almost 3,000 sequences

 152 patents have been applied for on rice, 21 on HIV, 13 on the eucalyptus tree and 11 on the spider.

 Among gene patent applicants are Queen Elizabeth college, Dublin (human eye), York University (rice), the Wellcome Foundation (HIV) and ICI (eucalyptus).

 Gene patenters are overwhelmingly from the US, western Europe and Japan.

Opponents of gene patenting believe companies using genetic information to develop real therapies and diagnostic techniques should be able to use the patent system to claw back the huge investment involved.

But they object to firms and other organisations being granted patents for genes when they cannot specify what the genes will be used for.

"Genes are isolated by computers on a routine basis," said Mr Schweiger. "There's no special intellectual work required. Even if the gene patenter doesn't ever develop a new drug or therapy with the gene, and somebody else does all the investment to find out what use can be made of the gene, all the investment is done by the second company and the first company still gets the money."

Concern is growing in continental Europe over an EU directive adopted two years ago which makes it easier to patent genes. In June, the French president Jacques Chirac wrote to the head of the European commission, Romano Prodi, saying that gene patenting should not be permitted.

Yet delegates to a rare diplomatic conference to revise the treaty governing European patent law, opening in Munich on Monday, are not even planning to discuss gene patenting. The British delegate, Alison Brimelow, said yesterday the issue would not be discussed until next year.

The British government has strongly supported liberalisation of the laws on gene patenting, hoping to nurture its own biotech industry and fearful the anti-GM backlash would persuade European and US biotech investors to relocate.

Much of the pressure to liberalise European gene patenting laws has come from the US. Last year the chairman of US drugs firm Pfizer, William Steere, said: "Europe seems to be entering a period of the dark ages, where witchcraft and sorcery are prevailing." The sentiment was shared by Andre Pernet, Genset chief executive. "I think the fear generated by the decoding of the human genome, that somehow people's 'essence' would be captured, has carried over into the gene patenting debate.

"You don't want to patent a gene and then just watch the patent time deadline melt away like a block of ice. There's no money to be made unless you really want to develop a drug."

fields.headline: Harry Potter put to flight by darker forces
fields.standfirst:
Whitbread book awards: Shortlists show children's fiction in a grim light, along with heavyweight biographies and some offbeat novels

Special report and shortlists
fields.trailText: The power of darkness finally overwhelmed Harry Potter yesterday when JK Rowling's wholesome, multi-million-selling hero was humiliatingly defeated in the £26,000 Whitbread book awards by a clutch of more sombre children's stories.
fields.body:
The power of darkness finally overwhelmed Harry Potter yesterday. JK Rowling's wholesome, multi-million-selling hero was humiliatingly defeated in the £26,000 Whitbread book awards by a clutch of more sombre children's stories - including one about a man who buries abandoned babies "alive or dead ".

Despite selling 833,000 hardback copies since July, the new Potter story, The Goblet of Fire, not only failed to reach the shortlist for its section but was not even among the titles considered. This was because "it simply was not considered as good" as the four stories - three of them dark in theme - which did achieve the list, it emerged last night. The judges called the shortlisted books a wonderful crop of new novels for the young.

Last night one of the three children's judges, the author Michael Morpurgo, said: "I think we just felt it was not as good as the last Harry Potter. We had other books which were very, very good".

He added that two children who were helping with the judging did not query its omission and little time was spent discussing it.

Last year Rowling won the £3,500 children's section award but missed the overall prize.

Her early defeat this year was disclosed when five shortlists were announced in the run-up to the awards final in January.

Notable choices on other lists were two of last week's Booker prize also-rans, Kazuo Ishiguro's When We Were Orphans and Matthew Kneale's English Passengers, on the novel shortlist. This also features Will Self's How the Dead Live, a vision of London as a necropolis of undead old age pensioners. Zadie's Smith's White Teeth, unlucky in the Booker and Orange prize awards, lives to fight another day in the shortlist for first novels.

Three blockbusting, highly regarded conventional biographies are on the shortlist for their section. They are John Ruskin: The Later Years, by the ex-Guardian art critic Tim Hilton; Fanny Burney, by Claire Harman; and Ian Kershaw's Hitler: 1936-45 Nemesis.

The list's wild card is Bad Blood, a brief, intensely personal memoir by Lorna Sage. On the poetry shortlist are John Burnside, Michael Donaghy, RF Langley, Michael Riordan and Anne Stevenson.

The authors who - unlike Rowling - succesfully made the Whitbread children's book of the year award are Heaven Eyes, by David Almond; Arthur: the Seeing Stone, by Kevin Crossley-Holland; Coram Boy, by Jamila Gavin; and Troy by Adele Geras. Geras's book is set in a besieged city where the heroine tends the wounded in a "blood room". Heaven Eyes opens in a "despairing" children's home from which runaways escape through nightmarish docklands.

And one reviewer wrote of Coram Boy: "This stunning novel is neither for the faint-hearted nor for anyone ever tempted to think nostalgically about the glories of Georgian England. It is about a ruthless dealer, who travels along the drovers' roads purporting to carry abandoned infants to London's new Coram Hospital for the Maintenance and Education of Exposed and Deserted Children.

"In fact, he buries the babies alive or dead while allowing most older infants to starve to death."

Mr Morpurgo said: "People felt they were all rather intense books. They were books I did not feel particularly comfortable in - but I did not want to leave them.

"They don't have the same popular appeal as Harry Potter. But they all deserve to do well and I think one or two of them will sell very well".

Sage, known to newspaper readers for 25 years as a literary reviewer, earned almost universal praise with her revelatory memoir about her upbringing with her maternal grandfather in Flintshire.

One reviewer said: "She won her prizes, but also insisted on listening to Elvis and stalking boys from the grammar school. At 16, and without realising that she had actually gone all the way, she found herself pregnant. She never asks for our pity".

fields.headline: Students march against tuition fees
fields.trailText: The biggest student demonstration in a decade is taking place today in London, as students voice their opposition to tuition fees. The National Union of Students estimates that some 15,000 students will turn out for the march, which starts at the University of London Union, in Malet Street, and finishes off after crossing Waterloo Bridge with a rally at Kennington Park. The demo is part of the NUSs "Winning for Students" campaign against the introduction of top-up fees. Students are also calling for the abolition of current tuition fees and the introduction of targeted maintenance grants. Owain James, NUS president, said: In 2001 the first batch of students who have funded themselves entirely through student loans will graduate. The deep-seated concern they feel is directly reflected in the high numbers coming down from all over the country for the march. This is the biggest student march in a decade. Guest speakers at the rally include: Paul Mackney, general secretary of Natfhe, the lecturers' union, Ken Livingstone, Mayor for London, and David Triesman, general secretary of the Association of University Teachers. This evening there will be an end-of-rally party at the Brixton Academy.

webTitle: What will the world be like in five years' time?

fields.headline: What will the world be like in five years' time?
fields.standfirst: Professor Jim Briden, Director, Environmental Change Institute, University of Oxford, asks what scientists will achieve
fields.trailText: In five years time our world will be different. We'll all be older and hopefully a little wiser. And pressing climate change issues will still be with us. But what will scientists and technologists have achieved in the intervening years? What will be the challenges in developing the energy-efficient technologies needed to reduce carbon dioxide emissions?
fields.body:
In five years time our world will be different. We'll all be older and hopefully a little wiser. And pressing climate change issues will still be with us. But what will scientists and technologists have achieved in the intervening years? What will be the challenges in developing the energy-efficient technologies needed to reduce carbon dioxide emissions?

By looking at recent developments in the UK and elsewhere, we can confidently predict that public attitudes towards government sustainability policies will have been expressed at the ballot box, and perhaps even in the streets. The UK has had a recently unprecedented 'fuel crisis' as truck drivers and other road users protested against partly environmental taxes. Within the past year, international demonstrators have protested in Seattle against the globalisation policies of the WTO, and in Prague to the IMF and the World Bank. Climate change demands global policies and global action - the purpose of COP6 and the Kyoto Protocol.

The eight years since the 1992 United Nations Biodiversity Summit in Rio have demonstrated spectacularly what governments around the world can do individually and collaboratively to tackle the unprecedented problem of global change. But we also have some pointers as to what cannot be done by this top-down approach to policy implementation. We have learnt that society does not adopt sustainable practices and innovative technology through legislation alone. For a sustainable future, success or failure lies as much in the hands of society as in governments and their legislation. In Europe, 70% of housing does not have a single energy-efficient light bulb yet they benefit the householder by reducing their electricity bills.

In the search for a lower-carbon future, science, business, and industry occupy the territory linking government and citizen. They innovate the technology and services that can achieve sustainability through the consumer market place. There is ample evidence in universities around the world and at the technology exhibition currently at COP6 of an abundance of innovation both for moderation of carbon dioxide outputs and for adaptation to climate change. Acceptance of sustainable technology into the market place and conquering the risks of climate change call for the development of new relationships between business, industry, innovative universities and consumers. Sustainable technology needs more than innovative ideas. It requires public dialogue to transform society towards an energy-efficient market place and to produce lasting climate change solutions.

The world is currently short of the types of organisations, mechanisms and representative groups that are likely to be required for this change of mind set. So just as universities have a role in technological innovation and solving of environmental problems, we also have a developing role in awareness and communication. Not only do universities need improved links with technologists and businesses; we also want dialogue with society and citizens.

Scientists and society alike have to realise that the benefits of responding to global change are not only altruistic towards future generations. The adoption of sustainable technology often brings immediate advantages in convenience, product quality, and finance. World-class universities like Oxford have a developing role as centres of impartial dialogue linking innovation, solution technology, and wider society. Science and society needs to move forward with this process, and we need to find the mechanisms for this sea change to happen. Sustainable technology might then become a lasting solution to moderating climate change. Without societal support and acceptance, Ôsustainable technologyÕ will remain a phrase for innovation without customers.

fields.bodyText: In five years time our world will be different. We'll all be older and hopefully a little wiser. And pressing climate change issues will still be with us. But what will scientists and technologists have achieved in the intervening years? What will be the challenges in developing the energy-efficient technologies needed to reduce carbon dioxide emissions? By looking at recent developments in the UK and elsewhere, we can confidently predict that public attitudes towards government sustainability policies will have been expressed at the ballot box, and perhaps even in the streets. The UK has had a recently unprecedented 'fuel crisis' as truck drivers and other road users protested against partly environmental taxes. Within the past year, international demonstrators have protested in Seattle against the globalisation policies of the WTO, and in Prague to the IMF and the World Bank. Climate change demands global policies and global action - the purpose of COP6 and the Kyoto Protocol. The eight years since the 1992 United Nations Biodiversity Summit in Rio have demonstrated spectacularly what governments around the world can do individually and collaboratively to tackle the unprecedented problem of global change. But we also have some pointers as to what cannot be done by this top-down approach to policy implementation. We have learnt that society does not adopt sustainable practices and innovative technology through legislation alone. For a sustainable future, success or failure lies as much in the hands of society as in governments and their legislation. In Europe, 70% of housing does not have a single energy-efficient light bulb yet they benefit the householder by reducing their electricity bills. They innovate the technology and services that can achieve sustainability through the consumer market place. Acceptance of sustainable technology into the market place and conquering the risks of climate change call for the development of new relationships between business, industry, innovative universities and consumers. Sustainable technology needs more than innovative ideas. It requires public dialogue to transform society towards an energy-efficient market place and to produce lasting climate change solutions. The world is currently short of the types of organisations, mechanisms and representative groups that are likely to be required for this change of mind set. webTitle: Alli joins Evans to bid for Daily Star

fields.headline: Alli talks to Evans about buying Daily Star
fields.trailText: 8am: Waheed Alli is teaming up with Chris Evans for a possible bid to buy the Daily Star and turn it into a sports and showbiz daily, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Waheed Alli is teaming up with TV star and media magnate Chris Evans for a possible joint bid for the Daily Star.

It has emerged that Lord Alli has talked to Mr Evans about a creating a consortium to bid for the paper, which is thought to include Matthew Freud, boss of PR company Freud Communications.

Lord Alli, who is leaving his job as managing director of Carlton Productions, has been approached by a venture capital firm about launching a bid for the paper, which would be transformed into a sports and showbusiness daily.

A source close to Mr Evans admitted that the pair have reopened talks about creating a "special interest, entertainment tabloid".

"If Waheed wanted to formalise this bid," the source added, "you would see a group of eclectic people working together on this to create a special interest magazine along the lines of the football titles we've seen more of recently."

Both Mr Evans and Lord Alli want to radically overhaul the paper, taking it away from its dated working class tabloid format but retaining the elements that have kept it selling over 500,000 copies a day.

Mr Evans, who has often said that he would be interested in buying the Star, approached Lord Hollick early in 1999 with a proposal to swap stock in his compan,y Ginger Media Group.

But the deal fell through after Apax Partners, part-shareholders in Ginger Media and Mr Evans' venture capital backers, backed away from the deal.

Any bid for the Daily Star would hinge on the sale of the Express newspaper group.

Formal bids have been launched by Daily Mail & General Trust and the HindujabBrothers, although Daily Telegraph-owner Hollinger and former Mirror Group chief executive David Montgomery have also expressed an interest.

The Hinduja brothers in particular are keen to offload the Star, which is at odds with their Hindu religious views.

A spokesman for the Hindujas said: "It's an interesting idea," but added that the brothers were focused on buying the Express first.

It is thought that any consortium including Lord Alli and Mr Evans would not launch a formal bid until after the sale of the Express Newspapers has been resolved. But they are understood to have had discussions with Apax Partners about securing finance.

webTitle: Russia may send new crew to Mir in January

fields.headline: Russia may send new crew to Mir in January
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Russia may send a new crew to the Mir space station on January 18, but the government hasn't decided how much longer to keep the 14-year-old outpost in orbit.
fields.body:
Russia may send a new crew to the Mir space station on January 18, but the government hasn't decided how much longer to keep the 14-year-old outpost in orbit.

Four Russian cosmonauts - a two-man main crew and two-man backup team - and one American potential "space tourist" are preparing for the flight at the cosmonauts' training center outside Moscow, said the center's chief, Colonel General Pyotr Klimuk, according to the ITAR-Tass news agency.

The American, businessman Dennis Tito from Santa Monica, California, is hoping to travel to the station for $20 million.

The Mir has been flying unmanned since its last crew left this summer. The Russian government earmarked $27 million last month for two supply rockets to deliver fuel to the Mir, but remained uncertain about whether to send another crew. A decision about the Mir's fate was put off until February.

But without that decision, it remained unclear what the next Mir crew would do if it goes up in January. They may help lower the Mir's orbit if the government decides to abandon the space station, Klimuk said. Otherwise, the cosmonauts will conduct science experiments, he said. The private Netherlands-based MirCorp has leased time on Mir and wants to use the station for commercial purposes, such as trips for tourists like Tito.

MirCorp has been trying to persuade the government not to abandon Mir, but Russian space officials seem to have grown skeptical that MirCorp can follow through with its plans.

The United States has pressured Russia to dump the Mir and concentrate its scarce resources on the new International Space Station, a 16-nation project led by the United States.

The first permanent crew of the ISS - mission commander William Shepherd, a Nasa astronaut, and Russian cosmonauts Yuri Gidzenko and Sergei Krikalev - have been living on the station for two weeks, installing and reactivating equipment, setting up communication systems and conducting experiments.

Russia plans to launch a cargo ship on Novomber 16 from the Baikonur cosmodrome in Kazakhstan to deliver fuel and food to the international station, ITAR-Tass reported.

webTitle: Celebrities add glitter to housing list

fields.headline: Celebrities add glitter to housing list
fields.standfirst: The list of powerful people in housing contains a healthy number of women, civil servants and even a few celebrities
fields.trailText: The list of powerful people in housing contains a healthy number of women, civil servants and even a few celebrities.
fields.body:
Power in housing is overwhelmingly concentrated in Whitehall, making it one of the most centralised areas of the public sector. Along with Treasury special adviser Ed Balls (whose position is normally reserved for a senior mandarin), there are five civil servants in the housing power list.

The most powerful person in the sector, Lady Dean, chairwoman of the Housing Corporation, is appointed by the secretary of state for the environment whose department sponsors the non-departmental public body.

But power and influence does not always respect hierarchy in Whitehall. Thus the sector's second most powerful individual is Michael Gahagan (whose influence stems from his knowledge and control of policy detail), ahead of Genie Turton, his boss at the DETR, whose decision making power is more formal. Power is relative. If Gahagan's influence (and Turton's) is limited, it is by what our panel perceives as a lack of DETR influence in the Treasury.

Ed Balls, the panel felt, is the key man, with immense potential to affect housing policy. Balls' colleague Nicholas McPherson, the Treasury's director for welfare reform, agrees that his influence on housing benefit policy will have far reaching effects on the housing sector.

The list also reflects - in perhaps a more direct and dramatic way on housing than on other sectors - the vast, impersonal power of the economy; hence the presence of Eddie George, governor of the Bank of England, which controls interest rates, the driver behind almost all housing development. The list is not all Whitehall functionaries; the presence of architect and Urban Task Force chairman Lord Rodgers and London mayor Ken Livingstone adds a splash of celebrity missing from our other lists.

Women have a significant presence on the housing list (four in total, including three in the top eight) and there is hardly a sign of gender equality in the sector as a whole. It compares well with our NHS list, where men dominate.

Cutting off the power list at number 15 is an arbitrary decision. Some of the influential names that just missed the cut are Steve Wilcox, University of York housing finance expert; John Perry, director of policy at the Chartered Institute of Housing; and London School of Economics professor of social policy Anne Power. Matthew Taylor, director of the Institute for Public Policy Research, and sponsor of a recent inquiry into social housing, just failed to make the list. But his influence across housing - and public sector policy as a whole - is set to increase, especially if Labour wins a second term.

Feedback: what do you think of the Power 90 panel's choices? Please send your comments to editor@societytheguardian.com

webTitle: The 15 most powerful people in local government

fields.headline: The 15 most powerful people in local government
fields.trailText:
1. Brian Briscoe
Chief executive, Local Government Association
LGAnet
Head of the LGA since its inception in 1997, he can take much of the credit for forging disparate council associations into a cohesive and effective whole that speaks for local government and commands the ear of ministers. Under Briscoe's administrative leadership, the organisation has become an impressive political machine, writing policy as well as influencing it.
fields.body:
1. Brian Briscoe
Chief executive, Local Government Association
LGAnet
Head of the LGA since its inception in 1997, he can take much of the credit for forging disparate council associations into a cohesive and effective whole that speaks for local government and commands the ear of ministers. Under Briscoe's administrative leadership, the organisation has become an impressive political machine, writing policy as well as influencing it.

Despite some criticism of its reluctance to publicly spar with the government, the association has scored notable successes, coming up with the concept of local public service agreements and seeing off attempts to bypass councils in school funding.

Briscoe has had to work hard to keep the association's party groups on board, but it is a job for which the former chief executive of a Conservative-led Hertfordshire county council is well qualified.

His ability to work across the party spectrum is vital, as his power stems from his elected masters, and the association's successes have been built on his partnership with LGA chairman Sir Jeremy Beecham.

Despite this, Briscoe's role as a broker between councillors, ministers and the civil service has cemented his position as local government's fixer-in-chief. A recent contract renewal means he is likely to remain at the top of lists like these for some time.

2. Sir Jeremy Beecham
Chairman, Local Government Association
LGAnet
Far and away the country's leading local politician, has successfully walked a fine line between influencing and infuriating his Labour colleagues, acting as both critical friend to the government and party insider through his membership of Labour's national executive committee. Slick political performance combined with a readiness to attack ministers when necessary means he commands respect across the political spectrum. Like Brian Briscoe, has led the LGA since its creation, and shares the credit for turning it into an effective political machine. Led Newcastle city council for 17 years and chaired the Association of Metropolitan Authorities before it entered the LGA.

3. Dr Wendy Thomson
Head of inspection, Audit Commission
The Audit Commission
As the human face of the government's "best value" continuous improvement programme for local government through her role in checking whether councils are adhering to its regime, she is able to command the respect of apprehensive local authorities and is regarded as essential to the regime's success. Ministers pressured her to stay on at the commission instead of running for chief executive of the Greater London Authority. The former London Borough of Newham chief executive is hotly tipped to succeed Andrew Foster as the commission's controller.

4. Mel Usher
Executive director, Improvement and Development Agency
IDeA Online
Is leading the fight to improve council service standards. Despite launching only last year, the IDeA has rapidly established itself as one of local government's most dynamic and successful institutions, and is becoming increasingly entrepreneurial.

5. John Stewart
Professor of local government and administration, Institute for Local Government Studies
INLOGOV
While other local government academics analyse the political agenda, he sets it. May not always be in favour with ministers, but leading edge work means his influence stretches far beyond Whitehall. Has probably helped form the world views of most people on this list.

6. Oonagh Aitken
Chief executive, Convention of Scottish Local Authorities
COSLA
One of the key links in the enviably close relationship between Scottish local and central government. This former teacher has an impressive local government track record, including a spell as assistant chief executive of Glasgow council and work in education, social services, housing and Europe.

7. Lord Filkin
Non-executive director of the New Local Government Network and chair of the beacon council advisory panel
New Local Government Network
Said to be Tony Blair's favourite local government adviser, has influenced the modernisation agenda through insider relationships with ministers and his position as one of the chief ideolgues of the New Local Government Network think tank.

8. Ken Livingstone
Mayor of London
London.gov.uk
Has power to affect the future of the capital and its councils, including direct ability to intervene in London planning and transport. His huge personal mandate means he is also in a position to bully local authorities and central government into getting things done.

9. Sir Robin Wales
Leader, London Borough of Newham
London Borough of Newham
As chairman of the Association of London Government, he speaks with a national voice, and his developing relationship with mayor Ken Livingstone is being watched carefully by authorities across the capital. A relatively young member of the local government aristocracy, his reputation is largely based on the improvements he and Wendy Thomson achieved in Newham.

10. Albert Bore
Leader, Birmingham City Council
Birmingham Assist
In five years' time, will probably be seen as the man who led a mayoral revolution in England and Wales. By steering his divided authority into a referendum on direct elections for the job of mayor, is already putting pressure on other large urban councils to follow suit. Likely to stand in any mayoral election that follows and could provide a role model for aspiring Labour city bosses.

11. Andrew Foster
Controller, Audit Commission
The Audit Commission
Power extends across the public sector. Influence on local government may have been eclipsed by the rise of Wendy Thomson, who many believe is destined to replace him at the top of the commission. Until she does, Foster still calls many of the shots that matter.

12. Gerry Stoker
Chair, New Local Government Network
New Local Government Network
Seen as a controversialist by some, but the government has taken the University of Manchester academic to its heart, and he has played an important role in the modernisation drive.

13. David Henshaw
Chief executive, Liverpool City Council
Liverpool City Council
As president of the Society of Local Authority Chief Executives, he must steer council bosses through a difficult period of political change, redefining the role of senior officers in relation to newly powerful politicians. Is launching a regeneration package in Liverpool to revive a city in the doldrums since the Militant era.

14. Sandy Bruce-Lockhart
Leader, Kent County Council
Kent County Council
Probably the most powerful Conservative in the country. Forward-looking attitude and strongly held opinions have won him a national profile that some of his party's front benchers will envy. Tipped as a future chairman of the Local Government Association.

15. Denise Platt
Chief inspector, Social Services Inspectorate
Social Services Inspectorate
In a key position to influence the future of one of local government's highest spending and most threatened services. Has taken a tough line on council deficiencies, but welcomed recent news of improvements.

Feedback: do you agree with the Power 90 panel's choices? Please send your comments to editor@societytheguardian.com

fields.headline: Women dominate social care list
fields.standfirst: The strongest contributors to social care are also the most influential - a mainly female group with a commitment to quality
fields.trailText: The strongest contributors to social care are also the most influential - a mainly female group with a commitment to quality.
fields.body:
Social care is a diverse world, delivered by charities, by democratically accountable social services and, increasingly, the private sector. Finding a consensus on where power lies is not easy.

There is no clear cut hierarchy or route to influencing government policy - different people and networks of influence prevail at different times.

Our list features a number of people whose power stems from their important contributions to social work and influence on their peers and practice. Visible in the list, however, is a very modern power presence - regulators. Quality is a key issue, reflecting the government's present priorities. And the regulatory bodies are the politicians' main weapon in realising those priorities.

Judging by the number cropping up - including in the number one slot, Denise Platt, the inspector of social services - senior figures in the regulatory bodies are in a powerful position in social care.

The list has the highest proportion of women of all our sectors, reflecting the female-dominated nature of social care. It is evidence that there are some impressive women rising through the ranks. But the lack of ethnic diversity is stark.

Among those who did not make the list, but whose power is felt in social care, are David Milliband, heading up No 10's policy unit; Simon Stevens, policy adviser to health secretary Alan Milburn; Matthew Taylor, director of the New-Labour-friendly Institute for Public Policy Research; and Ed Balls, adviser to Chancellor Gordon Brown. Apart from his powerful role holding the public purse strings, Brown is chairing the Cabinet committee that oversees the new cross-departmental children and young people's unit, which aims to have a big effect on the lives of the most deprived five to 13-year-olds.

Senior figures in health such as Nigel Crisp, the NHS Executive and Department of Health permanent secretary, and NHS Confederation chief executive Stephen Thornton could also have warranted a mention. Another omission, again because she's new to the role, is Association of Directors of Social Services president Moira Gibb. But others have already been impressed by her "sharp intelligence".

Feedback: what do you think of the Power 90 panel's choices? Please send your comments to editor@societytheguardian.com

Judging by the number cropping up - including in the number one slot, Denise Platt, the inspector of social services - senior figures in the regulatory bodies are in a powerful position in social care. The list has the highest proportion of women of all our sectors, reflecting the female-dominated nature of social care. It is evidence that there are some impressive women rising through the ranks. But the lack of ethnic diversity is stark. Among those who did not make the list, but whose power is felt in social care, are David Milliband, heading up No 10's policy unit; Simon Stevens, policy adviser to health secretary Alan Milburn; Matthew Taylor, director of the New-Labour-friendly Institute for Public Policy Research; and Ed Balls, adviser to Chancellor Gordon Brown. Apart from his powerful role holding the public purse strings, Brown is chairing the Cabinet committee that oversees the new cross-departmental children and young people's unit, which aims to have a big effect on the lives of the most deprived five to 13-year-olds. Senior figures in health such as Nigel Crisp, the NHS Executive and Department of Health permanent secretary, and NHS Confederation chief executive Stephen Thornton could also have warranted a mention. Another omission, again because she's new to the role, is Association of Directors of Social Services president Moira Gibb. But others have already been impressed by her "sharp intelligence". webTitle: Salad Cream saviour named new marketer of the year

fields.headline: Salad Cream saviour named new marketer of the year
fields.standfirst: Useful link: Salad Cream.com
fields.trailText:
12.15pm: The woman who saved Heinz Salad Cream from the axe was today named new marketer of the year.
Useful link: Salad Cream.com
fields.body:
The woman who saved Heinz Salad Cream from the axe was today named new marketer of the year.

Clodagh Ward, general manager of European condiments for Heinz, is seen as the year's most outstanding rising star by the Marketing Society.

She rescued the brand from near oblivion in March after the food giant threatened to ditch the brand in the face of seemingly insurmountable competition from rivals.

Salad Cream used to be one of Britain's best-sellers and a staple of every household. But in 1992, it began to slip in popularity and was overtaken by Hellman's mayonnaise.

Ms Ward increased the price from 59p to 99p to fund a £10m marketing programme and to counter the impression that it was a downmarket product and inferior to mayonnaise.

Ms Ward also launched a website and a major ad campaign with the slogan, "All food tastes supreme with Heinz Salad Cream".

In one memorable ad a young man in a bedroom is seen picking off a piece of old pizza stuck to his sheets. Instead of throwing it out, he adds a dollop of Salad Cream and eats the lot.

webTitle: Prescott pushes air traffic sale to prove his machismo

fields.headline: Prescott pushes air traffic sale to prove his machismo
fields.standfirst: Government plans to sell off air traffic control are unpopular, but, as Julian Glover explains, the issue is about more than political policy
fields.trailText: Government plans to sell off air traffic control are unpopular, but, as Julian Glover explains, the issue is about more than political policy.
fields.body:
In opposition, Labour taunted the Conservatives for their plans to part-privatise the National Air Traffic System (Nats). "Our air is not for sale," said Andrew Smith MP during the 1997 election. It was a popular line.

Strange, then, that in government, Labour ministers - not least the same Andrew Smith MP, now the chief secretary to the treasury - have been falling over themselves to put the Tory plans into practice.

Today, Labour whips will force the House of Commons to vote on the part-privatisation of Nats, in order to overturn an earlier defeat for the policy in the Lords.

The vote will be won, and ministers will salvage the policy just in time to pass it before the general election. But the move could hardly be less popular. Depending on the viewpoint, the government is showing brazen stupidity or rigorous defiance.

The House of Lords is against selling off Nats. Labour left-wingers are against it, the Liberal Democrats and (opportunistically) even the Conservatives are against it.

Equally opposed are Gavin Strang, Labour's first transport minister after 1997, the Nats' staff (despite a sweetener of 5% of the shares in the service) and most pilots.

Even Boeing, the world's biggest plane maker, has expressed its doubts about the scheme.

The EU is no big supporter of the policy either, and neither are Europe's individual governments.

They think the way forward for Europe is a united system, placing British traffic controllers with their German, Spanish, French and other colleagues in one giant darkened bunker, blinking at their screens together in charge of what has been dubbed "the single European sky".

Yet the British government is pressing ahead with what opponents call privatisation and supporters call a public-private partnership (a scheme devised by the Conservatives to funnel private cash into big infrastructure projects). Ministers are certainly determined. The big question is "why?"

The answer lies neither in the merits of the scheme itself nor in the cash that it will raise. The programme should inject around £500m into the system, but that is small change to a Treasury that is awash with billions.

And, as the string of objectors suggests, it is far from clear whether the scheme has other merits at all.

Certainly it raises plenty of questions about safety, especially in the wake of the Hatfield rail crash, which even Railtrack has ascribed partly to the chaos caused by privatisation.

No, the real reason John Prescott is pressing ahead with his plans has much to do with machismo and low politics. The case is almost identical to Prescott's equally unpopular plans to bring private money into London's tube network.

Machismo matters because Mr Prescott is not a man who likes to be defeated. Having said he will sell control of the nation's skies, he intends to do so, whatever the political cost.

And in the weird psychology of new Labour, unpopularity can be a boon as well as a burden: if the old left and the Tories are against something, the reasoning goes, then it is probably the right thing to do.

In this instance, it is almost certainly the wrong thing - but no matter. Much more important is the Treasury's influence. For though the Department of Transport, Environment and the Regions is leading the sell-off, it is only doing Gordon Brown's bidding.

Mr Prescott wants to keep in the chancellor's good books: he did well out of this summer's comprehensive spending review and needs the Treasury's continued support if he is to rescue Britain's collapsing transport system.

But Treasury support is a fickle thing. If the mandarins of Parliament Street sense that the DETR is prone to buckle under heat, they will withdraw it.

The result is that today's vote on the Nats sell-off has little to do with managing the nation's skies. It is a virility test for a transport department that cannot do without Mr Brown's largesse.

The pity is that passengers delayed at airports across Britain may be the ones to endure the consequences.
