webTitle: Sunderland scores high marks in social services review

fields.headline: Sunderland scores high marks in social services review
fields.trailText: Sunderland social services department provides high-quality services for adults and children, according to a joint review report published on November 15.
fields.body:
Sunderland social services department provides high-quality services for adults and children, according to a joint review report published on November 15.

The report by the Social Services Inspectorate (SSI) and the Audit Commission found that 86% of users and carers consider that Sunderland's social services are "good or excellent".

Key strengths included sound financial management and a commitment to consulting local people.

Sunderland city council lies in the fourth poorest health authority area in England and is the twenty-first most disadvantaged local authority, according to the Department of the Environment.

The joint review pointed to good staff morale as another reason for its success. It said staff are committed to improving services and to linking strategy with outcomes. The department demonstrated a focus on improving the quality and range of services such as core children's services and home care for the elderly.

"Sunderland is a prime example of an authority that works hard to improve continually its services," said David Ashcroft, joint reviews assistant reviews director. "The authority has successfully managed change in many aspects of social services over the last six or seven years."

The report described Sunderland's strong support for social services from the Labour-led council and its history of working well with other organisations including the health service. The authority had also made good progress in implementing the mental health national service framework. The review team pointed to some areas for improvement in rehabilitation services for adults and for children in need of protection. However, said Mr Ashcroft, Sunderland was aware of deficiencies and had a good track record in putting them right.

"Sunderland now has the opportunity to make further progress. Cooperation between partner agencies and the authority can ensure that their strategic objectives are translated into services that better meet the needs of local people."

Sunderland social services director John Marsden said: "We are pleased to have this confirmation from the Joint Review that our actions over recent years have resulted in improved services and high levels of user and carer satisfaction and staff morale. Public satisfaction is the most important measure of our achievement and staff morale is central to the effective delivery of social services. "We are not complacent about our achievements and, as the review team, noted we have shown a willingness to change which has been successfully put into practice."

fields.headline: Revolution round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: November 15.
fields.trailText: November 15: Teen website Wowgo ceases trading after Unilever pulls out.
fields.body:
Teen website Wowgo has ceased trading after Unilever pulled out.

News International is doing more e-commerce. It plans to launch Sunshop.co.uk and times-direct.co.uk, which will tie in to the newspaper websites and ailing auction site FiredUp.com.

Yes Television is to spend £500,000 on a global rebrand in time for a soft launch in early 2001.

Online booze retailer Lastorders.com is launching a two-hour delivery service.

Mykindaplace.com is encouraging teenage boys to use its chat rooms by placing ads in titles such as Match and Nintendo.

A bar-based digital ad medium is to be launched by consumer giant Diageo in January, following trials. The screens hang behind bars and show ads for Diageo.

Eventures has lost yet another exec - Carol Weatherall, chief of resourcing. She has gone to a new venture backed by Goldman Sachs, the Boston Consulting Group and General Atlantic Partners.

Ebop managing director Mike Murphy has blamed over-ambition for its current problems. It has laid off staff and is looking for a buyer.

webTitle: Undaunted Tory pretender puts on brave face

fields.headline: Undaunted Tory pretender puts on brave face
fields.standfirst: In the last of a series on next week's byelections we look at the late Audrey Wise's Preston seat
fields.trailText: In the last of a series on next week's byelections we look at the late Audrey Wise's Preston seat.
fields.body:
In 1745, Bonnie Prince Charlie marched through Preston on a campaign which did not have a happy conclusion.

Now the Conservatives have their own young pretender who is looking for a more triumphant outcome: Graham O'Hare is just 27 and has a mission to overturn an 18,500 Labour majority - or at least stay in front of the Lib Dems.

This week he was to be seen clutching a packet of Lemsip as an antidote to flu following a couple of weeks of canvassing in the great British downpour. Preston is not under water; but neither is it a bundle of laughs on a soggy November afternoon when the nights are drawing in faster than a Virgin train.

Labour's man has been dutifully trotting round town on the heels of John Prescott; the Liberal Democrat is sending out lots of leaflets; a couple of Christian candidates are preaching to the reluctant to be converted; an independent Labour candidate is standing up for socialism from his power base inthe Deepdale district; a Green and a BNP man (with the Anti-Nazi League on his tail) make up the names on the ballot paper.

But so far the byelection is sadly lacking in political drama: no meetings, no argument beyond a Tory yanking at a Labour balloon. Yesterday William Hague could have bumped into Jack Straw in the covered market. But he didn't, showing up 10 minutes after the home secretary had left following a flying visit.

Yet Mr O'Hare, who has all the eagerness of the chairman of the debating society at a nice independent school, refuses all temptations to be cynical. "Our job is to challenge Labour, to get as many votes as we can," he says in the Blue Room of the Conservative Club on Blackpool Road. Next door regulars are playing snooker and dominoes in a dense tobacco fug.

"We are not going through this half-heartedly. We are notputting up a token gesture. We are flogging our guts out trying to get the best result we can. We want to win." But Mr O'Hare is candid: "It may be just one of those campaigns that just doesn't ignite."

Perhaps that is because all three main party candidates are local and the hustings have the air of a contest for a precious seat on a parish council.

Mr O'Hare grew up in Preston and now lives in nice Walton-le-Dale; the Lib Dems' Bill Chadwick is leader of his party's group on Preston council and has fought the parliamentary seat twice before; Labour's man Mark Hendrick, was until last year MEP for Lancashire Central, which includes Preston.

There is talk of turmoil in the local Labour party, which lost four seats on Preston council in May and with them overall control. There was a major row following the sudden death of veteran left- winger Audrey Wise, Preston's MP since 1987. Her daughter Valerie wanted to stand but Mr Hendrick, a loyal Blairite, was selected instead.

"I don't think that's going to do me any damage whatsoever," he said yesterday in the drizzle. "The overwhelming majority of members are behind me in the campaign. We have drawn a line under that."

The voters have been talking to him about bread and butter issues - jobs, education, health service and crime. "The main issue for us is the share of the vote and if we can get anywhere near the share that we got at the general election, I'll be ecstatic."

Mr Chadwick lives next door to his campaign office and close to a town centre Tesco, whose imminent closure he is fighting to reverse. If that does not seem an issue likely to promote great oratory, he is quick to explain that it is part of a campaign to breathe new life into the town to enable it to compete for shoppers with Liverpool and Manchester.

He talks of 22 hectares of brownfield sites in the centre, of the population drift from the middle to the edge, of the traffic snarl ups that could be reduced by an integrated public transport system. (At present the bus and rail stations are about as unintegrated as they can possibly get).

On the stump, he has picked up concerns about cancelled operations and long waits in accident and emergency departments. But not much about fuel protests. Like Mr O'Hare, he is worried about nuisance crime and wants to see more police patrols and a better distribution of CCTV cameras. "I'm confident," he said. "We are chasing Labour really hard. And the Conservatives are out of the race."

The rain hammers down. But Mr Straw arrives with his soap box, from which he takes on all-comers in his Blackburn constituency every Saturday. The box has a slit in its metal lid which appears to be waiting for fivers for party funds.

After drifting through the market, which sells used shoes, George Formby LPs, and golf bags by the score, Mr Straw, climbed on his box, praised Gordon Brown and his friend Prudence and wondered where the Tories' proposed spending cuts would come from.

David Harris, a self-confessed white van man and engineer who sells collectables on the market after being made redundant, pleaded for a cut in indirect taxes to help people like him. Tax the rich, he cried, but Mr Straw explained that the rich dodge high taxes.

Enter, after a decent pause, Mr Hague, protected by half a dozen banners made from plywood which had been sawn the previous night outside Tory campaign HQ, a Portakabin in the Conservative club car park.

Mr Hague, who perhaps wished to keep his head dry, chose to visit the indoor market. He was ignored by the bacon counter but wished the clementines the best of luck. "Glad you are flying the flag and not those euro symbols," he cried, noticing the union jacks on a fruit and veg stall. He paused at the boiled sweet stall. "What are you going to give Mr Hague to keep him going?" Mr O'Hare ambiguously asked the proprietor.

The Conservative leader left without his aniseed candy but with the promised vote of stallholder Swarn Singh.

"I voted Labour at the general election but I will be voting Tory this time," he said. "The way Labour are going at the moment, they are not doing enough for people. Maybe it's time for a change again."

1997 general election result

Audrey Wise (below) Lab 29,220

Paul Gray C 10,540

Bill Chadwick LD 7,045

Lab majority 18,680

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's transfer gossip, clean-shaven and ready for work
fields.trailText: Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink will be a winter transfer target for Barcelona. According to reports in the Spanish press, coach Llorenc Serra Ferrer would like to partner Hasselbaink with Patrick Kluivert (the pair are expected to play together in Holland's friendly against Spain this week). But Hasselbaink told Marca this morning: "Barcelona is a phenomenal club. But I cannot say anything at this moment because it is not a possibility, since I do not think about leaving Chelsea."
fields.body:
Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink will be a winter transfer target for Barcelona. According to reports in the Spanish press, coach Llorenc Serra Ferrer would like to partner Hasselbaink with Patrick Kluivert (the pair are expected to play together in Holland's friendly against Spain this week). But Hasselbaink told Marca this morning: "Barcelona is a phenomenal club. But I cannot say anything at this moment because it is not a possibility, since I do not think about leaving Chelsea."

Arsene Wenger wants Coventry's Magnus Hedman as the long-term successor to David Seaman, claims the Mirror. Arsenal are ready to offer the Sky Blues £5m for their Swedish international goalkeeper. Planet Football suggests that the Gunners have also made an enquiry after Juventus striker Darko Kovacevic.

The Daily Express believes that Everton's Ghanaian midfielder Alex Nyarko will soon be leaving Goodison Park. The £4.5m summer signing from Lens has, according to the paper, failed to impress manager Walter Smith and will probably return to France when the European transfer window opens next month.

Winston Bogarde is unsettled at Chelsea, only two months after joining the club. "It's hard for me to sit continually on the bench," he admitted on his icons.com website. "I'm used to playing in every game for my previous clubs."

Jim Smith has put three of his Derby squad up for sale, according to the Sun. Deon Burton, Dean Sturridge and Lars Bohinen are all up for grabs as Smith looks to strengthen his squad by "wheeling and dealing".

Leeds's Norwegian triallists, Thorstein Helstad and Azar Karadas, have returned home after their club Brann Bergen refused to let them turn out in a reserve match for the club. Brann director Arme Moeller said: "The risk of them getting injured was too great."

fields.headline: 'Let the ballots do the talking'
fields.standfirst:
The American press are, with a few exceptions, treating the current presidential election crisis with reasoned calm, reports Derek Brown
Special report: US election
fields.trailText: Press review: The American newspapers are, with a few exceptions, treating the current presidential election crisis with reasoned calm, reports Derek Brown
fields.body:
Attention is still firmly focused on the see-saw state of Florida, but there are intriguing signals of post-electoral tension in other states, which could have a dramatic effect on the final outcome.

The Albany Times Union in upstate New York, for example, gives prominence to an Associated Press report of a remarkable turn-round in New Mexico (which commands five votes in the electoral college): "Democrat Al Gore regained the lead in New Mexico after picking up 500 votes today in Dona Ana County, where officials had misread an absentee total. Gore now leads Republican George W Bush by 374 votes, though New Mexico's five electoral votes are not enough to give either candidate the presidency. Gore moved ahead after a seesaw week in which his Election Night lead of 6,000-plus votes dwindled in the following days, giving Bush a narrow advantage. The latest change in Dona Ana County gave Gore 286,389 statewide to 286,015 for Republican George W Bush."

Many commentators have noted the remarkable patience with which most American voters are treating the recount imbroglio. The Atlanta Journal, in its leader column, has a crisp explanation: "The core of American democracy lies where it has always been - in the ballots that are cast by its citizens. So count the ballots. Count every legal vote that was cast in Florida, and count them by hand if necessary. Count them in Democratic areas; count them in Republican areas. And don't stop until you're finished. The candidate with the most votes then becomes our next president, fair and square. Amid all the legal wrangling and talk-show rhetoric, we're in danger of forgetting how utterly simple and definitive a resolution of this mess can be: Just count the votes. Let the ballots do the talking, because within those ballots resides the wisdom of the people."

The Detroit Free Press expands on the theme: "The key to a Bush presidency - or a Gore presidency if it comes to that - will be the credibility of the Florida vote, which seems certain to settle the election. Neither man would ever be able to claim anything like a mandate, but a credible victory in the deciding state is more valid than a favorable court decision."

The Houston Chronicle is in defensive mode, with an editorial on the foreigners who are "snickering" about US democracy. Americans, says the paper, are also laughing at themselves - and can afford to: "Mainly, though, Americans are going about their normal routine, calmly monitoring the progress of vote-counting and other developments. No violence, no coup attempts, no civil war. Most believe this situation eventually will be resolved to widespread satisfaction, even if about 50 percent of the voting public would have preferred the other candidate had won. That's why Americans in the end will laugh last."

The stridently tabloid New York Post has no doubt that its man, George W Bush, is heading for the White House. "Dubya closer to victory" yells its main headline, while its leader column rubbishes Al Gore's rearguard legal action: "The battle for Florida continued unabated yesterday, growing ever more confused except in one critical respect: Al Gore made it quite clear that he won't quit until he has robbed the American presidency of what little dignity it retained after eight years in the hands of Bill Clinton."

The Miami Herald, at the heart of the Florida recount action, deplores the legal wrangling which has eclipsed the democratic process: "As winter approached we in Florida expected a gaggle of geese. Instead, this dispute has brought a gaggle of lawyers. But this election does not belong to them or to the candidates; it belongs to the people. To engage lawyers to press endless esoteric arguments in this process would inordinately complicate rather than clarify a confused situation."

Even closer to the electoral epicentre, the Palm Beach Post reports that [Democratic] county officials are set to defy [Republican] State instructions, by proceeding with a manual recount of ballots, which just could decide the presidency. One local official says she is ready to go to jail if necessary. But the recount has been delayed by the intensely political bickering among Florida high officials: "Palm Beach County had made elaborate plans and mustered shifts of workers to begin the recount Tuesday. But the board held off because the state Division of Elections, under Republican Secretary of State Katherine Harris, claimed that the county had no authority to hand count all the ballots unless flaws were found in voting machines. Later Tuesday morning, the Attorney General's Office, under Democrat Bob Butterworth, said it could."

fields.headline: Marketing round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: November 16.
fields.trailText: November 16: Budweiser, Pepsi and Carling in Premier League sponsorship battle.
fields.body:
Budweiser and Pepsi are set to do battle with Bass lager brand Carling for the £60m sponsorship of the FA Premier League.

Vizzavi, the portal co-owned by Vodafone and French media giant Vivendi, is looking for its first international ad agency.

Nestle Rowntree has halted the supply of a limited edition Aero bar which declares, "Stuff Xmas! Treat Yourself" on the packaging, after the Church of England complained it was potentially offensive.

Clodagh Ward, Heinz's general manager of European condiments, has won this year's Marketing Society New Marketeer of the Year award for her role in turning around the Heinz Salad Cream brand.

World Online, the ISP, has handed Outside the Box its UK ad business, believed to be worth in excess of £12m.

Supermodel Caprice gives her first naked TV appearance in a series of new ads for Debenhams.

Sholto-Douglas-Home, the Millennium Dome's marketing director, has said the £10m marketing budget was not enough.

The Daily Mail has refused to run three of Queercompany's four new press ads, describing them as too controversial. Taglines include "If you think telling your parents that you're queer is hard, try telling your daughter" and "No white wedding. Sorry mum" next to two women holding hands.

Coca-Cola has split its £30m media business between Universal McCann and BBJ.

Go Racing, the consortium bidding for the UK horseracing media rights, has upped the stakes in the contest by pledging to spend £70m on marketing the sport.

webTitle: Xilerate picks up stake in clubbers website

fields.headline: Xilerate picks up stake in clubbers' website
fields.trailText: 11am: United News & Media's new media division, Xilerate, has taken a 46.5% stake in clubbers' website Spaced, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
United News & Media's new media division Xilerate has taken a 46.5% stake in a clubbers' website called Spaced.

The undisclosed cash injection will allow Spaced to expand site resources and move into new markets, namely the US, Europe, Australia and South Africa.

Spaced is expected to develop a number of tie-ins and promotions with complementary Xilerate websites including dotmusic and Rapture.co.uk.

United boss Lord Hollick laid down plans earlier this year to spend £370m on beefing up new media within the group and set up Xilerate as an umbrella brand for all digital activity.

The strategy follows United's decision to sell off the Express newspaper group and its ITV interests to concentrate on other media business. It has renamed the remaining parts of the group United Business Media.

The internet division's portfolio comprises more than 40 web properties, including LineOne, dotmusic, uTravel.co.uk, Megastar, allaboutparents.com and daltons.co.uk.

Spaced launched in June 1999 and has installed more than 30 web-enabled kiosks in nightclubs in the UK and Ibiza.

Spaced.co.uk offers an online photo gallery, lifestyle magazine, club listings, chatroom and Virtual DJ section.

Future plans for the site include broadband 'Spacedpods' where clubbers can communicate with each other via the kiosks.

fields.headline: Redknapp warns di Canio
fields.standfirst: What Paolo said
fields.trailText: Paolo di Canio's future at West Ham United is up in the air this morning after he was severely criticised by Harry Redknapp for attacking his team and training methods.
fields.body:
Paolo di Canio's future at West Ham United is up in the air this morning after he was severely criticised by Harry Redknapp for attacking his team and training methods.

Redknapp has warned di Canio that "enough is enough" after the fiery Italian striker yesterday claimed that Rio Ferdinand was not good enough to play for England.

Di Canio has already been involved in controversy this season when a serialisation of his autobiography including claims that Nigel Winterburn was a "coward," Joe Cole was not ready for international football and West Ham do not train hard enough.

On each occasion Redknapp has kept quiet, but last night he finally snapped. "I know Rio has been sickened by this," he said. "Enough is enough, and I can't allow this to go on."

"I have a terrific bunch of lads with a wonderful team spirit and will not stand by and watch somebody wreck it," he warned. "I don't care who he is or how much talent he has. Paolo cannot get away with this time and again."

"Paolo can try apologising but maybe it's too late and he's got an awful lot of people to say sorry to. There's no way that I will let one player spoil what I've got in the dressing room."

But Redknapp appeared to rule out selling Di Canio, although he warned him he would "take action."

"I'm so angry - it's just not on. I don't want to sell Paolo; that's the last thing I want because he's such a great player," he said. "But there comes a time when you have to do something about it and take action.

"We've got some very straight talking to do. Paolo is upsetting people right, left and centre and he should not be surprised if no one wants to talk to him."

webTitle: PM faces revolt over air traffic control sell-off plan

fields.headline: PM faces revolt over air traffic control sell-off plan
fields.trailText: The prime minister, Tony Blair, was today facing one of the biggest backbench rebellions of his premiership, amid anger over government proposals to partly privatise the national air traffic control system.
fields.body:
The prime minister, Tony Blair, was today facing one of the biggest backbench rebellions of his premiership, amid anger over government proposals to partly privatise the national air traffic control system.

Dozens of Labour MPs, who are worried about safety under the new system, are expected to vote against the government when the Commons considers a Lords amendment designed to keep it in wholly public hands.

In July, 47 Labour MPs broke ranks to vote against the government's proposals, which it has insisted would leave safety as the paramount issue. A further two dozen MPs pointedly abstained.

Unions representing air traffic controllers and airline pilots were today due to lobby Parliament to urge MPs not to allow the plan to go through.

And Martin Salter, MP for Reading West, who has led the revolt, said that he would again be calling for fellow backbenchers to vote against the government.

He said: "After the Hatfield and Paddington rail disasters, opinion seems to be hardening against these ill-thought-out privatisation proposals.

"Recent opinion polls now show 76% of the public against only 14% in favour, making the air sell-off even more unpopular than fox-hunting.

"It's difficult to find even the most serial loyalist to approve of the plans, and I'm calling on the government to listen to its own supporters, not only on the backbenches but out in the country to pull back now before it is too late."

Fellow Labour backbencher Gordon Prentice, MP for Pendle, said: "The Nats proposals were not in Labour's manifesto and there is no compelling financial reason why we need to do this.

"The air traffic controllers don't want it and neither do the pilots. No country has privatised its air traffic control - not even the US. I want to see air traffic control remain firmly in public ownership."

The Tory transport spokesman, Bernard Jenkin, said that Labour backbenchers had little reason to support the government's proposals. He said: "Labour had no commitment in their manifesto to privatise Nats. On the contrary, they said 'our air is not for sale'."

Most Labour MPs felt profoundly that "this botched privatisation is wrong", and the deputy prime minister John Prescott's handling of Railtrack did nothing to inspire confidence, Mr Jenkin added.

The government plans to create a new company owning 46% of the shares in the National Air Traffic Service, with 5% of shares going to employees, while retaining 49% itself. Ministers will also retain a so-called "golden share", meaning a complete sell-off in the future could not go ahead without its approval.

The Civil Aviation Authority would be the safety regulator for the Nats. Despite threats of a rebellion, the legislation is expected to pass comfortably through the Commons.

webTitle: Cable & Wireless boosts profits after strategic turnaround

fields.headline: Cable & Wireless profits jump after strategic turnaround
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Cable & Wireless has raised profits following its decision to concentrate on business internet services, writes Dan MIlmo.
fields.body:
Cable & Wireless has reaped the benefits from a strategic turnaround, after its concentration on business internet services produced a 33% rise in profits.

The UK-based communications company has changed its focus from the consumer to the business market by selling off a number of subsidiaries and concentrating on setting up a global internet network.

Cable & Wireless said its first-half results confirmed that the gamble was paying off, with pre-tax profits of £4.6bn, a rise of 33%.

The group's turnover from its remaining businesses came in at £3.43bn, up 15%.

However, the figures include the £4.2bn raised from the sale of its Hong Kong operations and the disposal of the Cable & Wireless Communications cable business, which was sold to UK cable operator NTL.

After taking out the benefit of the disposals, the group's profits exceeded analysts' expectations at £537m.

Graham Wallace, Cable & Wireless chief executive, said: "In the last six months we have put in place key components towards achieving our strategic objective - to be the leading global provider of internet protocol solutions to business customers."

The company is going full speed ahead with its network programme, signing deals with technology giants such as Microsoft, Nokia and Baltimore to build its internet backbone.

A key revenue earner for Cable & Wireless will be its 'voice over the internet' programme, which will operate around the world in three years' time.

The service will combine voice, internet and data over a single network and could hit the business operations of other telecoms companies.

Canadian telecoms group Nortel will build the company's voice and internet network in the US and Europe.

webTitle: Legislation blocks possibility of single ITV company

fields.headline: Government blocks single ITV company
fields.trailText: 9.45am: Michael Green and Charles Allen's dream of setting up a single ITV company will be dashed by government legislation. By Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
Michael Green and Charles Allen's dream of setting up a single ITV company will be dashed by government legislation.

According to reports today, the imminent communications white paper will relax current rules barring any one ITV company controlling more than 15% of the total audience share.

This would pave the way for a merger of Granada Media, run by Mr Allen and Carlton, run by Mr Green.

However, the effect of the liberalisation of the rules will be cancelled out by a government decision to retain the law barring one ITV company running two London franchises.

With London's weekend franchise, LWT, controlled by Granada and the weekday licence owned by Carlton, this effectively blocks a single ITV company.

webTitle: MP3.com to pay £37.3m to Universal Music Group

fields.headline: MP3.com agrees to pay £37.3m damages
fields.trailText: 10.15am: Internet music company MP3.com has agreed to pay £37.3m in damages to Universal Music Group, writes Amy Vickers .
fields.body:
Internet music company MP3.com has avoided certain death by agreeing to pay £37.3m in damages to Universal Music Group - almost £136m less than was originally mooted.

The settlement resolves a copyright infringement case that could have crippled MP3.com, which still allows users to download music tracks free of charge.

As part of the settlement, Universal has agreed to license its entire music catalogue, which includes U2, Jimi Hendrix and Eminem, to My.MP3.com, its web-based jukebox type service.

MP3.com has already settled out of court with four of the five largest global record companies - Warner Music Group, Sony Music Entertainment, EMI Group and Bertelsmann's BMG music arm.

MP3.com will now be able to develop its My.MP3.com service. It will be able to pay the fine from a war chest of £118m it had set aside to cover fines and legal bills.

The service is expected soon to start charging users for downloading music.

The judgement represents the second major breakthrough in the relationship between the traditional record business and internet companies.

Only last month, BMG dropped a copyright infringement suit against Napster in return for the music download site implementing a fee-based service that pays royalties.

webTitle: Social change from the newspaper age to the dot.com age

fields.headline: From the newspaper age to the dot.com age
fields.standfirst:
Twenty-one years ago, he
                                                        launched the Guardian's Society
                                                        section. Today, Malcolm Dean writes
                                                        about social change in the interim
fields.trailText: Twenty-one years ago, he launched the Guardian's Society section. Today, Malcolm Dean writes about social change in the interim
fields.body:
A new launch is a time to look forward. A 21st anniversary is a time to look back. Today is a double celebration: the 21st anniversary of the Guardian's Society section and the launch of the website SocietyGuardian.co.uk

A brief look back first. I launched the Society column in 1979 with a prediction that for the first time since the founding of the welfare state, it was no longer possible to predict that society was going to get better. Margaret Thatcher was in Downing Street and three separate spending squeezes were being planned.

Society, as a whole, did get better. Average household spending has gone up by more than half. Spending on travel and communication has more than doubled while spending on recreation, entertainment and education almost trebled.

Yet, as I note in today's printed Society section, the prediction was accurate for the poor. The number of children living in poverty tripled. No other developed state except New Zealand has experienced such a brutal reversal. When Labour came to power in 1997, one in three children were living in poverty (in households with below half average income).

In the run-up to the last election, Tony Blair gave his party a crucial test: "If the next Labour government has not raised the living standards of the poorest by the end of its time in office, it will have failed."

It is now clear Labour will meet this target. After the worst of beginnings - sticking to Tory spending limits for two years, implementing the Tories' lone parent benefit cut, squeezing incapacity benefits - the government is now on the road to creating a fairer society.

Labour is on course to lift about 1.2m children and 800,000 adults out of poverty by April 2002. All families will have gained (by almost £850 a year) but poor families will have gained the most (almost £1,500).

Better still, Tony Blair last year set Labour one of the biggest social challenges of the last 50 years: "Our historic aim will be for ours to be the first generation to end child poverty. It is a 20-year mission." Gordon Brown has subsequently set a 10-year target: "Halving child poverty by 2009."

Society readers cover a wide range of services. The hardest hit in the last 21 years has been housing. Public spending has shrunk from 1.5% of gross domestic product (GDP) to 0.4%. It is not quite as grim as this suggests because over 1m council homes have been sold; significant investment in "social" housing is now made by housing associations; and a large contribution to housing comes through a social security stream: housing benefits. Even so, the squeeze remains serious.

Basic housing conditions have improved. Those lacking basic amenities fell from 15% in the 1970s to 1% in 1991. Yet overcrowding increased for the poorest fifth after 1990. Satisfaction with housing conditions grew, but dissatisfaction with neighbourhoods rose.

Education suffered the sharpest rise and falls in spending in this period. The rise and fall of pupil numbers made this picture even more complicated. But compared with health, education has fallen behind in the spending league.

Health has had the healthiest injection of funds. Way back in 1973, it was only receiving 3.8% of GDP. It has now climbed to 6.8% and has been guaranteed a one third real terms increase over the next five years - the largest and most sustained increase since the NHS was set up in 1948.

So what does the future hold? It will be make or break for the NHS. If it fails to provide a more responsive service, Labour has signalled it will look at other alternatives. They are bound to involve more extensive deals with the private sector. But the NHS plan has produced a new sense of optimism. All parts of the service were consulted. All the new ideas, set out in the plan, are already being applied somewhere in the system. They do work.

Science and technology will remain powerful driving forces. About 90% of medicines in the early 1990s were unknown 30 years ago; 50% unknown six years ago. In the next three decades, all patients could have their genes profiled, stored in an NHS database, and used in computer diagnoses of sickness.

Crime is the most difficult trend to predict. It has increased on average by 5% a year since 1918. But in the last six years it has dropped - this is true for recorded crime and the more accurate British crime survey. (Recorded crime is less accurate because only half of all crime is reported, and almost half reported crime is not recorded.) Officials at the Home Office are expecting next January's figures to show a further drop in recorded crime. But how long this will continue no one is prepared to predict.

Part of the fall is clearly due to better prevention methods: more secure cars have drastically reduced the theft of vehicles and theft from them. More secure houses have caused a similar fall in burglaries.

The rise in imprisonment has had relatively little impact: it needs a 26% increase to achieve a 1% fall in crime. Interestingly, the fall in crime is not confined to the UK. It is happening across Europe and in some parts of North America. The big test for Britain is whether the new priority given to violent crime will achieve a similar fall to the drop in property crime achieved by targeting.

The welfare state abandoned the idea of a universal service many years ago. It still holds true in education and health, where private provision accounts for less than 10% of the state service. But in social security, both major parties are expecting the current ratio in pension provision (60% public to 40% private) to be reversed over the next 30 years.

It is going to be particularly tough for younger people in this new world of fixed-term contract working. As the proportion of retired people continues to rise, so will the demand for a later retirement age to cover this cost. Stand by for a more open inter-generational war.

fields.headline: Trouble in store for Oxfam
fields.standfirst: Britain's No1 charity shop is in crisis, with profits down and job losses on the way.  Patrick McCurry reports
fields.trailText: Britain's No1 charity shop is in crisis, with profits down and job losses on the way.
fields.body:
The Oxfam shop is a landmark of the British high street and a steady source of clothing both for the poor and the more eclectic trendsetters. But fierce competition among retailers, and the apparent failure of the charity's retail strategy, has left the shops facing a financial crisis.

Despite subsidised business rates, donated goods and an army of volunteer staff, Britain's most famous charity shop chain is haemorrhaging profits. A radical review of the 850 stores will lead to cost cutting and job losses.

The main reason for plunging profits is higher costs, such as Oxfam's decision to professionalise shop management two years ago by hiring some 500 paid managers to replace volunteers at the busiest outlets. Whether by bad luck or bad planning, this occurred just as the retail sector was toppling into a slump.

Details of the current crisis were passed to Society by Oxfam volunteers, following the recent controversy in the letters columns over the salary on offer (£75,000) for a new director of the charity. Internal documents show that an internal trading review found that, while overall turnover of the shops had remained constant at £60m, profits passed on for aid projects had fallen from £16.5m in 1997-98 to an estimated £7.6m this year and, if no action were taken, a projected £3.7m in 2003-04.

One volunteer wrote telling Society: "Our costs have spiralled out of control, so much so that Oxfam is in the middle of a crisis. They'll be making large numbers of employees redundant and closing offices all over the country." The problems had been developing over the past four years, she said, during which time director David Bryer had received salary increases worth at least £25,000.

Another Oxfam volunteer claimed that Bryer had presided over a culture of rising costs, with the result that less than 20p of every £1 earned in Oxfam shops was going to aid projects. The correspondent wrote: "This is a great charity, to which I have always been deeply attached and worked for as a volunteer for 10 years. I am very distressed to see the growth of bureaucracy and lack of financial control that has gone on now for a number of years."

Oxfam is rejecting any suggestion of lax management. Spokeswoman Alison Woodhead says that, despite the shops' problems, the charity last year increased the overall sums sent overseas to £87m, compared to £70m in each of the two previous years.

Bryer's pay boost was agreed following a review of pay and benefits, which found that Oxfam needed to increase salaries. "Even at £75,000, the director's salary is 40% less than for a similar sized commercial organisation and is in line with that paid at other charities," says Woodhead.

Oxfam blames the shops' troubles on increased competition in retailing, illustrated by the difficulties of commercial chains such as C&A and Marks & Spencer. The total number of charity shops, meanwhile, has doubled in the past decade.

Sarah Shekleton, manager of the trading review, says it is specifically upheaval in the clothing market that has hit profits, as clothing represents half the shops' business. The remainder, mainly trade in books and bric-a-brac, has held up well. Costs have increased, she says, because of higher rents on the high street and because Oxfam invested in new staff and activities shortly before the market downturn.

"For example, we took on people to help open new shops, but then didn't open as many as we'd expected, and we invested in new activities across departments - including extra support for our Fair Trade business," Shekleton says. Profit margins are inevitably affected by the charity's Fair Trade activities, by which it sells new goods made by third world producers. "If we just sold donated goods, the shops would make more."

The charity is not reversing its decision to use paid managers, which have added £3m a year to costs. "We still believe the combination of paid managers and volunteers works best in our busier shops," says Shekleton.

No decision has yet been made on the number of redundancies required to tackle the financial crisis, as consultation is continuing. The job losses are expected to come among middle managers involved in supporting the shops, as the plan is for shop managers to be given more autonomy over how their enterprises are run.

Oxfam aims to get annual shop profits back up to £10m, which would represent a margin of 17% if sales remained static. "I'd say a 20% profit percentage is reasonable," says Shekleton. "In the long run, we want to increase sales - but at the moment the priority is cutting costs."

webTitle: Marketing campaigns impact on consumer habits

fields.headline: Marketing campaigns impact on consumer habits
fields.standfirst: Andy Farquarson looks at the way partnerships between business and charities leave their mark on the consumer
fields.trailText: Andy Farquarson looks at the way partnerships between business and charities leave their mark on the consumer.
fields.body:
Cause related marketing campaigns are having a significant impact on consumer habits and are bringing benefits to both businesses and the charities they link up with, according to new research. This latest study looks for the first time at how people respond to such campaigns - rather than how they think they would.

The key finding is surprisingly high public awareness of campaigns such as Tesco's donation of computers to schools, Avon's support for breast cancer research, or the Andrex puppy appeal in association with the National Canine Defence League. Almost 90% of those surveyed had heard of at least one cause-related programme and almost half could spontaneously name a specific company or brand involved in a campaign. Two in three people believed more businesses should get involved.

Against this, however, a small percentage felt cause related marketing was exploitative, or that it was inappropriate for business to become involved in social issues.

Until now, research into the effectiveness of cause related marketing campaigns has focused on consumers' attitudes, rather than their actions. The new study, Profitable Partnerships, was commissioned by Business in the Community (BITC) and is based on a survey of 2,000 adults by the British Market Research Bureau.

While previous work has established that a majority of people support the concept of cause related marketing, and would probably express that support in their purchasing choices, the fresh research indicates that this broad approval is affecting consumers' choices.

More than 65% of respondents said they had participated in a cause related marketing campaign. Of them, three-quarters had either switched brand, tried out a product or increased their usage; and four in five had felt more positive about certain purchases, more loyal to a company or brand, and more inclined to look out for further cause related campaigns.

Although 30% of respondents were regular internet users, comparatively few had found cause related marketing campaigns on the web. Old media predominated, with awareness of campaigns garnered through in-store promotion (23%), television commercials (18%) and advertisements in print media (11%).

Cause related marketing is defined as any partnership between a business and charity which markets an image, product or service for mutual benefit. "This is not about corporate philanthropy," says Sue Adkins, BITC's director of marketing. "It's about commercial benefit for both cause and company. Any business which tries to project this sort of campaign as strings-free giving is heading for a fall; the public is not gullible."

A good match between partners is also vital, says Adkins. Unless campaigns are properly managed, and based on integrity and transparency, they can be counter-productive.

The new report does not specify what constitutes a "good" campaign. Among a wide variety of factors cited by those surveyed were schemes that supported local community activity, a high level of donation or support for the project or charity and clearly-communicated, unambiguous benefits.

Tesco's "computers for schools" initiative is a good example of such clarity, argues Adkins. It has delivered more than £30m of computer equipment to schools, raised Tesco's profile (more than 40% of adults know about the initiative), and bolstered public perception of the company as a good corporate citizen.

Unsurprisingly, Tim Mason, Tesco's marketing director, welcomes the BITC findings. "Successful marketing is all about meeting customer needs and most consumers expect companies to be socially responsible," he says. "That's what is driving the rapid growth of cause related marketing and I am sure that growth will continue for the foreseeable future."

Marketing departments may formulate corporate strategies, but it is the advertising industry that gets the messages across to consumers. So it is hardly surprising that advertising agencies are establishing specialist teams to provide cause related marketing expertise to their clients.

One of the longest established is Saatchi & Saatchi's "cause connection", set up in 1997 by Marjorie Thompson (who worked both in the public and voluntary sectors before joining Saatchis).

"There are huge opportunities to develop cause related marketing in the UK," says Thompson. "For instance, government could provide much more in the way of match-funding and tax breaks to encourage good corporate citizenship. That would help charities gain long-term funding and exploit the expertise of the communications profession to promote their missions and messages."

 Profitable Partnerships is available at £75, or £50 to registered charities, from BITC, 44 Baker St, London W1M 1DH. Further information at www.bitc.org.uk

fields.headline: Overgrazing has stripped the land
fields.standfirst: A case of sheep in sheep's clothing?
fields.trailText: A case of sheep in sheep's clothing?
fields.body:
As floods reached their highest levels for centuries, newspapers carried pictures of a flock of sheep huddled together in a farmhouse sitting room - yet more victims of the storm.

But amusement and sympathy may be misplaced. Sheep are deeply implicated in the floods that have menaced British cities, from York to Shrewsbury, in the last few weeks.

Ann Sansom, a rural land use officer in the north-east region, argues that we should take more notice of land use when looking at floods. She says: "We've focused on the water, but it's not the river that generates floods. It's the land."

She believes that a huge increase in sheep numbers has stopped the moors functioning as they always did - as giant sponges. In the 1860s, Britain's sheep population was about 8m. During the war, it was about 12m. Today, thanks to EU subsidies, there are more than 40m.

Sansom and other ecologists say that the fragile uplands can't support more than 1.5 sheep per hectare. But some moors have seven and never get the chance to recover because animals remain there all year, trampling in the land and stripping back the vegetation.

With vegetation stripped away and the land puddled, the water pours off the hills ever faster. Doubling a river's speed increases its erosive power fourfold and its power to carry sediment 64 times. As river beds are gouged deeper and deeper, lethal flash floods become common. Meanwhile, topsoil is washed into rivers, killing fish and wildlife, and reservoirs become choked. According to a report four years ago, sedimentation had reduced the capacity of Yorkshire Water's reservoirs by nearly 9,000m litres, or 7.5%. The company put the cost at £74m.

Overstocking of sheep also prevents water soaking into the ground. Research in the Pennines by the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds showed that trampling by cloven feet had sealed the ground. The top three or four inches were soaking but, just below, the soil was dry. With water unable to percolate into the aquifers that are a crucial source of drinking water, they fail to recharge and floods are followed by drought.

Sansom even warns of desertification on uplands stripped of fauna. "Spain is suffering desertification, but it has extreme conditions," she says. "We have a temperate maritime climate, so there is no excuse for things not growing here."

The implications of Sansom's thinking extend beyond Britain's moors and beyond the swollen rivers, such as the Ouse and the Severn, that drain them. "People must understand that if we alter a catchment upstream there'll be inevitable impacts downstream," she says.

fields.bodyText: As floods reached their highest levels for centuries, newspapers carried pictures of a flock of sheep huddled together in a farmhouse sitting room - yet more victims of the storm. But amusement and sympathy may be misplaced. Sheep are deeply implicated in the floods that have menaced British cities, from York to Shrewsbury, in the last few weeks. Ann Sansom, a rural land use officer in the north-east region, argues that we should take more notice of land use when looking at floods. She says: "We've focused on the water, but it's not the river that generates floods. It's the land." She believes that a huge increase in sheep numbers has stopped the moors functioning as they always did - as giant sponges. In the 1860s, Britain's sheep population was about 8m. During the war, it was about 12m. Today, thanks to EU subsidies, there are more than 40m. Sansom and other ecologists say that the fragile uplands can't support more than 1.5 sheep per hectare. But some moors have seven and never get the chance to recover because animals remain there all year, trampling in the land and stripping back the vegetation. With vegetation stripped away and the land puddled, the water pours off the hills ever faster. Doubling a river's speed increases its erosive power fourfold and its power to carry sediment 64 times. As river beds are gouged deeper and deeper, lethal flash floods become common. Meanwhile, topsoil is washed into rivers, killing fish and wildlife, and reservoirs become choked. According to a report four years ago, sedimentation had reduced the capacity of Yorkshire Water's reservoirs by nearly 9,000m litres, or 7.5%. The company put the cost at £74m. Overstocking of sheep also prevents water soaking into the ground. Research in the Pennines by the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds showed that trampling by cloven feet had sealed the ground. The top three or four inches were soaking but, just below, the soil was dry. With water unable to percolate into the aquifers that are a crucial source of drinking water, they fail to recharge and floods are followed by drought. Sansom even warns of desertification on uplands stripped of fauna. "Spain is suffering desertification, but it has extreme conditions," she says. "We have a temperate maritime climate, so there is no excuse for things not growing here." The environment agency can go on spending countless millions on flood defences, but over sheep regimes and new crop practices it remains powerless.

fields.headline: Quiet success
fields.standfirst: Care awards go ahead despite power cut
fields.trailText: Care awards go ahead despite power cut.
fields.body:
In the finest British tradition, the annual awards ceremony for the independent care sector went ahead regardless at the weekend despite a power cut that left the 500 guests without a main meal and the compere without a microphone.

The glitzy event had just got under way at a top London hotel when the neighbourhood was plunged into darkness. After a while, the candle-lit diners were told they would be moving straight from their starter (cured salmon or melon) to desert (chocolate marquise), owing to an inability to cook the planned supreme of chicken and vegetarian alternative.

With power unrestored, and the venue turning chilly, the Care Awards 2000 presentation got under way in what the host, broadcaster Nicholas Parsons, described as the most bizarre circumstances he had encountered. He was issued with a megaphone.

Speeches were cut, films went unshown and music was limited to unamplified drums and saxophone. But the guests entered into the spirit and nevertheless made the evening a success. As Chai Patel, chief executive of Westminster Health Care, commented, many workers in the care sector had recently been dealing, without complaint, with real adversity in the form of floods and transport disruption.

The awards, organised by Caring Times magazine, went to: Leanne Greenwood, of Roche Healthcare (carer); Sandie Oxborrow, of Pri-Med Group (care manager); Salma Chaudri, of Khubsuret House (sheltered housing manager); Nikki Carter, of Hica Specialised Care Homes (home care manager); Anthony Harrison, of Barchester Healthcare (care chef); Harvey Zemmel, of Aegis Residential Care Homes (care marketeer); Caroline Jones, of Westminster Health Care (care innovator); Michael Buckingham, of Care Management Group (care entrepreneur); Sue Hollin, of Tracs (independent care operator); and Barry Hassell, chief executive of the Independent Healthcare Association (care personality).

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText:
Ouse talking?
The House of Commons environment committee will shortly meet to discuss building on flood plains, and one of the key witnesses will be the environment agency which has been quick to condemn new buildings in these vulnerable areas and last year, quite rightly, objected to some 1,000 applications for such developments. They might like to ask the agency whether it objected to its own offices and fisheries' lab near Huntingdon which appears to be right in the path of the Great Ouse. Last year the river lapped at its doors, but this year has kindly called off its objections.
fields.body:
Ouse talking?
The House of Commons environment committee will shortly meet to discuss building on flood plains, and one of the key witnesses will be the environment agency which has been quick to condemn new buildings in these vulnerable areas and last year, quite rightly, objected to some 1,000 applications for such developments. They might like to ask the agency whether it objected to its own offices and fisheries' lab near Huntingdon which appears to be right in the path of the Great Ouse. Last year the river lapped at its doors, but this year has kindly called off its objections.

Bending rules
What is it about Somerset? The cows are taking matters into their own hands and now Mendip council has, after seven years, a judicial review and a public inquiry, given the Kingshill low-impact settlement full planning permission for 16 benders. In January last year, the Tinkers Bubble's collective was awarded a five-year planning consent for a similar settlement and smallholding outside Yeovil.

Field studies
Dorset seems to be catching the Somerset bug. In the first poll of its kind, the LibDems asked more than 2,300 households - that's a big sample - whether GM crops should be allowed to be grown in the county. A massive 72% said 'no', and 12% were undecided. Will the council now formally declare the county a GM-free zone? And if not, why not?

Pull the udder one
Eco soundings' thoughts turn to the National Institute of Agricultural Biotechnology at Brickley in Somerset which has been quietly - no, secretly - testing a GM maize crop called Sheridan. If eventually passed and placed on the national seed list, Sheridan would be fed to cattle. But has anyone asked the cows? Somerset's finest are not waiting for a referendum. The institute has had to write to the Ministry of Agriculture explaining that certain cattle got into the field and, er, trampled down the crop rendering the test useless. So did the protesting cows like their new grub? No question about that. The institute reported that none of the maize was eaten.

Treading water
The environment, transport and regional affairs committee of the Commons is to undertake an inquiry into walking in towns and cities, and is asking for submissions by January. A spokesman says he certainly does not intend to widen the brief, in the light of the recent flood in so many conurbations, to swimming in cities.

Something in the air
Tinsley is a multi-racial district of Sheffield somewhat isolated by motorways and major roads, and plagued by the ever growing volume of traffic on routes to the giant Meadowhall shopping complex, supermarkets and several sports arenas. The 4,000 strong community has set up its own air monitoring system, and - surprise, surprise - has found that the pollution levels in their gardens are regularly 50% worse than government targets. Never mind the noise and disturbance, one ward has the highest under-75 mortality for coronary heart disease in the city and childhood asthma has increased by half in the past 30 years. Now the Tinsley Forum, a vibrant group of several hundred locals concerned that they are effectively being killed by the fumes, has strung huge banners on the major roads warning motorists they are entering a "severe air pollution zone" and politely asking them to use public transport.

The missing years
The Tinsley residents should call in the Department of Health, which has concluded from a recent study that air traffic pollution in London brings forward 380 deaths, which equates to 34,000 years of life, a year - a far larger health impact than road traffic accidents.

Winds jammers
The Council for National Parks tries to protect and enhance national parks of England and Wales and promotes understanding and quiet enjoyment of them for the benefit of all. Fine. But it wins Eco soundings' "small mind of the week award" for strongly objecting to a few wind turbines proposed for a site not in the park, but near one end of it. Why do they object? Because, says their deputy director, in the run-up to the global warming talks in the Hague, the turbines would be visible from a footpath and "would therefore be very damaging". Question 1: Have they asked the views of people walking the Pembrokeshire trail if they think it would damage their enjoyment? Question 2: Would the CNP object to global warming causing a great storm and ripping out all the park's trees or foundering an oil tanker on its beaches?

fields.headline: Still kicking . . .
fields.standfirst: A former editor of Society looks back on 21 years of scandals and campaigns
fields.trailText: Malcolm Dean, former editor of Society, looks back on 21 years of scandals and campaigns.
fields.body:
It was launched 21 years ago, under a Society Tomorrow label, as a social policy column. Margaret Thatcher had moved into Downing Street. Three different squeezes were being applied to spending. At least I got one prediction right. My first column said that, for the first time since the founding of the welfare state, it was no longer possible to predict society tomorrow was going to be better.

For huge numbers of poor people it wasn't. Their numbers increased threefold in the next 20 years, with one in three children - totalling 4.5m - living in poverty when Labour returned in 1997. Many expert social scientists helped expose this scandal in these pages.

Ten years on from the launch, nurse Graham Pink set out a harrowing 3,500-word account of what life was like on a chronically understaffed ward for acutely ill elderly patients. He turned to us only after appealing to every official channel without success. It forced policy-makers to face the shameful conditions on geriatric wards.

But we haven't just concentrated on what was wrong. We have deliberately sought out successful schemes in the hope they would be copied elsewhere. We've promoted the annual Guardian award for outstanding charities. And we've helped launch numerous new projects. Michael Young, alone, has launched the following in these pages: the School for Social Entrepreneurs; the Baby Naming Society for non-religious parents; Language Line, providing interpreters to clients of public services; a national college to raise funeral directors' standards; the first summer university in a deprived urban area; and a bid to turn Robben Island, South Africa, into an open university.

As the space - and the adverts - expanded, we widened our focus. The launch of the pull-out section brought in the environment pages. They were looking at issues - floods, farming, climate change, global warming, GM foods, roads and the first interview with "Swampy" - long before they reached the front page, and helped the Guardian pick up a succession of environmental awards.

Our weekly diary section provided a soapbox for powerless, as well as influential, contributors. They included Big Issue vendors, HIV sufferers, shoplifters, drug addicts, burglars, backdoor abortionists as well as leading charity campaigners. Our feature writers excelled in spotting significant social change: corner shops, seaside towns, Asian footballers and their female supporter clubs, upmarket Irish wine bars.

Then there was the old front page - social change recorded in weekly newspapers which illustrated life in current Britain - now preserved farther back. It was Society that spotlighted the latest fish and chip shop dessert: deep-fried Mars bars. Reader surveys suggested it was one of the best read pages in the paper. It didn't just have its followers but a cult of contributors - one of whom, in Cumbria, raised £500 for his local hospital from the £15 fees.

Harry Venning, with his wicked portrayal of social workers in Clare in the Community, is still in negotiation with broadcasters to turn his cartoon strip into a television soap - social work's first. He received the ultimate accolade from a tough Guardian night editor, with no connections with social work, who told me how much he loved it.

I was proud of our special editions - the manifesto drawn up by 16 different specialists for the newly elected 1997 Labour government, or our 14-page special issue on the 50th anniversary of the NHS. The "terminological inexactitude" column helped spotlight the most offensive public lie of the week.

Editing the section was terrific fun and a great privilege. It is now in the safe hands of David Brindle. Thank you for reading it. Don't forget to follow our new website, SocietyGuardian.co.uk, launched today, with many names familiar to Society readers.

fields.headline: Front to back...
fields.trailText: Edited highlights from the local press.
fields.body:
Package tour An orphaned swallow too young to fly south for the winter from north Wales has been offered a lift to Africa by a courier firm. East Anglian Daily Times, 16.10.00 (John White, Clacton-on-Sea)

Spaced out Satellite pictures from space were used to prove that an 11-year-old boy in Mid-Glamorgan lived nine metres too close to school to qualify for free transport. Birmingham Evening Mail, 20.10.00 (David Spilsbury, Birmingham)

Roar of protest Fans of Hull City are angry that the football club's mascot, Roary the Tiger, has accepted the offer of a transfer to Exeter City, where he will become Alexander the Greek. Yorkshire Post, 25.10.00 (John Rossington, Bradford)

Hot meal The owner of snack bar used by factory workers in Flint, Denbighshire, is offering a free breakfast to the customer who comes up with the most romantic description of their sex life. Mold and Buckley Chronicle, 27.10.00 (L Sylvia, Wrexham)

Krispie crawlies Wildlife experts at a sanctuary in Buckfast, Devon, have found that a colony of leaf-cutter ants has developed a preference for Rice Krispies rather than leaves. Western Morning News, 31.10.00 (Nicola Neale, Sidmouth)

Fetch the dictionary The new owner of a Border collie brought up on the Hebridean island of Barra has had to learn Gaelic because the dog didn't understand commands given in English. Press and Journal, 26.10.00 (Marc Hindley, Nairn)

Woof justice A pet dog alleged to have fouled a public area was brought before magistrates at Bingley, Yorkshire, after its owner claimed it was a victim of mistaken indentity. Telegraph and Argus, 31.10.00 (E Frail, Bradford)

Supporting evidence A pensioner stopped and searched in her car by police in High Peak, Derbyshire, was found to have heroin concealed in her bra. Buxton Advertioser, 25.10.00 (Judy Jackson, High Peak

High drama Firefighters were called to rescue a cow near Taunton, Somerset, after it slipped down a grassy bank and got stuck in a tree. Sunday Independent, 22.10.00 (Hetty Fletcher, Budleigh Salterton)

By gum! Manchester airport has lifted a 10-year ban on chewing gum being sold in its shops after complaints by passengers that they use it to calm their nerves or to stave off the craving for a cigarette. Manchester Metro News, 27.10.00 (Gillian Oakes, Cheadle)

Silent rage A couple who hired an opera singer and a bagpipe player to perform at their wedding ceremony in Cranfield, Bedfordshire, got back their video and discovered that the cameraman had recorded without sound. Bedfordshire on Sunday, 1.10.00 (R Davies, Olney)

Parking offence Westminster council in London has sacked 10 parking wardens for issuing false tickets to get their own back on motorists who abuse them. Local Government First, 28.10.00 (Gilly Sweet, Shoreham-by-Sea)

Healthy colour A vegetable growing company near Sibsey, Lincolnshire, is marketing a red-coloured cauliflower in the hope that it will appeal to youngsters who don't like eating their greens. Shropshire Star, 10.10.00 (Alexander Welsh, Llanidloes)

Lopped out Staff at Mountfitchet Castle, Essex, have had to change the handles on their office doors after a Nubian lop-eared goat learned to open them with its mouth and got in and chewed up all the paperwork. Evening Standard, 11.10.00 (Jules Hurry, London N1)

 Cuttings, preferably from local papers, which reflect interesting or amusing aspects of life in Britain, must be sent on a postcard (with source) to: Society, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. £15 will be paid for each one used.

fields.headline: Fingers on the button
fields.standfirst: Today's launch of SocietyGuardian.co.uk  adds a new dimension to keeping in touch
fields.trailText: Today's launch of SocietyGuardian.co.uk adds a new dimension to keeping in touch.
fields.byline: Marianne Curphey, executive editor of SocietyGuardian.co.uk
fields.body:
Today we launch a new website from the Guardian with a unique combination of jobs, news, analysis, comment and interactive debate for everyone who works in the public sector.

SocietyGuardian.co.uk aims to take the strengths of the weekly print publication, Society Guardian, and build them into a daily, web-based service to make use of the enormous opportunities for communication, debate and interaction that the internet offers.

Our editorial team specialises in the key areas of social care, health, voluntary sector and charities, local government, regeneration and housing. Each of these sectors has a dedicated area of the site where you can find news and analysis that gets right to the heart of the issues.

The comment and analysis team is made up of many of the sector's leading names, including Peter Townsend, Sir Herman Ouseley, Stuart Etherington, Daphne Statham, Louise Casey, Ruth Lister, Tony Elliston and Bert Massie.

Today's launch is just the beginning. We'll be adding services constantly over the next six months but, in the meantime, sign up for our morning email briefing - giving you details of the latest news, comment and analysis on the site.

SocietyGuardian.co.uk is divided into different sections to make navigation around the site as simple as possible.

Big Issues

In the Big Issues section you'll find reports on a wide range of subjects - from asylum seekers to the Human Rights Act, and from the neighbourhood renewal strategy, payroll giving and fundraising to NHS quality and performance.

Careers section

From time to time you may need help in solving a career or a workplace problem. Are you really being paid what you're worth? Is your boss allowed to read your emails? Can you claim compensation if you have been injured at work?

Find out the answers to these and other questions in our Careers section, and in the interactive area of Information Exchange.

And if you decide you need a new challenge at work, you can search for a job in our extensive database of public sector appointments.

Information Exchange

Information Exchange is the place to ask a question, offer an opinion, read the comments of your peers and share information about research, projects and best practice.

If you want a less structured discussion, or just want to sound off online, you can register and log on to our talkboards.

Policy section

Perhaps you interested in how new government policy affects your working life? Check out the Policy section, where the effects of important announcements are analysed.

Practice section

Do you need inspiration to turn your project into a shining example of good practice?

Take a tour of the Practice section, where you'll find details of organisations who've pioneered a different approach to working.

fields.headline: Seeing is believing
fields.standfirst: John Cunningham  on how open captioning brings theatre alive for the hard of hearing
fields.trailText: John Cunningham on how open captioning brings theatre alive for the hard of hearing.
fields.body:
When the Royal Opera House provided surtitles in English for a performance of Britten's Billy Budd last month, the critics of the posh papers - including this one - were outraged. Insulting to the professionalism of the singers (whose diction is crystal clear) and to the erudition of the audience (who know the work intimately), they fumed.

The peacocks of the press were quickly and rightly shamed on the letters pages, where readers pointed out the value of surtitles to patrons with hearing loss, and praised the opera house management for its policy of surtitling all its operas, including those written and sung in English.

The critics' elitism has at least made a lot of people realise that many of the deaf, or those with impaired hearing, enjoy the performing arts, but feel excluded because many venues do little or nothing to enable them to understand what's going on.

The comprehensive and frequently updated access guide for disabled people, published by the Society of London Theatre, lists 50 West End venues, most of which cater to some extent for those with hearing loss. However, 13 have no sound amplification system for patrons with hearing loss, and 20 never offer signed performances. Of those that do, it tends to be one or two performances a season.

Most dispiriting to the hearing impaired is our general slowness in using computer technology, which has been around for decades. But now there is a ray of hope: it has been a long time coming, but it will be glimpsed tonight at the Barbican theatre in London when the Royal Shakespeare Company will provide an "open captioned" performance of Webster's The Duchess of Malfi.

On one side of the proscenium arch, the text of the Jacobean tragedy will be scrolled, three lines at a time, on a large computer screen, synchronised with actors speaking the words. A batch of seats in the stalls has been reserved for deaf members of the audience; another group of patrons will be interested in their reaction. These are theatre and arts managers from the commercial and subsidised sectors, most of whom will be seeing open captioning for the first time.

This may be hardly surprising, given that the equipment is not yet available in Britain. It is produced in the US and the fact that it is here at all is thanks to Peter Pullan, a frustrated but determined arts-lover who is partially deaf. He has spent £10,000 of his own savings to buy the equipment and loan it to theatres. With two friends, Merfyn Williams and Geoff Brown, he founded a company, Stagetext, which has applied for charitable status, to demonstrate the usefulness of open captioning.

Pullan, 53, who works full-time in industry, first saw open captioning at a theatre in New York. The oblong box, 1.4 me tres long (4ft 6ins), produces the text in letters 5cm (2ins) high and so transformed his enjoyment that he became obsessed with making it available here. He hopes that reaction to tonight's performance will prick the consciences of several theatre managements and open their chequebooks. "There's an awful lack of awareness," he says. "Managements say to us: 'Well, we don't get any complaints.' But that's because people with hearing loss hardly go to the theatre."

Well-meaning though managements may be, the provision they presently make for deaf playgoers is not adequate, Pullan argues. "There's a lot more to [accommodating] hearing loss than providing a loop or a signed performance. Many people have no idea that there are many different degrees and types of hearing problems."

His own case illustrates this - and shows how people use a combination of techniques to cope. He has no hearing in his left ear and loses some of the higher frequencies in his right, wears a hearing aid and gets by with a combination of partial hearing, lip-reading and body language. Until he experienced open captioning, he had to do a lot of preparation to get the maximum out of a theatre visit.

This meant reading the script, if available in advance; going only to plays he was familiar with; or, in the case of some musicals, watching a DVD version - again, if it was available.

The ideal solution, Pullan says, would be for all theatres to buy their own equipment, or for companies owning several houses to buy one set for pooled use. The hope is that representatives of Lord Lloyd Webber's Really Useful Company, and Cameron Mackintosh's organisation, will go along to the RSC and be sufficiently impressed to invest in the system. The RSC itself is on the point of buying its own open captioning equipment, which it will use on tour, as well as for its seasons in Stratford-upon-Avon and London.

It seems likely, though, that there will be a need for Stagetext for a long time yet. The group would like to see provincial theatres offering open captioning and its campaign is to be extended outside London. The Abbey National charitable trust has given it £16,500 to reimburse Pullan for the equipment and pay for the training of operators, who need to have full hearing so they can synchronise text with spoken or sung libretto.

Two years ago, Pullan tried to get the management of English National Opera to use surtitles for its operas, which are usually sung in English. It wouldn't do so, he says, because it feared it would be an admission that the words were unclear. But now the position has changed, at least a little.

A few weeks ago, Pullan was at the surtitled Billy Budd, along with the critics. His verdict: "It was sensational. I've never been to an opera in English before where I've understood every word. If we see the words just before they're sung, it enables us to hear it better. But we were terrified afterwards that the opera house would get cold feet because of what the critics said about it."

On the contrary, it was bouquets for the opera house, boos for the critics.

 Things are "improving quite considerably" for disabled people wishing to go to the theatre in London's west end, according to Brian Vickers, access officer with information and enabling charity Artsline.

No longer is it merely a question of ramps for wheelchairs and accessible toilets. "At the Palladium, and at any Really Useful Company venue, there is a member of staff to look after the needs of disabled people," says Vickers. "They will even bring a drink to you at the interval."

As well as aids for people with limited hearing, theatres may now offer "audio described" performances for patrons with limited sight.

Latest information on all facilities can be found at: www.theatre-access.co.uk, a website run by the Society of London Theatre.

Vickers cautions, though, that parking remains a considerable obstacle. As he says: "The big problem for west end theatres is that they are in the west end."
