fields.headline: Forward thinking in a community
fields.standfirst: Ex-footballer Howard Gayle is playmaker in the school of hard knocks
fields.trailText: Profile: ex-footballer Howard Gayle.
fields.body:
When Olympic rower Steve Redgrave recently announced his retirement, he also ruled out coaching. The point was to give up the gruelling schedule, he said, not put in more hours.

Ex-footballer Howard Gayle knows all about coaching commitments. He runs Stanley House Youth Academy in the Toxteth area of Liverpool, where he grew up and still lives. He trains with his young teams five nights a week, unpaid, in all weathers. "The hours are much longer than playing," he says. "When I'm not coaching, I'm planning trips, preparing training schedules, organising fundraising events, or advising players and parents."

Gayle, 43, played for Liverpool between 1977 and 1982, at a time when the team were top in Europe as well as in England, but long before professional footballers were celebrities with stratospheric salaries and egos to match. "There were better players than me who weren't getting the opportunities they should have," he says modestly. He was also the club's first black player and suffered the racism endemic in the sport at the time.

But it wasn't only the racism he noticed. Over the years, he saw talented young players plucked from obscurity to play in top clubs' youth teams, only to be dumped unceremoniously back in their communities if they failed to make the grade. Having been role models to their friends and families, they were often unable to handle what they perceived to be failure - with the community bearing the brunt if they went off the rails. When he retired in 1993, Gayle realised he could help the many talented youngsters he saw in his area, equipping them with the mental - as well as physical - skills needed to deal with this fickle sport.

"You have to be mentally hardened," Gayle says. "People only see the end product and not the hard work that's gone on during the week, the stuff you have to sacrifice, the disappointments of failures and injuries."

And it's becoming increasingly hard for a young English player to break into a premier league club. The big clubs cherry-pick the talent from youth teams and Sunday leagues, he says, raising hopes but not taking any responsibility for dashed dreams.

"Only a tiny percentage of boys will be picked to train on the club's YTS or football scholarship schemes, and success has to be immediate." A boy could then be playing for Liverpool's youth team for years, he points out, but if the club decides to spend £15m on a foreigner who plays in his position, the chances of getting into the first team are minimal. But while it must be nearly impossible to persuade a young player not to join Liverpool or Everton if invited, Gayle says he has convinced some to opt for another path. "I think players from inner-city areas like Toxteth can be better off going to smaller clubs and working their way up the ladder rather than going to the big clubs and being released. There isn't the support mechanism to get them back on track. They feel playing for teams like ours is beneath them after they've been at premiership clubs and a lot give up football altogether."

One of his former players, 16-year-old Leslie Afful, is now on a YTS scheme at third division Exeter City. Both Liverpool and Everton approached him, but he opted for Exeter - a lot less glamorous and a long way from home. "I thought I'd have a better chance of getting first team games in," says Afful, who is happy and settled in Exeter. "I never thought of football as a career, but playing at Stanley House gave me a passion for it." His foster mum has been to see him, he says, and he gets a lot of support from the club.

Mike Radford, youth development officer at Exeter, is delighted with Afful's progress. "He's a great ambassador for the club and he's doing brilliantly on the pitch as well," he says. "We only have 14 trainees and we only take them on if we genuinely believe they have a chance. They study for GNVQs and it isn't the end of the world if they don't make it to professional level, as many go into related careers such as sports science or media. In Leslie's case we saw him play and invited him back. In terms of personality I have to go on what Howard tells me, but I trust him implicitly and what he told me was spot on. We are immensely pleased with Leslie here."

In the US, sport has long been used as a tool to give youngsters opportunities, but also a sense of social responsibility. Gayle wants to see more of this thinking here, as well as finance applied at the grassroots level in inner-city areas. He has no official funding and, in fact, has to pay for the use of the council-owned sports centre where his teams train.

"Football at this level has been suffering for years," he says. "Managers of clubs like ours are running them on a shoestring, sometimes out of their own pocket, then gaps are left when the clubs take our best players." He wants the big clubs to acknowledge the talent they are acquiring with either a statutory fee or payment in kind such as new kit or balls for training.

Convinced of the benefits to the youngsters themselves and the wider community that Stanley House and other youth teams provide, Gayle's main concern is to see them achieving goals on and off the pitch. "What they learn extends beyond football. There's no point in them coming here and playing brilliantly and then going away and acting anti-socially. It's not a boot camp, but in a lot of cases it's the only discipline they have. This feeds back into their schoolwork and their behaviour."

Gayle is a modest man, and keen to protect his players - black and white - from the stigma so often attached to Toxteth, both within Liverpool and the country at large. "People think we are rough, but we're not. Kids who join us from other areas are amazed at how quickly they are accepted."

It is almost a rhetorical question to ask him what he gets out of it. "Being with young people," he replies without hesitation. "Seeing their faces when they achieve something. Watching them develop, watching them see themselves develop. It's not all a steady progression; we are trying to make them understand they have to be responsible."

fields.headline: Sweet charity
fields.standfirst: Jane Muir  on how an unexpected gift made up for years of asking for help
fields.trailText: Jane Muir on how an unexpected gift made up for years of asking for help.
fields.body:
Charity is surely one area of our lives where attitudes can still be resolutely Dickensian. It came as a shock to me when, at the age of 35, I had to become dependent on charity for the first time in my life. I had been an independent career woman, a teacher - one of the givers, rather than the receivers. And probably rather complacent, too.

People with disabilities get a certain amount from the government in the form of benefits and grants, but the rest must come from charity. My son, Alex, was born 10 years ago with cerebral palsy and, as a single parent having (and wanting) to stay at home to care for him, I have, like many others, had to work very hard at developing skills of persuasion and persistence.

At the moment, I am trying to raise £2,500 for a hands-free walking frame. I have written to 50 local companies with a smiley photo of my son and a plea for help. Fundraising for others is one thing; doing it for your own child is quite another. Choosing possible suitable companies. Phoning for names. Waiting for results. So far we've managed £25, which at least covers the postage and photocopying costs. People don't like giving to individuals rather than established charities, so you can easily feel like a fraud. I find the whole process demoralising - and downright embarrassing.

There are, of course, charities full of saintly people who will do it all for you. One well-known charity used to have a system where parents had to phone on the first Monday of each month until somebody answered the phone to put your name on the waiting list - the waiting list, that is, for an application form to be put on the real waiting list. I phoned determinedly for four months, phone stuck between my cheek and shoulder for hours on end, only to be told when I did get through: "I'm afraid we're not taking any more names now - could you try again next year?" The charity has since changed its system, in response to a plethora of complaints from infuriated parents.

The average waiting list for that kind of money from any charity is about a year. My son needs his walker now, owing to problems with threatening hip dislocation. Hence the do-it-myself attempt.

Meanwhile, another charity, "bringing gifts of happiness and hope", offered us a free, three-day break - not to Disneyland, Florida, as advertised in its leaflet to donors, but to anywhere in Britain, preferably Butlins or Center Parcs. As those weren't our kind of holiday, I asked if we could go to London instead. This threw up new problems. It takes two to get powerchair and ramps in and out of car, child in and out of bath, or up and down steps, but the charity wouldn't pay for my partner, who was the only person who offered to help - and he was understandably reluctant to pay £65 a night for the suggested hotel in addition to taking three days off work.

"It would be different if he was your son's father, of course," I was told. "We do pay for families."

The only other stumbling block was that I was to provide proof of cerebral palsy and a letter to say that the carer would be suitable. "But I'm not taking a carer," I said, "I'm going with him myself!"

"Oh well, in that case," the charity lady said sanctimoniously, "you will need a letter to say that you are a suitable person to accompany your son on holiday." I can't remember what I said, but I think I may have looked that gift horse in the mouth.

Another charitable approach is to "match" money raised by other means. Hence, one charity was pleased to give me £100 towards a computer joystick so long as I managed to find the rest from a different source. I naively thought this might be a sharing of the "burden" - but not so. It was apparently to make me "feel better" as I would have done more of the work myself. As if I have no other work to do - caring, after all, is not counted as a job.

Nobody likes being dependent on charity. There are certainly grants available for certain things from charities, such as the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, which try to cover the gaps left by health and social services. And yet at every stage of Alex's childhood, as with other families with disabled children, we have had huge expenses which can be met only by fundraising.

First, at age two, there were courses in conductive education (a specialised form of physiotherapy) at the Peto Institute. At three, a special supportive trike (provided by our local residents' association) cost £500. Then another at six when he outgrew that, and another at eight, provided by the local pub.

We need special, very expensive toys designed for uncoordinated hands, and hardback books which stay open better when he turns the pages to read (he cannot hold them down himself). Dribbling and food spillages mean constant changes of clothes, and special Pedro boots are £100 a pair if your health authority won't pay, as some won't. Car seats for older children who need extra support come in at £600. Wheelchairs, home adaptations and so on are provided, just as long as you don't want anything different from standard NHS issue. webTitle: The fight against cancer goes into the supermarket

fields.headline: The fight against cancer goes into the supermarket
fields.trailText: Unlike previous cause related marketing, the latest campaign from Tesco appears simply to raise awareness.
fields.body:
Unlike previous cause related marketing, where a purchase results in a charity or cause receiving cash or in-kind corporate support, the latest campaign from Tesco appears simply to raise awareness.

This month, Tesco customers in York and Oxford are being greeted with booklets, jointly compiled by the Imperial Cancer Research Fund (ICRF) and Tesco, explaining the link between diet and cancer and encouraging them to eat five portions of fruit and vegetables a day. In-store food demonstrations and money-off vouchers will reinforce the message.

The campaign will roll out in Tesco's 650 stores in the new year, all paid for by the supermarket. There are no on pack promotions, no staff or customer fundraising. On the face of it the cancer charity's objective appears to be making people aware of the simple steps they can take to help prevent cancer. Tesco's objective: to sell more fruit and veg while enhancing its reputation as a good corporate citizen.

Yet, according to Chris Gardner, ICRF deputy director of fundraising, this is all about fundraising. "This is a different route to raise money in a competitive market place. It will put the charity at the forefront of people's minds. People will recognise our brand and we are confident this will lead to an increase in donations in the future."

The danger is that while the campaign may raise awareness about cancer, the public may fail to remember the charity involved and donate money to a rival. Gardner says it would be churlish to think of such an outcome as bad. "If there was an increase in giving to cancer charities across the board because of our campaign, then we'd all benefit."

webTitle: How health claims over Shredded Wheat went too far

fields.headline: How health claims over Shredded Wheat went too far
fields.trailText: A charity's support of a company's product in return for cash doesn't always turn out the way it is intended.
fields.body:
A charity's support of a company's product in return for cash doesn't always turn out the way it is intended. Take the British Heart Foundation's "endorsement" of Shredded Wheat last year. Designed to raise £250,000, the charity put its logo on more than 10m cereal boxes. The message promoted the eating of Shredded Wheat as part of a healthy heart campaign and purchasers were invited to register for the campaign by sending money and buying merchandise. The deal landed Nestlé with a £750,000 fine earlier this year for making a medical claim about its product in breach of food labelling regulations. Up holding a complaint brought by Shropshire trading standards, the magistrate commented that it was "clear beyond doubt that the statements about Shredded Wheat attached to each of the campaign steps invite an irresistible inference that eating Shredded Wheat will reduce the risk of coronary heart disease".

The foundation is refusing to comment on the case, but maintains it has continuing relations with Nestlé.

The British Dental Association (BDA) also got into hot water with its endorsement of Ribena ToothKind. In July, the Advertising Standards Authority ruled against claims by SmithKline Beecham that its soft drink "does not encourage tooth decay". Such claims are supported by the BDA,through its food and drinks accreditation panel. While not strictly a cause related marketing campaign, the accreditation was publicised on packs in a bid to increase sales and the BDA received a £55,000 administration fee from the manufacturer. SmithKline Beecham has been granted leave to apply for a judicial review against the ruling.

fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.standfirst: Write to Guardian Society, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER; or fax 020-7713 4154 or email society@guardian.co.uk Please supply your full address. Letters may be edited
fields.trailText: Write to Guardian Society, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER; or fax 020-7713 4154 or email society@guardian.co.uk Please supply your full address. Letters may be edited
fields.body:
Wrong on Runnymede

The Runnymede report may have been circulating before its launch-date (When it pays to be clear, November 8) but it could not have circulated as far as the Guardian offices, since the paper's hostile and damaging editorial was written on the basis, not of reading the report, but of the Daily Telegraph's misrepresentation of it.

No acknowledgement of, or apology for, this curious editorial practice disfigures Malcolm Dean's column. Instead, he goes on a mischievous fishing expedition to sow discord among its authors and to discover scapegoats. To no one's surprise, he finds one - me! He says the report's "good analysis" of national identity is spoilt by a confused final message. Alas, he has understood neither.

Post-devolution, he still finds nothing wrong in conflating Britishness with Englishness. Post-the Good Friday agreement, he seems to think Northern Ireland's republicans will accept "British" on its own as a way of expressing their identity.

If New Labour's campaign to "make patriotism a key pillar in the next election", which Dean forecasts, is based on such tired and unexamined assumptions, heaven help the future of Britain as a multi-cultural society.

Stuart Hall, emeritus professor, Open University

 Malcolm Dean spent an entire column of valuable newspaper space doing nothing but adding further muddle to the Runnymede Trust's timely report by listing dozens of soundbite quotes out of context.

The report addresses issues which cannot be simplified. It demands all British citizens spend time applying real thought to the framing of a contemporary national identity. Stuart Hall speaks with utmost clarity about complex issues which each one of us needs to follow and work at in order to apply them to the context in which we find ourselves. It requires all of us to learn a lot. In particular, it exposes the need to be involved in the search for an agreed vocabulary upon which we can build a national discussion.

Judy Ling Wong, director, Black Environment Network

Problem with fertilizers

Could it be that farming's influence on flooding goes beyond the choice of crop cycle? (Don't blame the climate, November 8).

Might the shift in balance from using traditional organic fertilizers to using mainly mineral fertilizers have resulted in soil that is less able to retain moisture, and consequently allows rainwater to quickly pass through to watercourses?

If so, then recent extreme flooding is partially a consequence of cashing-in on the resource of soil condition, built up by many generations of farmers, in order to achieve high yields in the short-term.

James Brooks, Weymouth

Uncharitable behaviour

Thank you for your article on the multiplicity of charities (Too many cooks?, November 8).

As the recipient of many charity appeals each week, I suggest there are several other things you could have taken the lid off: the deplorable habit adopted by many charities of "suggesting" how much one should donate, the suggestions often beginning at £25 and rising to £2,500; failure to respond to letters of criticism about, for example, the above; and the tendency of some to send two or three appeals each month.

I have complained to the charity commission, but it seems to be a waste of time.

K Bakewell, emeritus professor of information and library management, Liverpool John Moores University

Positive images

As a disabled person and full-time wheelchair user for almost 30 years, who has nevertheless managed to access higher education and follow a successful career, I should like to commend the Royal National Institute for the Blind (RNIB) for the positive message in their current advertising campaign.

That charities need to invoke pity to raise funds has always seemed fallacious. Like Saqib in the RNIB ad, albeit a quarter of a century earlier, I went to Essex University to read economics - in my wheelchair - and had a great time. I hope he does too.

Barry Baines, Carlisle

Living room

I read the letter by Matthew Huntbacher (October 25) with the greatest interest. It seemed as if he was writing on my behalf.

I have been living in the same flat in the London borough of Lewisham for 12 years. It is a two-bedroom flat for a family of five, my children are two girls and a boy, ages 16, 12 and three. The boy sleeps in the same bed with me and his dad.

Family housing needs a nice sorting out. I am waiting for the next election to register my protest.

Bola Oyeyemi, London

Damage limitation

I don't accept hearing people in my lipreading classes for two very good reasons (Letters, November 8).

Some 17% of people suffer an acquired loss of hearing and could be said to be in need of a class. When I organised the (15) classes in Lothian region, there was always a waiting list.

Experience taught me that hearing people will progress faster at lipreading. This becomes demoralising for hard of hearing people. By limiting classes to people with a hearing loss, we ensure that they quickly turn into effective self-help groups where a great deal of mutual support goes on.

Sarah Kilbey, Edinburgh

Every job counts

"Sainsbury's has proved a useful source of jobs - albeit mainly for women" (The art of revival, November 8). Don't these count then?

Helen Griffith, Dartford, Kent

fields.headline: Big noises call for quiet
fields.standfirst: Southwark closes centre after complaints about kids
fields.trailText: Southwark closes centre after complaints about kids.
fields.body:
A pioneering drop-in centre for inner-city children, which has won the support of a host of high-profile benefactors, has been ordered to close on grounds of noise. But its supporters believe it is a victim of prejudice by well-heeled people moving into the area.

Thirteen local households lodged an array of objections to the Arches centre in Southwark, south London, after it emerged that the appropriate planning permission had not been sought five years ago to convert the space beneath six railway arches.

The Arches, which has brought some £4m in external funding into the borough from corporate donors including Andersen Consulting and Sainsbury's, provides sanctuary for children who have fallen through the safety nets of social services, education and health. Last year, it educated 29 children with a variety of special needs. After-school activities and meals draw in between 70 and 100 children, mostly from deprived homes on rundown estates. Many youngsters, the organisers claim, would not otherwise get an evening meal.

The objections included a claim that bad language was affecting other children playing in neighbouring gardens, and a contention that the centre had "altered the character of a conservation area". Only one grievance - excessive noise - was upheld.

Kids Company, the charity which runs the centre, says it has regenerated the arches, which had previously been derelict. Any noise is limited to a two-hour, early evening period and is not excessive.

Camila Batmanghelidjh, who runs the centre, claims the objections have amounted to an attempt to cleanse underprivileged children from an inner city area undergoing gentrification. "The closing of Kids Company is about the hypocrisy of people who pay lip service to social inclusion, but can't tolerate the sounds children make," she says. "It is about councillors who are lobbied by the articulate and threatened with loss of support if they fail to comply."

The planning decision has also infuriated many private and corporate supporters, some of which have recently spent £100,000 ensuring the Arches met all the council's regulatory requirements.

Alan Yentob, BBC director of drama, entertainment and children's programming, and a trustee of Kids Company, praises the children at the Arches, describing them as "socially aware, supportive and inclusive". He says: "The council has a responsibility to the residents of Southwark, who include those people from poor homes and backgrounds who need looking after.

"People need to know about the remarkable work that goes on at the centre. It takes potential criminals off the street and into an environment that is sympathetic. They are remarkably law-abiding and well behaved when they are there. They belong in the community. They are part of it. We need to consider whether it is right that these children should be pushed back out on to the street and ghettoised."

Michael Jackson, Channel 4's chief executive and also a Kids Company trustee, says he has made many visits to the centre and never noticed a problem with noise levels. "In a post-70s world where the state doesn't feel it can do everything any more, here is a very idealistic but equally practical solution that is proven to be working. It is really depressing that a local council, where Labour is the largest party, does not see this as a fantastic asset. It is a really successful alternative to the big expensive centralised route to tackling these problems."

But local ward councillor David Noakes, a Liberal Democrat, defends his constituents' objections. "As far as I can see, while they are in Kids Company the children are well behaved," he says. "But I cannot be 100% sure that, when it closes each night, they disperse to their homes.

"I knocked on the doors of the 40 closest properties and found that 60% were against the centre. Some of the residents were saying they could not continue to live in the area because of the centre. I am sure there may be one or two people who are not lobbying for all the right reasons, but there are a lot of people who are."

Stephen Lancashire, Labour councillor in charge of regeneration in Southwark, says: "This was a retrospective application which we had to deal with purely on planning grounds. We thought long and hard about the decision, but in the end the centre did not meet with strict planning guidelines.

"Because we felt so strongly about this specific situation, instead of giving Kids Company 28 days to move out, they have until June. In the meantime, we have instructed officers to help look for a more suitable site."

fields.headline: Beckham's vision key for England
fields.standfirst: Captain takes central role as Taylor gives young hopefuls their chance
fields.trailText: Captain David Beckham will take a central role in Turin tonight as Peter Taylor gives his young hopefuls their chance to impress. David Lacey reports.
fields.body:
The England team which will take on Italy in tonight's friendly in the Stadio delle Alpi looks quite a natty piece of Tayloring.

Whether it comes apart at the seams under pressure from an Italian side containing most of the players narrowly beaten by France in the final of Euro 2000 will depend on how strong the youthful ambition to establish reputations at this level really is. Certainly Peter Taylor is using his brief time as England coach between the resignation of Kevin Keegan and Sven-Goran Eriksson's arrival to build a suitable platform on which the international wannabes and maybes can perform.

"I've always felt that friendly matches should be used to play young players and give them a chance," Taylor said yesterday after picking a team with an average age of 24 and captained by a 25-year-old, David Beckham. But for injuries Manchester United's Wes Brown and Liverpool's Steven Gerrard would tonight be giving England an even younger look.

Gerrard yesterday became Taylor's fifth casualty after suffering a recurrence of the muscular stress which forced the 20-year-old midfielder to drop out of the World Cup qualifier against Germany which proved to be Keegan's last match. "At the moment Gerrard finds it difficult to play two games in quick succession," Taylor explained.

The withdrawals have changed the personnel of Taylor's intended team but not its shape. England have reverted to the 3-5-2 system favoured by Glenn Hoddle and which flourished abroad when they were qualifying for the 1998 World Cup.

Instead of Brown another Manchester United defender, Gary Neville, will join Rio Ferdinand and Gareth Southgate in the back three. United's Nicky Butt will take over Gerrard's midfield position, playing the anchor role to complement the attacking inclinations of Beckham and Kieron Dyer.

Taylor always intended using Emile Heskey up front with a man playing off the Liverpool striker. Paul Scholes, who dropped out on Monday, would almost certainly have been given the supporting role. Now it will be filled by Liverpool's Nick Barmby, the leading England scorer in this team with three goals, two of them against China.

The side is designed to rectify the faults which let England down so badly in the European Championship. Ferdinand will add a capacity to bring the ball out of defence and use it constructively, a quality badly lacking during the summer, and the presence of three central midfielders should lessen the likelihood of England being overrun as they were by Portugal and Romania.

Ray Parlour and Gareth Barry are England's wing-backs, Parlour with the daunting task of tracking Paolo Maldini when the Italian captain advances on the left, Barry to give the left side of Taylor's team a natural balance. Barry normally operates in Aston Villa's back three but quickly adapted to a more advanced role when England held France to 1-1 in Paris 2 months ago. Dyer will doubtless be pleased to play in his normal club position instead of being confined to the flanks.

Players, not systems, win or lose games and a lot will rest on how quickly the less experienced internationals adapt to strange and daunting circumstances. Hoddle's format worked because at its heart lay the experience and intelligence of footballers such as Teddy Sheringham, Paul Gascoigne and David Batty.

Tonight Ferdinand, Dyer, Barry and Heskey have to acquire instant wrinkles while Parlour, Butt and Barmby need to convince sceptics that, sound though they may be at club level, they also possess genuine international ability.

Much also depends on Beckham making a better go of his central role than he did in Paris. The Manchester United player spoke enthusiastically about getting the captaincy and eruditely about how he hoped to take on some of the qualities of leadership displayed at Old Trafford by Bryan Robson and Roy Keane.

Yet as Taylor explained: "David Beckham has not got to boss everybody about. He's got to control the game and then take on the extra responsibility of captaincy."

Beckham will be crucial to the task of stopping Italy gaining a grip in midfield through Demetrio Albertini linking with Stefano Fiore. Should the ball be given away as recklessly as it was under Keegan this is one Italian job which will not get out of Turin unscathed.

Eriksson will introduce himself to the England players but otherwise will confine himself to an observer's role. If tonight's performance sends him to bed with happy thoughts then whatever the result the evening, for England, will not have been wasted.

fields.headline: Marketing Week round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: November 16.
fields.trailText: November 16: Ads for MyKindaplace.com, the teenage girls' website backed by BSkyB and Freeserve, have been condemned as 'irresponsible'.
fields.body:
MyKindaplace.com, the teenage girls' internet portal backed by BSkyB and Freeserve, has been condemned as 'irresponsible' for an ad campaign designed to attract male users to the site's chat rooms. Taglines include "Go on a hot date with 15 girls."

Ian Schoolar, Natwest's head of brand advertising, is quitting to join the Inland Revenue as its first marketing director.

Unilever has reshuffled its marketing team at Elida Faberge, bringing in Van den Bergh's business group director, Jacqui Davies, to head it UK marketing division.

Dome chiefs seriously underestimated the marketing budget needed to promote the attraction, according to a National Audit Office report.

Discount retailer Poundland is to revamp its stores to compete with middle market retailers who are offering more discounts.

Allied Domecq is rebranding Beefeater Gin for the first time since it was launched in 1820 as part of an attempt to appeal to younger drinkers.

Matthew Williamson is working with Saatchi & Saatchi to help build his name into a global brand.

SmithKline Beecham is revamping health drink Horlicks and is thinking about changing its name to 'Horlickzzz'.

Yahoo! is launching its first retail outlet, the Yahoo! Shop, in Kensington High Street this week.

A new IPA report shows that only 9% of women make it to senior management in the UK's ad industry.

Global investment house Credit Suisse is launching a new internet service and has appointed Claydon Heeley to handle its £10m European direct marketing business.

Mars is working on a new ad campaign to rejuvenate its Mars Bar brand.

The Unilever-backed Wowgo webiste has been put up for sale just months after launch.

Mills & Allen , one of the outdoor advertising industry's oldest brands, is about to be axed by its French owner, JCDecaux.

fields.headline: Vodafone extends US reach
fields.standfirst: Nov 14: Vodafone rings up strong rise in profitability
fields.trailText:
Vodafone snaps up US mobile phone operator. By Dan Milmo
Nov 14: Vodafone boss hits out at BT over legal wrangle
fields.body:
Vodafone is showing no let-up in its aggressive expansion, after snapping up a US mobile phone operator.

The world's largest mobile phone company has agreed to buy Price Communications Wireless for $2.06bn (£1.4bn) through its Verizon Wireless subsidiary.

However, the deal will be postponed if Verizon Wireless does not float on the stock market before 30 September 2001.

Last month, Vodafone agreed with co-owner Verizon Communications that the telecoms sector was too volatile for an immediate IPO.

A successful deal will see the UK company making further inroads into the US market, adding 500,000 customers in the south of the country to its current user base of 26.2m.

Vodafone has a presence in all the major global markets, with the UK its biggest earner by far, followed by the US.

Vodafone's shares climbed 1.75p to 264.25p by late afternoon, following yesterday's 24p surge on the back of impressive half-year figures.

webTitle: Urban white paper promises tax breaks for regeneration

fields.headline: Urban white paper promises tax breaks for regeneration
fields.trailText: A government paper aimed at allowing local people and councils to shape the future of their communities is to be released today.
fields.body:
A government paper aimed at allowing local people and councils to shape the future of their communities is to be released today.

The urban white paper is designed to boost quality of life in the country's towns and cities.

The government has confirmed that it will take forward proposals from this September's local government finance green paper. These are likely to include new powers for councils to vary their business rates to raise additional revenue or to attract new investors to their area. Small businesses in particular could become eligible for rate relief.

Ministers may propose a local tax reinvestment scheme, which would allow authorities to keep increases in council tax revenue from successful regeneration work. The money would be spent on maintaining regenerated areas.

The paper is also likely to recommend an expansion of the government's urban regeneration company scheme. The companies, set up to coordinate and focus regeneration efforts in impoverished areas, are currently being piloted in Liverpool, east Manchester and Sheffield.

Ministers are expected to limit the number of companies to two in each region because of the financial pressures they place on local public and private finance, from which they will largely draw their funding.

Researchers at the universities of Manchester and Liverpool John Moores predict each regeneration company could cost up to £2bn over 10 years. Few companies would be likely to attract support on that scale and would place heavy administrative and financial burdens on regional development agencies. The companies, says the government, will be allowed to continue their work as long they are needed.

Councils want the paper to give them more freedom to tailor national policies to suit their local needs and to bolster the role of public services in regeneration. Sally Powell, chair of the economic development panel at the Association of London Government, said: "We hope that the urban white paper will provide a national framework for an urban renaissance, but also that it is flexible enough to recognise the scale and complexity of London's social and economic needs."

London councils and the Local Government Association are looking for greater coordination of the current panoply of regeneration initiatives.

A government spokesman said this issue would be tackled in the white paper: "It brings together all the various policies the government has been working on for the last three years, including those for ensuring better education, transport and planning. It will also contain measures to connect them together."

webTitle: Lack of money could force Letsbuyit to sell next year

fields.headline: Lack of funds may force Letsbuyit to sell up
fields.trailText:
9.15am: Letsbuyit.com could be sold by the middle of next year if it runs into fundraising difficulties.By Dan Milmo.

November 14: Letsbuyit makes tentative comeback
fields.body:
Letsbuyit.com could be sold by the middle of next year if it runs into fundraising difficulties.

Chief executive Martin Coles said the Amsterdam-based online auctioneer only had enough cash to last until the middle of 2001, when it will need fresh funds from investors.

He said: "We have a contingency plan in place if we fail to get the funding. We could have a partial or full sale of the company, depending on what kind of offer someone brings in."

Mr Coles admitted that bankers may be reluctant to invest in Letsbuyit due to the volatile market for internet stocks. However, he is confident that a successful fundraising campaign would take the loss-making company into the black.

The company will team up with a major retail company and an internet portal over the next few months to underline its commitment to a broader sales strategy.

Letsbuyit has around E50m (£30m) in the bank, but will increase its monthly spend by E1m (£0.59m) to E8m (£4.7m) for the Christmas season.

Mr Coles said the company will concentrate more on internet advertising after it decided to cut down its large marketing spend.

webTitle: City's thriving image masks health crisis

fields.headline: City's thriving image masks health crisis
fields.standfirst: Leeds is to receive the largest share of a £120m package of emergency funding for premature death blackspots
fields.trailText: Leeds is to receive the largest share of a £120m package of emergency funding for premature death blackspots
fields.body:
One of Britain's most thriving regional cities is taking stock of a less welcome title this morning as the national blackspot for premature death in both adults and childen.

Used to headlines about glamorous nightlife or the biggest concentration of lawyers outside London, Leeds is to receive the largest share of a £120m government package of emergency health funding for inner cities.

The move is designed to target inequalities in health care masked by overall average figures which make an NHS area look healthy when parts of it are in severe crisis. Leeds is a classic example, with the overall premature death rate the same as nationally, but figures more than twice the average in some central wards.

Central parts of Leeds come ahead of similar areas in Liverpool, Manchester and Teesside in rates of infant mortality and the big adult killers of cancer and coronary heart disease.

The £5m "inequality bonus" for Leeds was welcomed yesterday by the local health authority, which next week debates a local strategy to cut the annual coronary toll of 5,000 deaths.

"We are a very big city and our averages are in line with the country as a whole, but that hides the problems in central wards such as Chapeltown or Harehills," said Liz Scott, the director of public health. "A surprising side of this is that those wards show a very low take-up of health service provision, both in referrals to hospital and the use of modern treatments, like the 'defurring' of arteries."

Much of the £5m is expected to go on better health education in areas like Harehills - a bonus welcomed yesterday in the local Meeting Point cafe, run by the area's Anglican and Methodist churches.

Apart from all-day breakfasts, staff behind the steamed-up windows give informal health advice so efficiently that patients have been informally referred to the cafe by Harehills GPs.

The novel form of health education, which may be copied in similar schemes by the NHS, ranges from networking with social services to practicalities like getting to remote hospitals. Manageress Pauline Burrow cites a pensioner customer with a white stick, finishing his mug of tea, who was given a crucial hand when his wife was admitted to hospital.

"It was right the other side of town but we found out about the NHS Access bus for him, and he's got a weekly lift nicely sorted out," said Pauline, whose waitress colleague Brenda drew on her own experience to give other practical tips.

She said: "I've got high blood pressure which has been monitored very well now for years. But I only found out about it because I was with a group of friends including a trainee nurse who wanted to practice taking blood pressure."

Brenda's mother was less fortunate, dying of a coronary at 69 with her chronic high blood pressure undiagnosed. That sort of lack of regular contact with the health service is thought to be one of the causes of the high premature mortality.

But simply going more often to the GP or Jimmy's - the vast St James's University hospital which dominates Harehills - is not seen in the café as a realistic solution.

"The last time I was in casualty," said one of Brenda's colleagues, "I took my sister and we were there from 10 past five in the evening until five past midnight."

Mike Ramsden, chief executive of Leeds health authority, does not deny the charge - another reason why Leeds needs the inequality bonus. He says: "We're having to tackle the number of people with 12 month waits for major coronary surgery by offering them appointments at a private hospital in Sheffield, paid for by the NHS."

webTitle: Minister urges action to combat 'winners circle' in south-east

fields.headline: Minister urges action to combat 'winners circle' in south-east
fields.trailText: The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, will today challenge Tony Blair's official line of playing down the north-south divide by warning that rising prosperity in the south-east is failing to spread to old manufacturing heartlands.
fields.body:
The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, will today challenge Tony Blair's official line of playing down the north-south divide by warning that rising prosperity in the south-east is failing to spread to old manufacturing heartlands.

He will tell a regional conference in the City of London that analysis of the government's own statistics indicates that a "winners circle" is emerging in the home counties and East Anglia with other regions slipping further behind.

Calling for a "radical regional policy" to tackle north-south imbalances Mr Byers will warn that "simply tinkering at the edges" will no longer be enough to bring areas like the north-east and north-west up to the national average.

His remarks will be interpreted by some as a direct challenge to the prime minis ter who has been at pains to stress that divisions within regions are wider than any north-south divide. Less than two weeks ago in the north-east, speaking alongside Mr Byers, Tony Blair sought to play up the region's success in creating new jobs.

But the trade secretary, who represents a Tyneside shipbuilding constituency, has recently been strongly supporting backbench Labour MPs who argue that regions like the north-east are suffering at the expense of the south.

Mr Byers will say today that recent figures in his department show that manufacturing businesses invested over 10 times as much in research and development in the south-east than in the north-east.

"Nearly one fifth of people of working age in the north-east and West Midlands have no qualifications at all - compared to just over 11% in the south-east," he plans to say. "These are the underlying causes we need to tackle in regional policy - to widen the 'winners circle' and ensure all regions benefit from rising prosperity."

Older manufacturing regions needed to be renewed. "They were at the heart of the first industrial revolution and we must now ensure that they can play their part in the knowledge based economic revolution which is now taking place."

"Past policies have failed to resolve the underlying weakness of the least successful regions and have failed to capitalise on their strengths."

webTitle: Fertility clinic sued for unwanted third baby

fields.headline: Fertility clinic sued for unwanted third baby
fields.standfirst: Couple may get £100,000 after 'shock' of having triplets
fields.trailText: Couple may get £100,000 after 'shock' of having triplets
fields.body:
A couple who underwent fertility treatment will go to the high court today in an unprecedented compensation claim against a clinic for giving them three babies instead of two.

Peter and Patricia Thompson, who say they felt "shocked" to learn they were expecting triplets, are claiming damages for breach of contract by the Sheffield fertility centre.

The three day hearing at Sheffield, starting today, will decide whether the clinic is legally liable to compensate Mr and Mrs Thompson for the cost of bringing up the third baby. If the couple succeed, a later hearing will determine the damages, which could be about £100,000 to cover the cost of raising a child from birth to adulthood.

The notes of the couple's consultation with the clinic record that they wanted only two embryos inserted in Mrs Thompson's uterus. But the clinic claims that in a later conversation, not recorded in writing, Mrs Thompson was advised to have three to give her a better chance of a baby, and that she agreed.

The Thompsons, from Thrybergh, Yorkshire, say they love their girl and two boys. They had refused to have one foetus aborted when they learned there would be three, but they argue that the clinic breached the agreement with them not to put inmore than two embryos. They believe they should be compensated for the extra expense of a third child.

The couple are represented by Irwin Mitchell, the law firm which has just won compensation from the government for the victims of vCJD and their families.

The Thompsons are suing mainly for breach of contract rather than medical negligence - a course open to them because they paid for private treatment at the clinic, a registered charity. Had they had free treatment on the NHS, they would be barred from claiming the cost of bringing up a healthy child because of a House of Lords ruling last year. The law lords left open the question of whether compensation could be claimed where the birth resulted from a breach of a contract between a clinic and parents who paid for its services.

Mrs Thompson, 34, said she and her husband, 57, had been trying to conceive a child for five or six years without success when they decided to try in vitro fertilisation, or IVF.

"The clinic told us, if you go for three it's higher risk and you might not carry to full term so it's better to go for two. We opted for two hoping to conceive one and then to have another later."

Her husband was "very, very shocked" to learn that she was expecting three babies. "He went very white when they told him we'd got triplets."

The babies were born in March 1997. Mrs Thompson said: "Fortunately they all fed together. We had to take 12 bottles to bed just to get us through the night."

Twelve weeks after their birth Mr Thompson, a former engineer, had a heart attack and then a bypass operation. The couple now have four children under four because Mrs Thompson unexpectedly fell pregnant with a daughter, who has just turned two.

She said looking after the children left her no time even to read a newspaper. But she added: "It could have been a lot worse. They could have been poorly but they're not."

Elizabeth Lenton, director of the Sheffield fertility centre, said: "The Thompsons stated their wishes, which were that they only wanted two embryos at the consultation at the beginning." But she said that Mrs Thompson was later advised to have three embryos inserted in her womb and that she had agreed, although this was not recorded in writing. "I understand from my staff that they were quite comfortable that Mrs Thompson understood that they proposed to replace three embryos and that she agreed to that."

Mrs Thompson disputes this version of events and insists she only learned after the event that three embryos had been inserted. "I felt numb, but the shock didn't sink in until they said you've conceived triplets. They did suggest I consider having one terminated but I said no. When it's in there, it's a baby."

fields.headline: The race to buy life
fields.standfirst: The race for commercial control over the essence of life is threatening to spiral out of control with private firms, universities and charities claiming exclusive development rights over natural processes in the human body at the rate of 34,500 a month.
fields.trailText: The race for commercial control over the essence of life is threatening to spiral out of control with private firms, universities and charities claiming exclusive development rights over natural processes in the human body at the rate of 34,500 a month.
fields.body:
The race for commercial control over the essence of life is threatening to spiral out of control with private firms, universities and charities claiming exclusive development rights over natural processes in the human body at the rate of 34,500 a month.

For the first time, research commissioned by the Guardian reveals the awesome scale of the gene rush, as investors, scientists, entrepreneurs and lawyers use powerful new technology and obscure new laws to isolate and patent the genes which make us what we are - before they even understand what the genes do.

Biotech firms say they need patent protection to recoup their investments. But the risk to society is that future medical researchers - private and public - will have to hack their way through forests of patents, paying out hefty licence fees to a host of gene-squatters, before the miracle drugs of the genetics revolution reach the market.

"It's like someone buying a street and taking a toll from everybody passing through," said Thomas Schweiger, of German Greenpeace, which is campaigning against gene patenting.

Sue Mayer, head of GeneWatch UK, the independent watchdog body commissioned by the Guardian to analyse the gene patent rush, challenged the basis on which gene patents are granted - that genes, or bits of genes, are "inventions".

"What's striking is the speed and the scale at which patent applications are being made," she said. "It's impossible that this is caused by a sudden outbreak of creativity and inven tiveness. Unless people look at the issue seriously, unless the rules are changed in a few years time we will find very basic knowledge and information has been privatised."

Alongside human genes, patents are being sought by organisations, overwhelmingly from rich countries, on hundreds of thousands of animal and plant genes, including those in staple crops such as rice and wheat.

Patents are already pending or have been granted on more than 500,000 genes and partial gene sequences in living organisms.

When GeneWatch UK began its database search last month, patents had been granted or were pending on 126,672 whole or partial human genes. As of this week, however, that number had rocketed by over 34,500 to 161,195, an increase of 27%.

The Guardian's research found that

 One firm alone, Genset of France, has applied for patents covering 36,083 human gene sequences

 Patents are pending on genes controlling processes in the human heart, teeth, tongue, colon, skin, brain, bone, ear, lung, liver, kidney, sperm, blood and immune system

 The US department of health is the world's fifth biggest recorded gene patenter, with applications pending or granted on almost 3,000 sequences

 152 patents have been applied for on rice, 21 on HIV, 13 on the eucalyptus tree and 11 on the spider.

 Among gene patent applicants are Queen Elizabeth college, Dublin (human eye), York University (rice), the Wellcome Foundation (HIV) and ICI (eucalyptus).

 Gene patenters are overwhelmingly from the US, western Europe and Japan.

Opponents of gene patenting believe companies using genetic information to develop real therapies and diagnostic techniques should be able to use the patent system to claw back the huge investment involved.

But they object to firms and other organisations being granted patents for genes when they cannot specify what the genes will be used for.

"Genes are isolated by computers on a routine basis," said Mr Schweiger. "There's no special intellectual work required. Even if the gene patenter doesn't ever develop a new drug or therapy with the gene, and somebody else does all the investment to find out what use can be made of the gene, all the investment is done by the second company and the first company still gets the money."

Concern is growing in continental Europe over an EU directive adopted two years ago which makes it easier to patent genes. In June, the French president Jacques Chirac wrote to the head of the European commission, Romano Prodi, saying that gene patenting should not be permitted.

Yet delegates to a rare diplomatic conference to revise the treaty governing European patent law, opening in Munich on Monday, are not even planning to discuss gene patenting. The British delegate, Alison Brimelow, said yesterday the issue would not be discussed until next year.

The British government has strongly supported liberalisation of the laws on gene patenting, hoping to nurture its own biotech industry and fearful the anti-GM backlash would persuade European and US biotech investors to relocate.

Much of the pressure to liberalise European gene patenting laws has come from the US. Last year the chairman of US drugs firm Pfizer, William Steere, said: "Europe seems to be entering a period of the dark ages, where witchcraft and sorcery are prevailing." The sentiment was shared by Andre Pernet, Genset chief executive. "I think the fear generated by the decoding of the human genome, that somehow people's 'essence' would be captured, has carried over into the gene patenting debate.

"You don't want to patent a gene and then just watch the patent time deadline melt away like a block of ice. There's no money to be made unless you really want to develop a drug."

fields.headline: Beginner's guide to  gene patents
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: The answers to the main questions
fields.body:
What is a patent?
A patent is a kind of licence granted by a government to an inventor. It gives the inventor the right, through the courts, to stop rivals from making, using or selling an invention without his or her permission. When a patent is granted, the invention becomes the property of the inventor. However the patent can be bought, sold, rented or hired.

How long does a patent last?
Normally 20 years. After that, anyone can use the invention without restrictions.

Who issues patents?
In Britain, the UK Patent Office. But Britain is a signatory to the European Patent Convention, so inventions patented in one of 19 other European countries can have patent protection here too through the European Patent Office. Under the Trade-Related Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS) agreement, which came into force in 1995, almost the entire world is supposed to have acquired similar patent rules.

What are the criteria for granting a patent to an inventor?
An invention must be novel - no-one else can have made it public; innovative - it can't be a development which would be obvious to specialists in the relevant field; and useful - it has to aid a practical human activity. It cannot be simply a discovery.

But surely genes are pure discoveries?
So opponents of gene patenting argue. They also point out that with modern automated gene analysis techniques, the non-obviousness of genes is becoming doubtful. Supporters of gene patenting say gene function is not obvious and that genes are not mere discoveries because the genes are patented together with inventive descriptions of how they can be used for diagnosis or therapy.

So what living things can be patented?
Naturally-occurring life forms, from plankton to people, cannot. But genetically engineered plants and animals, such as GM maize or lab mice designed to be prone to cancer, can. So can the naturally-occurring chemical codes and substances which allow all plants and animals, including humans, to function on a cellular level - like genes, or hormones - as long as the 'inventor' can specify a use for them.

Why should anyone want to patent something which occurs in nature?
Holding a patent on a human, plant or animal gene gives the holder control over commercial exploitation of that gene. If it's a human gene, that may involve diagnosis or therapy for a disease; if plant or animal, it may also involve disease, the promotion of a desirable characteristic like a sweet taste, or the transfer of the gene from one organism to another.

If someone has patented something which occurs naturally in my body, do I have to pay them?
No. Confusingly, a naturally-occurring gene can be patented as an isolated sequence, but not a gene in its natural state.

Can someone use a patent to block research?
Yes and no. One of the claimed advantages of the patent system is that it obliges the inventor to publish details of his or her invention, allowing academic scientists to study it. But as soon as a researcher tries to make commercial use of developments based on the original patent - by going into partnership with a drugs firm, for instance, or charging patients at cost for a genetic test - the patent holder can step in to stop them, or oblige them to pay a licence fee.

How important are patents for innovative companies?
Traditionally very important, as inventor James Dyson's recent victory over Hoover in the bagless vacuum cleaner wars showed. Many biotech companies, big and small, argue that genes must be patentable to allow firms to recoup their investment in identifying them. But other firms fear allowing genes to be patented before any specific, proven use has been established for them will hold back medical advances.

Can governments override patents?
Yes, if they feel it is vital for the public good, and the patent holder is being too restrictive.

What would be the impact on the economy if gene patenting was banned?
Unknown. The majority within the biotech lobby argues that it would discourage investment in genetic research. Yet the cost of identifying the function of a gene is a fraction of the cost of turning that gene into something useful, like a drug. There is an argument that the pharmaceutical industry, which has to come up with the bulk of the money anyway, would do better if firms were able to work freely with any genes and focused on patenting drugs instead. However, gene patent ownership is so important a part of biotech companies' stock market valuation that to threaten the concept would cause a market upheaval.

It gives the inventor the right, through the courts, to stop rivals from making, using or selling an invention without his or her permission. After that, anyone can use the invention without restrictions. Who issues patents? In Britain, the UK Patent Office. But genetically engineered plants and animals, such as GM maize or lab mice designed to be prone to cancer, can. So can the naturally-occurring chemical codes and substances which allow all plants and animals, including humans, to function on a cellular level - like genes, or hormones - as long as the 'inventor' can specify a use for them. fields.headline: Mutual friends
fields.standfirst: Experts call on charities to group themselves under umbrellas according to the cause they work for
fields.trailText: Experts call on charities to group themselves under umbrellas according to the cause they work for
fields.body:
Charities should group themselves under umbrellas, according to the general cause they work for, in an attempt to simplify the picture of the voluntary sector and counter the proliferation of individual organisations, a Guardian-backed debate concluded.

Participants felt the sector should act on the example of the Disasters Emergency Committee, which has harnessed the energies of international aid charities and done much to prevent duplication of effort. Most significantly, in the public mind it has reduced multiplication of fundraising costs.

The debate, organised by the Media Trust, a charity working with the voluntary sector on communications issues, also came out in favour of a "brokerage" service to bring together groups that could co-operate on programmes, share costs and even merge. But John Stoker, chief charity commissioner and a panellist at the event, distanced the charity commission from such a role. "The brokerage idea is a good one, but I am not sure it's something the sector would welcome as coming from what they see as their regulator," he said.

The debate was prompted by the continuing growth of the charity register, which now stands at 185,000 organisations in England and Wales. Lord Falconer, Cabinet Office minister responsible for "active communities", told participants the government would not intervene to strangle development of grassroots movements that promoted volunteering, combated social exclusion and gave people a sense of purpose. "What I have said may well lead to more, rather than fewer, organisations," he said.

Other speakers, however, voiced concern at poll findings that the public thinks there are too many charities, often competing with each other, and that too little is known about their relative performance.

James Maxwell, a partner in the public relations company Ketchum Europe, which also supported the debate, said he had set up a cervical cancer charity - Jo's Trust - following his wife's death from the disease, but would wind it up as soon as he found the right merger partner. "I would like to see a brand for cancer, called something like 'Cancer UK'," Maxwell said. "It would be the gateway, the portal, into the cancer sector. Each charity would occupy its own slot, but work to an overall strategy and be partner to similar charities on a local level."

The idea was welcomed as "very exciting" by Deborah Lincoln, communications director of Macmillan Cancer Relief, and "long overdue" by Andrew Larpent, chief executive of the Cancer & Leukaemia in Childhood Trust. But some speakers thought such an approach might prove too sophisticated for donors, and John Downie, of homelessness charity St Botolph's Project, warned against enforced cooperation.

"Once upon a time we had the tyranny of innovation: it didn't matter what we did as long as it was new," said Downie. "I would fear the tyranny of partnership: it doesn't matter what we do, as long as we do it in partnership."

fields.headline: All in the same boat
fields.standfirst: Chris Baines, an ecologist and vice-president of the Wildlife Trusts, advised ministers on the rural white paper
fields.trailText: "Our economy, our culture and our landscape are entirely interwoven." Chris Bains, ecologist and adviser on the rural white paper, dismisses the myth that town and country are separate.
fields.body:
We seem to be a nation in denial. We are about to see the publication of two government white papers - one rural and one urban. Why? Our economy, our culture and our landscape are almost entirely interwoven, from the depth of the inner city to the most remote of rural villages, and yet we perpetuate the myth that town and country are somehow entirely separate places.

Of course, most of us know that there can be no real divide. The food in urban kitchens comes from rural farms. The daily tidal wave of traffic is made up of commuters driving between rural homes and urban car parks - and the roads, car parks and city centres offices themselves are built with stone and clay that has been quarried from the most remote of scenic rural landscapes. Much of the subsidy that helps to pay for managing farmland is raised from urban dwellers' taxes, and the stress of city living is relieved for many with a recreational trip out to the countryside.

We live in one big interconnected country, yet we still maintain a rural and an urban set of policies. Indeed, the Department of Environment, Transport and the Regions itself is split this way. No wonder joined-up government is proving to be so much of a challenge.

Now we have suddenly been inundated with spectacular evidence of the rural-urban link. High streets and housing estates all over Britain are awash with water which flowed down from distant hills, through lowland farmland and on into towns. It should have come as no surprise. If we seal the surfaces of urban Britain, graze the uplands bare, and pipe away the rain as rapidly as possible from farmers' fields, then all that water is inevitably bound to back up at the first real bottleneck.

Our national denial of the rural-urban link is clearly illustrated by the way those bottlenecks are tackled. Ask drainage engineers how best to remove water from a flooded city centre and they are almost bound to recommend a bigger plughole. That is exactly what the water companies have been told to do, with Ofwat sanctioning a five-year bill of £1.7bn to increase the size of combined sewer overflows. This will certainly make the water flow more easily - but only as far as the next bottleneck. In many cases, that bottleneck will be the local sewage treatment works, and the resulting failures will in turn trigger a further round of high-cost, end-of-pipe investment.

Surely it is time we posed a different set of questions? Ask those same engineers how best to stop the water flowing to the flood points in the first place and much more sustainable solutions emerge. We need more porous cities - car parks and roads that let the water pass right through; soak-aways instead of stormwater sewers; wetlands in parks, school grounds and other open spaces. We need a far more extensive canopy of urban trees, to slow the rate at which the rainfall hits the ground, and we need to acknowledge the fact that so many of our so-called brownfield sites are valuable as back-up ponds and soaking grounds for stormwater.

Most importantly, we need to manage the rural landscape in a far more imaginative way. While food and timber may still be essential outputs, they are certainly not the only ones that matter in the new millennium. We need to manage land and water in an integrated way, and look for benefits that make more sense to the whole nation. At present, our land use policies, both in town and country, simply add spectacularly to water management problems.

What would this new, sustainably managed rural landscape look like? There would be much more extensive broadleaved woodland on the hills, and this could be achieved quite naturally by fencing out the sheep. There are successful models in mid-Wales, the Scottish Highlands and elsewhere of birch, oak and rowan colonising where the grazing has been stopped. We're told that the current concern for scrapie, BSE and human health may mean a culling of the national flock. This could be the ideal opportunity to swap eroded grassland for new woodland.

In much of Europe and the eastern US, woodland is managed by the water industry as a filter and a flood control. In the UK, our water companies are among the biggest rural upland owners, so that ought to make this landscape change extremely easy.

The lowland farming countryside needs equally dramatic treatment. Already we are seeing farmland flooded to give temporary protection to the towns downstream, but farmers generally see this as a negative use of land and strive to drain away the water as soon as they can. We need, instead, to celebrate our river floodplains. We should be recreating seasonal water meadows, bringing back the reedbeds that land drainage has destroyed. If we do, the wetlands will provide all kinds of benefits for people. In times of flood, the surplus water will be held in check, but there would also be great benefits in times of drought, since wetlands help to moderate the flow of rivers, and recharge the drinking water aquifers below. Wetland ecosystems also act as biological filters, trapping silt, absorbing excess chemicals and cleaning up other polluting agricultural waste.

Biodiversity would benefit enormously. With so much of our rural wetland drained and damaged since the war, wildlife has suffered very badly. Otters and bitterns, frogs and dragonflies, ragged robin, lady's smock, marsh marigold and many more of our most beautiful wild plants and animals have become uncommon. With care, these functional new wetlands would redress the balance and begin to rebuild Britain's unique natural heritage.

Far from devaluing the role of the farmer and the forester, this move to more sustainably managed countryside should help them to rebuild their self-esteem by showing that their skills can benefit the whole community. There would be a warm welcome for a countryside that's fit to eat and drink, that absorbs rainfall, celebrates distinctive cultural heritage, nurtures nature and offers some tranquillity in a stressful modern world.

webTitle: Joint approach could ease winter crisis

fields.headline: Joint approach could ease winter crisis
fields.standfirst: Labour's health reforms face boost as local authorities report greater cooperation with NHS
fields.trailText: Labour's health reforms face boost as local authorities report greater cooperation with NHS.
fields.body:
A survey published today by the Local Government Association seeks to explode the perception that councils are resisting the drive by ministers to create a better partnership between the centrally-administered NHS and locally-run social services.

Despite recent allegations that Tory-led authorities are engineering a crisis in relations to strike a blow at Labour's health reforms, the figures suggest a good measure of harmony and progress. About three-quarters of local authorities in England and Wales answered the association's questionnaire on relationships with the NHS. Only 1% said they were poor and 16% said average. That left 63% saying partnership with the health service was good and 21% saying it was excellent.

Nearly nine out of 10 authorities said their relationship with the health sector had improved over the past three years and 71% said they already had joint arrangements for providing or commissioning services in their area.

The figures are important because good cooperation between health and social services will be the key factor in avoiding a crisis in hospitals' acute wards during the winter. The system relies on local authority staff working to reduce the need for hospital admissions and to facilitate discharge to avoid unnecessary bed blocking.

The LGA takes the view that winter pressures can best be avoided by continuing year-round cooperation with the NHS. "Focusing resource allocation and planning upon a particular point of time - winter - diverts it away from vital work that will alleviate the problem in the long term," a spokesman says.

The survey showed nearly half (43%) of authorities were considering pooling social services and NHS budgets, while 33% were thinking of allowing one partner to take the lead in commissioning particular services. A quarter said they were not looking into any of these options.

The LGA remains concerned, however, that a £630m fund for tackling winter pressures is being channelled through the NHS with little transparency about how far resources are flowing through to social services departments.

"There is a danger that the NHS may begin to spot purchase at higher rates than local authorities are able to pay, destabilising the market and resulting in higher costs across the system," the LGA says.
