webTitle: How the Beacon became a haven

fields.headline: How the Beacon became a haven
fields.standfirst: Five years ago Falmouth's Beacon and Old Hill estate was the poorest in Cornwall. Now it is on the up.  Linda Jackson  reports on the local partnership that has brought hope to a community
fields.trailText: Five years ago Falmouth's Beacon and Old Hill estate was the poorest in Cornwall. Now it is on the up.
fields.body:
The Beacon and Old Hill estate used to be viewed by police as an "open prison" where families warred over drugs, mothers fought each other at the school gates, pets were tortured and six-year-old boys were found drunk in the streets. Yet today, MPs will visit what has since become a model of neighbourhood regeneration.

The estate, then made up of long, dense rows of grey terrace houses and drab, low-rise flats clinging to the side of a hill in Falmouth, Cornwall, was a classic dumping ground for the disadvantaged and families with problems. Largely abandoned by the statutory agencies, police and social workers marked it down as one of the county's worst trouble spots.

But five years later, after a pioneering and award-winning initiative, the Beacon is a thriving community. So much so that today, members of the Commons health select committee are making a fact-finding visit as part of an inquiry into public health.

The source of the success has been the determination of a handful of residents, with the support of two dedicated health visitors, and local teachers, police and housing officers. Other key factors include a programme of energy conservation measures and a range of modest community projects.

The reforms have produced some impressive changes in the downtrodden residents and their families. Since 1995, the crime rate on the estate has halved, with 87% of those in the community now saying they feel safe. The number of children on the child protection register has fallen from 23 in 1995 to four in 1999. And the number of mothers with post-natal depression has dropped over the same period from 18 to four.

Children's exam results have improved dramatically: among 10 and 11-year-old boys, numbers achieving level four in national tests at key stage two have doubled. The number of childhood accidents has also fallen 50%. Last year, the estate's regeneration project became part of an NHS "beacon" network for its innovation and good practice. And those behind it have won a government Nye Bevan award for excellence.

Most of the Beacon estate was built in the early part of the last century to house the 3,000 employees of Falmouth's once thriving docks, which now employ only 300 casual workers. Hidden from the tourist, who could see only the surrounding splendour of the long marina and stunning estuary views, it had five years ago become an island of desolation. A Bristol University study found that, with a population of 6,000 in 1,500 homes, Beacon was the largest and poorest estate in Cornwall.

In 1995, eight out of 10 men on the estate were out of work. The Penwerris electoral ward, of which it is part, was one of the poorest localities in Europe. A comparison with 132 other wards in the south-west showed that Penwerris had the highest number of poor households, the highest proportion of children in households with no wage-earners and the second-highest number of lone parents. More than 50% of homes lacked central heating. Cold, damp homes meant childhood asthma, and other respiratory-related problems were commonplace.

"The estate was sinking into ghetto status," recalls Hazel Stutely, one of the health visitors. "The place was a virtual no-go area for the police. Social services cutbacks meant there was no hands-on help for people. The number of child protection referrals just kept increasing, more and more people were suffering from mental health problems, there was lots of domestic violence and lots of crime and harassment. My colleague and I thought if we did not try and reverse the spiral, we would have another Toxteth on our hands."

What followed was a meeting between Stutely, with her colleague Philip Trenoweth, and the local police, education officials, and representatives from Carrick district council. Residents were urged to confront their "enemies" over tea and biscuits at a series of meetings attended by officials from the council and the police.

The result was the birth of Penwerris Tenants' and Residents' Association - and a successful bid for £2.2m of government capital challenge funding for central heating and energy efficiency measures throughout the estate. Subsequently, the Beacon Community Regeneration Partnership was set up - a multi-agency group, led by the tenants.

The results are now there for all to see. The low-rise blocks on Old Hill are now painted in vibrant colours, all chosen by the tenants who want to re-name it Rainbow Hill. The grim terraces are no longer grey, but have been transformed by bright cladding. Recladding and energy conservation measures have been carried out on 900 properties and 300 homes now have central heating. Increased security street lighting has dramatically reduced vandalism. There is now a neighbourhood watch scheme and regular liaison with the police. And a £30,000 grant has just been won for landscaping across the estate.

At the top of Old Hill, next to the baker's, an empty shop has been converted into Beacon Energy Action Office, which offers housing advice and carries a Jobcentre vacancies board while acting as a neighbourhood meeting room. Just a few hundred yards away on the edge of the estate, a former dog salon is being transformed into Beacon Care Centre. Residents have asked for physiotherapy sessions, over-65 health checks, advice on contraceptives and a breast-feeding support group to be held at the centre when it opens early next year.

But, as Graham Whitfield, chairman of the community regeneration partnership, notes, it is not just the fabric of the estate that has changed. There has been a rebirth of community spirit.

"The estate is just buzzing," he says. "We've had garden competitions, luncheon clubs, baby shows and coach trips - the most recent being a week in Blackpool. We put on a variety show to celebrate the millennium and had a community fun day. We also organised a bungee jump on the estate and we are working together to raise money for a skateboard park."

A parent-and-toddler group meets every week. Mothers have been encouraged to train as crèche leaders in a twin attempt to improve their employment prospects and broaden their parenting skills.

Basic computing skills have also been taught. Both courses were held at the Falmouth Tavern - a local pub which has a children's ball pool, allowing youngsters to play while their mothers study.

Bob Meers, police community liaison officer for the past two years, says the regeneration project has restored a sense of pride in the community. "Old Hill used to be a place the police avoided. There was a lack of communication - an us and them approach. Now we are working with housing officers and tenants to do all we can to make people feel safe. If children misbehave, families are warned they could face eviction."

Richard Carter, headmaster of Beacon junior school, says the dramatic improvements in the housing stock appear to have lead to happier, healthier children who are beginning to work to their potential. For Stutely, the work goes on. She is now on secondment to the Department of Health, preparing to teach others about health-led community development. But her desire to help the community remains undiminished. "We haven't created Disneyworld," she says. "There is still much to be done.

She has since moved into permanent accommodation elsewhere with her two children, aged three and 20 months, but she still recalls: "I arrived on the estate when things were already happening. I took the children to the mothers' and toddlers' group, which was great for them and a fantastic help for me in meeting people.

"I've also trained as a crèche leader and done a computer course. It was held at the pub and the children were able to play while I studied. I really enjoyed it and now help at a local playgroup."

She describes her short time on the estate as "very happy", and she still keeps in touch.
fields.bodyText: The Beacon and Old Hill estate used to be viewed by police as an "open prison" where families warred over drugs, mothers fought each other at the school gates, pets were tortured and six-year-old boys were found drunk in the streets. Yet today, MPs will visit what has since become a model of neighbourhood regeneration. The estate, then made up of long, dense rows of grey terrace houses and drab, low-rise flats clinging to the side of a hill in Falmouth, Cornwall, was a classic dumping ground for the disadvantaged and families with problems. Largely abandoned by the statutory agencies, police and social workers marked it down as one of the county's worst trouble spots. But five years later, after a pioneering and award-winning initiative, the Beacon is a thriving community. So much so that today, members of the Commons health select committee are making a fact-finding visit as part of an inquiry into public health. The source of the success has been the determination of a handful of residents, with the support of two dedicated health visitors, and local teachers, police and housing officers. Other key factors include a programme of energy conservation measures and a range of modest community projects. The reforms have produced some impressive changes in the downtrodden residents and their families. Since 1995, the crime rate on the estate has halved, with 87% of those in the community now saying they feel safe. The number of children on the child protection register has fallen from 23 in 1995 to four in 1999. And the number of mothers with post-natal depression has dropped over the same period from 18 to four. Children's exam results have improved dramatically: among 10 and 11-year-old boys, numbers achieving level four in national tests at key stage two have doubled. The number of childhood accidents has also fallen 50%. Last year, the estate's regeneration project became part of an NHS "beacon" network for its innovation and good practice. And those behind it have won a government Nye Bevan award for excellence. Most of the Beacon estate was built in the early part of the last century to house the 3,000 employees of Falmouth's once thriving docks, which now employ only 300 casual workers. Hidden from the tourist, who could see only the surrounding splendour of the long marina and stunning estuary views, it had five years ago become an island of desolation. A Bristol University study found that, with a population of 6,000 in 1,500 homes, Beacon was the largest and poorest estate in Cornwall. In 1995, eight out of 10 men on the estate were out of work. The Penwerris electoral ward, of which it is part, was one of the poorest localities in Europe. A comparison with 132 other wards in the south-west showed that Penwerris had the highest number of poor households, the highest proportion of children in households with no wage-earners and the second-highest number of lone parents. What followed was a meeting between Stutely, with her colleague Philip Trenoweth, and the local police, education officials, and representatives from Carrick district council. Residents were urged to confront their "enemies" over tea and biscuits at a series of meetings attended by officials from the council and the police. The grim terraces are no longer grey, but have been transformed by bright cladding. Recladding and energy conservation measures have been carried out on 900 properties and 300 homes now have central heating. Increased security street lighting has dramatically reduced vandalism. There is now a neighbourhood watch scheme and regular liaison with the police. And a £30,000 grant has just been won for landscaping across the estate. "The estate is just buzzing," he says. "We've had garden competitions, luncheon clubs, baby shows and coach trips - the most recent being a week in Blackpool. fields.headline: Work break
fields.standfirst: Brokers offer job link to the disabled
fields.trailText: A national network of "job brokers" will be set up to offer people with disabilities support and guidance to find work.
fields.body:
A national network of "job brokers" will be set up to offer people on incapacity benefits support and guidance to find paid work, the government announced this week as it extended nationwide the New Deal for disabled people.

Unlike other New Deal projects, the scheme is aimed as much at changing the attitude of employers as persuading disabled people to apply themselves to seek jobs.

A prospectus encouraging the private and voluntary sectors to get involved has been published by Margaret Hodge, minister for disabled people. She says 2.8m disabled people of working age are locked into dependency on benefi, but surveys show 1m of them want to work and 400,000 could start jobs tomorrow if the government unlocked barriers by changing employers' preconceptions.

Successful pilots of the scheme have included 50 disabled people taken on by gas company Centrica in its Manchester call centre. Hodge says one was profoundly deaf, and had been out of work for five years, yet his productivity was found to be double the average for the centre. Colleagues have volunteered to learn sign language.

The Eastern Valleys pilot in Wales helped some 750 long-term sick and disabled people back into work, including a man on incapacity benefit for five years, after a spinal injury, who gained a PSV driver licence and a job with a bus company.

Hugh Bayley, the social security minister, says: "We have well-motivated disabled people who want to work and well-motivated employers who want to hire them. Now we want job brokers to bring them together."

Invitation to tender documents for companies and voluntary groups interested in delivering the scheme will be available from November 27 on the New Deal for disabled people website via a link from http//:www.disability.gov.uk.

fields.headline: Peaks of performance
fields.standfirst: Derby and Derbyshire councils urge caution over performance results
fields.trailText: Derby and Derbyshire councils urge caution over performance results.
fields.body:
You might think they'd be feeling pretty pleased with themselves at the social services headquarters of Derby and Derbyshire councils. After all, the two authorities have been identified as two of the three best in England in the government's latest social care performance indicators. But officials - and elected members - at the two councils are conspicuously reluctant to gloat. While quietly satisfied with their results, they are only too well aware of the limitations of the indicators as evidence of good practice - and of their sometimes double-edged nature.

"These results are obviously very gratifying, but the concept of doing well in social services is complex," says Margaret McGlade, Derby's director of social services. "For instance, staff can be satisfied that they are doing their best in particular circumstances, which is more important to them than having their efforts measured by an indicator. An appreciation of the broader picture is essential, because individual indicators only measure one particular thing on a particular day."

The Department of Health's second annual performance assessment framework findings, published last month, measured all 150 English social services departments against 37 indicators. Both Derby and Derbyshire were found to provide services of an "acceptable," "good" or "very good" quality on 30 of the 37 measures. The only other authority to do so was Redbridge, east London.

Derby was deemed to require urgent investigation of services in two areas: the timing of child protection reviews, and provision of statements of needs for elderly and disabled people and those with learning difficulties. Changes have already been made.

"We identified these areas last year," McGlade says. "But it takes time to turn things around, and some services are harder to change than others. What must also be taken into account is the problem of staff recruitment, both locally and nationally. The budget for social care is under pressure everywhere, and insufficient numbers are being trained."

Bruce Buckley, director of social services for Derbyshire, believes that, generally, league tables are "pleasing for staff, as they can highlight the good work that is done, work which is often hidden and doesn't receive the recognition it deserves". But, he adds: "They can't tell the whole story."

A case in point is the issue of fostering children in care under age 10. An authority can score highly if a certain number are successfully fostered; or that figure can be judged too high - some children perhaps having been fostered when they might have been adopted - and the authority's practices will be viewed less favourably.

The education of children in care - considered in need of major improvement in both authorities, as across the country - can be equally problematic when it comes to measuring performance. "Monitoring a child's progress is difficult," says Buckley. "In some cases, the fact that exams are actually being considered, and then taken, is suc cess in itself. But the stability of the child in care will influence this."

Karl Reid, who chairs the social services stewards' committee of Unison, the public services union, views performance indicators as evidence of a prevailing league table culture, which is not always necessarily helpful. "As a school governor," he says, "I am aware of the pressure they can bring to bear on people. Perspective can be lost when too much attention is paid to apparent under-achievement. Indicators would tell us more if they were used in the right context."

Distortion may also arise when comparing the performance of one authority with that of another - which league tables inevitably invite. Reid says: "Assessing the success or otherwise of an authority in a deprived area requires different criteria to be applied."

More straightforward is the significant improvement over the last year in Derbyshire's care for the elderly service, which has enabled more people to live independently at home. And the reason is simple.

"The increase in government funding has made a big difference," says Andrew Milroy, community social services manager for north-east Derbyshire. "This has meant greater stability and allowed us to work more efficiently with local NHS trusts. Because of the change in attitude and policy, primary health care has improved, as has recognition of our value to the elderly. More people are living longer, and now we can plan the development of our services with more confidence."

As executive member with responsibility for social care and health on Derby council, Lonny Wilsoncroft says the results of all performance indicators "should be explored in more detail, in order to see what we can learn from them". It is a view echoed by Buckley. "They are a step in the right direction," he says, "and, as such, a guide which we can use to ask questions of ourselves."

webTitle: Bush has 300 vote lead after Florida recount

fields.headline: Bush has 300 vote lead after Florida recount
fields.standfirst:
Special report: US elections 2000
More states to finish count
fields.trailText: Florida's top elections official announced on Tuesday night that Governor George Bush holds a 300 vote lead  over Al Gore based on US presidential vote returns submitted by all 67 of the state's counties.
fields.body:
Florida's top elections official announced on Tuesday night that Governor George Bush holds a 300 vote lead over Al Gore based on US presidential vote returns submitted by all 67 of the state's counties.

One week after the election, Florida's Republican secretary of state Katherine Harris said Mr Bush had 2,910,492 votes to Mr Gore's 2,910,192 - a difference of 300 votes out of 6m cast. An unknown additional number of overseas absentee ballots remain to be counted by Friday night, she added.

Although all 67 Florida counties filed final vote tallies with the state by the 5pm (2200 GMT) deadline, three counties - Palm Beach, Broward and Miami-Dade - informed Ms Harris that they might amend their vote totals on the basis of manual hand recounts requested by the Gore campaign.

Ms Harris has asked for a written statement from the three counties by 2pm on Wednesday "of the facts and circumstances that would cause these counties to believe that a change should be made" to the state vote count before it is finalised. Ms Harris said she would then decide whether to accept the counties' revised vote totals on the basis of their arguments. If not, after the overseas absentee ballots are counted, a final state vote count could be released on Saturday.

Ms Harris declined to field questions from reporters, acting, she said, on the advice of lawyers.

The Gore campaign responded swiftly to the announcement. "Several counties are proceeding to count their votes and the secretary of state should meet her responsibility to accept those votes before she certifies the election," said Gore campaign chairman Doug Hattaway.

Meanwhile, five other states had close votes, forcing county-by-county examinations of the totals and raising the possibility of other recounts.

 New Mexico: Gore leads by 375 votes out of more than 571,000 cast. Gore regained the lead Tuesday after picking up 500 votes in Dona Ana County, where officials had misread an absentee total. Election workers misread a 620-absentee total for Gore in one precinct, mistaking the figure to be 120.

 Wisconsin: Gore leads by 5,385 votes out of 2.5 million cast. Officials in heavily Democratic Milwaukee County were investigating a number of reports of questionable voting, including allegations that at least 174 Marquette University students voted multiple times.

 Iowa: Gore leads by 4,048 votes out of nearly 1.3 million cast. County officials continued to count absentee votes and ballots that were challenged on Election Day, a process that was set to conclude next Tuesday.

 Oregon: Gore leads by 4,233 votes out of nearly 1.4 million cast. Gore's margin was shaved Tuesday as officials continued counting the state's mail-in ballots. About 10,000 ballots were left to be counted, and officials expect to be finished by the weekend.

 New Hampshire: Bush leads by 7,211 out of more than 578,000 votes cast. A review of votes on Monday found proofreading and computer errors, which trimmed Bush's lead by 958 votes. But this result is expected to be final.

webTitle: Mirror tipster given date for tribunal

fields.headline: Mirror tipster given date for tribunal
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Anil Bhoyrul, one of the share-tipping City Slickers sacked from the Mirror, has been given a tribunal date to pursue a compensation claim against the paper.
fields.body:
Anil Bhoyrul, one of the share-tipping City Slickers sacked from the Mirror, has been given a tribunal date to pursue a compensation claim against the paper.

Mr Bhoyrul, who is claiming wrongful dismissal, has been given a hearing date at the industrial tribunal centre in Stratford, east London, on February 13 - almost a year after his sacking. Mr Bhoyrul and co-columnist James Hipwell were fired after it emerged that they were dealing in shares they subsequently tipped. Mr Bhoyrul is understood to have traded in about 20 shares while at the newspaper.

His lawyers intend to argue that his dismissal was unfair because the share dealings were done with the knowledge of Mirror editor Piers Morgan. David Price of David Price & Co said: "Dismissal for gross misconduct happens when there has been a fundamental breach of trust, but we will argue that everything Anil did was known of and had approval from Piers Morgan."

Mr Morgan has failed to shake off the controversy surrounding the acquisition of shares in Viglen Technology the day before the company was tipped by the Slickers. He has maintained that the decision to buy the shares was a coincidence and he was subsequently cleared of any wrong doing by an internal inquiry. The Department of Trade is investigating share dealing at the newspaper.

A Trinity Mirror spokesman said the group would offer a robust defence. "We held a full and thorough investigation and nothing new has come forward to change our minds."

webTitle: Owzat! The presidential election that just isn't cricket

fields.headline: Owzat! The presidential election that just isn't cricket
fields.standfirst: The US has never understood cricket. Perhaps now, the election saga bowls them a googly, Duncan Campbell suggests that they might understand the game a deal better
fields.trailText: The US has never understood cricket. Perhaps now, the election saga bowls them a googly, Duncan Campbell suggests that they might understand the game a deal better.
fields.body:
Most Americans have difficulty understanding the attraction of cricket. How is it possible, they ask, to have a contest that goes on for days and days, is full of arcane rules and odd terms, and does not always produce a winner?

Now, thanks to the presidential election process in Florida, New Mexico and perhaps four other states, they are beginning to understand.

It is a week since people voted - even longer than a Test match - and there have been as many calls for hand ballots as there would be for leg before wickets, there have been pipe-smoking discussions about the importance of 'chads' but still there is no winner.

Since there are no umpires of Dickie Bird's stature to take the bails off the stumps and declare that this is a draw, the logical step is to call for the ultimate umpire, the secretary general of the United Nations, Kofi Annan.

This is exactly what the subversive film-maker Michael Moore has done. He has fired off a letter to Mr Annan with the plea: "Help us! Massive election fraud is taking place in an area that looks like a banana republic - but is actually part of the United States of America!

"We are sitting here helpless as our leaders appear unable to do anything about this stolen election. On behalf of freedom-loving people everywhere, I appeal to the world community and the United Nations for immediate intervention."

Moore, famous for his muck-raking personalised documentaries, has asked Mr Annan to appoint Jimmy Carter to head up an official United Nations team of election observers from Rwanda, Brunei, Bosnia and South Africa and send them to Florida.

He draws Annan's attention to the weird situation in the Daytona Beach area, where the Socialist Workers Party candidate, James Harris, received a whopping 9,888 votes.

"When your observers arrive, they will discover that the socialist revolution in Daytona Beach is running a distant third to drunken college spring breaks and NASCAR racing.

"In fact, you will be hard-pressed to find a single Bolshevik in Daytona Beach, let alone a decent cappuccino."

Declaring that he is hoping for a peaceful solution, Moore continues: "If this kind of thievery were happening in any other part of the world, we would have bombed the crap out of it by now."

As for himself, Moore explains that, as a Nader voter, he is "currently in hiding, fearful for my safety... I am now being hunted down by liberals who, for the first time in years, have finally found something to get angry about.

"Any assistance your people can give ME for safe passage back to Michigan will be greatly appreciated."

So if Michael Moore has to remain in hiding and is therefore unable to make the much-needed documenatry of this extraordinary election, maybe the job should be handed to a feature film director.

fields.bodyText: Most Americans have difficulty understanding the attraction of cricket. How is it possible, they ask, to have a contest that goes on for days and days, is full of arcane rules and odd terms, and does not always produce a winner? Now, thanks to the presidential election process in Florida, New Mexico and perhaps four other states, they are beginning to understand. It is a week since people voted - even longer than a Test match - and there have been as many calls for hand ballots as there would be for leg before wickets, there have been pipe-smoking discussions about the importance of 'chads' but still there is no winner. Since there are no umpires of Dickie Bird's stature to take the bails off the stumps and declare that this is a draw, the logical step is to call for the ultimate umpire, the secretary general of the United Nations, Kofi Annan. This is exactly what the subversive film-maker Michael Moore has done. He has fired off a letter to Mr Annan with the plea: "Help us! Massive election fraud is taking place in an area that looks like a banana republic - but is actually part of the United States of America! "We are sitting here helpless as our leaders appear unable to do anything about this stolen election. On behalf of freedom-loving people everywhere, I appeal to the world community and the United Nations for immediate intervention." Moore, famous for his muck-raking personalised documentaries, has asked Mr Annan to appoint Jimmy Carter to head up an official United Nations team of election observers from Rwanda, Brunei, Bosnia and South Africa and send them to Florida. He draws Annan's attention to the weird situation in the Daytona Beach area, where the Socialist Workers Party candidate, James Harris, received a whopping 9,888 votes. "When your observers arrive, they will discover that the socialist revolution in Daytona Beach is running a distant third to drunken college spring breaks and NASCAR racing. "In fact, you will be hard-pressed to find a single Bolshevik in Daytona Beach, let alone a decent cappuccino." Declaring that he is hoping for a peaceful solution, Moore continues: "If this kind of thievery were happening in any other part of the world, we would have bombed the crap out of it by now." As for himself, Moore explains that, as a Nader voter, he is "currently in hiding, fearful for my safety... I am now being hunted down by liberals who, for the first time in years, have finally found something to get angry about. webTitle: Behind the scenes the mafia pulls the strings

fields.headline: Behind the scenes the mafia pulls the strings
fields.trailText: The Italian mafia have gone quiet, writes Rory Carroll in Milan, and that isn't necessarily a good thing
fields.body:
There have been feuds, jail breakouts and gun battles but, relatively speaking, these are quiet times for the mafia. There have been no assassinated judges, no massacres, no outrageous heists, no challenges to the Italian state.

Trials trundle on, ageing godfathers languish in jail. It seems the battle against organised crime is, if not triumphant, at least going well.

Think again. Lulls suggest two things, say the experts. The mafia is regrouping after a difficult period: consolidating traditional business, exploring new ventures; or, things are going so well that it wants to keep a low profile.

Only when the mafia feels threatened - a crackdown by the state, the squeezing of profits - does it tend to hit the headlines, lashing out in defence of its interests.

According to this analysis, these are happy days for mobsters, a conclusion reinforced by a conference in Milan organised by Confcommerci, Italy's leading retail association.

A report, titled Black Day, said the mafia controls 20% of retail business and 15% of factories, generating around $133bn annually. The implications are huge: one in five shops are mafia shops. Criminal revenue equals 15% of GDP. Combined assets are thought to be enough to pay Italy's national debt. Naturally the taxman does not get a look in.

This river of cash flows mostly from loan-sharking, extortion, prostitution, counterfeiting, drugs and human trafficking. Only Taiwan, South Korea, Thailand and China earned more from fake goods.

"We are sending a message that retailers no longer want to live with illegality. We want the light of hope to shine onto the blackness of the situation," said Sergio Bille, the association's leader.

Enzo Bianco, the justice minister, said more should be done to combat visible crime, such as selling counterfeit goods on streets.

"Local authorities are not doing enough, the are not devoting enough resources to stop these phenomena."

This hidden empire melts into the legitimate economy as the mafia needs to invest - and launder - its revenue by buying into supermarkets, banks, government bonds and internet companies.

Ottaviano Del Turco, the finance minister, asked the Bank of Italy to tighten controls.

"It is a known fact that it doesn't take more than an identification card and 20 minutes to transfer huge sums of cash from a small Italian city to banks in south east Asia, for example."

Milan chief prosecutor Gerardo d'Ambrosio was ambivalent about the retailers' claims.

"I haven't had a single complaint since I took up my post here - these businessmen talk a lot at conferences but not to the Prosecutor's Office."

Are they exaggerating to gain sympathy? Possibly, but there is little doubt about the mafia's resourcefulness. The supergrass system which brought the organisation to its knees in the early 1990s is now being rejected by judges who no longer trust the testimonies of so-called pentiti. Mobsters' morale is said to be improving.

According to a parliamentary report issued last week the mafia controls around 30% of Italy's rubbish disposal companies, including toxic waste, generating $6.66bn annually. The Naples-based Camorra and the Calabrian 'Ndrangheta were believed to be leading this ecomafia.

The Sicily-based Cosa Nostra is diverting time and resources into electronic crime. Last month it was discovered using the internet to try to siphon hundreds of millions of dollars from the Vatican and other banks.

Not all the old ways are being dumped, according to La Stampa. One Cosa Nostra boss is flouting environmentalists and police by grazing his flock of 600 sheep on Biviere natural reserve.

The animals are destroying the fragile ecosystem but park rangers who complain have received death threats. A note tagged to a ewe said: "Think of your daughter, she is little."

webTitle: MyKindaplace boss urges calm after Wowgo collapse

fields.headline: MyKindaplace boss urges calm after Wowgo collapse
fields.standfirst: Nov 14: Wowgo goes under after four months
fields.trailText:
8am: The boss of MyKindaplace, the BSkyB and Freeserve-backed teenage girls website, has called for calm after the collapse of rival site Wowgo, writes Amy Vickers
Nov 14: Wowgo goes under after four months
fields.body:
The boss of MyKindaplace, the BSkyB and Freeserve-backed website for teenage girls, has called for calm after the collapse of rival site Wowgo.

Shaa Wasmund, managing director of MyKindaplace, said there was still a viable online market for teen girls but that it was more important than ever to keep tight control of cash flow.

Ms Wasmund said: "The market is now far more realistic and what's happened to Wowgo is merely a reflection of the internet market.

"There were always going to be fluctuations - you only have to look at the offline magazine market to see that. In six months there's probably going to be another u-turn and everything will be rosy again. It's a vibrant but very competitive sector."

Ms Wasmund said MyKindaplace had taken a long-term view and had enough money to see it through to the end of next year.

The company has recently launched a catalogue that is being covermounted on the January edition of teen magazine Sugar.

Ms Wasmund said this was an interim solution to tie MyKindaplace over in e-commerce revenues until teenage e-commerce kicked off in two years' time.

MyKindaplace claims to have had 1.4m page impressions in October.

fields.headline: Rowland wins Sunny Delight account
fields.trailText: 8an: PR agency Rowland Communications has won the difficult task of defending Procter & Gamble's Sunny Delight brand before a sceptical UK press. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
PR agency Rowland Communications has won the difficult task of defending Procter & Gamble's Sunny Delight brand before a sceptical UK press.

The US consumer goods giant hired Rowland to handle the controversial drinks brand after incumbent agency Ketchum resigned the account.

The win gives Rowland a coveted place on the prestigious Procter & Gamble roster, but the agency faces an uphill struggle.

Sales of the children's drink slumped by a quarter earlier in the year after a barrage of negative media coverage contradicted the marketing of Sunny Delight as a healthy alternative to fizzy drinks.

Last December the tabloids had a field day with the story of a five-year-old girl who turned orange after she drank 1.5 litres of Sunny Delight a day.

And a report on BBC consumer programme Watchdog urged parents to take a closer look at what their children were drinking, focusing on Sunny Delight's high sugar content and the fact that it contains only 5% juice.

Rowland Communications is owned by the advertising agency Saatchi & Saatchi.

webTitle: BBC unveils new look Bill and Ben

fields.headline: BBC unveils new look Bill and Ben
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: In the age of Pokemon and Playstation, sticky-backed plastic and flowerpot puppets seem strange choices to launch a new era of children's programmes. But such is their enduring appeal that a made-over Bill and Ben join a revitalised Blue Peter at the heart of the BBC's new line-up for children.
fields.body:
In the age of Pokemon and Playstation, sticky-backed plastic and flowerpot puppets seem strange choices to launch a new era of children's programmes. But such is their enduring appeal that a made-over Bill and Ben join a revitalised Blue Peter at the heart of the BBC's new line-up for children.

Blue Peter is to run all year round, and a remake of the 1960s series starts in January. The corporation is also in talks to produce new versions of Andy Pandy and the Woodentops. "Just because they are old, doesn't mean they are old-fashioned or out of date," said Nigel Pickard, controller of children's programmes.

The BBC yesterday unveiled the new look Flowerpot Men, who owe as much to the latest technology as their basic puppetry roots. Cosgrove Hall, the company behind classic children's television shows such as Dangermouse, developed the new series of 26 episodes, which took a year to make.

Fans of the original series will recognise the two central characters, who still communicate in their barely comprehensible private language. But the producers have added a range of new characters, including Whimsey the spider and Whoops the worm. Weed, Bill and Ben's knowing mother-figure, has lost her mute status and now speaks for herself.

The characters will be voiced by John Thomson, Jimmy Hib bert and Eve Karpf. Plans for toys and other linked merchandise are under way.

New techniques have been used to bring the characters to life. Unlike the originals, the new Bill and Ben are not string puppets, but individual figures who are moved by hand between each shot. The foam latex skin of each figure conceals an intricate metallic skeleton which can be manoeuvred into whatever position is required.

Such is the painstaking de tail in which the creators worked, a crew of four animators produced just 48 seconds of film a day.

BBC chiefs say the remake is long overdue. Alan Yentob, the BBC's director of drama, entertainment and children's programmes, said: "Ask not why, just why so long?"

Mr Pickard, who was behind the massively successful ITV Saturday morning show SM:TV Live, has been poached to lead the BBC's children's output into the digital age. He is pushing forward plans for two new children's channels. The future of Live and Kicking, the BBC's ailing Saturday morning offering, will be reviewed in three months.

He revealed that Blue Peter will lose its 10-week summer break and be screened on BBC1 52 weeks a year, although the total number of editions in a year remains about the same. There will be three editions a week in winter, and two in summer. Newsround, the daily children's news bulletin, moves from its 5pm slot to 5.25pm, making it the final children's BBC programme of the day.

fields.headline: Flamboyant Labour peer quits Carlton to spend more time with his politics
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Lord Waheed Alli, the flamboyant Labour peer who brought the Big Breakfast to British television screens, quit Carlton yesterday after failing to secure a senior position in the broadcaster's new management structure.
fields.body:
Lord Waheed Alli, the flamboyant Labour peer who brought the Big Breakfast to British television screens, quit Carlton yesterday after failing to secure a senior position in the broadcaster's new management structure.

The multi-millionaire TV producer, who spearheaded the successful bid to bring Crossroads back to ITV, wants to concentrate on his political career.

Carlton insisted yesterday that the parting was amicable and long anticipated, but insiders at the London-based broadcaster said he was frozen out this week by a management reshuffle.

Lord Alli was brought in last year when Carlton bought Planet 24, the production company he ran with Charlie Parsons, in a £15m deal. Observers speculated that Carlton wanted a source close to Labour: Lord Alli is a friend of Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, and Tony Blair. He was also hired to boost the quality and quantity of Carlton's in-house programmes. Previously, its biggest asset was the long-running Inspector Morse - the final episode of which is aired tonight.

But Lord Alli's position at Carlton was never comfortable. To the irritation of some Carlton staff, he brought in a number of Labour apparatchiks, and his role as managing director of Carlton productions appeared to overlap with the broadcaster's respected director of programmes, Steve Hewlett.

Carlton said yesterday that Lord Alli had succeeded in building up its production division. His biggest triumphs were the £10m Crossroads commission and the acclaimed remake of the classic children's TV drama, the Railway Children.

There were suggestions that Lord Alli decided to leave when Carlton decided to reorganise its businesses into two sectors. The channel section will include the broadcaster's four ITV franchises and digital TV interests, and will be headed by Clive Jones, the chief executive of Carlton Television. A content division will include Lord Alli's productions department, the international sales section and Planet 24. Its chief executive is yet to be appointed - Lord Alli would have been a front runner.

The peer will not be financially disadvantaged by his departure. When he and Mr Parsons sold Planet 24 they hived off the rights to Survivor, the desert island game show that has taken the US by storm, to a separate company. The show has madethem tens of millions of pounds. Planet 24, which makes the Big Breakfast for Channel 4, will still produce ITV's version of Survivor next year.

Friends of Lord Alli insisted yesterday that he had been planning to leave Carlton since it became clear that Labour was not going to breeze through the next election. One said: "You don't get a peerage for nothing. And Waheed has ambitions to have a more active role in government, so he has got to spend more time on politics. He made a commitment to the government in February and spoke to Michael Green [Carlton's chairman] about this."

Lord Alli would not comment publicly yesterday.

fields.headline: Fuel protest crawls into London
fields.standfirst:
Campaigners' 350 vehicles are enough to produce chaos on key highway

Special report: the fuel crisis
fields.trailText: Campaigners' 350 vehicles are enough to produce chaos on key highway.
fields.body:
John Pratt, treasurer of the People's Fuel Lobby, put on a pinstripe suit and bowler yesterday and climbed on the back of a low-loading trailer in Hyde Park to address some 400 fuel protesters.

"You may think I'm a bit overdressed for a hill farmer from Wales," he said. "But I've got my coffin going up the Mall to Downing street right now and I shall be with it to meet the prime minister."

The pine coffin topped with lilies and draped in a Union flag travelled along the Embankment in a Land Rover belonging to Farmers for Action, closely followed by a tractor, lorry and combine harvester.

Six protesters against the fuel tax, including a haulier's daughter, a farmer's son and a pensioner, delivered a letter to Tony Blair in the final gesture of a go-slow convoy which over five days had travelled 350 miles from Gateshead in Tyne and Wear.

They also delivered a wreath - to show, they said, the protest was "not about the death of an industry, it was about all the farmers who had taken their own lives in desperation at the plight of farming today".

The final leg of the convoy had left Scratchwood truck stop near Edgware, north London, at 10am, having grown from 16 vehicles to nearly 100 overnight. Protesters also drove into London from Kent, Oldham, Luton and the south-west of England to make the total about 350 vehicles.

At 12mph, the Gateshead contingent took two hours to drive along the North Circular and Western avenue, stopping traffic at roundabouts and, at one stage, swelling to three lanes. On board the 22nd vehicle in the line - a coach of 30 Northumberland farmers - the mood was buoyant. All had blockaded the oil refineries at Jarrow last September. Banners on the coach read: "Truck Off Gordon Brown".

At midday, the convoy parked on the Westway flyover, one of west London's main arteries, causing traffic chaos. About 50 protesters marched from there to Hyde Park, where they met the leaders of the People's Fuel Lobby standing with Union flags and microphones on the back of a trailer in front of a crowd of some 300. Most were veterans of September's protest. Pensioners who had travelled by Underground and mainline trains, with anti-fuel tax slogans written on the back of envelopes, joined the protest, as did a number of mothers who had brought their children.

David Handley, chairman of the People's Fuel Lobby, took the microphone to warn: "We will be back in the new year." He added that more blockades in January were not ruled out.

Then he publicly stood down as head of the People's Fuel Lobby, saying he had to concentrate on saving his flagging family business. The position remains vacant.

Protesters' spokesman Andrew Spence said he was "over the moon" about the turnout. "Some people said there would only be two lorries or five lorries here - they will now be eating humble pie."

By 4pm, Hyde Park was empty as protesters returned to collect their trucks from the Westway and begin their long journeys home.

Gerard Seenan writes: A convoy of fuel protesters that began as a few lorries leaving John O'Groats three days before got to Edinburgh yesterday.

Although numbers were not as high as organisers predicted, around 80 lorries, coaches and private vehicles slowly made their way up Princes street, the city's main thoroughfare, before leaders handed in a petition at the Scottish parliament. Demonstration organisers had talks with the Scottish environment minister, Sarah Boyack, and pledged not to embark on any more direct action until the spring.

A spokesman for Lothian and Borders police said the protest had caused only minor disruption to rush hour traffic.

Robbie Burns, spokesman for the People's Fuel Lobby Scotland, said he was pleased with the turnout. "People can't afford days off when margins are so tight," he added.

fields.bodyText: John Pratt, treasurer of the People's Fuel Lobby, put on a pinstripe suit and bowler yesterday and climbed on the back of a low-loading trailer in Hyde Park to address some 400 fuel protesters. "You may think I'm a bit overdressed for a hill farmer from Wales," he said. "But I've got my coffin going up the Mall to Downing street right now and I shall be with it to meet the prime minister." The pine coffin topped with lilies and draped in a Union flag travelled along the Embankment in a Land Rover belonging to Farmers for Action, closely followed by a tractor, lorry and combine harvester. Six protesters against the fuel tax, including a haulier's daughter, a farmer's son and a pensioner, delivered a letter to Tony Blair in the final gesture of a go-slow convoy which over five days had travelled 350 miles from Gateshead in Tyne and Wear. They also delivered a wreath - to show, they said, the protest was "not about the death of an industry, it was about all the farmers who had taken their own lives in desperation at the plight of farming today". The final leg of the convoy had left Scratchwood truck stop near Edgware, north London, at 10am, having grown from 16 vehicles to nearly 100 overnight. Protesters also drove into London from Kent, Oldham, Luton and the south-west of England to make the total about 350 vehicles. At 12mph, the Gateshead contingent took two hours to drive along the North Circular and Western avenue, stopping traffic at roundabouts and, at one stage, swelling to three lanes. On board the 22nd vehicle in the line - a coach of 30 Northumberland farmers - the mood was buoyant. All had blockaded the oil refineries at Jarrow last September. Banners on the coach read: "Truck Off Gordon Brown". At midday, the convoy parked on the Westway flyover, one of west London's main arteries, causing traffic chaos. About 50 protesters marched from there to Hyde Park, where they met the leaders of the People's Fuel Lobby standing with Union flags and microphones on the back of a trailer in front of a crowd of some 300. Most were veterans of September's protest. Pensioners who had travelled by Underground and mainline trains, with anti-fuel tax slogans written on the back of envelopes, joined the protest, as did a number of mothers who had brought their children. David Handley, chairman of the People's Fuel Lobby, took the microphone to warn: "We will be back in the new year." He added that more blockades in January were not ruled out. Then he publicly stood down as head of the People's Fuel Lobby, saying he had to concentrate on saving his flagging family business. The position remains vacant. Protesters' spokesman Andrew Spence said he was "over the moon" about the turnout. "Some people said there would only be two lorries or five lorries here - they will now be eating humble pie." By 4pm, Hyde Park was empty as protesters returned to collect their trucks from the Westway and begin their long journeys home. Gerard Seenan writes: A convoy of fuel protesters that began as a few lorries leaving John O'Groats three days before got to Edinburgh yesterday. Although numbers were not as high as organisers predicted, around 80 lorries, coaches and private vehicles slowly made their way up Princes street, the city's main thoroughfare, before leaders handed in a petition at the Scottish parliament. Demonstration organisers had talks with the Scottish environment minister, Sarah Boyack, and pledged not to embark on any more direct action until the spring. A spokesman for Lothian and Borders police said the protest had caused only minor disruption to rush hour traffic. Robbie Burns, spokesman for the People's Fuel Lobby Scotland, said he was pleased with the turnout. "People can't afford days off when margins are so tight," he added. webTitle: How IT can change the way we deliver public services

fields.headline: How IT can change the way we deliver public services
fields.standfirst: Tony Blair has committed the government to an electronic revolution of its care programme by 2005. Is this realistic?
fields.trailText: Can IT really change the way we deliver public services?  Michael Cross reports.
fields.body:
Here's an idea for relieving this winter's inevitable NHS bed crisis: don't put patients in intensive care after their operations - send them home. It's already happening in the US. Diann Martin, a community nurse at the University of Chicago, says that discharge within 24 hours of serious surgery is now routine, with home care taking the place of hospital. "We're doing things at home that five years ago were done in intensive care," Martin told a recent conference in London.

What makes this possible is the emerging technology of "telecare". In Chicago, wound-care specialists monitor patients' progress over the internet. An electronic device in their home collects data such as blood-pressure and respiratory rate and takes regular snapshots of the wound. If all goes well, the rest of the patient's care can be done during a daily visit by a community nurse.

Home care is the fastest growing sector of America's trillion dollar health industry. It's easy to see why: a day in hospital intensive care costs an insurance company $2,500, says Martin, but a visit by a district nurse is $100, and a routine "teleconsultation" is $35.

Telecare is also coming - somewhat patchily - to the NHS. Since summer last year, the North Manchester primary care group has cut average waiting time for a dermatology appointment from 18 months to 17 days with teleconsultations. Nurses working for a specialist contractor visit GP surgeries, photograph patients' skin ailments with a digital camera and store electronic images on their laptops for downloading to specialist dermatologists who can decide which patients need further treatment. It may not be comparable to what is happening in the US, but it is a start.

Providing targeted medical advice over the internet is about the highest level yet of what the government calls the electronic delivery of public services. Tony Blair has committed the government to delivering 100% of government services electronically by 2005 - two years later than the target in the US.

At one level, the British target is patently absurd. Whatever advances take place in computer technology between now and 2005, it will not be possible to deliver meals on wheels down the internet. But because it is a prime ministerial target, it has to be met. The Cabinet Office has even counted how many individual government services there are (457 of them) and is ticking off those that are delivered electronically. The suspiciously precise figure so far is one-third.

The snag is that the further you go from the Cabinet Office and the closer to the front line of delivering public services, the less confident people are about delivering services electronically. A survey by Mori for BT found that, in central government, more than 77% of officials were confident they would reach the 2005 target. In health and local government, however, barely more than a quarter were confident - and most were not.

Malcolm Wylie, head of IT at Cambridge city council, says the picture is more subtle. "Technically, if we just set out to put the tick in the box, we could do it within a year. But to get the real benefits is much more difficult. The jury's still out."

But on the front line of care, IT is beginning to make a difference. The key is where it allows the joining up of services. One example is Suffolk social services, which has developed an electronic customer record on computer, allowing care professionals to call up a complete history of their clients.

Joan Miller, Suffolk's head of information management, says that, as with the telecare example, the technology can cut demand for hospital beds. "In the case of a request for an older person needing help, the system would say if they already have a home care service. Our professionals can make a better decision on that basis, and maybe avoid a hospital admission."

But running an electronic customer record is a major undertaking. Persuading staff to change from pen to keyboard "has taken a long time", Miller admits. And that's only the beginning of the process, as care workers need to change the whole way they work. Computers force care workers to enter records consistently and in a structured form - a good thing for generating management information, but a new skill that has to be learned.

And in some cases, a computer is out of place. Miller says: "A social worker's job is talking to people. In some cases, technology will get in the way." In highly emotional circumstances, the last thing a worker wants is to pull out a laptop.

Part of the problem is that today's portable computers are too heavy, run down their batteries too quickly and are too attractive to muggers. Even the IT industry admits that the right gizmo isn't there yet. "It's all to do with size and convenience," says Alan Jones, of CSW Health, a company specialising in electronic health record systems. The solution, he believes, is a palmtop computer with web access, just coming on to the market in the US. "We're three or four months behind," says Jones.

Three other obstacles lie in the way of the government's vision of joined-up electronic service delivery.

 Confidentiality. For health and social care, the next challenge is to join up health records - currently held by GPs - with social care records, held by local authorities. This enters a minefield of questions about confidentiality and access. The Department of Health has published a consultation document, Information for Social Care, which suggests solutions to some of the issues. Consultation is open until December 15.

 Reliability. Public sector IT projects are notorious for turning into disasters. The latest to go off the rails is the probation service's £100m case recording system, which is being abandoned after only 16 out of 54 probation services took it up. Another project which has gone awry recently is "government gateway". This is supposed to be the system which joins together separate local government and health databases, while ensuring that only the right people have access. The system is due to be up and running in 2001. But in October, talks with the prime contractor, Compaq, broke down and a successor has yet to be found.

 Resources. In September, Tony Blair promised £1bn funding for electronic government as part of his "UK online" initiative. Local government will get £350m. Few on the front line regard this as generous. Local government is "90% of government's face to most people", says Chris Haynes, head of the information society programme at Knowsley council, Merseyside, one of the pioneering local authorities in IT. And at Suffolk, Miller says that experience shows the real problem is not the cost of computers, but of training. For every £1 spent on IT, twice as much again goes into training and new procedures for staff.

"The 2005 target is a nonsense," concludes Haynes. "Our real target is getting people in the community to benefit from the e-society."

 Michael Cross is news editor of www.kablenet.com Information for Social Care is at www.doh.gov.uk/scg/information.htm

webTitle: Nervous Britain rejects call to elect EU president

fields.headline: Nervous Britain rejects call to elect EU president
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Germany's foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, injected passion and controversy back into the European debate yesterday with a call for future presidents of the European commission to be directly elected, to help the EU attain greater democratic legitimacy.
fields.body:
Germany's foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, injected passion and controversy back into the European debate yesterday with a call for future presidents of the European commission to be directly elected, to help the EU attain greater democratic legitimacy.

Though such an idea is not on the agenda for next month's EU summit in Nice, British ministers are sufficiently nervous of a tabloid-driven public relations disaster at the summit that Downing Street quickly slapped down the "hypothetical" suggestion which has no official status, even in Germany.

In a pointer to Tony Blair's thinking, No 10's deputy spokesman referred approvingly to "the primacy of the council of ministers" - the elected leaders of the 15 EU states who currently dominate the union's proceedings, rather than the commission, whose president is appointed.

Speaking in the Belgian parliament, Mr Fischer - a hate figure for British eurosceptics because of his avowed federalism - argued that it is already necessary to look beyond Nice to answer the big questions about the EU's ultimate destination.

"Everywhere on our continent there is a desire to resume reflection on the merits and objectives of integration rather than the mechanisms of treaties or the size and shape of European cucumbers," he said.

German officials said he intended the Brussels address to resume the debate about the future of the EU, following major speeches by the French president, Jacques Chirac, in the summer and Mr Blair in Warsaw last month.

Mr Fischer himself invoked "a European parliament and a European government which really do exercise power" in a speech in May. Yesterday's remarks prompted the Tory foreign affairs spokesman, Francis Maude, to insist that "the agenda to build an EU superstate is alive and well".

Mr Blair and fellow EU leaders are currently entering the endgame of a more mundane agenda: the highly complex negotiations which will culminate in a new treaty at Nice.

Diplomats predict a cliffhanging finish to a limited but difficult reform agenda that includes reweighting the votes of the 15 member states and scrapping several national vetos to move to more majority voting. They are needed to help the EU work effectively when it enlarges.

"We are going to accomplish two essential tasks: complete the biggest enlargement in the history of the EU and at the same time set the keystone in the edifice of European integration, that is, political integration," Mr Fischer said. "The essential principle resides in a very clear sharing of sovereignty between Europe and the nation states."

But underlining problems ahead for Mr Blair at Nice, Mr Fischer said Germany was ready to surrender its veto on some aspects of tax and social policy - both of which Britain and several other members insist they will not countenance.

In his previous speech, the German minister put forward the idea of a federal Europe where member states would pool even more of their sovereignty. If states were not prepared to do so, a "core group" of countries should make the first move, to be followed later by the rest.

Mr Chirac followed with a call for a "pioneer group" of leading states, but without a federalist structure. Both Mr Blair and Mr Fischer are proposing a second chamber for the European parliament - consisting of parliamentarians from national parliaments - to help boost the legitimacy of the EU's institutions.

webTitle: How one family became addicted to carbon

fields.headline: How one family became addicted to carbon
fields.standfirst:
As environmental talks continue in the Hague, artist James Marriott examines the influence of his ancestors on the current weather crisis, and looks at the impact on future generations

Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Passing the Keswick family's grand home in rural Surrey, one night in the early years of the 20th century, a villager might have seen an unusual sight through a window - a yellow light flashing on, or a brightly lit room turning black, with equal suddenness.
fields.body:
Passing the Keswick family's grand home in rural Surrey, one night in the early years of the 20th century, a villager might have seen an unusual sight through a window - a yellow light flashing on, or a brightly lit room turning black, with equal suddenness.

This was not the fading and brightening of paraffin lamps, or the softer, yellower gaslight the Keswick family had used to light Eastwick Park in Bookham since 1897, when the Leatherhead Gas Company first piped coal gas to the village.

For the less travelled inhabitants of Bookham, it may have been their first glimpse of electric light. In the countryside, it was a rarity. There was no national grid. If you wanted electricity you had to be wealthy and adventurous enough to put in your own generator - like William Keswick.

For Keswick's great-grandson James Marriott, an artist who has turned his family history into a true saga of the reckless western guzzling of fossil fuels, these years were the beginning of his ancestors' descent into carbon addiction - a path they set out on early because of their wealth, but which we would all follow.

It was a time when the individual choices of millions of people began to influence the climate, when men and women first began to be defined as consumers. Marxists and capitalists alike had a boundless belief in the virtue and inevitability of human progress, and the world seemed to be for taming and using, not protecting.

Marriott's performance-work, Carbon Generations, which is part of an ongoing project by arts group Platform, looks at his family's energy use over four actual and three future generations, inspired by a tradition among Iroquois American Indians that leaders have to consider the impact of decisions on seven generations.

Past and future

"We're always being told in environmental debates that we have to consider the impact of what we do today on generations yet to come," said Marriott. "But if at the same time we don't look at what past generations were doing to get us where we are today, we become lost."

William Keswick, born in 1834, was a trader in the Far East from 1855 to 1886, when the first mass consumer use of a product refined from crude oil - paraffin - was taking off. He returned to England by coal-powered steamship, a journey lasting several weeks, and settled at Eastwick Park, a rambling Georgian pile.

The house was occupied by the Keswick family and half a dozen live-in servants. Before the oil age, energy for hot water, cooking and heating rooms was supplied by coal. Travel was by horsepower and coal-powered train.

How much coal the Keswick household used is hard to estimate, but James Marriott has worked out that another of his great-grandparents, Charles Marriott, had 25 fireplaces in his Leicestershire home, of which an average of eight were used daily, giving a figure of eight tonnes of coal a year.

For the energy released, coal is a more potent source of carbon emissions than oil. If the Keswick family members had replaced coal power with oil power, they would have generated less carbon dioxide than before. Instead, they kept using coal, and began consuming oil as well.

Not long before the Keswicks went electric, they acquired the family's first car, a Cadillac. Their chauffeur was responsible for running the generator as well as the car. After all, they both ran on oil.

An early picture of William Keswick's Cadillac can be fixed in time - 1906 ,when Keswick won an election in Epsom. He died six years later. His fourth daughter, Kay, was born in 1904. She was James Marriot's great-aunt, and grew up into a more energy-rich world than her parents.

With the launch of the National Grid in 1926, electric lights and household appliances such as radios became commonplace; huge coal and oil-fired power stations supplied the growing electrical demands of consumers and industry.

Electric-powered industry was cleaner than its steam-powered predecessor, but because it was producing more consumer goods for the ever more affluent world, the overall carbon emissions were greater.

Meanwhile, the west's love affair with the car grew apace. When Kay Keswick passed her driving test in 1925, at the age of 21, and bought a Citroën for £150, her horizons broadened dramatically.

"At every stage of her life, oil was one of the underpinnings of her freedom," said Marriott. "The freedom of driving in London in the 1920s, the freedom to travel by car through France and Italy in the 1930s.

"Oil underpinned the means by which she served her country - driving an army canteen in East Anglia, in north Africa, Italy and liberated Germany. She continued to drive until she was 92."

Kay Keswick's niece, James Marriott's mother, Sally Coles, was born in 1937; Richard Marriott, his father, in 1930. Theirs was the generation that saw the dying of the coal industry in Britain, the end of the train's dominance of the mass transit market, and the explosive growth of consumer electrics in the home.

In 1962, a year before James, their second son, was born the Marriotts, then living in West Sussex, abandoned coal fires and installed oil-fired central heating. This should have meant a big cut in the family's carbon emissions, but because of their increased car use and appetite for consumer goods, their overall carbon use was greater.

They used electricity for cooking, but since the electricity was made by coal-fired power stations, their carbon emissions were simply transferred higher up the distribution tree. Although they acquired a Kenwood mixer in the 1950s, it was the 1960s that saw the electricity bill shoot up: they bought a washing machine, a record player, a television, a fridge and a tumble dryer. In the 1970s, they acquired a tape recorder and a freezer.

James Marriott's generation lives a paradox - it is the first to feel guilt and a degree of fear about the consequences of what reckless burning of fossil fuels is doing to the climate, and the first to take long-distance air travel for granted.

Trips abroad

He first flew in 1965, from Gatwick to Malta. Since then he has flown to Munich, Zurich, Barcelona, Pisa, Paris, New York (twice), Hong Kong, Beijing, Tokyo, Tel Aviv, Cairo, Amman, Malaga, Warsaw, Delhi, Kathmandu, Trabzon, Prague and Venice - a distance, at a rough estimate, in excess of 100,000 miles. That's the equivalent of around 8.5 tonnes of carbon.

His 18 childhood return trips from Sussex to the family cottage in the Highlands would have used another 1.8 tonnes.

A dedicated environmental activist, the younger Marriott, together with his partner, Jane Trowell, are trying to live the carbon-light life, but it is far from easy. They don't have a fridge, saving about 30kg (66lb) of carbon a year over their parents' generation. But they do have a personal computer, which uses 4kg a year for every hour of daily use. They don't have a car. But instead of oil-fired central heating or the more efficient gas, they use a wood-fired stove for heat and hot water.

Wood produces even more carbon dioxide per kilo than coal. On the other hand, it comes from a local, renewable source. But Marriott knows it's not the answer. "It's an elite game," he admits. "Not everyone can get their energy from wood. Otherwise we'd need a forest bigger than Britain."

Marriott and Trowell might have children, yet looking forward to the next three generations, they are anxious about the burden of carbon cutbacks they will inherit - according to one estimate, the average British household will need to cut back its current carbon output of 25 tonnes by 90% by 2040.

"I don't have a car or a fridge, but daily I utilise hydrocarbons in a myriad of unconscious ways," he said. "Can I imagine doing my work without a phone or a computer? Will it come to that?"

He fears he may have no choice, and compares the future upheaval to that faced by his great-great-grandparents, who emigrated to Newfoundland from Scotland with little in the way of baggage.

"The sixth generation begins in 2020, the seventh in 2050," he said. "All predictions suggest that it is the sixth generation that faces the largest challenges. Or rather that if we don't face up to our challenges now, and make changes now, the sixth generation will have to make drastic changes in order to avoid catastrophe in the seventh."

Marriott's performance-work, Carbon Generations, which is part of an ongoing project by arts group Platform, looks at his family's energy use over four actual and three future generations, inspired by a tradition among Iroquois American Indians that leaders have to consider the impact of decisions on seven generations. Past and future "We're always being told in environmental debates that we have to consider the impact of what we do today on generations yet to come," said Marriott. "But if at the same time we don't look at what past generations were doing to get us where we are today, we become lost." William Keswick, born in 1834, was a trader in the Far East from 1855 to 1886, when the first mass consumer use of a product refined from crude oil - paraffin - was taking off. He returned to England by coal-powered steamship, a journey lasting several weeks, and settled at Eastwick Park, a rambling Georgian pile. The house was occupied by the Keswick family and half a dozen live-in servants. Before the oil age, energy for hot water, cooking and heating rooms was supplied by coal. Travel was by horsepower and coal-powered train. How much coal the Keswick household used is hard to estimate, but James Marriott has worked out that another of his great-grandparents, Charles Marriott, had 25 fireplaces in his Leicestershire home, of which an average of eight were used daily, giving a figure of eight tonnes of coal a year. For the energy released, coal is a more potent source of carbon emissions than oil. If the Keswick family members had replaced coal power with oil power, they would have generated less carbon dioxide than before. Instead, they kept using coal, and began consuming oil as well. Not long before the Keswicks went electric, they acquired the family's first car, a Cadillac. Their chauffeur was responsible for running the generator as well as the car. After all, they both ran on oil. An early picture of William Keswick's Cadillac can be fixed in time - 1906 ,when Keswick won an election in Epsom. He died six years later. His fourth daughter, Kay, was born in 1904. She was James Marriot's great-aunt, and grew up into a more energy-rich world than her parents. With the launch of the National Grid in 1926, electric lights and household appliances such as radios became commonplace; huge coal and oil-fired power stations supplied the growing electrical demands of consumers and industry. Electric-powered industry was cleaner than its steam-powered predecessor, but because it was producing more consumer goods for the ever more affluent world, the overall carbon emissions were greater. Meanwhile, the west's love affair with the car grew apace. When Kay Keswick passed her driving test in 1925, at the age of 21, and bought a Citroën for £150, her horizons broadened dramatically. "At every stage of her life, oil was one of the underpinnings of her freedom," said Marriott. "The freedom of driving in London in the 1920s, the freedom to travel by car through France and Italy in the 1930s. "Oil underpinned the means by which she served her country - driving an army canteen in East Anglia, in north Africa, Italy and liberated Germany. She continued to drive until she was 92." Kay Keswick's niece, James Marriott's mother, Sally Coles, was born in 1937; Richard Marriott, his father, in 1930. Theirs was the generation that saw the dying of the coal industry in Britain, the end of the train's dominance of the mass transit market, and the explosive growth of consumer electrics in the home. In 1962, a year before James, their second son, was born the Marriotts, then living in West Sussex, abandoned coal fires and installed oil-fired central heating. This should have meant a big cut in the family's carbon emissions, but because of their increased car use and appetite for consumer goods, their overall carbon use was greater. They used electricity for cooking, but since the electricity was made by coal-fired power stations, their carbon emissions were simply transferred higher up the distribution tree. Although they acquired a Kenwood mixer in the 1950s, it was the 1960s that saw the electricity bill shoot up: they bought a washing machine, a record player, a television, a fridge and a tumble dryer. In the 1970s, they acquired a tape recorder and a freezer. James Marriott's generation lives a paradox - it is the first to feel guilt and a degree of fear about the consequences of what reckless burning of fossil fuels is doing to the climate, and the first to take long-distance air travel for granted. Trips abroad He first flew in 1965, from Gatwick to Malta. Since then he has flown to Munich, Zurich, Barcelona, Pisa, Paris, New York (twice), Hong Kong, Beijing, Tokyo, Tel Aviv, Cairo, Amman, Malaga, Warsaw, Delhi, Kathmandu, Trabzon, Prague and Venice - a distance, at a rough estimate, in excess of 100,000 miles. That's the equivalent of around 8.5 tonnes of carbon. His 18 childhood return trips from Sussex to the family cottage in the Highlands would have used another 1.8 tonnes. A dedicated environmental activist, the younger Marriott, together with his partner, Jane Trowell, are trying to live the carbon-light life, but it is far from easy. They don't have a fridge, saving about 30kg (66lb) of carbon a year over their parents' generation. But they do have a personal computer, which uses 4kg a year for every hour of daily use. They don't have a car. But instead of oil-fired central heating or the more efficient gas, they use a wood-fired stove for heat and hot water. Wood produces even more carbon dioxide per kilo than coal. On the other hand, it comes from a local, renewable source. But Marriott knows it's not the answer. "It's an elite game," he admits. "Not everyone can get their energy from wood. Otherwise we'd need a forest bigger than Britain." Marriott and Trowell might have children, yet looking forward to the next three generations, they are anxious about the burden of carbon cutbacks they will inherit - according to one estimate, the average British household will need to cut back its current carbon output of 25 tonnes by 90% by 2040. "I don't have a car or a fridge, but daily I utilise hydrocarbons in a myriad of unconscious ways," he said. "Can I imagine doing my work without a phone or a computer? Will it come to that?" He fears he may have no choice, and compares the future upheaval to that faced by his great-great-grandparents, who emigrated to Newfoundland from Scotland with little in the way of baggage. "The sixth generation begins in 2020, the seventh in 2050," he said. "All predictions suggest that it is the sixth generation that faces the largest challenges. Or rather that if we don't face up to our challenges now, and make changes now, the sixth generation will have to make drastic changes in order to avoid catastrophe in the seventh." • Carbon Generations is part of PLATFORM's ongoing project, 90% Crude.
