webTitle: Evidence piles up against human profligacy

fields.headline: Evidence piles up against human profligacy
fields.standfirst:
Scientists paint a grim picture of global warming in the 21st century

Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: The world is getting warmer, and by the end of the 21st century could have warmed by another 6C, according to research published this month. Warming on such a scale, over so short a time, has no precedent. And climate scientists at the heart of the research are now convinced that human action is to blame for some or most of this warming.
fields.body:
The world is getting warmer, and by the end of the 21st century could have warmed by another 6C, according to research published this month. Warming on such a scale, over so short a time, has no precedent. And climate scientists at the heart of the research are now convinced that human action is to blame for some or most of this warming.

"We are increasingly confident that a substantial proportion of the warming can be attributed to human activity," says Geoff Jenkins, of the Hadley centre for climate prediction at the Meteorological Office.

Climate is a machine, and the sun, the atmosphere, the oceans, the continents, the mountains, the poles and the seasons are its moving parts. Volcanic eruptions that pump tiny dust particles into the stratosphere can lower temperatures dramatically; the 11-year sunspot cycle marks its own little pattern on climate history; changes in the earth's orbit around the sun alter the amount of light received by the earth over periods of 100,000 years or so.

The shape of continents and their position on the globe - all the continents are moving, surely but imperceptibly -played a role in climate history. Once, Antarctica and northern Alaska were forested and populated by dinosaurs. Some think the slow collision of In dia with Asia 60m years ago, creating the Tibetan plateau, precipitating a set of events which led to the massive spread of ice from both poles.

Everywhere climatologists look - at tree ring patterns, fossil successions in rock strata, ocean floor corings, the annual layers of ice in Greenland or Antarctica - they see evidence of dramatic shifts from cold to hot to cold again, associated with carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere. None of these ancient shifts can be blamed on humans, who have only been burning fossil fuels, or grinding up rocks to make cement, or clearing forests on any significant scale for the last 200 years.

There is still room for argument about the precise role of the sun, or other natural cycles, in the contribution to global warming. There has been scoffing by highly vocal groups backed by the US oil and electricity industries, but there has also been dissent from respected academic climate scientists.

Richard Lindzen, a leading meteorologist at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said earlier this year that the picture of consensus about global warming was "misleading to both the public and even to scientists - few of whom have actually worked on the physics of the so-called greenhouse effect".

But most climate scientists have made one thing clear in the last year: they now believe that climate is being influenced by humans. And their diagnosis is grim. How grim is always uncertain, but the uncertainties are being narrowed. In recent weeks, researchers whittled away two of them.

One was that there could be some kind of "feedback" to damp down the rate of warming. More heat would mean more evaporation, and more water vapour would mean more clouds which would reflect sunlight back into space.

But an expert at Nasa's Goddard Institute for Space Studies looked at three years' worth of data about low cloud over land and found no comfort. Warmer air actually meant thinner clouds and therefore a feebler parasol effect. If anything, he said, the prediction by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change of a minimum warming of 1.5C in the next century was too low.

The second unknown was sorted out last week. Scientists reasoned that as carbon dioxide increased in the atmosphere, plants would grow more lustily, forests would benefit and trees would soak up a lot of the extra carbon in the atmosphere.

Scientists from the Hadley centre put every factor they could into computer models and tried to work out what would happen to forests - and the carbon stored in their soils. They figured that as the northern forests warmed, there would be less ice and snow, so less sunlight would be reflected into space, which meant forests would flourish.

But after a while - perhaps around 2050 - the amount of carbon released from the soil by bacteria would be greater than the amount soaked up by the trees, and warming would accelerate.

The most dramatic warming has already been in the Arctic, where the ice pack is shrinking, and thinning: according to one US team, Alaska and northern Eurasia have warmed in the winter months by 6C in 30 years. But the warming is everywhere: a British team has calculated that the greenhouse effect is stronger now than at any time in the past 20m years.

In the past century, the planet has warmed on average by about 0.6C, but the cost - in lives and to economies - of climate related disasters has risen dramatically. Most of this has been because there have been more potential victims, and more economic development, but climate scientists have warned that a warmer world will mean more storms, floods, droughts and snowfalls. And although the rate of warming has so far been slow, it is accelerating.

The growing season in Europe is now 11 days longer than it was 30 years ago. Some bird species are nesting on average 17 days earlier than they did in the 1960s. Six of the 10 warmest years ever were in the 1990s, and the other four were in the 1980s. The US national climate data centre calculates that on the evidence of the past 25 years, the rate of warming has moved to 2C per century.

The answer, climate researchers keep pointing out, is not to hope for a quick "technical fix": some way of disposing of carbon dioxide under pressure in rock caverns or the seabed, or some way of fertilising the oceans to absorb more, or some way of erecting a sunscreen to damp down warming.

The answer is to cut greenhouse gas emissions. But, they warn, even if everybody, everywhere, turned to "green" solar or tidal energy, the world would still be in for a period of warming: another 1C over the next 20 or 30 years. And sea levels, they predict, could go on rising for a century.

Planet in peril

Sea-level rise

•Sea-level predicted to rise by 20cm to 100cm over next century, largely due to thermal expansion (warmer ocean water = greater volume = higher sea level)

•Warmer oceans endanger cold-water fisheries such as North Sea cod fishery (already at risk from over-fishing)

•At least two low-lying (uninhabited) islands in South Pacific have already submerged as a result of sea-level rise

Deforestation

•Substantial dieback of tropical forests and grasslands especially in South America and central Africa

• Vegetation dieback covering an area of 0.5m km2 by 2050s, 3m km2 by 2100

•Biodiversity/plant and animal habitat destruction

•10% loss of wetlands by 2050, in addition to current 1% annual loss to direct human reclamation

• Coral bleaching will increase over 20 to 40 years, eventually leading to death of some major reefs

•Northern and Arctic habitats in Russia, northern Scandinavia and Canada seriously at risk, affecting walrus, polar bears, caribou

•Central American cloud forest (unique habitat) ecology already being damaged by drier conditions

Research by Rebecca Spencer and Leah Whitcher

webTitle: Children lead the way for surfing

fields.headline: Children lead the way for surfing
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Children are the fastest growing group using the internet, according to Britain's first full year of web statistics.
fields.body:
Children are the fastest growing group using the internet, according to Britain's first full year of web statistics.

According to MMXI Europe, 3m surfers joined the online population from October 1999 to September 2000. In September, 11m people, a fifth of the population, were using the internet from home, with children taking to the net more rapidly than adults. The agency does not cover usage from the workplace or mobile phones. There has been a rise of 89% in "unique visitors", aged between two and 17, from 1,224,000 in January to 2,312,000 in September.

Mari Kim Coleman, UK managing director of MMXI Europe, said the growth is due the number of sites targeting chil dren, their technical know-how and the rate at which they pass on sites to friends.

Ms Coleman said the sites the age group are attracted to are "much more cutting edge" and offer mainly games, chat and music downloading. The most popular site for 12 to 17-year olds is another.com which provides services such as email, while the favourite site for two to 14-year-olds is MSN.com, the entertainment and information portal.

The research shows men in Britain continue to use the internet more than women, but women have been catching up. In October 1999 34.9% of women used the internet at home, compared with 54.4% of men. In September 2000 the percentage had increased to 36.1% for women and fallen to 49.2% for men.

webTitle: Letsbuyit.com seeks aid from traditional sector

fields.headline: Letsbuyit.com seeks aid from traditional sector
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Letsbuyit.com, the online retailer, yesterday said it was looking for a strategic partner to provide it with funding until it reached profitability at the end of 2002.
fields.body:
Letsbuyit.com, the online retailer, yesterday said it was looking for a strategic partner to provide it with funding until it reached profitability at the end of 2002.

The company indicated that a traditional "bricks and mortar" company would be an ideal partner because it would give Letsbuyit the ability to provide consumers with all channels of distribution.

Martin Coles, chief executive of Letsbuyit.com, said the combination would bring in cash from other sources and bring profitability nearer.

Mr Coles said: "We definitely will be looking for cash, we're talking to people right now about the potential for investment.

"We'd be looking around the €80m mark (£48m)."

The company, which brings together buyers to place a bulk order for a particular product in order to press down prices, has €51m, which is enough to take it through to the middle of next year.

The company reported a 28% increase in turnover in the quarter, from €7.2m to €9.3m, and a reduction in losses.

Losses fell from €42m in the previous quarter to €26m for this quarter. Sales and marketing costs were down by 69%.

webTitle: Extra addresses will push internet into new domain

fields.headline: Extra addresses will push internet into new domain
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Net regulators in California are poised to approve a new batch of web address suffixes to add more permutations to the fast-dwindling stock of dot.com addresses.
fields.body:
Net regulators in California are poised to approve a new batch of web address suffixes to add more permutations to the fast-dwindling stock of dot.com addresses.

Up to 44 new "top-level domains" are being considered by the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (Icann), including .biz, .health, .travel, .xxx and .kids. Generic suffixes for personal web pages, including .per and .nom, may also be introduced.

Experts say the move, similar to creating new telephone dialling codes, is needed to increase the capacity of the domain name system despite fears that new suffixes could trigger a fresh outbreak of cybersquatting, as speculators snap up well-known addresses with new suffixes to sell on for huge profits.

Pam Brewster, at Icann, stressed that a limited number of domain names would be introduced "in a responsible manner". The Icann board is expected to approve between three and 20 top-level domain names at a conference in California tomorrow.

Ms Brewster said there are a variety of reasons for introducing new names. "Some people say all the good names are taken so we need more," she said. "Some people want more domains to add more competition and diversity to the domain name system. It could also make it easier to find what you are looking for on the internet."

The internet's naming system, featuring dot.com, .org and .net, alongside country codes such as .uk and .fr, has remained unchanged since its inception in the mid-1980s..

Numerous public figures, including Madonna, Jeanette Winterson and George W Bush, have fought cybersquatters for colonising their names on the net. Despite tough new US anti-cybersquatting laws, the global reach of the internet has made it difficult to prosecute websites which infringe upon registered trademarks.

To deter cybersquatting on the new suffixes, Icann may initiate a "sunrise" early registration period, during which only trademark owners can buy names with the new endings.

The price of internet "real estate" has been driven up by firms competing for the dwindling number of prestigious dot.com addresses. Legal experts hope that increasing the supply of potential names may dissuade speculative squatters.

"If we have .biz as well as dot.com that should considerably reduce the extent to which cybersquatting is lucrative, but without in any way removing it," said Professor Graham Greenleaf from the University of New South Wales's faculty of law.

New top-level domain names could also be used to regulate porn. If adult websites carry a .xxx suffix filtering software could more easily identify pornographic material, and prevent children accessing it. Although Icann suggested it was premature to release the naming convention before the ability to force the net porn industry to adopt it.

Firms who sell registered domain names stand to make the most from the reforms, as those with a dot.com address rush to re-register their name.

Internet registration firms are playing down the potential boom, however.

"I think it will make an impact but not a huge one," said Pablo Kleckin of Domain Names Australia. "Anybody who thinks a new whizz-bang three-letter suffix is going to outdo a dot.com is not really being realistic. The dot.com is still the holy grail of the domain names. If you can get a sexy name in a dot.com you've got a licence to go global with your business."

fields.headline: Ellison trashes Microsoft
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: the future of Microsoft
fields.trailText: Larry Ellison, the multibillionaire chairman and chief executive of Oracle Corporation, mounted a sustained and sometimes humorous attack on Microsoft during his speech at the Comdex computer trade show in Las Vegas.
fields.body:
Larry Ellison, the multibillionaire chairman and chief executive of Oracle Corporation, mounted a sustained and sometimes humorous attack on Microsoft during his speech at the Comdex computer trade show in Las Vegas.

Mr Ellison, head of the world's largest supplier of computer database software, launched his first attack on Microsoft in Paris in 1995, when he said the PC was a "ridiculous" device that would be replaced by the simplified "network computer".

Microsoft, based in Redmond, responded recently by trumpeting the fact that its much cheaper Sequel Server database outperformed Oracle in an industry-standard banking benchmark test called TPC-C. Mr Ellison claimed Oracle performed better with typical applications and was more reliable.

"They're telling everyone Microsoft is very fast, albeit only for one application, and not for very long. We'll pay you $1m if we don't triple the performance of any Microsoft website [with Oracle 9i], except for running TPC-C," a clearly irritated Mr Ellison told the audience.

Both companies have increased the level of "trash talking" recently, and Microsoft's chief executive, Steve Ballmer, mocked Mr Ellison before the speech.

"Larry's been talking about ideas that have gone nowhere for years. How long has he been talking about the [network computer]? Six years, seven years? Where did it go? Nowhere," said Mr Ballmer.

Although his attacks on the PC made headlines, Mr Ellison's credibility has been damaged by the commercial failure of numerous alternative "network computers" and "information appliances" while PC sales have continued to grow to about 140m a year.

According to US research company International Data Corporation only 11m information appliances were sold in 1999, and almost two thirds of those were handhelds such as Palm electronic organisers.

Mr Ellison said that he had modified his views, and he was now in favour of standard configurations of all types of computer, large or small.

"It's a fundamental mistake the computer industry has made to only do custom configurations," said Mr Ellison.

Although users liked to choose their own hardware and software, this made every computer unique, and there were too many variations for anyone to test properly.

The war of words between Oracle and Microsoft looks likely to continue. Microsoft staff handed out mugs before Ellison's talk which were printed with instructions for negotiating discounts, such as: "When Oracle salesman pitches $5m of overpriced software, glance down at mug."

fields.headline: Beef on the bone off the menu as Jospin bows to French fears
fields.standfirst:
The French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, bowed to mounting public panic and the populist savvy of President Jacques Chirac yesterday by banning beef on the bone and suspending the use of animal-based meal in all livestock feed.

Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: The French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, bowed to mounting public panic and the populist savvy of President Jacques Chirac yesterday by banning beef on the bone and suspending the use of animal-based meal in all livestock feed.
fields.body:
The French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, bowed to mounting public panic and the populist savvy of President Jacques Chirac yesterday by banning beef on the bone and suspending the use of animal-based meal in all livestock feed.

Among a raft of measures aimed at calming consumer fears over mad cow disease, Mr Jospin also announced random tests on cattle entering the food chain and a tripling of funds for research into BSE, linked to the fatal brainwasting ailment in humans, new variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.

"The government has decided to suspend the use of meat and bone meal in feed for pigs, chickens, fish as well as domestic animals," the prime minister said. "This temporary and general ban appears technically possible and acceptable from a public health standpoint."

A decision on a permanent ban on animal-based meals, a step taken by Britain in 1996, would be made once the national food safety agency, Afssa, had assessed the possible risk associated with them, he said, probably in about three to four months' time.

Aware that the drastic new precautions might serve only to fan French fears, Mr Jospin sought to reassure consumers about the spread of BSE and about food safety in general, saying there was "no scientific proof at present to suggest that eating beef or drinking milk poses a health risk".

But he added that cote de boeuf and several other prized French cuts of beef were being banned because the infectious agent that causes BSE could exist in the bone that comes with them, despite government precautions.

Beef sales have plunged by as much as 50% in France and school meal services throughout the country have withdrawn the suspect meat from canteen menus since it emerged last month that several large supermarket chains had unknowingly sold potentially infected cuts.

Consumer concern has been further fuelled by a sharp increase in the number of cattle found to have been suffering from mad cow disease, which under a more thorough and systematic screening system has jumped from 31 in all of 1999 to more than 90 so far this year.

According to a poll published this weekend in the Journal du Dimanche, 70% of the French are worried about animal-based feeds, which were banned for cattle in France in 1990, and nearly 80% want an immediate ban.

Most French cases of BSE have been traced to "cross-contamination" - cattle that have been fed, either deliberately or accidentally, with animal-based meals intended for livestock like pigs or chickens.

The moratorium on the use of meat and bone meal marks a political defeat for the prime minister, who described the panic gripping French con sumers as "a national psychosis" and favoured what he termed the "more calm and rational approach" of waiting for Afssa's expert opinion before taking such a drastic step.

Last week he underlined the major problem of banning the materials, saying France would be forced to incinerate three times as many animal carcasses as it does now: the pollutants like dioxin that entered the atmosphere as a result would represent a more serious health hazard than the original feed, he said.

But Mr Jospin was outmanoeuvred by Mr Chirac, who grasped perfectly the mood of the French public last week and, to the prime minister's fury, publicly demanded an immediate ban on animal-based meals. The Green party and the Communists, both members of the ruling Socialist-led coalition, subsequently joined the call, leaving Mr Jospin no choice.

The decision is not without consequences. France produces around 430,000 tonnes of meat and bone meal each year, and French newspapers put the cost of banning the products at between £300m and £500m. Some 870,000 tonnes of feed will have to be stocked and incinerated, and France will need to increase dramatically its imports of soy to replace the banned protein-rich products.

Mr Jospin said Paris would also ask the European commission in Brussels to examine how domestic output of oilseeds and other sources of vegetable protein could be boosted.

That, however, could risk triggering a new trade row with the United States by violating the 1992 Blair House accords, which limit the amount of oilseeds the European Union is allowed to plant.

webTitle: QC rejects media gag over killers

fields.headline: QC rejects media gag over killers
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Bulger case
fields.trailText: Rather than ban newspapers from identifying Jon Venables and Robert Thompson, the courts should prosecute people who threaten them, a QC suggested at the high court yesterday.
fields.body:
Rather than ban newspapers from identifying Jon Venables and Robert Thompson, the courts should prosecute people who threaten them, a QC suggested at the high court yesterday.

Representatives of the teenagers who killed the two-year-old James Bulger and who may soon be released from their secure units, have asked the president of the family division, Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, to grant a lifelong injunction barring publicity about them.

But Desmond Browne QC, representing various newspapers, opposing the application, yesterday said: "If there truly is a threat to the boys then the court should direct its powers against those responsible for the threats, not create a judge-made exception to the law of freedom of expression."

Following a ruling by the lord chief justice, Lord Woolf, saying the 18-year-olds had now served the minimum tariff necessary under their life sentences, Thompson and Venables hope to win parole and be given new identities by early next year.

Mr Justice Morland granted an interim injunction in July barring the media from taking or publishing photographs or reporting on their progress. Yesterday, Edward Fitzgerald QC, representing Venables, told the court that it was the duty of the state to protect the teenagers, and that their right to freedom from persecution took precedence over the media's right to freedom of expression. But Mr Browne said that the arguments for lifelong injunctions "are robbed of their force when one appreciates they are uttered in the context of attempts to restrain freedom of expression".

Mr Browne said that if, for example, one of the teenagers were found near a primary school, then publication of the details would be justified. "It would be quite wrong for a restraint to be in existence that would prevent publication."

He added: "This case is of some importance because it is not simply a one-off. Doubtless it would be applied if Myra Hindley is released." A lifelong injunction could set a precedent. "It immediately strikes one as a paradox that the more detestable the crime the greater the claim would be to anon ymity. That cannot be right."

Open justice and the public's "overriding right to know the identities of those who committed serious and detestable crimes would be imperilled", he said. Serious crime would then become a "passport to anonymity".

The hearing continues today.

webTitle: Minister urges action to combat 'winners circle' in south-east

fields.headline: Minister urges action to combat 'winners circle' in south-east
fields.standfirst: Special report: north-south divide
fields.trailText: The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, will today challenge Tony Blair's official line of playing down the north-south divide by warning that rising prosperity in the south-east is failing to spread to old manufacturing heartlands.
fields.body:
The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, will today challenge Tony Blair's official line of playing down the north-south divide by warning that rising prosperity in the south-east is failing to spread to old manufacturing heartlands.

He will tell a regional conference in the City of London that analysis of the government's own statistics indicates that a "winners circle" is emerging in the home counties and East Anglia with other regions slipping further behind.

Calling for a "radical regional policy" to tackle north-south imbalances Mr Byers will warn that "simply tinkering at the edges" will no longer be enough to bring areas like the north-east and north-west up to the national average.

His remarks will be interpreted by some as a direct challenge to the prime minis ter who has been at pains to stress that divisions within regions are wider than any north-south divide. Less than two weeks ago in the north-east, speaking alongside Mr Byers, Tony Blair sought to play up the region's success in creating new jobs.

But the trade secretary, who represents a Tyneside shipbuilding constituency, has recently been strongly supporting backbench Labour MPs who argue that regions like the north-east are suffering at the expense of the south.

Mr Byers will say today that recent figures in his department show that manufacturing businesses invested over 10 times as much in research and development in the south-east than in the north-east.

"Nearly one fifth of people of working age in the north-east and West Midlands have no qualifications at all - compared to just over 11% in the south-east," he plans to say. "These are the underlying causes we need to tackle in regional policy - to widen the 'winners circle' and ensure all regions benefit from rising prosperity."

Older manufacturing regions needed to be renewed. "They were at the heart of the first industrial revolution and we must now ensure that they can play their part in the knowledge based economic revolution which is now taking place."

"Past policies have failed to resolve the underlying weakness of the least successful regions and have failed to capitalise on their strengths."

webTitle: Behind the glamour, a health crisis looms

fields.headline: Behind the glamour, a health crisis looms
fields.standfirst:
Why go-ahead Leeds is to receive the largest share of a package of emergency health funding for inner cities
Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Why go-ahead Leeds is to receive the largest share of a package of emergency health funding for inner cities.
fields.body:
One of Britain's most thriving regional cities is taking stock of a less welcome title this morning as the national blackspot for premature death in both adults and childen.

Used to headlines about glamorous nightlife or the biggest concentration of lawyers outside London, Leeds is to receive the largest share of a £120m government package of emergency health funding for inner cities.

The move is designed to target inequalities in health care masked by overall average figures which make an NHS area look healthy when parts of it are in severe crisis. Leeds is a classic example, with the overall premature death rate the same as nationally, but figures more than twice the average in some central wards.

Central parts of Leeds come ahead of similar areas in Liverpool, Manchester and Teesside in rates of infant mortality and the big adult killers of cancer and coronary heart disease.

The £5m "inequality bonus" for Leeds was welcomed yesterday by the local health authority, which next week debates a local strategy to cut the annual coronary toll of 5,000 deaths.

"We are a very big city and our averages are in line with the country as a whole, but that hides the problems in central wards such as Chapeltown or Harehills," said Liz Scott, the director of public health. "A surprising side of this is that those wards show a very low take-up of health service provision, both in referrals to hospital and the use of modern treatments, like the 'defurring' of arteries."

Much of the £5m is expected to go on better health education in areas like Harehills - a bonus welcomed yesterday in the local Meeting Point cafe, run by the area's Anglican and Methodist churches.

Apart from all-day breakfasts, staff behind the steamed-up windows give informal health advice so efficiently that patients have been informally referred to the cafe by Harehills GPs.

The novel form of health education, which may be copied in similar schemes by the NHS, ranges from networking with social services to practicalities like getting to remote hospitals. Manageress Pauline Burrow cites a pensioner customer with a white stick, finishing his mug of tea, who was given a crucial hand when his wife was admitted to hospital.

"It was right the other side of town but we found out about the NHS Access bus for him, and he's got a weekly lift nicely sorted out," said Pauline, whose waitress colleague Brenda drew on her own experience to give other practical tips.

She said: "I've got high blood pressure which has been monitored very well now for years. But I only found out about it because I was with a group of friends including a trainee nurse who wanted to practice taking blood pressure."

Brenda's mother was less fortunate, dying of a coronary at 69 with her chronic high blood pressure undiagnosed. That sort of lack of regular contact with the health service is thought to be one of the causes of the high premature mortality.

But simply going more often to the GP or Jimmy's - the vast St James's University hospital which dominates Harehills - is not seen in the café as a realistic solution.

"The last time I was in casualty," said one of Brenda's colleagues, "I took my sister and we were there from 10 past five in the evening until five past midnight."

Mike Ramsden, chief executive of Leeds health authority, does not deny the charge - another reason why Leeds needs the inequality bonus. He says: "We're having to tackle the number of people with 12 month waits for major coronary surgery by offering them appointments at a private hospital in Sheffield, paid for by the NHS."

fields.headline: New air traffic revolt looms
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Rebel Labour MPs will tonight join forces with Conservatives and Liberal Democrats in an atempt to thwart the part-privatisation of the national air traffic control system (Nats), despite John Prescott's warning that they will be handing new constitutional powers to a hostile House of Lords.
fields.body:
Rebel Labour MPs will tonight join forces with Conservatives and Liberal Democrats in an atempt to thwart the part-privatisation of the national air traffic control system (Nats), despite John Prescott's warning that they will be handing new constitutional powers to a hostile House of Lords.

Last month a cross-party alliance of peers voted by 119 to 90 to postpone the partial sell-off until after the expected spring election. Mr Prescott believes that would create a precedent for the half-reformed but increasingly assertive Lords to dictate a Labour government's timetable. As the rebel MPs threaten to muster more opposition to the government's bill than the 46 who revolted in May, the deputy prime minister will be fighting both in private and on the floor of the Commons to minimise the revolt. All ministerial leave has been cancelled and potential rebels offered the day off.

The rebels share the Lib Dem view that the sale of 51% of the shares - including 5% to Nats staff - will put profits in conflict with safety, as the crisis of confidence in the privatised railways has underlined.

Mr Prescott remains adamant that his public/private partnership (PPP) model is the answer and will generate the £1.3bn of investment needed in the years ahead as air traffic pressure over Britain intensify.

He is privately angry and astonished that Labour MPs, including his ex-deputy, Gavin Strang - sacked from cabinet in Tony Blair's 1998 reshuffle - are willing to encourage the Lords which defeated the government on one bill six times in a night last month. "John regards this as totally unacceptable. It would strike at the heart of any government's timetable," said one pro-Prescott MP.

As pressure grows on ministers to complete their legislative timetable before the Queen's speech early next month Tory peers believe they can still defeat the government on one major measure due to lack of time.

He is privately angry and astonished that Labour MPs, including his ex-deputy, Gavin Strang - sacked from cabinet in Tony Blair's 1998 reshuffle - are willing to encourage the Lords which defeated the government on one bill six times in a night last month. "John regards this as totally unacceptable. It would strike at the heart of any government's timetable," said one pro-Prescott MP. fields.headline: These are the ministers to blame for the rail scandal
fields.standfirst:
There is no redress against ministerial malpractice on a major scale
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: There is no redress against ministerial malpractice on a major scale
fields.body:
Railtrack this week told its shareholders that "better times are to come". So they raised the dividend for shareholders by 5% (underlying inflation is 2%).

That must have pleasantly surprised them on the day the company warned its profits were down by 31%. With the company near meltdown after Hatfield, the profit warning was only to be expected: £100m extra is being spent on crisis rail repairs, £150m must be paid to train-operating companies in compensation for all the chaos. But no worries, "Better times are to come".

Where are "better times" to come from? There is only one source and every reason for shareholder confidence that it will deliver: the Treasury's 10-year plan for the railways is investing £29bn of public money. Indeed, shareholders might expect continuing rises, for who controls how much of the subsidy given to this leaky bucket drips into dividends?

Not us, says the rail regulator: "That's a matter for a private company. No regulator ever comments on dividends or share prices of a utility." But this utility is different -dependent on state subsidy. Does the shadow strategic rail authority monitor dividends? Not us, they said: "Dividends are a matter for Railtrack alone to decide. You could try the rail regulator ... "No doubt the Treasury keeps an eye, but what sort of Chinese walls allow money pouring in one end to seep out the other?

Another question: which purchasers of Railtrack shares ever thought this company - alone among all Europe's railways systems - was ever going to make money, except via the cash-cow of government subsidy? With train tickets already the highest in the world due to decades of lowest subsidies, higher fares will not provide "better times" for Railtrack shareholders.

As for those train operators who have made money on profitable lines, with no cross-subsidy possible under this chopped-up privatisation, some have been busily reinvesting profits in transport systems abroad, says Transport 2000. So state money leaks from the railways that way too.

Railtrack is now worth £5bn. From 1997 to this March, Labour had already paid out exactly that sum in railway subsidy, with much more to come. So why doesn't the government own it by now - or at least a significant slice of the shares? Why has it got nothing at all for our money? If the exchequer were a bank it would have repossessed this effectively bankrupt business long ago in exchange for its lost cash.

Forget sleaze, forget Aitken's lies and Hamilton's brown envelopes. Of all the scandals that engulfed the Major government, nothing tops the reckless, ideological sale of British Rail. They were drivers who went through a score of red stop signals, feet on the dashboard, swag-bag hanging on the dead man's handle. They were told countless times by their own experts that it could not and would not work - especially in the shambolic form they chose. They pushed it through a month before their deserved demise, leaving this dynamite on the tracks of their successors.

It was a deliberate and wicked piece of political vandalism. Boys putting bricks on the line would be in prison, but they sit on boards: there is no redress against ministerial malpractice. When you ask them, they say they have nothing to apologise for. "No regrets," said Sir George Young yesterday. Same goes for John MacGregor, though he adds in sanguine tones, "Of course we would always have made a few changes as it went along."

What sort of changes? Probably much the same as Labour's - dollops of dosh. The reason Margaret Thatcher wanted to privatise British Rail was the very reason it was impossible - it always required a huge state subsidy. Only absurdist upside-down accounting could ever produce figures that could make it look "private". John Major cannot have believed figures that budgeted for an ever-decreasing state-subsidy, de-escalating year by year: this year, according to their fantasy accounts, subsidy should have dipped well below a billion. Instead, it's up and up.

Back in the mists of time it began with the Adam Smith Institute, the very clever far-right thinktank that devised the poll tax. If John Major was still in power, no doubt recent rail events would have brought him down as surely as the poll tax destroyed Mrs Thatcher. The institute's first clever idea which Mrs Thatcher briefly fancied, was to tear up all the rails and put toll-roads in their place. Ideas puffed up and down the line but rightly got nowhere.

Finally John Major grasped at it, needing a privatisation of his own. His Hovis view of Britain imagined a Hornby railway in the old private liveries of the Great Western and Great Eastern. But market ideology demanded competition, not regional monopoly, so BR was sliced all ways - cut into regions as well as split between track and flotillas of train operators, 150 contracts dispersing accountability like confetti. Who is to blame? All of them - John Major most of all. (Does he write condolences for the fatalities?)

The rails were sold to Railtrack for just £1.93bn, the whole of BR raised only £5bn, a disgracefully low price: they pretended they were getting rid of a liability. Asked yesterday who was to blame for this gross fiscal negligence, those Tories said, amazingly, it was Clare Short's fault. Why? Because as shadow transport minister, she vowed Labour would renationalise it, which depressed its selling price.

Of course, all such talk was stopped dead by pre-election New Labour, afraid of old Labour imagery. Besides, they said, money must be spent on transport renewal, not on compensating shareholders. But did they realise they'd be investing more than 15 times enough for Railtrack to fall back into their hands anyway under normal rules of business, if they wanted it?

For some reason, they don't want it, though the longer they are in office, the more they take the blame anyway for anything that happens on the railway. Voters' memories are short, train delays long. Prudence would take back what is already paid for and put it in a trust, able to borrow money. Train operators can fall back as their franchises expire.

Labour cannot do the same to London Underground. No, they say, it's quite different. Not different enough. The New York subway genius, Robert Kiley, a wise and astute politician, may find a third way face-saver to rescue both Labour and Ken Livingstone. But if Kiley walks away declaring the PPP unworkable, there will be no rescuing Labour.

Imagine the next tube disaster: (they happen roughly every 15 years, it's now year 13.) Labour ministers and 51 London MPs must each take personal responsibility on this. All "privatisation" of publicly financed services - hospitals or trains - makes profit straight from the public purse. The idea that their superior efficiency earns those profits is a fairytale that died at Hatfield.

fields.headline: Stuck down the Tube
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: There is near-unanimity that the world's oldest underground rail system, used by three million people a day, is in a state of collapse, hopelessly managed and in desperate need of large-scale investment. But, outside Whitehall and the corporations queueing up to get their hands on the London Tube, the consensus is almost as broad that John Prescott's "public-private partnership" is likely to prove expensive, bureaucratic and even dangerous.
fields.body:
There is near-unanimity that the world's oldest underground rail system, used by three million people a day, is in a state of collapse, hopelessly managed and in desperate need of large-scale investment. But, outside Whitehall and the corporations queueing up to get their hands on the London Tube, the consensus is almost as broad that John Prescott's "public-private partnership" is likely to prove expensive, bureaucratic and even dangerous.

The government's third way wheeze is to split the underground into three parts and hand over track, signalling and maintenance to private companies on 30-year contracts before mayor Ken Livingstone takes over responsibility for the network next year.

But one transport expert after another has argued that such a spatchcock scheme would fragment the system, rejected government claims that it would effectively transfer risk to the private sector and maintained it would be far cheaper to boost investment by keeping the Tube publicly owned and issuing bonds.

The principal rail safety inspector warned of "growing concern" about the likely impact of the government's plans on safety and Industrial Society director Will Hutton - commissioned to report on the sell-off as a condition of Labour politicians joining Livingstone's mayoral administration - concluded it should be abandoned unless there were major changes.

Last month's Hatfield train crash cemented public conviction that rail privatisation has been a catastrophic failure. Livingstone has meanwhile succeeded in persuading Robert Kiley, the man credited with turning round the New York subway system, to be London's first transport commissioner.

The arrival of a world-class manager with a proven record of using bond finance to transform public transport systems has cut the ground from beneath the government's case. Ministers have long insisted that private- sector expertise is necessary because of London Underground's abject management failures - another one is currently looming, with managers threatening to close down services after 4pm on New Year's Eve - and claimed it would more than compensate for the higher cost of private borrowing.

With Kiley preparing to take over, that is no longer credible. But instead of swallowing hard and listening to his diplomatically framed warnings that the public- private partnership will not work, Prescott has gone on the offensive - refusing Kiley confidential access to the contract bids he would have to implement and blustering: "Commercial information will not be made available to Ken or any guy he brings over from America."

Most bizarrely for a government renowned as the focus groups' slave, it is driving through this discredited policy in the teeth of London opinion. The unions are implacably hostile and last weekend's Greater London Labour party conference voted overwhelmingly to oppose the part-privatisation scheme.

Most Londoners feel the same, according to a Mori poll published yesterday, lining up two to one against the Prescott plan and convinced that the Tube will be less safe, less reliable and worse value for money if it goes ahead. Even the business lobby London First is pressing the government to explore a bond- financed public-sector option. Given that Livingstone was elected mayor on a platform of opposition to the Tube sell-off, maybe it should be no surprise that none of this cuts much ice in New Labour circles.

Tony Blair has always appeared to believe that resistance to the government's privatising plans for the London Underground is simply ideological. But when ministers persist with a scheme rejected by London voters, which sets performance targets 5% below the level currently being achieved, when two of the contractors now bidding against each other, Bombardier and Adtranz, have just agreed a merger, and another, Balfour Beatty, was responsible for track maintenance at Hatfield, it is hard to avoid the conclusion that the ideological bias is more the government's.

Perhaps Blair and Prescott are involved in a poker game with Livingstone, while looking for an elegant way out. There are plenty of possible compromises. The manifesto commitment to a public- private partnership was vague and could easily be accommodated by private consultancies and construction contracts. Contrary to government claims, bond finance could be raised quickly if the current plans were abandoned.

Both the health and safety executive and the national audit office are reviewing the government scheme and could offer lines of retreat. But if ministers refuse to take them, they stand to bequeath chaos to London.

webTitle: Business: East Anglia rail revenues hit

fields.headline: East Anglia rail revenues hit
fields.standfirst:
Operator seeks compensation

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The train operator GB Railways yesterday said it could face cash problems early next year because of falling passenger numbers after the Hatfield tragedy.
fields.body:
The train operator GB Railways yesterday said it could face cash problems early next year because of falling passenger numbers after the Hatfield tragedy.

The company, which runs services from London to East Anglia, said revenues were "significantly below budget" due to the reduced timetables and speed restrictions imposed after last month's crash, in which four people died.

Jeremy Long, GB's chief executive, said that the company would seek compensation from Railtrack as well as from its own insurers. He admitted that it may take many months for customer levels to return to normal.

He said that confidential discussions about the future of the Anglia franchise, which is due to run until 2004, were already under way with the shadow strategic rail authority.

GB is understood to be concerned about the long-term viability of the franchise should passenger numbers be seri ously down in January, although observers say that it is unlikely that the company will walk away from the contract.

According to sources, the talks also include "competition issues" with rival operator Great Eastern, arising from timetable changes on the line to Ipswich.

The SSRA itself is expected to take the opportunity to start renegotiating the Anglia contract as part of its shake-up of rail franchises across the country.

The authority wants to renegotiate within two years more than half of the 25 train operators' franchises, which normally run for seven years, and offer lucrative 20-year terms to the successful bidders.

It had originally planned to initiate discussions with GB some time next year.

In yesterday's statement to the stock market, GB, which refused to clarify the amount of compensation it was seeking, said Anglia Railways had suffered a reduced service, while its new Hull Trains operation had been affected by the temporary closure of the east coast main line between London, Newcastle and Edinburgh.

"It will be some time before the full impact and the longer term effects of this exceptional set of circumstances will be calculable," it read. "In the meantime, the company faces a potential cash shortfall in the new year as a result of continuing current losses."

The news, which industry observers said was expected, went down badly in the City with the company's shares dropping 28p, or 32%, to a year low of 58.5p at last night's close.

One analyst said it had been a tough time for all companies involved in the rail industry and estimated Railtrack will eventually face a compensation bill of around £150m.

"We've been aware there were some companies with cash flow problems and expected GB to be one of them," he said.

GB is next month due to announce its interim results for the six months to September 30.

fields.headline: Biopirates who seek the greatest prizes
fields.standfirst: At the frontier of the gene rush stands a breed of explorer who scours the world for traditional knowledge, then sells it on to the main players
fields.trailText: At the frontier of the gene rush stands a breed of explorer who scours the world for traditional knowledge, then sells it on to the main players
fields.body:
Dr Conrad Gorinsky is an ethnobotanist, prospector, environmentalist and, on his mother's side, a member of the Atorad tribe in Guyana. He stands accused on four continents of being a "biological (or bio-) pirate" - someone who identifies and extracts material from plants for profit.

Earlier this year, having spent months in Amazonia with the Wapishana tribe, he patented a chemical protein of the greenheart tree, one of the most valuable woods in Guyana but one of the most threatened by logging. The nut of the greenheart (Ocotea rodiaei) produces an ingredient called tipir. Gorinsky's description to the US patent office, says this is an antipyretic, capable of preventing the return of diseases like malaria, and useful in treating cancer and perhaps even the Aids virus.

But Tipir's medicinal properties are also well known to the Wapishana who grate the nut and use it to stop haemorrhages, prevent infections, as a contraceptive and to provoke abortions. Gorinsky named the ingredient "rupununine", and has run into a political row and a potential court case. The tribe is furious saying that their knowledge has been stolen. They want the patent rescinded and compensation and are being helped by Brazilian lawyers and northern groups. Gorinsky, who is seeking investors, is unrepentant. "Tough, isn't it?", he says. "I was not the only person looking at the greenheart. I just picked up a nut and said 'what can I do with this?'. I have analysed the chemical structure but I have not patented the tree or a life process. How can I tell the Wapishana about the science? They just inherited the greenheart. They don't own it. I have invested in this with my own money".

But behind Gorinsky marches an army of biotechnology, agricultural, cosmetic and phamaceutical corporations, all linking with northern governments, foundations, universities, institutions, botanical gardens, museums and individuals who don't recognise such a distinction in their bid to seek and patent genes and the proteins that they express. They're known as bioprospectors - or biopirates depending on your point of view.

Gorinsky's defence that he is realising benefits to humankind is countered by critics who argue that stealing knowledge is a question of national sovereignty. The gene rush is speeding up as it is realised that every gene and property of every plant and animal down to the smallest microbe is potentially patentable and thus available for commercial ownership and profit. It has no boundaries and is only limited by people's understanding of the fiendishly complex patent laws. Companies with large legal budgets for patent lawyers often understand it best.

The big prizes, and the first to have been patented, say watchdog groups like Action Aid, Grain and Rafi, are the staple cereal crops with huge global commercial value like rice, maize, wheat, millet, sorghum, soya and cassava. Patent protection by agri-business companies now covers many of their genes and gene sequences, compounds and properties.

Then come the common vegetables like the root crops and brassicas, bushes like cocoa and coffee and fruits. They and plants such as the tomato have all had some or many genes patented and many are near or in commercial production. A third category of potentially massive value are the 35,000 plants believed to have some pharmaceutical value.

The race is led from the front by the US. There the government is subsidising bio-prospecting by awarding large grants to companies like Glaxo-Wellcome, American Cyanamid, and Monsanto. The US National Cancer Institute alone has collected and genetically screened over 50,000 plants and animals samples from plants and micro-organisms in 30 countries. The US army is known to hold gene patents on tropical disease treatments, including a Pacific plant called mamala (Homolanthus acuminatus) widely used in Samoa as a medicine, and micro-organisms which could be used in biological warfare. Meanwhile, drug giant Pfizer wants a deal with the Ecuadorean government for exlusive access to the genetic material of every plant in the botanically super-rich country.

The prospectors have concentrated on the traditional pharmacopia of developing countries. At least 35,000 plants are thought to have medicinal value alone. The companies are finding rich pickings by working with traditional healers. Almost 90 per cent of the plants used by Samoan shamans have displayed significant biological activity when tested. Many have now been patented. Indian researcher Devinder Sharma fears that the whole Ayurvedic traditional base, based on up to 7,000 plants, is being systematically patented.

Despite the fact that patent law insists the invention must be "novel" patents are still being granted on properties which have been well known for generations. For example, the University of Mississippi has US patent no 5,401,504 on turmeric, which Indians have long known can heal wounds faster. There are more than 400 patents, mostly by the giant agro-chemical companies, on Bacillus thuringiensis gene sequences, long known as an insecticide and now the basis of Bt cotton, wheat, maize and potato. Belgium's Plant Genetic Systems has a US patent for "all transgenic plants containing Bt". Meanwhile, the US Mycogen company, owned by Dow, has a European patent covering the insertion of "any insecticidal gene in any plant". Such broad patents, say critics, confer huge market power to the company that wins.

Individual biologists, chemists, and healers are being offered ad hoc payments, but because of outrage in the south, increasingly, compensation agreements are being made with communities and governments. The University of Chicago, the Missouri Botanical Garden and the New York Botanical Garden have all signed "bio-prospecting" agreements. The US National Cancer Institute has signed up with Bangladesh, Costa Rica, Ecuador, Guyana, India, the Philippines, Russia, Tanzania and Zimbabwe. fields.bodyText: Dr Conrad Gorinsky is an ethnobotanist, prospector, environmentalist and, on his mother's side, a member of the Atorad tribe in Guyana. He stands accused on four continents of being a "biological (or bio-) pirate" - someone who identifies and extracts material from plants for profit. Earlier this year, having spent months in Amazonia with the Wapishana tribe, he patented a chemical protein of the greenheart tree, one of the most valuable woods in Guyana but one of the most threatened by logging. The nut of the greenheart (Ocotea rodiaei) produces an ingredient called tipir. Gorinsky's description to the US patent office, says this is an antipyretic, capable of preventing the return of diseases like malaria, and useful in treating cancer and perhaps even the Aids virus. But Tipir's medicinal properties are also well known to the Wapishana who grate the nut and use it to stop haemorrhages, prevent infections, as a contraceptive and to provoke abortions. Gorinsky named the ingredient "rupununine", and has run into a political row and a potential court case. The tribe is furious saying that their knowledge has been stolen. They want the patent rescinded and compensation and are being helped by Brazilian lawyers and northern groups. Gorinsky, who is seeking investors, is unrepentant. "Tough, isn't it?", he says. "I was not the only person looking at the greenheart. I just picked up a nut and said 'what can I do with this?'. fields.headline: Dark and light
fields.standfirst: How biotech firms became trapped in  a battle of  good and evil
fields.trailText: How biotech firms became trapped in a battle of good and evil
fields.body:
Biotechnology entrepreneurs often complain that the public flatly refuses to distinguish between genes, genetics, genomics and genetically engineered tomatoes. The industry feels bruised and misunderstood - it is keen to counter the allegation that everything it does is dangerous and bad. Anxiety about the activities of biotech firms has been fuelled by films such as Mission Impossible 2 - in which Tom Cruise saves the world from a deadly virus unleashed by an evil megalomaniac from an unethical Australian biotech firm.

Andrew Heath, chief executive of a Macclesfield-based biotech firm, Protherics, says: "There is a polarisation of opinion - people either see us as very good or very evil." Protherics specialises in developing antidotes for poisons - it has just developed a new drug to neutralise rattlesnake bites. Heath says: "We have to get in touch with the public, so that people understand not just the risks but the opportunities of biotech."

One of the problems for the industry's image-makers is that that term "biotech" is so vague. It can refer to any biological process, including traditional cheesemaking or beer brewing. The best modern definition is the use of cellular or molecular methods to develop new products. The roots of the multi-billion pound industry lie in the musty Cambridge laboratory where, in 1953, James Watson and Francis Crick discovered the structure of DNA. That opened the door to the manipulation of genetic traits to affect the susceptibility of individuals to disease. A huge amount of research began - academic and commercial - to develop medicines which could directly target the body's governing elements.

It was not until the late 1970s that this groundwork blossomed into genuine commercial endeavour. Among the pioneers of the industry were US firms such as Amgen and Genentech. Government research funding played a major part - in 1980, Celltech became Britain's first biotechnology company, with the National Enterprise Board as its major shareholder. A 1983 American law - the Orphan Drugs Act - further encouraged small start-ups. It gave market exclusivity for a preferential period to drugs tackling relatively rare diseases. With the knowledge that, if successful, they could corner the market for many years, small companies could target niche markets which the bigger pharmaceutical organisations tended to ignore.

There are now 1,283 biotech companies in the US alone, employing 153,000 people, with a total stock market value of $97 billion. Britain has 460 firms, with over 40,000 staff, and the vast majority of them have never made a profit. Financial institutions are only too happy to fund research into new medicines - the rewards can be enormous. For example, the University of Chicago recently calculated the potential economic value of reducing deaths from cancer in the US at $46.5 trillion. Julie Simmonds, a biotech analyst at stockbroker Beeson Gregory, says: "Investors expect these companies to offer high growth - it's about the value they're going to create tomorrow, rather than the losses they're making today." For many smaller firms, just one successful product can be enough to generate years of profit. Simmonds says: "The market is massive providing you can create useful pharmaceuticals - people are always going to spend money on healthcare."

Several "hot" areas of research dominate activity. Many companies are developing ways of reproducing antibodies - the disease-fighting cells produced by the body to stave off illness. One specialist in this area, Cambridge Antibody Technology, has a market value of more than £1.2bn despite having just four drugs in clinical trials. Taking this a step further, a clique of companies including Britain's KS Biomedix are trying to take antibodies from animals, such as sheep, and adapting them for use in humans.

A more controversial area is gene therapy - the science of introducing new, adapted, genes into the body. Oxford Biomedica is a player in this field. An offshoot of this is proteomics - developing therapies to target specific proteins, which are the by-products of genes.

Other hot topics include altering the genetic make-up of animals to produce useful substances. PPL Therapeutics, a spin-off from the Roslin Institute which famously cloned Dolly the Sheep, has altered the genes of lambs to make them produce a lung enzyme in their milk which could be used in treating cystic fibrosis. PPL wants to go several steps further by growing entire human organs in animals - a technique called xenotransplantation. This has attracted considerable opposition because of the risk of diseases specific to animals transferring into humans in transplanted organs.

fields.headline: America holds the cards
fields.standfirst: Ethical unease is not about science - it's about the politics of power
fields.trailText: Ethical unease is not about science - it's about the politics of power
fields.body:
An instinct of revulsion is not a bad place to start an ethical analysis, though it may be a bad place to end. And the patenting of gene sequences is revolting to most people on two grounds: it seems an invasion of personal privacy, and it threatens the sovereignty of almost every country in the world except the US.

The first of these reasons was dramatised last spring by the Donna MacLean, the Bristol poet who applied to patent the whole of her own DNA. Since even the most determined solipsist could hardly claim to be the author of their own genetic material, with its unique mix of DNA from each parent, this is not a scientifically valid approach, but it accurately expresses the unease we feel at the thought some giant company has somehow acquired the rights to exploit parts of our own bodies.

But this unease is economic or political, not biological. The difficult questions raised by gene patenting are practical. They are not questions about who owns the soul of a patented person: even if souls exist, they are not made of DNA any more than people are. What makes these questions so difficult is that there has not been enough practice yet in the field to tell what works, and the decisions which must be made today must, therefore, be based on inadequate information.

The purpose of any patenting regime is to strike a balance between the interests of the inventor, the investor, and the public, so that there is an incentive to produce knowledge and to use it as widely as possible. Whether this incentive actually works with sequences of DNA is a separate question.

Though numerous patents have been granted on particular genes, it is arguable that the chief beneficial effect of patent legislation has been to spur opponents of gene patenting into publishing as much of their work as possible quickly to prevent it being patented by other researchers. This is undoubtedly a benign consequence, but can't be called an intended one.

It should serve as a warning to anyone who thinks that the outcomes of patent legislation can be confidently predicted. Very small technical changes may have huge effects in 20 or 30 years time, just as the technical decisions made by the founders of the Internet when you could fit them all into one room are still influential now the network spans the globe.

Gene patents are particularly complicated because the law involved is international, which means that the parties whose interests it is supposed to balance may not subscribe to the same patent regime at all. If the interests of American investors must be balanced against those of British inventors and Indian consumers there is no body which all sides feel has legitimate authority in these disputes and certainly none which can rise above international political pressure in the way that judges are supposed to do.

American law is felt by the rest of the world to be too biased towards the influence of large corporations; on the other hand, third world countries rip off foreign intellectual property with astonishing zeal and this is not ideal either. In all this, Europe, is uniquely placed as the only large trading bloc which enforces intellectual property laws throught the European Patent Office (EPO) and which is in a political position to balance the interests of all the parties involved.

So it is important that the EPO, which already allows gene patenting, should be careful to keep the scope of these patents as narrow as is necessary to ensure that they don't simply become another instrument for transferring power and money from poor farmers in poor countries to the shareholders in rich biotech companies. American law means that American companies have no choice but to maximise the gains of their shareholders. Those aren't necessarily the interests we want our governments to look after.

One of the troubles with the extension of patenting is that it sets up an arms race. Companies or universities must feel they must patent their discoveries defensively to stop other companies taking advantage if they don't. In the US, they could even be sued by their shareholders if they did so. So it is quite possible that most or all of the patents granted on DNA sequences today will come to nothing. The real problems will come later on, once companies start to patent gene sequences that are nowhere found in nature.

That is when the real dilemmas of gene patenting will emerge in focus, for the problem there is not whether it should be possible to patent a naturally occurring substance like an isolated sequence of naturally occurring DNA. Any conceivable patent law would protect an artificially designed sequence of DNA and the process of inserting it so that it did the job for which it was designed. But if some of the hopes of biotechnology are realised, and such a gene slows down the ageing process, boosts the intelligence of children, or even boosts the production of attractive hormones, the company that patents it could grow rich beyond the dreams of Bill Gates.

Should that matter? The real ethical problems arise from the fact that there is more profit to be made from curing the chronic disease of the rich world than in the simpler and much cheaper work of preventing acute diseases in the third world. The best we can hope from gene patenting is that it should not further skew this balance.

fields.headline: Agribusiness sows its seeds down on  the pharm
fields.trailText: "Biotechnology in drugs is well regulated and well understood. Ag-bio is less so," says Dave Hales, a biotech consultant at Ernst & Young. "It seems to touch a raw nerve with the public much more than biotech on the therapeutic side does."
fields.body:
"Biotechnology in drugs is well regulated and well understood. Ag-bio is less so," says Dave Hales, a biotech consultant at Ernst & Young. "It seems to touch a raw nerve with the public much more than biotech on the therapeutic side does."

What's at stake in the biotechnology revolution is the ability of companies to fiddle with the genetic make-up of seeds to produce crops with stronger attributes such as taste, size, disease resistance or shelf life. This is why companies are applying for patents on the gene sequences of plants, for example identifying the gene which triggers sweetness or increases yield. The gene patent acts as a deterrent to other companies, but is no more than the starting block for research into a genetic modification which could be commercially profitable.

Britain's first experience of a genetically modified product was tomato puree which was developed by Zeneca, the life sciences company which was originally part of the huge chemicals group ICI. Ian Weatherhead, a spokesman for Zeneca Agrochemicals, says: "We adjusted an enzyme in the tomatoes so that they would ripen normally but they softened less readily. It made them firmer, which was a huge bonus for processing."

Gene patents are crucial to the development of such products, claim companies like Zeneca (which is now part of the Anglo-Swedish group AstraZeneca) to prevent competitors from simply copying them. To get the patent granted, it is not enough to identify the gene sequence, there also has to be an "inventive step".

Critics anxious about the power of a handful of western multinationals who dominate ag-bio, contend that the corporations are over-zealous in their patenting and are permitted by lax regulators to obtain protection over crops by adding the simplest of "inventive steps".

Increasingly, what concerns critics of the ag-bio industry is the growing concentration of ownership in the hands of a relatively small number of major companies. Zeneca Agrochemicals is about to be merged with the agricultural arm of the Swiss group Novartis, to form the world's biggest player in food biotechnology, called Syngenta, with worldwide sales of $7.4bn (£5.1bn). This is one of a number of recent deals in the industry, others include Monsanto's merger with the US-Swedish firm Pharmacia & Upjohn.

What's at stake is the expanding global food market. Population growth and economic expansion is driving up demand. The International Food Policy Research Institute expects a 40% rise in demand for grain within 20 years. On top of all that, arable land is becoming increasingly scarce, as towns and cities sprawl out into the countryside, so agrochemicals companies argue that the world has little choice but to examine ways of increasing crop yields.

One of the biggest players in the food market is Monsanto. Originally a chemicals company, it has been involved in agrochemicals for more than 30 years and has some 13,000 employees around the world. Among its first biotechnology products was BST, a hormone injected into cows to make them produce more milk, which remains controversial seven years after its launch. Others heavily involved in patenting crop types include Dow and Du Pont, both big US chemicals corporations with agribusiness arms. Strasbourg-based Aventis is another leader, the company was formed just last year through a merger between German life sciences group Hoechst and France's Rhone-Poulenc.

The most popular area of research is into maize, where a host of corporations are trying to develop insect-resistant and herbicide-tolerant strains. Beyond this, soya beans are a popular target, these are vulnerable to viruses, which could be relatively easy to neutralise through genetic changes. Critics claim that these companies are positioning themselves to monopolise the world's food supply. Not so, claims Professor John Hillman, of the Scottish Crop Research Institute, who claims that the big companies are relatively small players in the global seed supply and points out that, "About 70% of the world seed trade is in the public sector. The other 30% is controlled by 10 multinationals and hundreds of niche players."

Companies privately admit that the debate raging over genetically modified foods has slowed their research over the last few years, in particular, uncertainty over the regulatory approach to be adopted by the European authorities has been damaging to them. Ernst & Young's Dave Hales says the furore has also put off potential investors: "For people to attack trial sites for GM crops must make the industry an unattractive investment. If I was looking for an area to invest in at the moment, I wouldn't go for agricultural biotech." Despite this, the big players in the industry show little sign of scaling down their activities. Monsanto's website quotes former US president Thomas Jefferson, who said: "The greatest service which can be rendered any country is to add a useful plant to its culture."
