webTitle: Patenting life: America bends the rules

fields.headline: How US muscle bent the rules in Europe
fields.standfirst: European patent law is in a mess. But while the biotech industry wants it relaxed, developing countries are looking for a champion
fields.trailText: European patent law is in a mess. But while the biotech industry wants it relaxed, developing countries are looking for a champion
fields.body:
To the outsider, it's one of America's great paradoxes - how widespread belief in the literal truth of the Book of Genesis can coexist with a boundless faith in the ability, and right, of man to interfere with the natural (in Christian terms, God-created) world for short-term gain. From the European perspective, in the GM foods debate, the second faith smothered the first. The US appealed to Europe not to be "irrational". Europe did not listen, and GM foods have, so far, been rejected.

With the patenting of genes, it's a different story. The Byzantine nature of the arguments have kept the public at a distance. The US insistence that it should be possible for companies to patent genes, the essential codes of life, has been eagerly taken up by European business and by some European governments like Britain's. Yet even as one faction within European governments tries to slow down the liberalisation of gene patenting, another is moving to speed it up. A perfect opportunity to thrash out the issues - a once-in-30-years international conference to revise European Patent law in Munich later this month - will not even discuss gene patenting. In an astonishing move, delegates have voted to strike it from the agenda.

How did we get here? For about two centuries after the US won its independence from Britain and Thomas Jefferson drew up its first patent act, the States ring-fenced life forms as something that could not be patented. In 1952, Congress went a step further, declaring that "anything under the sun that is made by man" could be patented. Then, 28 years later, at the dawn of the biotech revolution, the US Supreme Court took the fateful step of endorsing the patenting of life, when it awarded a patent to Ananda Chakrabarty for a bacterium he created in the lab to feed on crude oil.

The huge commercial possibilities in agriculture and medicine opened up by biotechnology advances lagged only a little way behind the IT revolution, and in the US, which led the field, the corporate lobbyists and lawyers staked out their requirements in the 1980s. Their clients - drugs companies, biotech startups, big food companies - wanted 20 years of patent protection on genetically modified animals for use in medical research; on GM plants; on existing animal and plant varieties; on naturally-occurring chemicals in plants; and on human, plant and animal gene sequences. In a series of court judgements, the US Patent and Trademark Office has been forced to concede what they wanted. But it did not satisfy them.

The US biotech lobby and their feisty counterparts across the Atlantic, wanted the same kind of patent protection in Europe and the wider world. After a long struggle with European legislators, they seemed to have succeeded in 1998 with the passage of an EU directive allowing the patenting of genes. A similar lobbying effort went into winning favourable terms for patenters in the World Trade Organisation's Trade-Related Intellectual Property Rights agreement, TRIPS, which came into force across the planet in 1995.

Tony Blair has been an enthusiastic supporter of the patenting of life's components and GM organisms. The prime minister entered his term of office, advised by Lord Sainsbury and Jack Cunningham and encouraged by the US, seeing food and medical bio-technology purely as a business opportunity. British brains and companies should not be left out of this gold rush and be encouraged to exploit it.

Yet western biotech firms are by no means certain to get their way in the long run. The TRIPS agreement, for instance, does not give companies cart blanche to patent genes and bioresources - there are provisions for countries to assert their rights, if their governments can stand up to pressure from the developed world.

Vandana Shiva, the eminent Indian physicist and philospher turned campaigner, has articulated the concerns of millions of small farmers in her home country and across the developing world over biopiracy and crop patenting. She sees a sinister side to the biotech food industry, dominated by US companies, buying up seed companies across continents and, she believes, attempting to control the world food supply. Forget superior weaponry, she says, who controls the food supply controls the world. Shiva sees Europe as critical - a continent with the economic weight and intellectual mood to stand up to America and its own biotech lobbyists and draw the line at the patenting of life, without holding back scientific advances.

Unfortunately, patent law in Europe is a mess. At the centre of the swamp is a largely unaccountable organisation called the European Patent Office, based in Munich. You might assume the EPO was a branch of the European Union. Think again. The EPO is a dinosaur, left over from an earlier age of European cooperation. It issues patents covering 20 European countries - not just the EU. It is headed by a German named Ingo Kober and gets its powers from a treaty called the European Patent Convention. It can issue Euro-wide patents - most US patent holders use it to extend their patents to Europe - and allows patents issued by national patent offices to extend across the continent. It is its own court of appeal. In theory, it is answerable to convention signatories, but in practice, it is left to its own devices.

The EPO's advantage is that a patent it grants is valid in all signatory states, and can be defended in national law. To make this possible, national patent laws have been harmonised. But the biotech lobby was unhappy about the convention's woolly references to "morality" and "public order", unhappy that it didn't specifically allow gene patenting, and even more unhappy that the EPO kept issuing contradictory decisions on biopatents in general. So it began its campaign to get the EU to "clarify" the convention - even though the EU had no right to do so.

Hence the 1998 EU patenting directive, which specifically allowed the patenting of genes. But this left the EPO in an awkward position. Some of the signatories of the convention which had set it up weren't in the EU. Mr Kober decided he would not let this worry him, and asked his administrative council - representatives of the national patent offices - to let him implement it anyway. They agreed. The EPO argues it was acting within its rights. But many legal experts and organisations like German Greenpeace, which have campaigned actively against gene patenting, contend that it breached the terms of the original patent convention.

"The culture and tradition of the EPO is such that they are a law unto themselves," said Professor Deryck Beyleveld, head of the Sheffield Institute of Biotechnological Law and Ethics. As if this wasn't weird enough, a group of EU governments, including the Netherlands, Italy and France, are challenging the legitimacy of the EU directive. Yet the same governments have have agreed to take the issue off the agenda at the vital diplomatic conference set up to renegotiate the convention which takes place in Munich on 20-29 November.

Biotech lobbyists and European patent officials are working in a public attention vacuum, with national governments divided within themselves over the patent issue and only a handful of organisations, like German Greenpeace, trying to raise the alarm. "They seem to operate on the assumption that it doesn't really matter what the law says, as long as you can get away with it," said Prof Beyleveld. His colleague, Dr Margaret Llewelyn, speculated that a struggle might have begun between the EPO and Brussels to prove to the biotech industry who could be the best guardian of their interests. Who, then, will guard our interests? "It's getting almost to a war situation between the EPO and the EU," said Dr Llewelyn. "This is the start of what could be quite a bloody battle."

fields.headline: The top patenters in food
fields.trailText: Dow
fields.body:
Maize

1 Dow (US, including its subsidiary Agrigenetics) has applied for patents on 655 maize gene sequences, which is 30.3% of the total number of applications so far

2 Du Pont (US) has applied for 587, 26.9% of the total

3 Affymetrix (US) has applied for 418 (19.2%)

4 Monsanto (US) claims 102 sequences (4.7%)

5 AstraZeneca (UK) has 83 (3.8%)

The top 5 maize patenters have 84.9% of the total of 2,181 applications between them

Potato

1 Ribozyme (US) has applied for patents on 796 potato gene sequences (71.7%)

2 Monsanto (US) 62 (5.6%)

3 Danisco (Denmark) 40 (3.6%)

4 AstraZeneca (UK) 36 (3.2%%)

5 National Starch (Anglo-US) 24 (2.2%)

The top 5 potato patenters have 85.7% of the 1,110 current applications between them

Wheat

1 Du Pont (US) has applied for patents on 117 wheat gene sequences, which is 40.6% of all applications

2 Monsanto (US) has 78 (27.1%)

3 Aventis (France) has 14 (4.9%)

4 Novartis (Switzerland) 12 (4.2%)

5 CSIRO (Australia) 8 (2.8%)

The top 5 wheat patenters have 79.6% of the total (288) between them

fields.headline: The primary patents
fields.standfirst: 9,364 patents relating to the human  body have been filed for so far.   The applications made cover 126,672 genes or partial sequences. Here are some of them
fields.trailText: 9,364 patents relating to the human body have been filed for so far. The applications made cover 126,672 genes or partial sequences. Here are some of them
fields.body:
TCP-1, 2, and 3
It's a matter of taste but for what?
These genes, involved in taste buds on the human tongue, were patented by the prolific researchers of the University of California last year, although their application warns that the US government, which part-funded the research, also has an interest. The potential for commercialisation of the mechanics of human taste - which distinguishes between salt, sweet, sour, bitter and unami, the taste of monosodium glutamate - seems immense. However, the 'inventors' do not specify what practical use their 'invention' could be put to.

DRD2
Rewards and pleasures in the mind
Sometimes popularly known as an 'alchoholism' gene, DRD2 encodes for an important chemical sequence involved in the chain of rewards and pleasures in the brain. Research suggests that certain mutations of DRD2 make individuals more likely to become alcoholic, and an application granted in 1990 to the University of California and the University of Texas System gives them the patent on the gene's mutant link to 'compulsive disorders'. Scientists believe flaws in the gene may be responsible for much more than alcoholism - it has been linked to cocaine abuse, obesity, smoking and gambling.

KIM
Exploiting the potential of self-repair
When kidneys are damaged, they have a powerful natural ability to repair themselves. One of the genes involved in this repair process has been isolated and patented by Biogen, a firm based in Cambridge, Massachusetts. The discovery of the gene and the protein it produces could be enormously valuable in treating kidney disease and injury. The patent application is typically broad, covering a huge range of potential uses for the gene, most if not all of which are potential rather than actual.

The work by scientists at Biogen - which claims to be the world's oldest independent biotech company - could and probably will one day help kidney patients. But will their proprietorial hold on the KIM gene promote or hinder the enormous task of turning hope into reality?

BCRA2
Searching for a predisposition to cancer
One of two genes where certain mutations give women a predisposition to develop breast cancer. The gene patent has been granted in the US to the Utah firm Myriad Genetics, but the UK Patent Office has given a patent for the same gene to the commercial arm of the Cancer Research charity and its US partner, Duke University.

It is not clear how this dispute will be resolved, although Myriad is in talks with the Department of Health about using its breast cancer genetic test in Britain. Although the patent holders have made the link between the mutant version of the gene and breast cancer, they do not know what the function of the non-mutant version is - yet they could still stake a claim to its exploitation when that function is discovered.

Unnamed
The gene that encourages growth
A Japanese firm called Sumimo Metal Industries has been granted a worldwide patent on an unnamed human gene, the natural chemical it produces and the use of that chemical to heal bone diseases like osteoporosis. Sumimo researchers found that a similar gene in rats encourages bone growth.

Although the gene and the chemical codes for it exist naturally in humans, and clearly have a vital function in encouraging bones to grow, the patent application describes the chemical as 'novel'. Sumimo's patent is one of several bone-building genes patented by companies around the world, all claiming to offer hope to osteoporosis sufferers, begging the question as to whether a successful gene-based osteoporosis therapy might not depend on access to all the patented genes together.

fields.headline: Gold rush
fields.standfirst: Microbes make millions in a  new Klondyke of microfactories
fields.trailText: Microbes make millions in a new Klondyke of microfactories
fields.body:
Think of them as huge opportunity for the small investor. There could be 10 billion potential business units in a gram of soil, or 1,250 million in a teaspoonful of lake water. The ultimate in nice little earners, these microscopic factories already refine copper, ferment wine, digest food and cultivate yoghurt. They make undreamed-of enzymes, brew up insulin for diabetics, and purify water. They make oxygen to breathe, they take nitrogen from the air and turn it into plants, and they take plants and turn them into natural gas.

There are some that mop up crude oil slicks, some that thrive on toxins, some that swallow radioactive spills. They are the planet's arbiters of life and death: but businessmen now look to them for a killing on the stock exchange. These microbes will make millions. They include bacteria of the kind that deliver tuberculosis and cholera and bubonic plague, and the viruses of the kind that spread influenza, Aids and the pox. They have between them taken tens of millions of lives, but now they are also already beginning to take over whole economies.

Governments get involved in such invisible earnings. When in 1984 Robert Gallo in the US and Luc Montagnier in France simultaneously claimed the discovery of, and then tried to patent diagnostic tests for the virus that caused the then new disease of Aids, they triggered a series of running battles over the genetic sequence of the human immunodeficiency virus that had to be resolved by agreement between President Jacques Chirac and President Ronald Reagan that the spoils might be shared.

According to William Haseltine, now chief of Human Genome Sciences in Maryland, US, the rush for patents did not hamper Aids research. In those days, he worked with the team that deciphered the DNA of the HIV virus, and then worked out the sequences of its genes, and discovered some of the proteins those genes made. His name is on more than a dozen patents on the Aids virus - but the patents are held by the cancer institute he then worked for at Harvard Medical School.

"I would guess there may be 1,000 patents filed by now, each one building upon the other; not all, but many very important in stimulating investment in HIV tools," he says. "You would be very hard pressed to make the case that a patent on the virus, a patent on the genome sequence, a patent on individual sequences, is in any way inhibiting rather than stimulating of productive research, both in academia and in companies. I can think of no case in which a patent has ever inhibited an academic scientist."

He thinks that patents speeded up the assault on the virus itself. Protected by licences from the patent holder, scientists at Merck, the big pharmaceutical company, could examine the precise atomic structure of a protein used by the virus, and then begin to design a precise atomic spanner called a protease inhibitor to shove in its works. Such drugs are expensive, but in the developing world, they have dramatically cut deaths from Aids.

Dr Haseltine is still involved in the war against Aids: in February his biotech business Human Genome Sciences - with more than 7,500 applications for patents on human genes already - was issued a US patent on the CCR5 receptor gene. It is one of a class of things on the surface of the cell that could provide a target for a drug: to treat allergies, to relieve indigestion and cure ulcers, to treat migraine or relieve inflammation. But, the patent application also pointed out, it was one of those structures that a virus uses to bind to a cell. Other researchers confirmed what might have been seen by some as a hunch: that the CCR5 receptor gene makes a protein that the HIV virus uses to smuggle itself into an immune cell. People who don't have a functional CCR5 receptor gene don't seem to get infected with with HIV. The gene could be the key to a new class of treatment for one of the world's most difficult diseases.

By then, Human Genome Sciences had the patent on the gene in the US, and had applied for a European patent on it too. Dr Haseltine doesn't have to look for the other component, the piece of genetic machinery the virus itself uses to lock on to human cell it is about to hi-jack: that was identified years ago, he says. But this lock-and-key approach - the DNA machinery of the pathogen, and the genetic description of its human target - is about to change medicine, alter lives and reshape economies.

Biotech firms and university researchers are combing the genetic sequences of pathogens and plants, animals and algae for possible new treatments for cholera and tuberculosis, for vaccines for malaria and meningitis, for new kinds of weapons against antibiotic resistance. They are examining harmless bacilli that might help block bowel disease, and ulcerative colitis.

The first patent on a living organism was on a genetically-altered microbe that digested oil spills: now genetically-altered bacteria are the new microfactories and microbes have become the workaday instruments of multinationals. Researchers have patented DNA from the thermophiles, the bacteria that multiply at the boiling point of water, because they want to find enzymes that survive cooking. They have begun exploring psychrophiles or cold-lovers that survive in the Arctic because they need enzymes that work at refrigerator temperatures for the perfume industry, and acidophiles that can survive in vinegar, and alkalophiles that can survive laundry detergents, and salt-loving bacteria that could help extract more crude oil from subterranean wells.

Microbes like these may be the ultimate bedrock of industry: two years ago a team from the University of Georgia tried to assess the number of bacteria on the planet. They arrived at a figure with 30 zeroes in it. They tried to calculate the mass of all the carbon in those bacteria. They figured that this totted up to more than the landmass of the United Kingdom. If the microbial world is the new Klondyke, the prospectors will still be staking claims for decades to come.

Other researchers confirmed what might have been seen by some as a hunch: that the CCR5 receptor gene makes a protein that the HIV virus uses to smuggle itself into an immune cell. People who don't have a functional CCR5 receptor gene don't seem to get infected with with HIV. The gene could be the key to a new class of treatment for one of the world's most difficult diseases. By then, Human Genome Sciences had the patent on the gene in the US, and had applied for a European patent on it too. Dr Haseltine doesn't have to look for the other component, the piece of genetic machinery the virus itself uses to lock on to human cell it is about to hi-jack: that was identified years ago, he says. But this lock-and-key approach - the DNA machinery of the pathogen, and the genetic description of its human target - is about to change medicine, alter lives and reshape economies. Biotech firms and university researchers are combing the genetic sequences of pathogens and plants, animals and algae for possible new treatments for cholera and tuberculosis, for vaccines for malaria and meningitis, for new kinds of weapons against antibiotic resistance. They are examining harmless bacilli that might help block bowel disease, and ulcerative colitis. The first patent on a living organism was on a genetically-altered microbe that digested oil spills: now genetically-altered bacteria are the new microfactories and microbes have become the workaday instruments of multinationals. Researchers have patented DNA from the thermophiles, the bacteria that multiply at the boiling point of water, because they want to find enzymes that survive cooking. They have begun exploring psychrophiles or cold-lovers that survive in the Arctic because they need enzymes that work at refrigerator temperatures for the perfume industry, and acidophiles that can survive in vinegar, and alkalophiles that can survive laundry detergents, and salt-loving bacteria that could help extract more crude oil from subterranean wells. Microbes like these may be the ultimate bedrock of industry: two years ago a team from the University of Georgia tried to assess the number of bacteria on the planet. They arrived at a figure with 30 zeroes in it. They tried to calculate the mass of all the carbon in those bacteria. They figured that this totted up to more than the landmass of the United Kingdom. If the microbial world is the new Klondyke, the prospectors will still be staking claims for decades to come.

webTitle: Patenting life: The growth of the use of biotech

fields.headline: Your day has been patented ...
fields.trailText: It's still dark outside, but by the glow of your alarm clock (a luminous bacteria living on a Hawaian squid has been patented by a US university)
fields.body:
It's still dark outside, but by the glow of your alarm clock (a luminous bacteria living on a Hawaian squid has been patented by a US university), you can tell it's nearly 8 o'clock. Throwing back your cotton (Monsanto owns US patent no. 5,159,135 which covers all GM cotton but there are 228 other cotton gene sequences patented, too) duvet cover, slipping out of your silk pyjamas (there are 43 patents so far on silk genes, including several on the golden orb-weaving spider which makes the strongest and finest thread), you head for the shower and breakfast.

Mankind depends utterly on the plant and animal kingdom, none more so than when it grooms and feeds itself. Thank heavens, then, for the sub tropical aloe vera bush, extracts of which are used in many soaps, shampoos and cosmetics and on which there are now 39 genetic sequence patents. Brush your teeth with a paste flavoured with mint (six patented genes) Dry skin? The jojoba plant is used in many moisturisers and has three patented genes.

Look in the mirror. Flabby? Enter Millennium Pharmaceuticals Inc, which has worked on mice and has patented a genetic sequence dubbed "the obese gene", which their scientists say is involved in regulating body weight in mammals and may, they hope, one day come your way. Losing a bit of hair? French cosmetics giant L'Oreal has patented a gene from the Kava herb to prevent baldness. It is used throughout the Pacific for ceremonial purposes. Feeling coldy? Pop that vitamin C pill, almost certainly derived from maize, which has 2,181 genes patented.

Head down the stairs (24 trees have had genes patented mainly to grow mainly faster, taller and straighter) and collect the newspaper which may well in future be made from wood with a patented eucalyptus gene which reduces lignin and helps paper making. AstraZeneca, Monsanto and the US forestry industry are just some of the tree patent holders.

Never mind the mouse in the kitchen - there are 14,000 mouse genes alone patented - breakfast is a veritable feast of gene patents. Your porridge, made of oats, has eight patented genes, the banana has 37. Two universities and a French company have patents for the gene sequences that govern the fruit's flavouring. The US Boyce Thompson Institute of Plant Research has a patent on the chitinase gene which is important for its ripening.

Eat up your genes. There are 25 patents on pineapples, 25 on raspberries, 21 on grapes and pears, six on kiwi fruit, 11 on oranges, nine on apples, eight on pawpaw, four on strawberries and cherries, two on grapefruit, one each on tangerine and peach. There are no patents yet however on the blackberry, the elderberry or blueberry but someone is quite likely working on them.

There are almost more patents on a slice of toast or a bowl of cornflakes than there are crumbs or flakes. Wheat is the great hope of the GM food companies and 288 different gene sequences of it are patented.

GM wheat is not on the world market yet, but is expected in the next few years. No time for sausages or bacon but your breakfast conversation might include the observation that there are dozens of patents out on the genes of pigs and soon there may well be "pharm" animals producing drugs and genetically modified to grow faster, fatter, tastier and leaner. Most will be fed on soya (523 gene patents).

There's still some way to go before you can drink genetically engineered coffee but Nestle, the University of Hawaii (working with Monsanto) and the Hawaii Biotechnology Group Inc have patents on coffee gene sequences that may allow the bush to grow caffeine-free. Remarkably, there are no genetic patents yet on tea, except for developing a caffeine free blend.

Meanwhile, your coffee sweetener could well in future be derived from the J'oublie plant from Gabon. The Wisconsin Alumni research foundation has two patents (US 5346998 and US 5527555) on the gene sequence which governs its sweetness.

Into the car. Gene sequences of the rubber tree have been patented. The anti-freeze could in future be enhanced by the patented genes or products from beetles. Those animals you see in the fields (there are patents out on several grasses) all have genes that have been patented.

Lunch is a another feast of patents. Your avocado starter has just two patented genes, but the tomato has 774, the carrot 52, the cucumber 41 and the broccoli 38. Fancy some fish? Tuna, salmon, halibut have all had genes patented. So, too, have goldfish and carp, but they are not on the menu. A glass of wine? There are 21 patents on grape genes.

Work over, there's time for a quick drink in the pub where one of the genes from the hops that go into making the beer have been patented and so have several in the tobacco you inhale. Need something stiffer, like a tequila? It's going to be a scarce drink, says the barman, because there's a chronic shortage of the drink's key raw ingredient, the cactus-like agave plant. Help may be on the way. Researchers are trying to patent one of its genes.

For supper, perhaps a quick Indian. Virtually the whole subcontinent's menu has been patented, mainly for its pharmaceutical benefits, but also for flavourings and crop potential. The lentils in the dahl have five patented genes. There are 152 patents covering 584 sequences of rice. Chicken tikka? There are more than 500 gene sequences on chickens patented so far. Avigenics, a US biotech company, plans to create, using its patented technolgy, a strain of bird which has an extra large breast and with a DNA copyright tag inserted among its genes to stop anyone breeding it without permission.

Back home. Just time for that TV gardening programme featuring roses and geraniums (one has had a gene patented for its red colouring, the other to help prolong the shelf life of cut blooms) and the late night wildlife film about bottle-nosed dolphins (one gene patented for its red blood cell potential), gorillas, chimps and oran-utangs - all of which have (patented) pharmaceutical potential.

Can-t stick it? Well, a barnacle gene has been claimed for its adhesive potential. But, seriously, if your patented day is all too much, don't turn to drugs. A gene from cannabis, the marijuana plant , has been patented by the University of Strathclyde.

webTitle: Patenting life: Top 10 patenters on the human body

fields.headline: The top 10 patenters on the human body
fields.trailText: Genset of France
fields.body:
1 Genset of France has applied for patents on 36,083 gene sequences.

This represents 28.5% of all applications relating to human genes. The company has 530 staff and a market valuation of $500m.

2 Ribozyme (US) claims patent applications on 15,863 sequences, 12.5% of the total.

The Colorado-based firm owns the nobel prizewinning technology of 'molecular scissors' which can cut tiny RNA.

3 Genetics Institute (a subsidiary of American Home Products) has applied for patents on 9,876 sequences, 7.8% of the total.

It has products on the market for cancer and haemophilia.

4 Genzyme (US) has filed applications on 8,546 - 6.7% of the total.

This sprawling biotech company has an operation developing transgenic goats.

5 Hyseq (US) claims 6,147 sequences (4.9%).

The Californian company is developing drugs for heart disease and inflammatory ilnesses.

6 Human Genome Sciences (US) has filed for patents on 3,964 (3.1%).

Recently awarded patent on gene believed to be 'docking point' for the Aids virus.

7 US Department of Health 2,991 sequences (2.4%).

8 Affymetrix (US) 2,079 sequences (1.5%).

Owns technology which stores genes on slides or chips.

9 Genentech (US) 1,995 sequences (1.5%).

Founded in 1976, was one of the first companies to specialise in gene-based medicines.

10 Incyte (US) claims 1,755 (1.4%).

Has put a 60,000-strong database of genes on the Internet.

The top 10 human gene patenters claim 70.4% of the total of 126,672 human gene sequences between them.

webTitle: Patenting life: The rush for 'human rights'

fields.headline: Why you are first in the great gene race
fields.standfirst: The rush for rights to your body is under way and already patents have been applied for on a fantastic 127,000 bits of your genes
fields.trailText: The rush for rights to your body is under way and already patents have been applied for on a fantastic 127,000 bits of your genes
fields.body:
One hot, dusty day in September 1893, at the sound of the starting guns, the rich prairie soil of the Cherokee Strip in Oklahoma was darkened by a flowing wave of humanity, horses and wagons. The US government was giving away 13,000 square miles of Indian territory to any settler able to race fast enough to stake a claim. One hundred thousand men, women and children stormed across the starting line to seize their piece of land.

More than a century after the Great Land Run became a symbol of the American frontier spirit, another rush for rights is under way. This time the claimants are in white lab coats and business suits, and the arena is the chemical sequence which makes us what we are: the set of genes each of us carries, in trillions of copies, in the cells of our bodies.

Research commissioned by the Guardian shows that pharmaceutical companies, biotech firms of all sizes, government institutes and universities have filed patents on a staggering 127,000 human genes or partial human gene sequences. They have patented genes which make our brains work, which build our bones, which make our livers grow, which keep our hearts beating, which can give increased chances of getting cancer and which may predict our likelihood of becoming addicted to drugs. They've patented genes even before they know what they do: they've taken out speculative patents on treatments based on genes even though no such treatments exist.

Our genes are nature's software - chemical codes honed by millions of years of evolution to fabricate the substances that make us what we are. Scientists' new knowledge of these codes, and their commonest flaws, promises to make the 21st century an era when some of the deadliest diseases are eradicated. By patenting gene sequences, the claimants argue, they are ensuring they will be able to recover the money they have spent to find them, and gain the financial incentive to work out how to use them to benefit humankind. Not so, argue the critics of gene patenting. For one thing, to claim exclusive rights to commercial exploitation of something everyone is born with is to abuse the patent system, which was set up to reward inventors, not discoverers.

Some genes are more valuable than others. Professor Simon Lovestone, of the Institute of Psychiatry in London, is one of a group of several dozen scientists around the world about to spark off a new gene hunt when they publish the results of research pinpointing a region of human DNA where a gene contributing to the onset of Alzheimer's disease is to be found. One "Alzheimer's" gene, known as ApoE, has already been identified, but by itself it is a poor indicator of how likely someone is to get the disease. Patent control over a second Alzheimer's gene would make reliable advanced diagnosis more likely, and could contribute towards developing a cure. One estimate of the annual market for Alzheimer's therapy is £100 billion. An Alzheime's gene patent, even without a cure, would do wonders for a firm's share price in the cut-throat world of biotech competition.

Had Prof Lovestone and his collaborators been working for a private firm, they would have held off publishing details of their discovery until they had found the exact location of the gene, recorded its chemical sequence, and filed a patent application. This is what the Icelandic firm, DeCode, did with its recent announcement that it had found a "schizophrenia gene." By publishing early, Prof Lovestone's team throw the hunt open to everyone. A big private firm is quite likely to find the gene first, and patent it. If Lovestone et al find it, they may patent it too - a "defensive" patent, to keep the gene in the public domain.

"Our academic group will publish as soon as it can, in order that other groups may work on it," said Prof Lovestone. "Of course it would cause me anguish if another group found the gene and patented it. We want to be the ones to find it because of normal academic competitiveness. If somebody else finds it and then clamps some kind of restriction on it which prevents others working on it, that would make me very unhappy."

He could see the biotech companies' point of view: "There is the argument that being able to patent genes encourages firms to spend large amounts of money on developing tests and therapies based on those genes. I don't know what's right and what's wrong, I really don't. I think it's genuinely difficult.

I find the patenting of genes anathema, but equally I think it's absolutely essential that big pharmaceutical companies are involved in this kind of research. It's probably no longer possible for governments to sponsor this sort of work."

The patenting of human genes tends to be seen as largely a US-driven phenomenon, fuelled by idiosyncratic American patent laws, but just as the Cherokee Land Run fades into insignificance compared to European appropriation of colonies, so European firms have become some of the most enthusiastic stakers of claims on human DNA. Patent applications on no fewer than 36,083 genes and DNA sequences - 28.5 per cent of the total claimed so far - have been filed by a single French firm, Genset. Andre Pernet, GensetÍs chief executive officer, said: "It's going to be a race. The whole genome will have been patented two years from now, if it hasn't been done already." He said Genset did not claim patents on genetic data without "adding to its usefulness", although neither the company nor its partners have so far produced any treatments based on their patented sequences.

Genset is working on drugs linked to two patented genes - one associated with prostate cancer, another with obesity. "If I invest $45 million per year finding useful drug targets using isolation genetics and genomics, then I can demonstrate usefulness, and I think these are valid patents," said Pernet.

So far, gene patent holders have trodden cautiously in enforcing their monopolies. They like to maintain, publicly, that they have not actually patented genes - only a specific use for them. But in gene patents, the written sequence of the gene's chemical code, and the description of its function, are usually the only novel things there.

The Utah-based company Myriad Genetics, for instance, has patented two human genes, mutations which make women more susceptible to breast cancer. It has patented these in the context of a test for susceptibility to the disease - but the technology to carry out the tests is patented by other companies. What Myriad brings to the table in terms of "novelty" is the gene sequence and nothing more. One patent lawyer likened it to a lock and a key: all the locks are similar, but the key is unique.

Patents aside, Myriad is trying to introduce something novel to the world of genetic testing - a monopoly. It has stopped US labs screening for mutations on a non-profit basis by demanding they pay a licence fee. In Britain, its local agent has taken a more cautious approach so far. The company claims it must recoup the $10 million it spent tracking down the genes. But much of the work involved was actually carried out by others, including non-commercial scientists in Britain who dispute Myriad's rights to ownership of one of the genes.

In this complex and important area, one thing is clear: the British government is not going to rock the boat. Tony Blair's reported anxiety to keep genetic sequence information from the Human Genome Project in the public domain does not extend to keeping genes out of the patent arena. Judging by a parliamentary reply he gave in February when asked about Myriad's approach, he neither knows, nor cares, the difference between a genetic test and a drug, between a gene patent and the patent on a traditional medicine.

"We have no interest in the particular issue to which the honourable gentleman refers, other than to ensure that people get the best treatment possible," he said. "We have no more interest in one specific drug than another."

The patents

The information in this patent research was compiled by GeneWatch UK by searching the Derwent GENESEQ database. This database includes all the DNA sequences (partial and complete gene sequences) which have been recorded in patents from 40 patent authorities worldwide, including the US, European, World, Japanese and German patent offices.

The database includes information on which organism the gene sequence was obtained from, its characteristics and uses. GENESEQ is a commercial database which can be used to determine whether a particular gene sequence has been patented, follow competitors' work and reveal if a patent has been infringed. Additional data was obtained from the UK and European patent offices' searchable databases.

The number of patents which include gene sequences is growing exponentially as progress in genetic research becomes more rapid. A patent may cover one or many (up to 2,000 in some cases) partial or complete gene sequences. One patent may also cover many variants of the same gene. Because there is a delay of some 3-5 years or even longer in the assessment of patent applications, the majority of patent applications included in this research (approximately 60% to 70% depending on organism) have not yet been granted.

The European Patent Office currently has a backlog of some 15,000 biotechnology patent applications. The US Patent office does not publish patents until they are granted so pending gene patents filed there and nowhere else cannot be examined. Research for this supplement was specially commissioned from GeneWatch UK, a policy research group based in Derbyshire which evaluates the science, regulation and control of genetic technologies. The researchers were Sue Mayer, Ben Ayliffe and Becky Price.

To find out more about GeneWatch UK, its publications and online database, visit their website at www.genewatch.org or e-mail mail@genewatch.org.

It has patented these in the context of a test for susceptibility to the disease - but the technology to carry out the tests is patented by other companies. What Myriad brings to the table in terms of "novelty" is the gene sequence and nothing more. One patent lawyer likened it to a lock and a key: all the locks are similar, but the key is unique. Patents aside, Myriad is trying to introduce something novel to the world of genetic testing - a monopoly. It has stopped US labs screening for mutations on a non-profit basis by demanding they pay a licence fee. In Britain, its local agent has taken a more cautious approach so far. The company claims it must recoup the $10 million it spent tracking down the genes. But much of the work involved was actually carried out by others, including non-commercial scientists in Britain who dispute Myriad's rights to ownership of one of the genes. In this complex and important area, one thing is clear: the British government is not going to rock the boat. Tony Blair's reported anxiety to keep genetic sequence information from the Human Genome Project in the public domain does not extend to keeping genes out of the patent arena. Judging by a parliamentary reply he gave in February when asked about Myriad's approach, he neither knows, nor cares, the difference between a genetic test and a drug, between a gene patent and the patent on a traditional medicine. "We have no interest in the particular issue to which the honourable gentleman refers, other than to ensure that people get the best treatment possible," he said. "We have no more interest in one specific drug than another." The patents The information in this patent research was compiled by GeneWatch UK by searching the Derwent GENESEQ database. This database includes all the DNA sequences (partial and complete gene sequences) which have been recorded in patents from 40 patent authorities worldwide, including the US, European, World, Japanese and German patent offices. The database includes information on which organism the gene sequence was obtained from, its characteristics and uses. GENESEQ is a commercial database which can be used to determine whether a particular gene sequence has been patented, follow competitors' work and reveal if a patent has been infringed. Additional data was obtained from the UK and European patent offices' searchable databases. The number of patents which include gene sequences is growing exponentially as progress in genetic research becomes more rapid. A patent may cover one or many (up to 2,000 in some cases) partial or complete gene sequences. One patent may also cover many variants of the same gene. Because there is a delay of some 3-5 years or even longer in the assessment of patent applications, the majority of patent applications included in this research (approximately 60% to 70% depending on organism) have not yet been granted. The European Patent Office currently has a backlog of some 15,000 biotechnology patent applications. The US Patent office does not publish patents until they are granted so pending gene patents filed there and nowhere else cannot be examined. Research for this supplement was specially commissioned from GeneWatch UK, a policy research group based in Derbyshire which evaluates the science, regulation and control of genetic technologies. The researchers were Sue Mayer, Ben Ayliffe and Becky Price. To find out more about GeneWatch UK, its publications and online database, visit their website at www.genewatch.org or e-mail mail@genewatch.org.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: While others fret about who leads the free world, we are concerned only with the letter-writing career of Daily Telegraph cricket man Lord Michael Henderson.
fields.body:
 While others fret about who leads the free world, we are concerned only with the letter-writing career of Daily Telegraph cricket man Lord Michael Henderson. Since mentioning his complaint of last week about my capacious arse waddling along the Goldhawk Road, we learned of missives to my colleagues David McKie and Gary Younge. Now Tom Fountain and Mike Bradwell from the Bush Theatre - also, oddly, in the Goldhawk Road - forward a missive received after G2 ran their article about the importance of new writing in British theatre. "What a pair of dimwits you make!" begins Michael, on his beloved Telegraph writing paper. "Good work never palls - Writing, like painting or music, has nothing to do with 'real life' or 'relevance'. It has to do with emotional truth, as Shakespeare made clear in Hamlet. But then you wouldn't have heard of him, would you?" If anyone has any more Hendo gems, I have publishers interested in the concept of a witless, irony-free Henry Root, and would love to see them.

 Just the four apologies today. 1) Bury's ground is Gigg (not Gig) Lane; 2) thanks to all who wrote to point out that "religious", as used in the Catholic Herald, has a technical meaning any remotely educated person should know; 3) Stephen Pound, the Mockney MP for Ealing, points out that "the guv'nor" (his wife) was in fact "well chuffed" with the dome, not "well choked"; 4) Alistair from Stirling sent the joke about "super sex", not Alistair Stirling. Another great day for our fact-checking, then, and good luck for tomorrow.

 After watching Richard Caborn appear before the DTI select committee recently, the comedian Mark Thomas tried to snatch a word with the trade minister about his support for the Ilisu dam. As he approached, however, Dick sprinted away, but courageously left behind a civil service press officer to block Mark's way, and particularly impressive was this chap's refusal to give his name or position, a moving paean, Mark felt, to Dick's endorsement, in a debate that day, of the concept of transparency.

 A fuller account arrives of the Independent on Sunday's Rushdie fiasco. When reporter Sophie Goodchild wrote a balanced report about calls for Salman to lose his police protection, deputy editor Michael Williams asked someone to "do a Chittenden" (after the Sunday Times's Maurice Chittenden, so well-loved for his gift for inflating small stories). The result incensed Rushdie, who lashed the IoS in his next column, causing staff to threaten injuncting their own paper. Naturally, Mr Williams washed his hands of the affair, but news editor Barry Hugill had had enough and walked out. Tut, tut. Whether owner Tony O'Reilly wants Janet to spend less time chilling with Pet Shop Boys at the Groucho and more trying to reverse this chaos, we will have to wait and see.

 Keith Roberts writes from Portsmouth to report seeing, on Saturday morning at Havant's new Asda Walmart store, large stocks of "the famed Aitken autobiography priced at £2.26. Sad to relate, no one seemed to be buying them. Maybe you could lend a hand?" I'd like to, Keith, of course I would, but public taste is an unmalleable thing. Still, so long as we have money for lavish parties for our old mum (albeit not quite enough to repay our creditors), let's not worry about being in the bargain basement yet.

 Encouraging news for George Dubya from Denmark, where two ballot papers have reached the city of Odense. The Kain family, who'd requested travel brochures from a US firm, assumed they must be extra advertising, but on opening one envelope found a pro-Bush ballot (wisely, they stopped there and did not open the other) filled in by information consultant Steven H Forrest, who has no idea how his vote ended up 10,000 miles away. Lawyers expect the supreme court to decide on this as soon as they've sorted out Florida, by April or May 2009.
E-mail: diary@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Your life in  their hands
fields.standfirst: When you patent a human gene, in what sense is it yours? European ministers have a chance to discuss the ownership of life when they meet in Munich next week. But they may already be too late
fields.trailText: When you patent a human gene, in what sense is it yours? European ministers have a chance to discuss the ownership of life when they meet in Munich next week. But they may already be too late
fields.body:
Life is what you make of it. Right now, what you make of it is money. You can isolate a length of DNA, describe it, make something inventive and not obvious from it, propose a use, pay some money and claim it as yours at a patent office.

Congratulations. You have joined the 21st century gold rush. You have staked out your claim, and you can exploit it. What you have is microscopically small - not tissue, not a cell, not even a chromosome but a tiny fragment of a chromosome - but it is an acorn from which a great oak forest may grow.

You are part of an industry that barely existed five years ago, but which is now worth £30bn. In Britain, there are already 450 biotechnology companies in the business of making something new from life. In Europe, there are probably 800 small and medium enterprises doing the same thing. In the US there are around 1300 such firms, all hoping to make a killing from life. The industry is growing at 20 per cent per year, on something which most people hadn't realised could be claimed as a possession at all: life. So far, private enterprise and public institutions have filed claims on more than 127,000 human genes or partial human gene sequences. Other groups have been ransacking the rest of creation for wealth-creating DNA, for genes that generate something that no ordinary chemical process could ever hope to fabricate. They are looking for tests, treatments, cures and vaccines for thousands of diseases; they are looking for new ways of delivering medicines and new ways of making medicines. They have been fossicking in the tropical forests, quizzing shamans and medicine men, turning over exotic crops in traditional kitchen gardens.

They want to make old crops grow faster or keep better, or make new kinds of health food called nutraceuticals, or organic answers to industrial pollution. They have patents on biological information that may make you fat or thin, live longer or give birth more easily. They want to find the genes that prevent sponges from getting cancer, or slugs from getting skin diseases. They want to put more beef on bullocks, conjure up new fabrics based on the chemistry of spider's silk or make plastics you can grow in a field of potatoes.

Modestly-sized companies have been filing patent claims at the rate of 100 a week, and then reassuring their shareholders with the potential of their portfolios. Many of them have staked claims on discoveries only possible because of years of research by scientists in academic institutions, who thought they were working for the public good, or for groups of patients cursed by congenital affliction. But many of them are also scientists who made a discovery, and formed a start-up company to exploit it. Many of them will fail: only about one patent in 14, of any kind, ever gets to market. But the ones that succeed could end up in a new plutocracy: lords of life and death and DNA.

That is the apocalyptic view. Another way of looking at it is that a whole new generation of bright and often young risk-takers have seen an opportunity to relieve human suffering, treat once incurable illnesses and generate new possibilities, with no guarantee of ultimate success and the very limited protection of an old-fashioned and sometimes clumsy industrial instrument called a patent which gives them no more than a head start, a few years in which they can have their little corner of the field to themselves. A gene, for them, is not life. Life is an abstraction: you cannot patent it, nor anything inside a living thing. But a gene tidied up, topped and tailed, cloned and crystallised in a form you could post in a package is something else, they argue. It is the information behind a process that leads to a product that - once made - someone will be prepared to pay for.

And a patent is no more than a temporary protection which prevents others from making money from that discovery. When businesses have filed a patent claim, they can publish, and other researchers all over the world can use what could be information of value in other ways. With a patent, they can risk the 10 years and the £100m needed to take a drug from idea to pharmacy counter.

Britain has had patents since Tudor times; Thomas Jefferson launched a US patent office; Europe - a single market far larger than the EU - has a European Patent Office with 20 member nations. Europe hammered out a biotechnology directive in 1998, and pushed it through, and harmonised patent law to give European scientists and investors the chance to make one application for one big market, rather than separate applications for lots of little ones. It also - say the directive's opponents - gave European entrepreneurs the right to patent life, or to put it another way, to own it.

The first gene-based patents were made 20 years ago, but they were few, and many were never exploited. Now, in the last two or three years, the biotech companies have been sprinting from the lab to the patent office, with applications by the armful. There has been intermittent anger and anxiety, but almost no public debate. European patent chiefs are meeting next week in Munich to revise the European Patent Convention. But it isn't clear that they are encouraging any discussion of the biotechnology directive that has turned genes into intellectual property, to be kept on a shelf, licensed to the highest bidders or simply lost in the tangle of takeovers and bankruptcies inevitable in new high-risk industries.

What is clear is that European decisions are being driven by the American stampede for patents. The US patent office has different rules and a different philosophy and - critics say - a tendency to let applicants get away with very broad claims. A US chief biotechnology patent examiner implicitly conceded this when he warned this year that anyone who wanted to patent a new transgenic mouse would have to do more than just claim that it was useful as petfood.

Patents are a human invention, and like humans, faulty. There are other built-in difficulties. By definition, patent officers have to make decisions about unheard-of propositions every day. Privately, some concede that if the European biotechnology directive were being introduced now, it would not have the same form. They, too, see potential problems. Could two separate groups patent the same piece of genetic information for two different functions? If so, there could be no question of anyone "owning" of a gene. That, says the UK Patent Office, is not clear: it needs a test case. There is a gentleman's agreement in the biotech industry that a patent does not prevent academic research, but the text of the legislation isn't quite clear on that point either.

The practitioners do not quarrel with the patenting of genetic information, and they do not see it as claiming a monopoly on life. They see it as business as usual. But the new businessmen are in a game of monopoly, and this time the real estate is something intangible, and already incorporated by everybody, everywhere: genetic information.

The systematic search for this information was begun 20 years ago by doctors and scientists in search of the causes of muscular dystrophy, or Huntington's disease, or thousands of other afflictions that have plagued families for generations, and the money for this search was raised by charities begun by those families.

The search has widened, and accelerated: it has gone from muscular dystrophy to maize and manioc and myrrh and 10,000 other lifeforms in the forests and savannahs of the globe. If new products and effective new treatments emerge that are widely available, then that will be a benefit.

The key phrase is: widely available. Because the alarm is that once again, natural resources intended to help the hungry, the sick, the desperate have been cornered by the rich world, which will use them to get richer. Once again, this gain is likely to be at the cost of the developing world.

fields.headline: Don't dump the dome
fields.standfirst:
Whatever its failings the structure is great

Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Whatever anybody thinks about the contents of the Millennium Dome, the building itself has proved a stunning architectural success. Michael Heseltine is absolutely right: it would be a tragedy to tear it down now.
fields.body:
Whatever anybody thinks about the contents of the Millennium Dome, the building itself has proved a stunning architectural success. Michael Heseltine is absolutely right: it would be a tragedy to tear it down now just because an immediate use cannot be found and politicians are desperate to wash their hands of it before the election gets under way.

What next? Ministers appear to be very cool towards the property developer Robert Bourne's £150m scheme to build a sort of eco-friendly Silicon Valley. They may have good reasons - but it is a fine idea in theory, not least because of the site by the Thames and proximity to the Jubilee Line extension, another scheme that did the millennium double - architectural wonder and financial disaster. Politicians should rise above themselves, forget about short-term politics and think again about the long term.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: Our graphic of the Alpine tunnel fire, page 3, November 13, referred to the 40km journey of the funicular train up the mountain. That should have been 4km, a distance the train normally covered in 9 minutes. In the accompanying report and in a caption we referred to the vacuum created by the fire. This would not have happened. However, there would have been a reduction in pressure which would have allowed fresh air to enter the tunnel and fan the flames.
fields.body:
Our graphic of the Alpine tunnel fire, page 3, November 13, referred to the 40km journey of the funicular train up the mountain. That should have been 4km, a distance the train normally covered in 9 minutes. In the accompanying report and in a caption we referred to the vacuum created by the fire. This would not have happened. However, there would have been a reduction in pressure which would have allowed fresh air to enter the tunnel and fan the flames.

 In a report headed India starts to count its losses, page 16, October 31, we said, "There is nothing new about migration from the Indian subcontinent. It was, after all, Indian architects who built the great temples at Angkor Wat in Cambodia in the 12th century." The Khmer Institute has asked us to point out that scholars now generally accept that the temples were designed and constructed by the ancient Khmer people themselves.

 In a paragraph at the end of a piece headed Ferguson in war of hearts and minds, page 34, yesterday, we said lawyers for Sir Alex Ferguson were seeking an apology and damages for an article in the BBC's Match of the Day magazine, written by Pat Murphy. Mr Murphy was not the author of the article involved in this dispute. Apologies for saying he was.

 In the TV review, page 5, Saturday Review, November 11, we said that Clarissa and the Countryman, "sallied forth to north-east England to race their greyhound in the Waterloo Cup". That would be at Altcar in Merseyside, very much in the north-west.

 Rock Star, the book by Jackie Collins, was accidentally attributed to her sister Joan, page 32, Weekend, November 11. Apologies.

 Darren Johnson, the leader of the Green group in the London Assembly and environment adviser to the mayor, has asked us to point out that, contrary to what David Ford said in a letter, page 23, November 13, he will be visiting Washington with Ken Livingstone, not New York (and his name has no "t" in it).

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. webTitle: Comment: John O'Farrell on the US election

fields.headline: The great transatlantic game show
fields.standfirst:
Can't we get Anne Robinson to ask both candidates a few questions?<
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Can't we get Anne Robinson to ask both candidates a few questions?
fields.body:
I cried on the day President Kennedy was shot. I was lying in my cot and I'd dropped my rusk through the bars. Next week sees the anniversary of that infamous assassination, and America looks set to commemorate it by killing off another rightful president.

For years the debate will rage - was the Florida judge acting alone or was it part of some wider conspiracy? Was there a second judge hiding behind the grassy knoll? Show that film again - there's definitely a second hole going into that ballot paper.

There is of course a difference between Kennedy and Gore. Kennedy won the presidency by only 100,000 votes, whereas Gore beat Bush by more than twice that. We keep being told that America is the greatest democracy in the world. Well yes, apart from the minor quibbles that less than half the electorate voted and the bloke who got least votes looks set to win. Deciding who's actually been elected could not be taking longer if Edward Heath was in charge of it all. And soon the billions spent on the election will be as nothing compared with Jeremy Paxman's hotel bill for his extended stay in Washington.

Immediately it became apparent that neither candidate had won decisively, all sorts of accusations and recriminations started being thrown about. Gore was told he blew it by not being enough like Clinton. Instead of going around shaking people's hands he should have locked himself in the stationery cupboard with his secretary.

Then it was claimed that some ballot papers were so confusing that less intelligent electors voted for the wrong person. So at least Gore got Bush's vote. Meanwhile careful analysis of the figures show that the governor of Texas has been seeking to gain an unfair advantage over the past few years by executing more Democrats than Republicans.

It must be said that as political dynasties go, they don't come much less glamorous than the Bush family. If the original President Bush had been a film, would anyone have bothered with a sequel? But now in the land where anyone is supposed to able to reach the White House, the son of the last Republican president looks set to inherit it because of dubious electoral practices in the state where his brother is governor. So that's why George W Bush went into politics. He wanted to spend more time with his family.

There must be a simple way to sort this all out. Can't we get Anne Robinson to ask both candidates a few general knowledge questions and then say, "George W, you are the weakest link. Goodbye!" Or maybe a more American way would be for the two candidates to fight it out in the style of the World Wrestling Federation. Al "The Jogger" Gore versus George "The Executioner" Bush. It would still look less fixed than the result in Florida.

"It could never happen here of course," we all say smugly. Except it has happened here twice since the war, most spectacularly in 1951, when Attlee's government got the highest percentage poll of any political party since the advent of universal suffrage and yet Labour were thrown out of office. And who can forget the things that Churchill's 1951-55 government then did without a proper mandate? Well, we all can as it turns out.

Events across the Atlantic should make us look again at our own political system. We can hardly laugh at the Americans, when our own head of state was chosen by dint of being the eldest daughter of an accidentally crowned king, descended from a foreign prince who was brought in at the last minute to keep out the Catholics. (I don't why the Tories are so paranoid about us being ruled by the Germans, when they've been sitting on the British throne since George I.) Maybe in this area we should seek to be more like the Americans - the Queen and Prince Charles should have televised debates to decide on the top job. Charles would be accused of being pro-gun-control as the Queen shouted "God Bless the Good ol' United Kingdom!" and everyone would whoop and cheer as red, white and blue balloons descended from the ceiling.

The unsettling reality is that it is in exactly this type of constitutional deadlock that the Queen would wield genuine political power. And you could bet your bottom billion dollars that the people advising her would be arguing for a Conservative administration rather than Labour. The American constitution might be showing its age a bit this month but at least they've actually got one.

We still have an unelected second chamber, an unrepresentative House of Commons and a voting system that leaves millions of people feeling that their votes simply don't count. We'll only realise how deeply flawed our political system is when William Hague walks through the door of Downing Street after most people have voted against him. And then we'll wish we had a more liberal and intelligent leader - someone like George W Bush.

fields.headline: Presidency in a tangle
fields.standfirst:
Whoever eventually wins the US election will be bound by the need to heal a suspicious and divided nation
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Whoever eventually wins the US election will be bound by the need to heal a suspicious and divided nation
fields.body:
They have a slogan here about "government in the sunshine" - and the funny thing is, they mean it. Early yesterday morning, the two women and one man who make up Palm Beach county's election-supervising body met to decide whether to recount their region's votes by hand. They did not gather behind closed doors, away from view. In fact they didn't meet behind doors of any kind: they held their session outside, on a makeshift platform, in front of the cameras and the crowds. This was not a press conference, but an actual discussion by three election commissioners. It took place right there, in the open: government in the sunshine.

That little scene is typical of the mess America is in, one week after it was meant to have chosen a new president. To the naked eye, the Palm Beach session looked palpably absurd: a decision which could determine the next leader of the free world taken by a trio of amateurs, in barbecue conditions. Yet underneath that shambolic surface was a noble intent: truly open government. The same is true of so much of what has gone wrong here. The dizzying, chaotic torrent of rulings and reversals that came from a clutch of courts and commissions yesterday left most Americans bewildered, with the US media struggling to understand, let alone explain, them. It looked ridiculous.

In almost every case, judgments were challenged because the decision-makers were accused of being biased or partisan: Florida's chief election official is a Republican, while the state's attorney-general is a Democrat - and both gave opposite advice on the legality of the hand count. On Monday a federal judge ruled in favour of the Al Gore camp, and was instantly condemned because he had been appointed to the bench by Bill Clinton. Yesterday no fewer than five judges in Palm Beach county stepped aside, one after the other, because they feared they would be seen as partial. The whole thing looks nuts.

But look closer. The reason why none of these officials was deemed neutral was that they were all either elected or appointed democratically. If they had simply emerged, accountable to no one - like our own judiciary or quangocracy - the problem would not have arisen. But Americans prefer democracy. The same spirit lies behind that laughably complex "butterfly" ballot paper in Palm Beach county. It came about thanks to America's faith in true devolution, allow ing every region to do things, including ballot design, for themselves. As with that early-morning display of sunshine government, in America what looks like farce often conceals an admirable pursuit of democracy.

It's worth remembering all this, as Britons join the rest of the world in a warm bath of smugness, jeering at the American behemoth for stumbling so clumsily. We should recall how we would cope if one of our elections ended up in a similar dead-heat. A hung parliament would be resolved by that titan of modern, streamlined democracy, Her Majesty the Queen: she would break the tie by inviting one party leader to form a government. And if there was a dispute over voting irregularities, who would resolve that? Would elected officials come before us to debate, before the cameras, under a cloudy Westminster sky? Or would a quango suddenly appear, some body of great and good which none of us had ever elected, never heard of and never seen?

So we should pause before feeling too smug: much of America's current trouble comes from having too much democracy, not too little. Not that that makes it any easier for Americans to bear. They know they should follow the legal, democratic procedure - they've heard the ever-schoolmarmish Gore praise the last seven days as a national civics lesson - but they'd still like it over with. For once, George W Bush has come up with the perfect metaphor. Not with any words he has used - that really would be news -but rather with his face. Since the weekend it has been marked by a large blemish, hidden under a plaster. Americans see that and have a collective impulse: it's time to lance the boil.

Finality is the word of the hour - election 2000's equivalent of "closure" during the impeachment farrago of 1998. The assumption is that finality will come when a president-elect is at last in place - even if that takes till noon on January 20, when one of these two men will raise his right hand and swear the oath of office.

But is that right? Or might the radiation from this blast keep poisoning the atmosphere, contaminating the next presidency from now until 2004?

The precedents are not encouraging. When Rutherford B Hayes won the presidency after failing to win the popular vote in 1876, he was mocked as "His Fraudulency". That fate could await W if he scrapes home in Florida but stays behind in the total national vote. People will always wonder what strings Florida's governor, Jeb Bush, pulled to deliver for his brother. The conspiracy theories are already circulating. One placard-holder at a Jesse Jackson protest rally on Monday night urged me to remember Bush Snr's former job - as director of the CIA.

Gore's prospects are equally bleak. He knows the American right never regarded Clinton as a fully legitimate president - and he won two clear mandates. Imagine what they would do with a court-imposed President Gore.

Whoever he is, the next president will take office under a dark cloud. A Gallup poll yesterday found that about a third of both Bush and Gore supporters would not accept the other as legitimate, even if he is declared the winner. Add to that a House and Senate all but split 50-50 and you see a Washington divided as it has not been since the aftermath of the civil war.

The optimists wonder if this might lead to balance and cross-party cooperation, essential if either side is to get anything done. Something like that may come, but not from any spirit of bipartisanship. Rather there will be a vast scaling back of ambition. Gore's biggest programmes, on prescription drugs for the elderly for example, are bound to be dropped, one close aide told me yesterday. Bush's trillion-dollar tax cut is already history. Both men would have to appoint leading figures from the other side, creating a virtual government of national unity: we may not know who is going to be president, but Colin Powell is surely a cert for secretary of state under either man.

On policy, it will be a case of little by little. Gore would push more slowly than planned to give all American children healthcare coverage. Bush would hesitate before naming any ultra- conservative judges to the supreme court. For the next president will face a task much larger than any agenda of his own: he will have to win the acceptance of a suspicious electorate and heal a divided nation. The longer this race goes on, the smaller the prize becomes.

jonathan.freedland@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Look east: Doors open to majors
fields.trailText: Supply shortages have sent oil prices racing ahead this year - to over $35 per barrel from less than $10 in early 1999, and investment bank Merrill Lynch has predicted that higher oil prices are here to stay for some years.
fields.body:
Supply shortages have sent oil prices racing ahead this year - to over $35 per barrel from less than $10 in early 1999, and investment bank Merrill Lynch has predicted that higher oil prices are here to stay for some years.

But the long-term picture remains cloudy with some predicting prices will fall drastically as more and more discoveries appear, such as the offshore strike at Kashagan in Kazakhstan.

One of the industry's most highly respected figures - former Saudi oil minister Sheikh Yamani - predicts crude will rapidly lose its value and the "oil age" will end within a few decades.

This is partly because of finds in the Caspian, off West Africa and Brazil but mainly because of the development of new technology such as fuel cells which could take over from petrol to power cars.

"The stone age came to an end, not because we had a lack of stones, and the oil age will come to an end not because we have a lack of oil," Yamani, who in the 1970s helped alter the balance of world power, has said.

These predictions cut little ice among the oil majors. High crude prices have filled their coffers and cash is pouring into exploration and production . Mature areas such as the North Sea and the Gulf of Mexico are being revisited. Technological breakthroughs are bringing down costs and helping operators to increase the amount of oil they can retrieve from old reservoirs.

Explorers have benefited from the introduction of 4D seismic , by which geological structures can be photographed and reviewed over a number of years. Since the break-up of the Soviet Union, governments in Asia and the Caucasus have opened their doors to western oil, anxious to attract investment and transform their economies.

Wood Mackenzie, the Edinburgh-based energy consultancy owned by Merrill Lynch, believes Kazakhstan, Azerbaijan and Turkmenistan could produce 4m barrels of oil a day by 2015.

'The stone age came to an end, not because we had a lack of stones, and the oil age will come to an end not because we have a lack of oil' Sheikh Yamani, legendary Saudi oil minister

webTitle: Human capital frittered away, says EBRD

fields.headline: Human capital frittered away, says EBRD
fields.standfirst: Development coming to terms with a Soviet legacy
fields.trailText: Development coming to terms with a Soviet legacy.
fields.body:
Economic growth in the old Soviet bloc this year will be the fastest since the fall of the Berlin Wall and the end of the region's centrally planned economies, according to the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

The surge in growth, expected to see the region expand by 5% this year, is being driven by high oil prices and by the currency devaluations following the Russian debt crisis in 1998, which have boosted competitiveness.

But large areas are still facing poverty, unemployment and skill shortages, and the EBRD warned yesterday that the current robust economic performance cannot continue without structural reform.

In its annual report on the progress made by the countries of central and eastern Europe, the Baltic states and the Commonwealth of Independent States in moving from central planning towards market economies, the bank argues that the benefits of reform have not been evenly distributed.

It is concerned that, although the region is receiving a boost from the rise in the price of commodities like oil, one of its most precious resources - its "human capital" - is in danger of being frittered away.

At the start of the transition process many countries of the former Soviet Union were expected to benefit from a combination of low labour costs and high eductional standards.

But in a special analysis of labour markets in the region the EBRD says that, although there has been tremendous resilience in the face of dramatic change, the conventional wisdom is proving flawed.

Although some workers have been able to take advantage of new opportunities, many others have been forced into the black economy and to talk up more than one job in order to make ends meet.

In the CIS - broadly the old Soviet Union - the bank says that despite shortages, skilled employees often find themselves locked into dead end jobs in declining industries.

"It is clear that the two most abundant assets in eastern Europe - the people and their skills - are underemployed," the EBRD"s chief economist Willem Buiter says. "This considerable potential can be unlocked through significant improvements in the business climate, particularly those that help start-ups. In many countries there is also an urgent need to overhaul social safety nets to reduce resistance to painful but inevitable industrial restructuring."

Among the factors the bank believes are required for successful market economies are secure property rights, respect for contracts, transparent governance and low barriers to market entry and exit.

"Other necessary features are the absence of the use of threats, intimidation, harassment and extortion by private parties or by the state and low levels of corruption, including state "capture'."

But Mr Buiter said countries in western Europe had a part to play in the transition. Any delay in the timetable for the first wave of eastern and central European countries joining the EU "could really hurt" the countries involved.

Even after the first wave the EU would need to maintain an open market stance towards countries in south eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union. "It is important we don't replace the iron curtain with the Brussels lace curtain," said Mr Buiter.
