fields.headline: Eddington ousts BA 'deal maker'
fields.standfirst: Year's salary after talks failed
fields.trailText: Rod Eddington, the chief executive of British Airways, has reorganised his management team after the company's failure to clinch a planned merger and its struggle to improve its transatlantic business.
fields.body:
Rod Eddington, the chief executive of British Airways, has reorganised his management team after the company's failure to clinch a planned merger and its struggle to improve its transatlantic business.

Carl Michel, the commerce director, is to leave at the end of this year under the first reorganisation since Mr Eddington took over six months ago. As the senior director in charge of alliances, Mr Michel was involved in the talks with KLM, the Dutch carrier, which broke down earlier this year.

His responsibilities will now be shared between three other directors.

In an internal announcement of the changes, Mr Eddington said that Mr Michel, one of his youngest executives at 37, was leaving with "our best wishes".

David Noyes, director of alliances and franchises, will now report directly to Roger Maynard, head of investments.

Industry analysts had expected more sweeping changes to the team Mr Eddington inherited from Robert Ayling, who was ousted in March. Sources close to the company said yesterday that the Australian chief executive was "looking very carefully at the civil service mafia" appointed by Mr Ayling, a former government lawyer.

BA executives have come under fire for failing to pull off a transatlantic alliance which would improve its flights to and from the US. The company reopened talks with American Airlines last week after negotiations stalled in the face of government rejection and BA's own see-sawing strategy. BA has considered a deeper alliance with Northwest Airlines, an American rival, as well as other continental partners since Mr Eddington took over.

Analysts yesterday said BA needed a transatlantic deal to protect itself against unwanted suitors. There has been speculation that Goldman Sachs, the investment bank appointed to sell BA's low-cost airline, Go, has already drawn up a defence document. Neither BA nor the bank would comment.

Mr Michel was promoted just over a year ago in a previous reshuffle. The former chief executive of Deutsche BA, he is to leave with a golden handshake understood to total at least one year's salary.

Martin George, director of marketing, will be given responsibility for corporate communications following the secondment of Simon Walker to Buckingham Palace.

Carl Michel, the commerce director, is to leave at the end of this year under the first reorganisation since Mr Eddington took over six months ago. As the senior director in charge of alliances, Mr Michel was involved in the talks with KLM, the Dutch carrier, which broke down earlier this year. His responsibilities will now be shared between three other directors. In an internal announcement of the changes, Mr Eddington said that Mr Michel, one of his youngest executives at 37, was leaving with "our best wishes". David Noyes, director of alliances and franchises, will now report directly to Roger Maynard, head of investments. Industry analysts had expected more sweeping changes to the team Mr Eddington inherited from Robert Ayling, who was ousted in March. Sources close to the company said yesterday that the Australian chief executive was "looking very carefully at the civil service mafia" appointed by Mr Ayling, a former government lawyer. BA executives have come under fire for failing to pull off a transatlantic alliance which would improve its flights to and from the US. The company reopened talks with American Airlines last week after negotiations stalled in the face of government rejection and BA's own see-sawing strategy. BA has considered a deeper alliance with Northwest Airlines, an American rival, as well as other continental partners since Mr Eddington took over. fields.headline: Vodafone dispels gloom
fields.standfirst: Mobile group's results cheer telecoms sector and defy analysts' expectations
fields.trailText: Vodafone yesterday calmed fears that fierce competition had stunted growth when it reported a 107% increase in pre-tax profits to £1.8bn in the first half of the year.
fields.body:
Vodafone yesterday calmed fears that fierce competition had stunted growth when it reported a 107% increase in pre-tax profits to £1.8bn in the first half of the year.

Shares in the mobile phone firm were marked up 24.5p at 262.5p in response to the figures, helping to dispel some of the gloom that has been hanging over the telecoms sector.

Chief executive Chris Gent added to the more bullish sentiment when he said he expected the second half of the year to outperform the first. "Far from the rumoured profit warning, we expect growth to be better year on year," he said.

The company also offered some reassurance regarding the amount it intends to spend on the acquisition of third generation mobile licences.

So far it has spent £15bn, and that is likely to reach no more than £17bn, excluding the US. At the market peak, some analysts had predicted Vodafone's liability to be more in the region of £25bn-£30bn.

The results outstripped ana lysts' expectations. Group revenues in the six months to the end of September rose 32% to £10.2bn, and Vodafone's customer base swelled from 42.3m to 65.5m users.

Vodafone shares have taken a mauling recently as some analysts lowered their forecasts because of anticipated problems for the company in Germany. Rapid growth and a price war have led to costly customer acquisitions.

During the half-year, Vodafone's D2 added a record 5.4m new customers, causing margins to fall from 45% to 30%.

Mr Gent said price rises in Germany would improve margins again in the second half, adding that new users would also begin feeding through to earnings for the next six months. "We have a very good underlying business in Germany," he said.

Mr Gent said Vodafone was in an acquisitive mood, although that would not be at the expense of huge debt. Vodafone could be in the market for some of the assets being sold off by BT, itself divesting to reduce debts of £30bn.

"One or two of the Asian as sets could be interesting," he said. "There are bargains out there because there is a limited number of people able to finance transactions."

Vodafone's debt has reached £13.2bn, which it aims to reduce to £10bn by the end of the financial year.

Mr Gent said the failure of some recent third generation auctions in Europe to raise anything like the windfalls accorded to the British and German governments was simply down to companies running out of money.

"I don't believe there has been any collusion between bidders," he said. Data accounts for 5% of revenues, and Mr Gent said Vodafone was still on track to reach 25% of revenues by 2004. But he warned that GPRS, the next standard that is expected to launch wireless internet, is not likely to be commercially available until spring next year.

BT said it would press for substantial damages from Vivendi for being excluded from its Vizzavi internet portal with Vodafone. Reports have suggested BT is seeking a sum in the region of £500m.

fields.headline: Knighthood for a 'kleptocrat'
fields.trailText: A head of state, alleged to have accepted £25m in bribes, this afternoon will be given the red carpet treatment by the Queen when he arrives in London on a three-day visit.
fields.body:
A head of state, alleged to have accepted £25m in bribes, this afternoon will be given the red carpet treatment by the Queen when he arrives in London on a three-day visit.

Nursultan Nazarbayev, president of Kazakhstan, will receive the Order of the Knight of the Grand Cross of St Michael and St George at Buckingham Palace. On Thursday he meets Tony Blair at Downing Street after lunch in his honour at the Cafe Royal. There will be talks with ministers including Stephen Byers, Geoff Hoon and Keith Vaz.

He will hold discussions with defence contractor BAE Systems, and oil and gas companies BP, Shell and BG.

Mr Nazabayev was named in a bribery case by the US justice department. An investigation is under way into the activities of James Giffen, a New York banker and adviser to Mr Nazarbayev. Mobil, Amoco and Phillips Petroleum are alleged to have passed £25m to companies controlled by Mr Giffen which was then passed to the president. All parties deny impropriety but the story has inflamed passions in Kazakhstan and encouraged western media to accuse Mr Nazabayev of presiding over a kleptocracy.

Mr Nazarbayev ran the Communist party in Kazakhstan when it was a Soviet republic. He took power in 1991 when the region elected to leave the USSR.

webTitle: Rate cut hope as house and fuel prices cool inflation

fields.headline: Rate cut hope as house and fuel prices cool inflation
fields.trailText: Hopes of a cut in UK interest rates were raised yesterday after government figures showed that falling petrol prices helped drive down inflation last month.
fields.body:
Hopes of a cut in UK interest rates were raised yesterday after government figures showed that falling petrol prices helped drive down inflation last month.

After going up in September during the fuel protests, pump prices declined last month according to the Office for Na tional Statistics, sending the headline rate of inflation down to 3.1%, from 3.3% in September.

The cooling housing market also contributed to lowering inflation, according to the ONS, as house prices, estate agents fees and contents insurance are all falling.

On the government's preferred measure, which ex cludes mortgage interest costs, inflation fell to 2% from 2.2% in September. The underlying rate has now been below the government's 2.5% target for 19 months.

Some City economists believe yesterday's figures signal that the Bank of England can safely cut interest rates, which have been on hold at 6% since February.

"These are undeniably good numbers for the gilt market," said David Brown, chief European economist at Bear Stearns. "They underline that inflation risks have receded for the Bank of England."

Inflation in the service sector fell to 3.1% in October, its lowest level for two and half years, according to the ONS. The divergence between services and goods inflation, where price pressures have been subdued has been a major concern for the Bank.

"The continuing decline in service sector inflation is particularly welcome," said Geoffrey Dicks, UK economist at the Royal Bank of Scotland.

However shoppers are getting less of a bargain on the high street where shops have offered smaller reductions in this year's autumn sales than in last year's.

The Bank will publish its quarterly inflation forecast tomorrow, a closely watched guide to the views of its key interest rate-setting committee. A forecast below 2.5% for inflation in two years time could signal that the committee is preparing to cut rates.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Don Cruickshank, the chairman of the London Stock Exchange fresh from fending off the hostile bid by OM of Sweden, was accused by MPs yesterday of "dismal chairmanship".
fields.body:
MPs attack LSE chairman

Don Cruickshank, the chairman of the London Stock Exchange fresh from fending off the hostile bid by OM of Sweden, was accused by MPs yesterday of "dismal chairmanship".

Questioned by the commons Treasury select committee, Mr Cruickshank said the LSE had to "march to our customers' drum" and find a way to participate in the "rationalisation" of Europe's stock markets. He refused to comment on the intentions of the American hi-tech market Nasdaq, now regarded as the front runner to merge with the LSE.

Barclaycard's new plastic

Barclaycard, Britain's biggest credit card issuer, is attempting to fend off rivals by trialling a range of new cards, including one aimed at small businesses and another targeted at the growing number of DIY and gardening enthusiasts.

It is also market testing a card which gives people cash back, depending on how much they spend, similar to cards offered by Egg and Alliance & Leicester, plus a low cost, no frills card modelled on those offered by US-based issuers.

Threat to M&S cake workers

More than 500 bakery workers who produce cakes for Marks & Spencer are likely to lose their jobs following the takeover of their company by Northern Foods.

The food group acquired Swindon-based cake company R&K Wise last month and now plans to shut down the plant and transfer the business to an existing Lancashire operation.

The job losses were revealed as Northern Foods, which makes own-label foods for most of the top supermarket chains, reported first half profits up 2.2% to £42m.

Playboy calls off online IPO

Playboy Enterprises cancelled the proposed initial public offering of its online business yesterday in the latest sign of market weakness for dot. coms.

The adult entertainment site filed for a $50m share offering in January, when the valuations of new media companies were at record levels.

Christie Hefner, chairman and chief executive, said: "We do not believe that, under current market conditions, we would receive a valuation that reflects the extraordinary potential of this business." It expects to be profitable by 2002.

Chrysler chief to be replaced

The head of DaimlerChrysler's US division may resign this week, according to local media reports. Chrysler Group chairman James Holden would be replaced by Dieter Zetsche, head of DaimlerChrysler's commercial vehicle unit, the Detroit News reported.

fields.headline: Energis joins BT protest
fields.trailText: Energis chief executive Mike Grabiner yesterday called for a further regulatory crackdown on British Telecom, joining protests that it was dragging its feet in opening up local networks to rivals.
fields.body:
Energis chief executive Mike Grabiner yesterday called for a further regulatory crackdown on British Telecom, joining protests that it was dragging its feet in opening up local networks to rivals.

Mr Grabiner said he was very frustrated by BT's reluctance to liberalise the networks - which carry traffic over the "last mile" to homes. He demanded further separation between its networks and its retail business. BT has said it will split the two businesses, but has not set a date.

He was speaking as Energis's half-year losses jumped 148% to £45.3m pre-tax, owing to interest costs arising from acquisitions and investment in its hi-tech voice and data network.

The company has been a big beneficiary of Freeserve's popular offering of unmetered internet access - the service uses the Energis network. The firm has also won deals to provide servers to host websites for dreamticket.com and bootsphoto.com - which allows customers to create online photo albums.

Shares in the company, which was spun out of National Grid two years ago, rose 33p to 490p.

fields.headline: Corporate jet taxi service halted
fields.trailText: A corporate jet taxi service backed by one of Scotland's richest businessmen was banned from accepting fare-paying passengers yesterday after a civil aviation authority inquiry found the firm was operating without a licence.
fields.body:
A corporate jet taxi service backed by one of Scotland's richest businessmen was banned from accepting fare-paying passengers yesterday after a civil aviation authority inquiry found the firm was operating without a licence.

Corporate Jets, which runs three Lear jets from Glasgow's Prestwick airport and is 60% owned by multimillionaire retail entrepreneur Tom Hunter, was prevented from taking passengers by the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions.

The CAA said the group "was engaged in the unlawful operation of non-UK registered aircraft by flying to and from the UK for reward without obtaining permission".

Corporate Jets' aircraft are registered in the US, and would require two separate forms of approval to operate as UK public transport - a go-ahead from the DETR and an air operator's certificate. The company had neither but was issuing invoices to passengers to cover the cost of their travel.

Mr Hunter, 39, is rated as Scotland's second richest man, with a personal fortune re cently estimated at £400m. A former market trader, he built the Sports Division retail chain before selling out to rival JJB for £250m.

Some of the proceeds were reinvested in other retail projects, including the Fosters menswear chain and Toyzone, an internet retailer. His partners in that enterprise included showbusiness PR man Matthew Freud and TV presenter Jonathan Ross.

Some of the JJB cash was also directed into Corporate Jets, which Mr Hunter co-owns with brothers Neil and Erik Cochrane.

Last night Erik Cochrane, managing director of Corporate Jets, confirmed the company had been banned from accepting paying passengers but insisted the fleet had not been grounded and that there were no concerns about the safety of the jets.

He said Corporate Jets was "currently involved in a dispute with the DETR" but was unwilling to provide details of the company's regular routes or clients. He also refused to outline the nature of the dispute. "We don't want to discuss anything," he said. "We are getting legal advice".

fields.headline: Imprudent Equitable needs to be saved
fields.standfirst: Notebook: pensions firm friendless
fields.trailText: The country's oldest mutual insurer, Equitable Life, once regularly cited as an attractive takeover target for a hungry quoted rival, could yet be spurned on the marriage market.
fields.body:
The country's oldest mutual insurer, Equitable Life, once regularly cited as an attractive takeover target for a hungry quoted rival, could yet be spurned on the marriage market.

Only three months ago the insurer, which hung up a for sale sign after losing its lengthy legal battle over pension guarantees, claimed to have at least 12 potential suitors. The annuity affair visited a £1.5bn-plus hole on its balance sheet, leaving Equitable no option but to find a partner if it wanted to keep up returns to the rest of its policyholders.

Now, just days before the rumoured deadline for final offers from interested bidders, the crescendo in the City suggests just one party - Prudential - is still courting the mutual.

Names such as CGNU, GE Capital, and Barclays Bank have come and gone. Even attempts earlier this week by pan-European insurer Eureko to throw together a last minute bid for Equitable are only being taken half seriously.

If Prudential does turn out to be the last remaining suitor for Equitable, there is the prospect of a serious row: it is widely believed that the Pru's main motivation in chasing this damaged business is in order to put its so-called orphan assets to use, although its policy holders might have other ideas on what could be done with a total of around £8bn of unclaimed money.

While we are speculating (and it should be pointed out that the Pru has never publicly confirmed its interest), it is also worth asking what might happen to Equitable if the Pru were to pull out at this late stage.

This is a business with 600,000 policy holders and 2,000 employees. No wonder, then, that investment bankers Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, handling the marriage arrangements, has already extended the deadline for interested parties once (to the end of this month) and could well extend it again.

Chatter that Equitable might be broken up sounds idle, since it really only has a salesforce to hive off. But at the same time there have been rumours that the regulators may be forced to step in to orchestrate a forced marriage as the only alternative to Equitable closing its doors to new business and effectively "running off" its existing policies.

None of this bodes well for Equitable's policy holders, many of whom have continued to dream of a traditional demutualisation windfall.

In may prove to be the case that the financial black hole created by meeting promised guarantees is actually much bigger than many had assumed.

Perhaps, coming up with a clever way to "ring fence" any losses may be one way to persuade bidders that the Equitable name - historically one of the cheapest providers in the industry - is worth preserving. Then again, too much reputational damage may have already been done.

Hole in ground

Allegations of corruption and environmental destruction seem to follow the energy industry round like a cart behind a horse. Is this the true price of oil?

Just like a British lottery winner, Kazakhstan is discovering there are two sides to a fairy story of untold wealth from black gold in the Caspian Sea.

The oil majors are variously accused of being mixed up in bribery allegations concerning the president, killing off the seal population and destroying the fish that create the world's top supply of caviar. In turn, the Kazakh top man, Nursultan Nazarbayev, is alleged to be diverting oil revenues to his cronies and ignoring the plight of his impoverished countryfolk.

Much of this is patently untrue, all remains unproven. But few people in either the east or west will give the oil majors any benefit of the doubt. Critics say their track record puts them on a par with the defence sector when it comes to unsavoury practices.

Which is a pity, since although BP has had its problems in Colombia and Shell its issues in both Nigeria and the North Sea with Brent Spar, both have been working hard over recent years to prove they are good corporate citizens.

Indeed these top oil majors, which helped make the Kashagan oil strike in the Caspian, have been at the forefront of efforts in Kazakhstan to introduce a sustainable social programme that already is benefiting local people.

The potential tragedy of all this revolves around the sky-high expectations being raised by Kazakh government officials. Only one well has been drilled on Kashagan and no one can possible say at this juncture exactly how much crude lies under the sea. For Mr Nazarbayev to suggest that Kazakhstan is on the brink of becoming the next Saudi Arabia is foolhardy to say the least.

If the oil majors eventually discover they are sitting on 6bn barrels of crude, not 60bn, we all know who the scapegoats will be. And it will not be the president.

In turn, the Kazakh top man, Nursultan Nazarbayev, is alleged to be diverting oil revenues to his cronies and ignoring the plight of his impoverished countryfolk. Much of this is patently untrue, all remains unproven. But few people in either the east or west will give the oil majors any benefit of the doubt. Critics say their track record puts them on a par with the defence sector when it comes to unsavoury practices. Which is a pity, since although BP has had its problems in Colombia and Shell its issues in both Nigeria and the North Sea with Brent Spar, both have been working hard over recent years to prove they are good corporate citizens. Indeed these top oil majors, which helped make the Kashagan oil strike in the Caspian, have been at the forefront of efforts in Kazakhstan to introduce a sustainable social programme that already is benefiting local people. The potential tragedy of all this revolves around the sky-high expectations being raised by Kazakh government officials. Only one well has been drilled on Kashagan and no one can possible say at this juncture exactly how much crude lies under the sea. For Mr Nazarbayev to suggest that Kazakhstan is on the brink of becoming the next Saudi Arabia is foolhardy to say the least. If the oil majors eventually discover they are sitting on 6bn barrels of crude, not 60bn, we all know who the scapegoats will be. And it will not be the president.

webTitle: Business: Nationwide claims influx from big banks

fields.headline: Nationwide claims influx from big banks
fields.trailText: Nationwide will claim tomorrow that it is luring lucrative current account customers from NatWest and Barclays as well as grabbing a 5% share of new current accounts.
fields.body:
Nationwide will claim tomorrow that it is luring lucrative current account customers from NatWest and Barclays as well as grabbing a 5% share of new current accounts.

The claim of 200,000 current accounts opened in the past nine months with the country's largest building society comes as other financial companies are trying to break the stranglehold of the big four - Lloyds TSB, NatWest, Barclays and HSBC - in the current account market.

Halifax, for instance, is aiming to attract customers by offering 4% on deposits for those paying in £1,000 a month while Abbey National has also set its sights on the current account market.

The increased number of current accounts claimed by Nationwide takes its total to 1.7m, still small compared with the likes of Barclays, which boasts more than 8m, and fewer than the 2m or so with Halifax and Abbey National. A spokesman said 45,000 of the new customers had come from NatWest and Barclays.

The building society, which will publish its interim profits figures tomorrow, will reveal that it took in more than 25% of the nation's savings during some months in the latest trading period.

Some of these have been generated by its new e-savings online account launched in June which has 140,000 accounts. The account has topped best-buy tables with its 7% interest rate on deposits, and has £1.2bn of savers' money.

The e-savings account is linked to Nationwide's flex-account, the name of its current account, which customers must open to have access to the rates offered by the online account.

About 40% of new flex-accounts opened are coming via the internet while 30% of all its deposits from savers are coming online.

The building society is expected to claim tomorrow that it has returned more to its members in the past six months than it would have if it had been a bank. In the last profits figures, it said it had saved members £1bn over three years.

webTitle: Business: Abbey spends £55m to lure new affluents

fields.headline: Abbey spends £55m to lure new affluents
fields.trailText: Abbey National has invested £55m in setting up its new wealth management business called Inscape, launched yesterday, and aims to recruit more than 100,000 customers over the next four years.
fields.body:
Abbey National has invested £55m in setting up its new wealth management business called Inscape, launched yesterday, and aims to recruit more than 100,000 customers over the next four years.

The new venture is being targeted at the 4m people in Britain with at least £50,000 to invest and will provide a tailored, face-to-face investment management service via a network of nationwide advice centres.

Abbey denied the move would harm Cater Allen, the City-based private bank already targeting higher net worth individuals, which was acquired by Abbey in 1997. The two businesses will operate separately but Inscape managing director Malcolm Parker hinted they could be brought together at a later date.

Inscape wants £8.5bn of funds under management by December 2004. It has opened six advice centres - in Hanover Square in London's Mayfair, Watford, Bromley, Manchester, Birmingham and Leeds - and plans to open six more next year. These will be open seven days a week.

Inscape has signed deals with nine fund management groups including Schroder, Goldman Sachs and Dresdner RCM which will manage clients' money in markets worldwide.

But it faces competition from a number of rival banks - HSBC and Merrill Lynch, Swiss bank Credit Suisse and Schroders have all recently launched ventures targeting so-called "new affluents".

Mr Parker said most of these were "missing the point for the part of the market we are aiming at". Many of the rival ventures are internet-based but Inscape aims to cater for those seeking face-to-face advice. There will, however, be an online service.

fields.headline: Planting takeover thoughts
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: Market forces.
fields.body:
The bid-chattering classes are getting vocal again. After a few quiet days spent toasting their success in the likes of Lasmo and Ellis & Everard, the market's more clairvoyant players were yesterday predicting plant hire group Ashtead would be the next company to fall to a bid approach.

At the wine bar level the story went like this. Ashtead's decision to remain independent and to expand into the North American plant hire market, via the purchase of Rentokil Initial's plant hire shops, has been a strategic success. So much so that it has attracted the attention of a North American predator (said to be United Rentals) prepared to pay 160p for each of Ashtead's 323m shares. However, traders were not convinced.

As far as anyone could tell the tale rested on the fact that Ashtead's chief executive and chairman are currently in North America on business. With sources close to the company insisting the trip was no more than a regular visit to its US operations, Ashtead shares closed 1p lower at 119.5p, hardly the behaviour of a stock that will be on the end of bid approach.

Nevertheless, volume, at over 1m, was robust for the second consecutive session, suggesting some people were quite literally buying the story.

If the Ashtead story was drawing mixed reviews, then so were events in the wider market. Although the FTSE 100 finished 138.1 points higher at 6,412.9, clawing back all Monday's losses, and the FTSE Techmark 100 rose 99.97 to 3,177.21, City traders remained on guard.

It felt like a rally but traders were not sure what sort of rally it was.Basically, there are two types: the genuine and the sucker. The latter, known as the bear-trap, usually occurs after a period of weakness when investors (normally inexperienced retail punters) move back into the market under the mistaken impression that stocks prices have returned to attractive levels.

Certainly there was enough evidence to suggest yesterday's rally was of the sucker variety. Vodafone, the markets biggest and most influential stock, got things going after it reported better-than-expected interim figures that reaffirmed its status as a growth stock. After what seemed like the whole of London's broking community had issued "buy" notes on the mobile phone giant, its shares closed 24.25p higher at 262.5p.

Predictably this was the cue for investors to pile into the rest of the sector, ignoring the fact that Vodafone is about the only telecom stock that does not have a serious debt problem. So, Energis , which also produced strong figures, rose 33p to 490p and Colt Telecom put on 139p to £17.39. Lower down the corporate scale Kingston Communications also got in on the act, rising 23.5p to 264.5p.

And when Wall Street's most influential analyst, Goldman Sachs' Abby Joseph Cohen, came out and said equity valuations were the most attractive they have been all year, markets on both sides went crazy for tech stocks. So, up went the likes of Logica, 133p better at £18.00p, CMG, 65p higher at £11.05, and Misys, 36.5p stronger at 646p. Even Bookham Technology, a stock dealers could not give away on Monday, rose 205p to £16.

But with Vodafone, which accounted for a quarter of total market turnover and almost half of the FTSE 100's gain, stripped out of the equation there was little to suggest the day's performance was anything other than a blip. Vodafone aside, dealers said most of the buying was related to short covering by hedge fund and the proprietary trading desks of big investment banks.

Elsewhere in the market, car hire group Avis Europe ended 45p higher at 215.75p after some shenanigans in the closing auction. Some unlucky punter ended up paying 220p for a chunk of stock that is bound to open sharply lower today. Paper producer Inveresk fell 5.5p, or 39%, to 8.5p after a profits warning.

fields.headline: Black gold brings petrodollar to the edge of the world
fields.standfirst: In Bautino, rusting hulks litter the jetties and the petrol ran out years ago. Now it's about to become the Klondike of the Caspian as the west arrives in search of oil
fields.trailText: In Bautino, rusting hulks litter the jetties and the petrol ran out years ago. Now it's about to become the Klondike of the Caspian as the west arrives in search of oil.
fields.body:
Bautino in Kazakhstan seems to be perched on the edge of the world. Separated from London by a distance of more than 3,000 miles the tiny, crumbling town can only be reached via three flights and a drive of two hours in sub-zero temperatures.

These days the town clings to the shores of its only remaining lifeline - the Caspian Sea. In its heyday, Bautino - whose population is fewer than 4,000 - was a bustling fishing port providing a welcome rest for travellers on the Silk Road between China and Turkey.

Now rusted trawler hulks litter the harbour, a fish canning factory lies abandoned and amphibious landing craft - formerly the pride of the Red Army - lie disintegrating in what remains of their assembly yard.

The petrol station closed seven years ago, and little moves in Bautino because the fuel has run out. But all this is about to change, for Kazakhstan appears to be on the brink of a "black gold" rush.

Oil, which has trickled around the region since the days of Marco Polo, could flood Kazakhstan's empty state coffers. There are glimpses of this new world in a tiny enclave at the edge of the town.

Behind a high chainlink fence and stiff security, oil men from as far afield as Cardiff and Rotterdam, Texas and Milan tuck into steak au poivre and an assortment of sweets.

They enjoy salaries of at least £50,000 a year working for the biggest energy companies in the world. They could be worth every penny to Kazakhstan because they have struck black gold off the coast. Bautino is promised not just more oil than Aberdeen but more than Saudi Arabia by Kazakhstan's president.

The Offshore Kazakhstan International Operating Company (OKIOC) - which includes BP, Shell and BG - started drilling in the north-east Caspian Sea in August 1999 and by this summer had struck lucky. "Preliminary results suggest that the Kashagan field is one of the largest discoveries made in the last 30 years," said Bill Zempolich, the project's chief geologist.

Kazakhstan's new frontier of oil exploration has made it one of the west's most favoured nations. President Nursultan Nazarbayev is in London today and will be greeted by the Queen, Tony Blair and representatives of big business.

The oil companies are keen to take a slice of the Kashagan find - reckoned to cost £20bn to develop - while governments are keener still to maintain relations with a country which potentially could break the grip of Opec - the 11 country cartel that controls the supply and hence the price of oil. Despite sitting on a single field with one and half times the oil of the entire North Sea and being feted in western capitals, there are no celebrations in Bautino.

"None of [the benefits] will come to us," says Victor Sutyagin, a correspondent for the Interfax agency. "We have had TCO [a Chevron consortium working on the smaller Tengiz development] since 1993 and there have been no changes. We have seen no money. Bribery and corruption is common here," says Mr Sutyagin.

He claims local people oppose the development plans. He is against the scheme as are his colleagues in the media, he says. They all fear the local environment will be damaged and the wealth squandered by the country's ruling elite.

Mr Sutyagin dismisses suggestions by the Kazakh president that his country will be producing 8m barrels per day - as much as the world's biggest crude exporter, Saudi Arabia - by 2015 and everyone will benefit.

"Oil companies like TCO are exempt from taxes. We want control over oil profits, more transparency. And what about the environment? Thousands of seals have already died in the Caspian since drilling started here," he adds through Aina Zubair, an interpreter working for OKIOC.

Assets on tap

Many are concerned about the tapping of the Caspian Sea's precious liquid resource. According to a paper for American University in Washington DC: "Existing oil drilling in the sea is a major cause of pollution. The US Embassy in Baku reports that one can see an oily film on the sea's surface. Another problem is the flaring of natural gas - about 4.5m cubic metres a day."

The sea also contains Kazakhstan's other great export - sturgeon. And oil companies have found few friends among the fisher folk whose homes line the harbour in Bautino. Fishing is a big political issue because the sturgeon population is diminishing. Kazakhstan and Russia are the biggest producers of the high quality black caviar derived from sturgeon.

Kazakh fishermen caught 100 tonnes of sturgeon this season - nowhere near their agreed quota of 360 tonnes - and complained the fish were hard to find. On top of this are estimates that between 10,000 and 20,000 dead seals were washed up on the shores of Kazakhstan between April and June this year.

The reduction in fish catches has been attributed to a number of possible causes, including poaching and pollution from heavy metals being brought down the Volga and Ural rivers from Russia.

OKIOC has been forced to defend its prospecting by calling in experts such as Callan Duck from St Andrews University in Scotland to look at the seal deaths.

The consortium, perhaps unsurpris ingly, concluded that the seals died of a form of canine distemper virus which they believe has nothing to do with any tiny oil seep that has so far surrounded their Kashagan drilling. They point out that seals coexist - with trouble - with oil developments elsewhere in the world.

Matt Bateson, a Shell secondee who acts as external affairs manager for OKIOC, says the consortium is acutely aware of its environmental responsibilities and is monitoring the situation closely.

He said: "How much interest was there in seals before the deaths? Not much."The Kazakh government and Chevron also reject the criticism.

The San Francisco-based oil company says it does pay state taxes, and a spokesman for the Kazakh embassy in London claims Chevron has just paid $600m (£419.2m) into a special future fund which will go towards the good of the country as a whole. He points out that Kazakhstan has changed dramatically in the last decade, compared to many other former Soviet republics.

According to the embassy official in London: "There is no starvation and you do not see people in line for bread. Inflation was 2,000% in 1993 and is barely in double figures now.

"The president is as concerned as everyone about corrupt gangs, and organised a conference on this. With the top job in the country why would he need to accept money himself?"

Green cost

As for the environment, the Kazakh embassy says there is no evidence the seal deaths have been caused by oil spills.

Despite the debate there is little argument that the country needs petrodollars. The population fell by 1% last year and 35% of those left live below the national poverty line. The country's gross domestic product, a crucial indicator of wealth creation, plummeted from $39m in 1989 to $15.9m last year, while Kazakhstan has outstanding debt of $8bn.

Around 200 miles to the north-west, back in Atyrau where OKIOC and TCO have their international headquarters, Big Oil has tried to soften the face of the foreign multinationals through a host of social infrastructure projects.

Mr Bateson is keen to show off three schools which the consortium helped to build and a range of other projects, including a sturgeon farm.

But the issue of the environment will not go away. Neither, immediately, will allegations of bribery between energy groups and the Kazakh president - despite the denials by all parties.

Whether there is further money to be made, either personally or collectively, in Kazakhstan depends on whether the western oil consortium can firm up the estimates of oil at Kashagan, which range from 6bn to 60bn barrels. Once the reserves are proved to exist, the OKIOC will have to find a way of transporting oil and gas from this remote location.

Russia and the US have already sent their foreign ministers into the fray.

The most economic route would be south to Iran and on to the Persian Gulf, where it could easily be carried by sea-going tankers around the world.

But the US regards that as a security threat, and supports the construction of a pipeline to Turkey. The Russians, who are trying to reassert their authority over Kazakhstan, want the crude put into their own pipeline network.

Kazakhstan might be physically four times the size of France, but politically it remains a fledgling independent state.

Local journalists are aware of this and worry about the power of the multinationals. While they are wary of the OKIOC, they do believe that the consortium is trying harder to be more transparent than its predecessors.

Still, says Mr Sutyagin, the experience with the TCO consortium at Tengiz over tax, fears about the environment and the allegations of corruption left a difficult legacy which affects the public perception of BP, Shell and others drilling at Kashagan.

He says the issue for the oil industry is this: "We have lost trust." The oil majors have a public relations mountain to climb on land - even before they have begun to prove how much black gold lies at the bottom of the Caspian Sea.

Kazakhstan might be physically four times the size of France, but politically it remains a fledgling independent state. Local journalists are aware of this and worry about the power of the multinationals. While they are wary of the OKIOC, they do believe that the consortium is trying harder to be more transparent than its predecessors. Still, says Mr Sutyagin, the experience with the TCO consortium at Tengiz over tax, fears about the environment and the allegations of corruption left a difficult legacy which affects the public perception of BP, Shell and others drilling at Kashagan. He says the issue for the oil industry is this: "We have lost trust." The oil majors have a public relations mountain to climb on land - even before they have begun to prove how much black gold lies at the bottom of the Caspian Sea.

fields.headline: At this price? Oxford Instruments
fields.trailText: For a firm which recently built the world's most powerful magnet, Oxford Instruments is finding it surprisingly difficult to attract investors.
fields.body:
For a firm which recently built the world's most powerful magnet, Oxford Instruments is finding it surprisingly difficult to attract investors.

The company, a spin-off from Oxford University in 1959, specialises in making medical instruments and research products. Its magnets are often used by drugs companies - to help determine the structure and layout of molecules.

It is restructuring after taking on too many manufacturing contracts, culminating in four profits warnings over two years. Chief executive Andrew Mackintosh has cut 150 jobs, contracted out manufacturing of simpler products and concentrated on building technical expertise.

His reorganisation programme, called "Top Flight," will cost £1.8m this year and is due to yield annual savings of £4m. It is beginning to pay off. Half-year operating profits edged up from £300,000 to £500,000, excluding contributions from buinesses recently sold.

Mr Mackintosh wants to focus on niche products such as semiconductor detectors - used, for example, to measure the amount of sulphur in petrol or to identify impurities in electronic products. The market is yet to be convinced. The shares fell 3.5p to 165p yesterday, a long way off their 1996 peak of 541p. The company is valued at £79m, surprisingly low for a business with 1,200 employees.

Critics complain that Oxford Instruments has missed forecasts so many times that it has lost the trust of the City. As recently as June, it produced full-year results which were in the red, when analysts had expected break-even.

A profit of £4m is expected in the second half, followed by £8m in the year to March 2002. By that time, Mr Mackintosh's shake-up will be complete, with the firm operating from four, rather than seven, sites. Few would argue that the shares are cheap but given the firm's unreliable recent record, investors should wait to see if it can deliver profits at the end of this financial year.

fields.headline: EasyJet takes off
fields.trailText: Stelios Haji-Ioannou's budget airline, EasyJet, comes to market today, and all the indications are that the flotation is likely to go with a bang. Whispers coming from float managers UBS Warburg and CSFB yesterday suggested demand for the stock had been strong.
fields.body:
Stelios Haji-Ioannou's budget airline, EasyJet, comes to market today, and all the indications are that the flotation is likely to go with a bang. Whispers coming from float managers UBS Warburg and CSFB yesterday suggested demand for the stock had been strong.

Pricing for the 63m new shares EasyJet is offering in the flotation was taking place last night and according to the gossips, they are likely to placed with institutions in the middle of the 280-340p range announced last week. Cantor Index was last night offering a grey market in EasyJet shares of 300-310p.

At the mid-point the flotation would value EasyJet, Europe's second largest budget airline, at £778m and raise £195m.

However, retail investors will not be able to get their hands on the stock for another seven days, when unconditional trading in EasyJet is scheduled to begin.

fields.headline: A quick one
fields.trailText: So Harry and I are hunched in the gloomy afternoon light of a pub in the West End. The only other drinker is an enormously old man who sits alone, a cigarette unicorned to his head. When he shuffles painfully out of the bar, Harry conjectures that he is off to play the detective in The Mousetrap. We finish our pints and follow him out, for we too are going to the theatre.
fields.body:
So Harry and I are hunched in the gloomy afternoon light of a pub in the West End. The only other drinker is an enormously old man who sits alone, a cigarette unicorned to his head. When he shuffles painfully out of the bar, Harry conjectures that he is off to play the detective in The Mousetrap. We finish our pints and follow him out, for we too are going to the theatre.

Attending matinees makes me feel guilty that I am not working but also virtuous because I am not watching TV. Actors are also ambivalent about them. They hate doing them and yet a disproportionate number of theatrical anecdotes seem to involve high jinks during an afternoon performance. Here's one: an actor noted for his drinking wakes up in the early evening with a hangover and realises he's missed the matinee. He rushes to the theatre and says he's sorry. The company manager replies, "I should think you are. That was the worst performance I've ever seen."

In actorly legend matinees are sparsely attended by mad old ladies and schoolchildren who fart and eat crisps. This wasn't the case at Stones in His Pockets, at the Duke of York's. It was almost sold out and the teenagers present were well behaved to the point of primness. Admittedly most of the audience were getting on a bit, but so what? So am I.

Harry, who has written plays, believes that Irish playwrights have an advantage over other dramatists. They have a history rich in war and persecution; they have the theme of the longing to escape (usually to America) and the desire to stay (usually in a village with a made-up name). If the play's flagging you can stick in a bit of rousing Riverdance stuff. Always on tap is that delicious Irish "nostalgie de la peat". Stones in His Pockets had all these elements and more. I loved it.

Harry agreed that it was well-written and beautifully acted, but this did not prevent him from staying in the pub during the second half. He could not endure another hour without a cigarette. It is dark when I rejoin him. We drink more Guinness. I go home and put the Pogues on. Another afternoon dispatched.

fields.headline: Snap decisions
fields.standfirst: A national photography gallery? Well, there's one in Bradford, one in Bath, another in London... and soon, Devizes.  Jonathan Jones asks why Britain can't have a single collection
fields.trailText: A national photography gallery? Well, there's one in Bradford, one in Bath, another in London... and soon, Devizes. Jonathan Jones asks why Britain can't have a single collection.
fields.body:
When the 18th-century writer Arnold Houbraken published a biographical dictionary of Dutch artists he made only a perfunctory mention of the obscure Delft painter Jan Vermeer. A century and a half later the French critic Thoré-Bürger wrote enthusiastically about a great artist he had discovered. Almost overnight Jan Vermeer became what he is today, one of the most revered painters in the world. What had changed? The answer is the invention of the photograph.

It was only when people compared Vermeer's silent interiors to photographs that they were enraptured by him, by that woman holding a jug, letting a white stream of milk pour into a brown bowl. By the standards of art criticism in previous centuries, when narrative painting was the highest art, it is all utterly banal.

As banal, and fascinating, as the haystack photographed by William Henry Fox Talbot in 1844, in which every strand of hay is visible. By the 1890s haystacks would be fit matter for painting. Monet's paintings of haystacks are not allegories; they are just studies of light falling on these objects in the fields. The photograph gave art a new love of the ordinariness of ordinary things. Yet photography itself remained a despised, suspiciously technical newcomer among the arts.

This is especially true in Britain where something went sadly wrong at the end of the 19th century. The photograph was a product of Victorian scientific curiosity, but just as the energy of 19th-century architecture and engineering gave way in Britain to a timid anti-modernism after the first world war, so did the Victorian passion for photography.

Britain, the first country to take the photograph seriously, now gives it the shortest shrift in its national art museums. There is no central, authoritative public photography collection in Britain. Instead the Royal Photographic Society in Bath, founded in 1853 and one of the oldest collections in the world, with spectacular holdings of 19th-century greats such as Fox Talbot and Julia Margaret Cameron, is fighting to maintain its priceless prints, negatives and other materials.

"We have a very important national photography collection which is held by a private institution and with the best will in the world we can't put enough money in it to behave like a national collection at the moment," says its curator Pam Roberts.

In the absence of national public support the collection, which is funded by the membership of the RPS, is currently pursuing a lottery partnership grant with the Wiltshire public records office. If this is awarded the RPS will move to a new building in Devizes, a fairly remote location for a national centre for photography. The RPS say they have to move to a modern building better equipped than their current 18th-century home. "This is not about a beleaguered society," insists the company secretary, Barry Lane. Nevertheless, its exhibition gallery in Bath will close when the current show Photogenic, a survey of the entire collection, ends.

The Victoria and Albert Museum has collected photographs since 1856, but does not present them in relation to high art. When the V&A opened the Canon Photography Gallery in 1998, it published a book championing photography as "An Independent Art", a modest claim for a medium that has revolutionised human consciousness. And in Bradford there is the National Museum of Photography, Film and Television, established in 1983. "Between us we have better collections than anywhere," insists Lane. But what we do not have is the institutional weight that can only be given to photography by displaying it in a national art museum.

This is because photography in Britain has never played the game of defining itself as an art. In the 19th century this was not a problem; early photographers made no distinction between aesthetic and practical uses of their medium. The RPS was founded "to promote the art and science of photography". Yet in the 20th century those who championed photographs as high art have striven to separate the "art photograph" from the snapshot and photojournalism. "There are two distinct roads in photography - the utilitarian and the aesthetic," wrote the American critic Charles Caffin in Photography as a Fine Art in 1901, "the goal of the one being a record of facts, and the other an expression of beauty."

What alarms us about photography is its universality. To define a photograph as art is to democratise the very idea of art. Tate Modern, for the first time in Britain, incorporates photographic images in a systematic way in its displays. But the criteria which make one photograph suitable for Tate Modern and consign another to an archive are as elitist today as they were in the early 20th century.

The story was different in the US, where the photographer and artist Alfred Stieglitz saved photography for art by separating it from function. Since the 1980s postmodern theory has saved photography for art by denying that light registering on sensitised paper has any authenticity.

This should be fun, but lately has given rise to some astonishingly bad art. When Cindy Sherman made her first Untitled Film Stills in the late 1970s there was real excitement. She could change her face, become a girl in a thriller, a victim in a horror film. Today, this use of the camera is academic; it is a cliche to think that the camera always lies. Artists assume the camera is a tool to make images rather than find them. This is the photographic art that is promoted by art galleries today, art that is recognised as art because it is about ideas.

"What most artists using photography feel that they need to do is to show that they are serious, that they are not taking snapshots," says Wolfgang Tillmans. "To point a camera at something does not qualify you as an artist because everybody has done that." Tillmans's photographs have been nominated for the Turner prize. If he wins, he will be the first photographer to do so. If he doesn't, it will be because his work looks too much like mere photography.

In the National Gallery there is a painting by Georges Seurat of an expanse of nothingness at the edge of a community, recorded without emotional inflection. Seurat's Channel at Gravelines (1890) is a painting that could not have been conceived before photography. We could not enjoy a painting like this, could not even see it as art, without unconsciously thinking of photography; Seurat could not have painted it without the example of photography.

Yet the National Gallery, like the Tate until recently, has never talked about photography in the same breath as painting. In New York's Metropolitan Museum you can stroll from the painting galleries to take in an exhibition of photographs; at the Museum of Modern Art you can look at the work of Walker Evans, Garry Winogrand or William Eggleston alongside paintings by Robert Rauschenberg and Andy Warhol, and see for yourself how it all adds up. We don't have that opportunity and it is one of the limits on our visual culture.

 Photogenic is at the Royal Photographic Society, Bath (01225 462841), until January 28. The Turner prize show is at Tate Britain, London SW1 (020-7887 8008), until January 14.

webTitle: Theatre: Max Stafford-Clark talks to  Lyn Gardner

fields.headline: 'The middle classes are the movers and shakers. They get things done'
fields.standfirst: Max Stafford-Clark explains his brand of personal politics to  Lyn Gardner
fields.trailText: Max Stafford-Clark explains his brand of personal politics to Lyn Gardner
fields.body:
When he left the Royal Court in 1993 there were many who thought Max Stafford-Clark would never again be a major player in British theatre. He had been at the Court for 14 years, and his undignified and unwilling departure suggested that he had become institutionalised. What the doubters underestimated was just how shrewd an operator Stafford-Clark is, and how capable of creating his own luck. Within a year he was making the news, this time for the right reasons.

Stafford-Clark had founded that rarest of things: a highly successful touring theatre company specialising in new work. Out of Joint's most famous production - Mark Ravenhill's Shopping and Fucking, with its mix of hardcore sex and takeaways - made theatre suddenly seem upfront and essential; and its premiere of Caryl Churchill's Blue Heart paved the way for the theatrical obsession with the unreliability of language.

Stafford-Clark's latest production for Out of Joint is a double bill that you might call a state-of-the-nation evening, if that didn't make it sound old-fashioned. It certainly reflects the fact that words like "socialism" and "working-class" have disappeared from New Labour's vocabulary, while phrases such as "underclass" now fall from Tony Blair's lips.

The evening comprises a revival of Andrea Dunbar's brutally funny account of life on a Bradford housing estate, Rita, Sue and Bob Too, which Stafford-Clark first directed at the Royal Court almost 20 years ago. He has paired it with a new play, A State Affair, that revisits Dunbar's Bradford and deprived estates in other parts of Britain and makes vital, living theatre out of the verbatim testimony of those living there and trying to survive the consequences of drug addiction, child abuse, domestic violence and lack of hope. This is an infinitely more shocking evening than Shopping and Fucking.

Stafford-Clark makes no apologies for putting it in front of our noses or the fact that these two plays will, like most theatre, almost inevitably play to the well-heeled.

"I like the middle class," he declares. "Without the middle class there would be no theatre. They are the movers and shakers, the people who get things done. They are the people who need to be acquainted with this world and understand it. I've no problem with the fact that theatre plays to the intelligentsia. The first audience I seek to engage is my peer group. Sometimes what you do becomes a popular success. But you can't aim at it. All you can aim to do is please yourself."

If this double bill were broadcast on TV it would provoke a national debate. The fact that it appears in the theatre means it will probably pass almost unnoticed. But its very existence points to Stafford-Clark's greatest gift and the reason for his longevity - an ability to sniff the zeitgeist and turn it into theatre. Unlike many directors of new writing - and indeed many critics - his taste has not become fixed at some date in the past when he was in his prime. It is constantly being moved on by an inquisitiveness about the world and about other worlds. It is why, with 60 staring him in the face, he is still a credible champion of new writing and not just a silly old has-been trying to be young and trendy.

"I am very much aware that I will be 60 next year, but I am not sure that it matters if you are engaged with the world. Just as I can explore the other world of a Bradford housing estate through these plays, so I can approach the world of youth in a similar way. If I were simply defined by the world I knew, I would only do plays by middle-class doctors' sons, which I suppose would qualify me for Chekhov and not much else. A writer's life can be brutally short because they deal with first-hand experience. But a director's life is longer because we are collaborative artists and work off the inspiration of others. If you are open to it, you could go on for ever."

Stafford-Clark has been at it for over 30 years, first making his mark at Edinburgh's Traverse theatre then co-founding the political theatre collective Joint Stock in 1974. That lead to his appointment to the Royal Court in 1979. I remember him there during the mid-80s, his glossy moustache and long hair giving him the look of a neurotic King Charles Spaniel. There was a lurking sense of paranoia evident in the sorrowful, tear-stained letters that he would send to you if he thought you had given one of his productions less than its due, and in the annual critics' Christmas lunch in which he would take his revenge by making critics play unwinnable party games that demonstrated just how hard it was to run the Court.

Looking back, Stafford-Clark probably had justification for his paranoia. There is now plenty of evidence that during the Thatcher years there were many who would have liked to have seen the demise of the Royal Court. Of course Stafford-Clark made mistakes, most notably over deciding to stage Jim Allen's anti-Zionist play Perdition and then abandoning it; but if you take his predecessor Bill Gaskill's maxim that the first task of the Court's artistic director is to survive, and the second is not to miss the best play of the decade, then Stafford-Clark did pretty well in an era of increasing opposition and diminishing funding. In a decade that didn't throw up too many gems he championed the cause of women playwrights and nurtured two major talents in Caryl Churchill and Timberlake Wertenbaker. If the Court was sometimes an unhappy ship during his time there, full of rumour and intrigue, that is perhaps the nature of the organisation: his successors Stephen Daldry and Ian Rickson have fared no better.

Stafford-Clark can evaluate his time at the Court more dispassionately these days. "I was managing a retreat at the Court during the 80s, and it is never so glorious conducting an army in retreat than an army in advance. I did stay too long because I didn't have the imagination to leave. But when I did leave I didn't have one moment's nostalgia, and I'm proud I left the Court with the £350,000 surplus that funded the work Stephen Daldry used to expand. He had the personality for expansion - I didn't."

Stafford-Clark retains a connection with the Court and regularly attends script meetings, but his energies are with Out of Joint, the company that has given him a new lease of life. "One of the things I love about Out of Joint is that because we only do two or three productions you need only do plays that you are really passionate about, not the ones that aren't at the centre of your taste but that you think you ought to do. That's freedom."

But surely he must miss running a building? "Only in very fleeting moments. I did visit a regional theatre in a mess a while back and just for a moment thought 'Wouldn't it be exciting_?', but it was only a moment. I can't imagine circumstances in which I would leave Out of Joint, but of course_," he pauses, his eyes twinkling. "What can you do if the nation calls you?" The room rings with his laughter. The old Stafford-Clark would never have been able to send himself up like that.

 Rita, Sue and Bob Too and A State Affair are at the Mercury, Colchester (01206 573948), until Saturday, then tour to Eastbourne, Plymouth and the Soho Theatre, London WC2 (020-7478 0100).

The evening comprises a revival of Andrea Dunbar's brutally funny account of life on a Bradford housing estate, Rita, Sue and Bob Too, which Stafford-Clark first directed at the Royal Court almost 20 years ago. He has paired it with a new play, A State Affair, that revisits Dunbar's Bradford and deprived estates in other parts of Britain and makes vital, living theatre out of the verbatim testimony of those living there and trying to survive the consequences of drug addiction, child abuse, domestic violence and lack of hope. This is an infinitely more shocking evening than Shopping and Fucking. Stafford-Clark makes no apologies for putting it in front of our noses or the fact that these two plays will, like most theatre, almost inevitably play to the well-heeled. "I like the middle class," he declares. "Without the middle class there would be no theatre. They are the movers and shakers, the people who get things done. They are the people who need to be acquainted with this world and understand it. I've no problem with the fact that theatre plays to the intelligentsia. The first audience I seek to engage is my peer group. Sometimes what you do becomes a popular success. But you can't aim at it. All you can aim to do is please yourself." If this double bill were broadcast on TV it would provoke a national debate. The fact that it appears in the theatre means it will probably pass almost unnoticed. But its very existence points to Stafford-Clark's greatest gift and the reason for his longevity - an ability to sniff the zeitgeist and turn it into theatre. Unlike many directors of new writing - and indeed many critics - his taste has not become fixed at some date in the past when he was in his prime. It is constantly being moved on by an inquisitiveness about the world and about other worlds. It is why, with 60 staring him in the face, he is still a credible champion of new writing and not just a silly old has-been trying to be young and trendy. "I am very much aware that I will be 60 next year, but I am not sure that it matters if you are engaged with the world. Just as I can explore the other world of a Bradford housing estate through these plays, so I can approach the world of youth in a similar way. If I were simply defined by the world I knew, I would only do plays by middle-class doctors' sons, which I suppose would qualify me for Chekhov and not much else. A writer's life can be brutally short because they deal with first-hand experience. But a director's life is longer because we are collaborative artists and work off the inspiration of others. If you are open to it, you could go on for ever." Stafford-Clark has been at it for over 30 years, first making his mark at Edinburgh's Traverse theatre then co-founding the political theatre collective Joint Stock in 1974. That lead to his appointment to the Royal Court in 1979. I remember him there during the mid-80s, his glossy moustache and long hair giving him the look of a neurotic King Charles Spaniel. There was a lurking sense of paranoia evident in the sorrowful, tear-stained letters that he would send to you if he thought you had given one of his productions less than its due, and in the annual critics' Christmas lunch in which he would take his revenge by making critics play unwinnable party games that demonstrated just how hard it was to run the Court. Looking back, Stafford-Clark probably had justification for his paranoia. There is now plenty of evidence that during the Thatcher years there were many who would have liked to have seen the demise of the Royal Court. Of course Stafford-Clark made mistakes, most notably over deciding to stage Jim Allen's anti-Zionist play Perdition and then abandoning it; but if you take his predecessor Bill Gaskill's maxim that the first task of the Court's artistic director is to survive, and the second is not to miss the best play of the decade, then Stafford-Clark did pretty well in an era of increasing opposition and diminishing funding. In a decade that didn't throw up too many gems he championed the cause of women playwrights and nurtured two major talents in Caryl Churchill and Timberlake Wertenbaker. If the Court was sometimes an unhappy ship during his time there, full of rumour and intrigue, that is perhaps the nature of the organisation: his successors Stephen Daldry and Ian Rickson have fared no better. Stafford-Clark can evaluate his time at the Court more dispassionately these days. "I was managing a retreat at the Court during the 80s, and it is never so glorious conducting an army in retreat than an army in advance. I did stay too long because I didn't have the imagination to leave. But when I did leave I didn't have one moment's nostalgia, and I'm proud I left the Court with the £350,000 surplus that funded the work Stephen Daldry used to expand. He had the personality for expansion - I didn't." Stafford-Clark retains a connection with the Court and regularly attends script meetings, but his energies are with Out of Joint, the company that has given him a new lease of life. "One of the things I love about Out of Joint is that because we only do two or three productions you need only do plays that you are really passionate about, not the ones that aren't at the centre of your taste but that you think you ought to do. That's freedom." But surely he must miss running a building? "Only in very fleeting moments. I did visit a regional theatre in a mess a while back and just for a moment thought 'Wouldn't it be exciting_?', but it was only a moment. I can't imagine circumstances in which I would leave Out of Joint, but of course_," he pauses, his eyes twinkling. "What can you do if the nation calls you?" The room rings with his laughter. The old Stafford-Clark would never have been able to send himself up like that.  Rita, Sue and Bob Too and A State Affair are at the Mercury, Colchester (01206 573948), until Saturday, then tour to Eastbourne, Plymouth and the Soho Theatre, London WC2 (020-7478 0100).

fields.headline: Paris: caught on camera
fields.trailText: In France, as Joni Mitchell sang, they kiss on Main Street; in Paris they kiss in squares, bars, bedrooms, wherever, but, it seems, always for the camera.
fields.body:
In France, as Joni Mitchell sang, they kiss on Main Street; in Paris they kiss in squares, bars, bedrooms, wherever, but, it seems, always for the camera. Remember Doisneau? The city's visual narcissism knows no bounds: since the invention of photography in 1839, Paris has been its own mirror. Consider the city's 20th Month of Photography, just launched, in which there are over 60 exhibitions, the majority of which are about Paris itself.

At the Musée d'Histoire de France there is the official photographic version on display - pictures from the universal exhibitions between 1855 and 1900, during which time the city could strut as the cultural and perhaps industrial capital of the world. But at the Archives de Paris, you can see the flip-side - photographs taken in 1900 of tough streets and poor people by L'Union Photographique Française.

Then there's the intriguing show Nietzsche's Paris, which is all very well, but Nietzsche never visited Paris. Paris is always doing this - inventing implausible excuses for little trysts with itself. At the Hotel de Ville there is an exhibition - Des Européens à Paris - devoted to how foreigners have seen the city; while at the Goethe Institut is one of the best shows, of the work of Ilse Bing. This German Jew bought a Leica in 1929, arrived in Paris the next year and spent the low, dishonest decade working for Harper's Bazaar and Le Monde Illustre. Look at the flashing skirt of her can-can dancer at the Moulin Rouge in 1931 and you can see how badly she fell in love.

Paris is also in love with the medium of photography. Consider La Maison Européenne de la Photographie, which has just finished a marvellous retrospective of Vogue photographer Irving Penn and is starting one of Magnum photographer Raymond Depardon. Photography is treated seriously here - not just as an art form, but as ethnography, documentary, sociology. At the Musée Carnavalet is a show of 3D pictures from 1850 stereoscopy to virtual reality. This is a fascinating historical exhibition, but one can't help feeling that it's a pretext for a series of virtual Parises so that the city can enjoy exploring itself.

fields.headline: We ask the questions
fields.standfirst: The art of interrogation
fields.trailText: The art of interrogation
fields.body:
Questions are a wonderful device for obtaining access to knowledge, and yet the less they help us learn about the world, the more we seem to value them. Take this delirious sequence from a recent Hello! interview with Claudia Schiffer: "How can a girl like you love insects?"; "Are there a lot of people in the world who collect insects?"; "Are insects the only thing that you and Johnny Depp have in common?". I now understand less than I ever did about Claudia, Johnny, entomology or the mindset of a Hello! interviewer. But my awareness of the imponderability of all things is strangely enhanced. Wittgenstein could have used a subscription to Hello!.

I'll never be able to read the magazine in the same way again, or watch University Challenge, or listen to parliamentary question time after seeing Forced Entertainment's 12-hour Quizoola! this weekend. Billed as a "durational performance", Quizoola! could be described as an inquiry into inquiry itself.

The show has been going, intermittently, since 1996 and has been staged in venues that include the basement of a destroyed building in Beirut. The latest venue was the second floor of the provisional exhibition space The Museum Of, on London's South Bank - a long, warehouse room, cold, dusty, just the place you might walk in on a bunch of villains making friendly enquiries of a bloodied associate. Here, even more unnervingly, you find two people sitting in smeared clown make-up, inside acircle of lightbulbs, engaged in a seemingly eternal loop of questions and answers. Every now and then the questioner asks, "Do you want to stop?" and the pair exchange roles. During the day, new participants come to replace one of the pair.

The performance looks as though it should be a straight TV show parody, but that is only one of many possible interpretations. Through the day, the performance resembles a police interrogation, an Ionesco play, Derek and Clive routines, Paxman quizzing a politician, Paxman quizzing a UMIST postgraduate student. The relations between questioners and respondents change all the time: brutal impersonality suddenly becomes conspiratorial or even intimate. At one point, between a man and a woman, the investigation touches on mutual attraction, then on gynaecological detail.

But we never know exactly who we are watching: actors performing a role, comics improvising, or depersonalised subjects of a ghastly, gruelling ritual, stripped of personal identity by their clown make-up. And because we don't know who they are, we can't be sure about the truth of their answers. It's a safe bet that the man in the yellow shirt is neither a postman nor a gladiator nor a colleague of Elvis Presley. But does this mean that the man in the red shirt is not really the father of a three-year-old boy called Jacob? Or that Frederick Forsyth is not the author of The Dogs of War?

The interrogation begins with a set of 2,000 questions prepared by Forced Entertainment writer/ director Tim Etchells. The questioner starts from the text, receives an answer, then either uses that as a cue to invent another question, or returns to the text. Etchells' rules of play propose that everything should depend on "the feeling that the performers themselves are bound up with the task - that they have something at stake in it."

Other stipulations are that entirely facetious answers are banned, and that performers should not pursue a coherent line of inquiry for too long. But the fact that there are rules opens the game all the more to the vagaries of individual performance. The first three hours I saw, from noon to three, were mesmerisingly energetic, with the performers developing a tense, yet oddly casual, rapport. By evening, two less charismatic performers had taken their place, and over an hour with barely any modulation, you felt you were sitting in on a listless therapy session or a student production of Beckett.

The most unnerving thing about the 12-hour show was the thought that you could leave at any time and know that up in that chilly space, the ritual would be continuing, two people still forcing out responses, still shivering away in their smeared greasepaint. It was as if the entire repertoire of questions in the world were being exhausted in that room, so that no one outside would ever need to ask anything. At midnight, a cluster of viewers were still huddled, waiting to see whether Quizoola! would reach any climax or closure. But bang on 12, there was just a discreet "Do you want to stop?" I wonder if they touched on the issue of Claudia's insects while I was out.

 Quizoola! will be in Dartington, Devon, on November 29 and Leeds on December 15; further dates will be added for spring 2001. Details: 0114 279 8977.
