webTitle: Timorese pay the price for stability

fields.headline: Timorese pay the price for stability
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: International realpolitik proved more important than humanitarian concerns yesterday when the United Nations admitted it was better to keep Indonesia's president in power than to fight for 120,000 starving East Timorese refugees who have been held as political pawns in West Timor for the past 14 months.
fields.byline: John Aglionby in Atambua, West Timor
fields.body:
International realpolitik proved more important than humanitarian concerns yesterday when the United Nations admitted it was better to keep Indonesia's president in power than to fight for 120,000 starving East Timorese refugees who have been held as political pawns in West Timor for the past 14 months.

A team of seven UN security council representatives, including Britain's deputy permanent representative, Stewart Eldon, said during a visit to Timor that no action would be taken against Indonesia's president, Abdurrahman Wahid, for failing to comply with the council's resolution ordering a rapid conclusion to the refugee crisis.

The mission's leader, Namibia's UN representative, Martin Andjaba, said just before leaving independent East Timor for Indonesian West Timor that he was "not here to punish Indonesia or to recommend to the security council to call for punishment".

"Our mission is not to destabilise," he said. "We do not want any confrontations. We want cooperation with the Indonesian authorities so everything can be done to address the issue of the refugees and bring them back to East Timor."

More than 170,000 refugees have already returned home but the flow of repatriation has practically dried up since after all international and the majority of local agencies pulled out of the region following the murder of three UN refugee agency staff in the West Timor border town of Atambua on September 6.

They were killed by a mob of pro-Jakarta East Timorese militia who, backed by elements of the Indonesian army, had been terrorising the refugees and the humanitarian workers since their arrival in September 1999 to help resolve the crisis.

The security council immediately passed a resolution calling for the disarming and disbanding of the militias, the prosecution of the murderers, the restoration of law and order, and a greater effort to help repatriate those refugees who want to return to East Timor.

Jakarta immediately deployed more than 5,000 troops and police to West Timor and, in a grand public display, began searching for weapons. More than 90 automatic rifles and hundreds of homemade guns were seized and several people were arrested in connection with the murders.

The UN representatives are in Timor to assess progress and to gauge the best way forward. The team is due to visit Atambua today, but it is unlikely to get a true picture of events; the trip is being carefully stage-managed. More than 1,000 soldiers have been deployed in the town.

They have already heard first-hand from newly returned refugees to East Timor that the reality in West Timor is that the militias and some military units are still terrorising the refugees, preventing them from making a free choice about whether to return to East Timor.

It is also clear that the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and other international agencies would face enormous hostility from the militias if they tried to restart humanitarian assistance and repatriation programmes in West Timor.

One UN source in East Timor said: "Everyone here in East Timor recognises that it's in no one's interests, least of all the refugees, to rock the fragile political position of President Wahid in Jakarta."

President Wahid is under increasing pressure to resign. The crisis in West Timor is just one of several battles he is fighting. Rapidly escalating separatist conflicts in Aceh and Papua, two financial scandals, his failure to end the country's prolonged economic turmoil and the government's inability to find the fugitive son of the former dictator, Suharto, are also being used as ammunition by his critics.

However, the international community regards Mr Wahid as the safest presidential candidate, according to the UN source. "The worry is that if Mr Wahid is forced out," he said, "Indonesia could very well descend into long-term political instability that might pave the way for a military takeover."

fields.headline: Judging prisons
fields.standfirst: If we are to accept that jail works, and incarcerate more people for longer, we must have a public debate on penal reform
fields.trailText: If we are to accept that jail works, and incarcerate more people for longer, we must have a public debate on penal reform
fields.body:
We are seeing a political revival of imprisonment. Instead of considering it a measure of last resort, both Labour and the Tories are presenting prison as an instrument of individual reform and public protection, with an enthusiasm not seen since the middle of the 19th century.

The movement comes from two directions. One is the development of training and rehabilitative courses within prisons - for offending behaviour, drug abuse, for sex offenders - which make ambitious claims for their success in terms of the prisoner's return to "normal life" and the prevention of reoffending. As well as paying for another 2,660 prison places in the July spending plan, the government announced a "custody to work" programme, aiming to double the proportion of prisoners going directly into jobs on release. Money has been provided to increase by 50% the number of national qualifications which prisoners achieve in prison. They have been rising, as the chart shows.

The government's strategy for women offenders is full of similarly good intentions, while the Tories go further and propose financially self-supporting industrial prisons, where prisoners earn wages from which they will pay for their keep and support their families.

The thesis here is that prisons "work" not only in preventing offenders from committing further offences against the public, but also in reforming their characters.

The other direction is policies which deliberately increase the use of imprisonment - not only for dangerous or persistent offenders - for failure to comply with orders or conditions. The prison population has risen by a half since 1992. The number of women prisoners has more than doubled, and the population of juveniles under 18 has tripled. The Tories want juveniles to be imprisoned in even larger numbers.

The prison population is projected to increase by a further 7-20% by 2007 depending on what assumptions are made of the effect of new policies and legislation. Overcrowding seems set to continue indefinitely.

It becomes more acceptable to send more people to prison if it is thought they will benefit from their experience. This also applies upward pressure on the length of sentences: there is no point in sending people to prison unless they stay long enough to get that benefit.

The trouble is that similar aspirations have failed in the past. Unrealistic expectations are built up around the effect of prison on future behaviour - but nothing is done to change the offender's family and social environment, over which the prison has no control. Successive governments and the courts have failed to stabilise the prison population at a level where training and rehabilitation programmes can be sustained.

Measures to improve prisoners' treatment and rehabilitation should not be promoted on a false prospectus. They have to be realistic and deliverable.

If we are to move in the "prison works" direction, three conditions need to be satisfied. First, programmes must be monitored and evaluated. The government's support for research deserves applause. But programmes must be subject to checking and part of a wider assessment of the prison experience and its social effects.

Second, the prison population must be stabilised at a level which matches the capacity of the system to fulfil the promises being made. There should be no new laws on sentencing until the government and judiciary come to an understanding on its purpose and principles; on the intended size, composition and geographical distribution of the prison population; and on the sentencing practices and procedures for release by which that optimum size of the prison population is to be achieved. That is to say, assumptions about sentencing and the prison population must be turned into policies. There is no longer any other area of the public sector where it is acceptable just to "predict and provide".

Third, there must be reform of the prison service itself - of its relationship with other services and with the communities which it serves and from which it will need commitment and support; of the composition and skills of its staff; and of its values and culture. Racism, where it exists, shows a more general lack of professional integrity.

The prisons have experienced countless reviews and reorganisations over the past 40 years. All have been in response to an immediate political demand or operational crisis; none has found a lasting solution, and none has examined the system from first principles, although Lord Woolf's report in 1991 came closest to doing so.

The time has come to re- examine the foundations of the prison system's authority and legitimacy. The Human Rights Act provides a special opportunity and a point of reference: it may in time provide an imperative. But this is not a subject for just another review, with a chair, terms of reference, invitations to give evidence and a time limit set by the political agenda.

We need a public debate in which everyone can take part - through articles in journals, attending conferences and seminars, by contributions to official rethinking. The prison service's own review of boards of visitors, now in progress, offers one of many such opportunities. It challenges us all - the Howard League, the Prison Reform Trust, the crime reduction charity Nacro, Justice and the International Centre for Prison Studies - to help shape the process of penal reform.

 David Faulkner is chair of the Howard League for Penal Reform
ccr@crim.ox.ac.uk

The Tories want juveniles to be imprisoned in even larger numbers. The prison population is projected to increase by a further 7-20% by 2007 depending on what assumptions are made of the effect of new policies and legislation. Overcrowding seems set to continue indefinitely. It becomes more acceptable to send more people to prison if it is thought they will benefit from their experience. This also applies upward pressure on the length of sentences: there is no point in sending people to prison unless they stay long enough to get that benefit. The trouble is that similar aspirations have failed in the past. Unrealistic expectations are built up around the effect of prison on future behaviour - but nothing is done to change the offender's family and social environment, over which the prison has no control. Successive governments and the courts have failed to stabilise the prison population at a level where training and rehabilitation programmes can be sustained. Measures to improve prisoners' treatment and rehabilitation should not be promoted on a false prospectus. They have to be realistic and deliverable. If we are to move in the "prison works" direction, three conditions need to be satisfied. First, programmes must be monitored and evaluated. The government's support for research deserves applause. But programmes must be subject to checking and part of a wider assessment of the prison experience and its social effects. Second, the prison population must be stabilised at a level which matches the capacity of the system to fulfil the promises being made. There should be no new laws on sentencing until the government and judiciary come to an understanding on its purpose and principles; on the intended size, composition and geographical distribution of the prison population; and on the sentencing practices and procedures for release by which that optimum size of the prison population is to be achieved. That is to say, assumptions about sentencing and the prison population must be turned into policies. There is no longer any other area of the public sector where it is acceptable just to "predict and provide". Third, there must be reform of the prison service itself - of its relationship with other services and with the communities which it serves and from which it will need commitment and support; of the composition and skills of its staff; and of its values and culture. Racism, where it exists, shows a more general lack of professional integrity. The prisons have experienced countless reviews and reorganisations over the past 40 years. All have been in response to an immediate political demand or operational crisis; none has found a lasting solution, and none has examined the system from first principles, although Lord Woolf's report in 1991 came closest to doing so. The time has come to re- examine the foundations of the prison system's authority and legitimacy. The Human Rights Act provides a special opportunity and a point of reference: it may in time provide an imperative. But this is not a subject for just another review, with a chair, terms of reference, invitations to give evidence and a time limit set by the political agenda. We need a public debate in which everyone can take part - through articles in journals, attending conferences and seminars, by contributions to official rethinking. The prison service's own review of boards of visitors, now in progress, offers one of many such opportunities. It challenges us all - the Howard League, the Prison Reform Trust, the crime reduction charity Nacro, Justice and the International Centre for Prison Studies - to help shape the process of penal reform.  David Faulkner is chair of the Howard League for Penal Reform ccr@crim.ox.ac.uk

webTitle: Experts find first clue to Austrian tunnel fire

fields.headline: Experts find first clue to Austrian tunnel fire
fields.standfirst:
Families prepare to sue as safety shortcomings become apparent
More about the tunnel tragedy
fields.trailText: The discovery yesterday of an oily substance on an Alpine railway track in Austria gave the first clue as to what may have caused the tunnel blaze on Saturday that killed almost 160 people.
fields.body:
The discovery yesterday of an oily substance on an Alpine railway track in Austria gave the first clue as to what may have caused the tunnel blaze on Saturday that killed almost 160 people.

Experts said that the molten material could be a lubricant, possibly oil, but refused to be more specific until chemical tests were carried out.

"It looks as if the material might have dropped from the vehicle," said Christian Tisch, a police forensic engineer. It is the first hint by police that the train may have been defective before entering the tunnel.

But investigators said it could be months before they discover the cause of Europe's worst winter-sport disaster.

Salvage workers yesterday continued to sift through the ashes and collect human remains to be flown to Salzburg for examination by forensic scientists. By last night, 128 sets of remain had been removed, while the official number of identified victims fell to 156.

Military personnel and forensic scientists were gathering evidence along the length of the railway, said the leading police investigator, Major Franz Lang. State prosecutors are overseeing the investigation, which could lead to criminal proceedings.

The operation was severely hampered by a strong wind which grounded helicopters for some hours.

The train, loaded with skiers and snowboarders, climbed steep tracks on Saturday morning before entering the tunnel leading towards the Kitzsteinhorn glacier near Kaprun, 50 miles south-west of Salzburg.

Minutes into its journey, witnesses reported seeing smoke and hearing an explosion. Twelve people managed to escape the ensuing inferno which claimed the lives of 92 Austrians, 37 Germans, 10 Japanese, eight Americans, a British man, three Slovenes and a Czech. The nationalities of four other victims who have been officially identified is not known.

Safety experts yesterday intensified their criticism that certain basic safety measures were lacking on the railway, which was built in 1974.

It has been confirmed that there were only two fire extinguishers, situated in the driver's cabin and only operable by a trained person. Neither the train nor tunnel had a sprinkler system, which could have dampened the blaze. The doors were controlled by the driver, and manual or mechanical opening was only possible outside the train.

The tunnel had no emergency exits, only a horizontal passageway at the middle-station where workers could enter to carry out repairs.

The Austrian transport ministry and Gletscher Bahnen AG, the railway owner, also confirmed that no fire drill had ever taken place in the tunnel.

"The idea that a fire could break out in the tunnel was considered to be something unimaginable," said Peter Präauer, the train firm's commercial director.

As to the absence of sprinklers, largely inaccessible fire extinguishers and other safety shortcomings, Mr Präauer said: "That wasn't legally required by the authorities, even if one says in hindsight that that was a mistake."

Meanwhile, families of some victims from Bavaria in Germany have launched a lawsuit against the railway owner, claiming criminal liability.

While officials at Austrian ski resorts continued safety checks on similar railways, the French transport minister, Jean-Claude Gayssot, ordered the immediate inspection of three glacier trains in France.

There have been calls in Austria for tougher fire protection regulations for ski clothing, after experts confirmed that synthetic clothing worn by the passengers, along with lacquered plastic snow-boards, skis and boots, almost certainly added to the rapidity with which the fire took hold.

"The outfit and snowboard of just a single person would have the same burning capacity as 30 litres of heating oil," a fire expert told Austrian television.

Last night, psychologists in Kaprun and Salzburg said they were trying to dissuade families who wanted to see the remains of their relatives. "We're been trying to gently convey to them that it would be quite terrible to see the remains, when in nearly all cases there's almost nothing left," said Bernhard Hittenberger, chief of Salzburg social services.

webTitle: India sifts over site of 'suspicious' crash

fields.headline: India sifts over site of 'suspicious' crash
fields.trailText: India's air force was investigating the possibility last night that one of its helicopters, which crashed during mysterious circumstances on Sunday close to the border with Pakistan, may have been shot down by a Pakistani missile.
fields.body:
India's air force was investigating the possibility last night that one of its helicopters, which crashed during mysterious circumstances on Sunday close to the border with Pakistan, may have been shot down by a Pakistani missile.

The helicopter plunged into remote marshland in the western state of Gujarat, killing seven of the 12 people on board. Investigators were still trying to retrieve the wreckage yesterday, their efforts hampered by soggy terrain.

India's defence minister, George Fernandes, initially dismissed the idea of Pakistan's involvement, but he was later contradicted by the chief of the Indian air force, AY Tipnis. After touring the crash scene in the Rann of Kutch, about 60 miles south of Hyderabad, Mr Tipnis said he could not rule out that the helicopter had been shot down. "It is a possibility," he said. But he called it "premature" to blame Pakistan.

The accident site is close to where India shot down the Pakistani reconnaissance aircraft Atlantique last year. New Delhi said the plane had strayed into its airspace, a claim denied by Pakistan.

Indian armed forces in the Kutch area had already been placed on a state of high alert following recent reports - also denied by Islamabad - of large-scale Pakistani troop exercises across the border.

fields.headline: The disunited states of America
fields.standfirst:
Voter split: election reveals huge divide through nation

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Voter split Election reveals huge divide through nation.
fields.body:
Ultimately, the battle being fought out in the Florida courts yesterday is neither a technical dispute about election law nor proof that America is in near-terminal constitutional crisis. But it is the latest combat in the culture wars that define the modern United States.

When Americans went to the polls last week, they split the country. The presidential election ended in the continuing 48%-48% shootout between Al Gore and George W Bush. The new House of Representatives is divided 221-212, which in the fluid world of US party loyalties is tantamount to a tie. The Senate might still end up with 50 Republican seats and 50 Democrat.

"Never in our history have we ever had a partisan balance across the country as even as this," says Norman Ornstein, a political scholar at the American Enterprise Institute.

Yet the stand-off in last week's election results reflects something deeper and wider about America. The intense dislike of the Bush and Gore camps for one another - fully on view in Florida once more yesterday - is not merely the mistrust of two groups of exhausted partisans at the end of a hard-fought campaign. It is the mutual incomprehension of two Americas which are finding it increasingly difficult to live as neighbours.

To some observers, including many foreigners, the US election was a battle between two barely distinguishable dynastic centrists. But that is a fundamental misreading. Mr Bush and Mr Gore are, in fact, the standard bearers and embodiments - imperfect and improbable though they are - of two deeply different alliances of Americans.

Mr Bush speaks for culturally conservative America. He speaks for most men, for a majority of whites, for the rural heartlands, for moral conservatives, for the military, for angry guys and for country and western music.

Mr Gore speaks for most women, for black Americans and the other racial minorities, for cities, for moral liberals, for dissenters, for taking a relaxed view and for rock and roll.

Both sides intensely believe that they speak for the majority. Mr Bush's forces believe that the eight years of Democratic rule in the White House are a historical aberration and that the natural order is about to be re-established. That goes a long way to explain the Bush campaign's over-confidence during the closing days of the election campaign and its eagerness to parade itself as the presidential team in waiting ever since November 7.

The Gore campaign, by contrast, comes from the generation of "new" Democrats that believes its party has remade itself as the voice of a new middle-class majority - a third-way party open to the centre, not a party resting forever on the class-based pillars of yesteryear.

But the two groups suffer from the same delusion: both believe they are the majority. They are both wrong. As last week's results so powerfully showed, each represents only half of the nation.

This is not primarily a division between social and economic classes, although the Republicans remain the party of the richest Americans and the Democrats are still the party of the poorest. It is a fluid moral and cultural divide, with many cross-currents. Inevitably, less than two years after the event, it is a divide that vividly recreates the fault lines of the Clinton impeachment crisis of 1998-99.

That event, so widely seen as mere entertainment by the rest of the world, was always treated more seriously by Americans. In the light of last week's elections, it may even be right to call it the defining cultural event of today's United States.

Though the stakes could hardly be higher in the current Florida disputes over election ballot counts, the sheer animus of the two sides can be fully understood only as an attempt by one side to purge America of the Clinton culture, and by the other to die in the last ditch rather than surrender to the party of Kenneth Starr, the special counsel whose investigations led to the impeachment of the president.

That is why the aftermath may be so difficult, whichever side wins. Washington today is full of talk about the need for "reaching out across the divide", for bringing the nation together, even - in the op-ed columns of commentators such as Joe Klein and Thomas Friedman - for coalition government.

Talk of a Gore administration featuring the Republican likes of Colin Powell, or of a Bush administration with a place for Richard Holbrooke, may appeal to Washington power brokers. But it is at odds with the mood of the country. America's sense of itself as one nation is one of its greatest strengths. But it is currently being put to a test it has not faced at any time since the Vietnam war.

The mood of the coming months will be dominated not by reconciliation but by the desire for revenge.

webTitle: Democrats turn on Nader in search of a scapegoat

fields.headline: Democrats turn on Nader in search of a scapegoat
fields.standfirst:
Green camp: pundits split on man whose Florida votes led to chaos

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Green camp Pundits split on man whose Florida votes led to chaos.
fields.body:
So was Ralph Nader an egocentric Don Quixote who has possibly handed the country to George W Bush or has his candidacy energised the electoral process, forced Democrats to re-examine their consciences and provided a breath of fresh air into the contaminated US political system?

Mr Nader, the Green party presidential candidate, took 2.7m votes across the nation - around 3% per cent of the vote. Most crucially, he took 97,000 votes in Florida.

Within hours of the count, he was being savaged by the Democrats for having given the presidency to Mr Bush and putting at risk the environment, the minimum wage and a woman's right to choose over abortion. Now Nader supporters are fighting back and the airwaves of the land are echoing to the great "Nader Factor" debate. Has he been proved right or wrong? People's hero or self-centred villain?

One theme among Nader supporters has been that Al Gore cost Mr Nader vital votes rather than the other way round. Many who would have voted for Mr Nader in marginal states such as Washington, Oregon and Pennsylvania and, not least, Florida were persuaded at the last minute to vote for Mr Gore. This, says the Nader camp, means the Green party fell well short of its own target of 5% - needed to get federal funding for the race in 2004 - and that Gore's siren song derailed the Green party of its immediate hopes of being an effective third force.

The Nader camp also argues that exit polls showed fewer than half of Mr Nader's votes would have gone to Mr Gore anyway: 40% of those asked said they would not have voted at all if Mr Nader had not stood and 20% would otherwise have voted for Mr Bush.

Coming to Mr Nader's defence in the radical publication, In These Times, Doug Ireland wrote: "The hysterics among those Democratic liberals and party familiars in the blabbering classes who accuse Ralph Nader of creating a constitutional crisis are spouting nonsense. Nader did receive nearly 100,000 votes in the Sunshine State, but as he kept repeating in the campaign, only Al Gore could beat Al Gore. That's what happened in Florida. If Gore loses there, it's because he failed to carry the seniors, who were supposed to be the Democrats' firewall."

Ireland added: "Nader's great achievement was injecting a radical, systemic critique into the national discourse for the first time since such thinking was ostracized by the cold war. Nader won't be going away. And that's healthy for progressive politics."

Nowhere has the debate been fiercer than in The Nation, a barometer of left-liberal American thinking. Contributing editor Marc Cooper had advocated a Nader vote before the election as the alternative was "to continue to abandon hope and stay paralysed". He concluded after the vote: "This result is far from the best scenario for those who hoped that Nader would hand the Greens substantial future leverage. Given the failure to establish a federally funded national Green party, however, future clout will depend mostly on Nader's ability and willingness to take his list of 75,000 campaign contributors and hone it into an identifiable political entity. That could be rendered even more problematic by those who will blame Nader for a Gore defeat."

Fellow Nation commentator Eric Alterman wrote in an article entitled Left in Shambles: "Nader may have polled a pathetic 2 to 3% nationally, but he still affected the race enough to tip some important balances in favour of Bush and the Republicans. For now, we can expect an ugly period of payback in Washington. Funders will tell him to take a hike. Sadly, his life's work will be a victim of the infantile left-wing disorder Nader developed in his quixotic quest to elect a reactionary Republican to the American presidency."

It is this view that Robert Scheer, formerly of the radical 60s Ramparts magazine, also holds. Writing in his regular slot in the Los Angeles Times, Scheer accused Mr Nader of being "elitist in the extreme" to scorn critics in the women's movement and the unions who tried to persuade him to deflect his support towards Mr Gore. "What Nader did was to impulsively betray a lifetime of painstaking, frustrating but most often effective efforts to make a better world."

Mr Nader is now setting up two new projects, one which will act as a watchdog of how politicians vote. The other, the People's Debate Commission, will campaign for presidential debates in the future to allow access to more than just Democrats and Republicans.

The real test of what Nader did or did not achieve will come over the next two years when it will become clearer how many of those who answered his call to redefine American politics stick around and become involved. Nader and his Green party supporters remain, in the words of one party organiser, "unashamed and unabashed".

fields.headline: Vietnam forgives but can't forget
fields.standfirst: President Clinton makes a landmark visit to a former enemy whose people still suffer the scars of war
fields.trailText: President Clinton makes a landmark visit to a former enemy whose people still suffer the scars of war.
fields.body:
Bill Clinton's last scheduled foreign trip as president will take him to Hanoi this week where, according to US officials, he will try to promote reconciliation and bring "closure" to a war that cost 58,000 American and over 2m Vietnamese lives.

"There was a war in Vietnam. It ended in 1975. It's past tense. Way past tense," said Pete Peterson, the US ambassador to Hanoi. Mr Peterson was himself a prisoner of war in Vietnam and symbolises the Clinton administration's attitude to the country. "I was deeply involved in the conflict. But I have come back here because I want to build bridges not destroy them," he said.

Most Vietnamese express remarkably little resentment about the war and the huge loss of life it caused. US veterans who have returned to Vietnam are often surprised by the welcome they receive. While the conflict is not forgotten, for the most part it is forgiven.

Back in the 1960s Chuck Searcey was a Saigon-based US military intelligence analyst. He has returned to manage various development projects in Hanoi. "Over the last six years I have travelled all over Vietnam. In all that time only three people have asked me in a negative way if the US knew what it was doing back then," he said. "It is remarkable to me that only three people have asked me that."

While the Vietnamese seem at ease with their 1975 victory, the White House is well aware of the sensitivities that still exist in the US. Unsurprisingly, President Clinton, who arrives tomorrow, will not visit the mausoleum of Vietnam's revered wartime leader, Ho Chi Minh.

Nor will he visit a less politically charged alternative - the tomb of the unknown soldier. Too many US veterans are not ready for such a gesture; especially from a draft dodger.

Clinton's decision to study in Oxford rather than fight in Vietnam may have caused him persistent political difficulties in the United States but it will play well in Hanoi. "We welcome President Clinton because he was himself against the war," said Lieutenant-General Xuan Vinh Vu. Like other senior Vietnamese leaders, he recognises that there are limits beyond which Mr Clinton will not able to go. "The Americans were at fault here but we do not expect him to apologise - it is better to make up for what happened by action."

Mr Clinton's actions have already spoken louder than words. Over the last eight years he has lifted the US economic embargo on Vietnam, normalised relations, exchanged ambassadors and, crucially, signed the bilateral trade agreement which will give Vietnam access to US markets.

These developments, combined with the policy of Doi Moi or renovation, have transformed Vietnam's economic prospects. While western companies complain about the bureaucratic obstacles they face, they are still investing in Vietnam.

Andrew Steer of the World Bank says: "Compared to where Vietnam was 12 years ago, there has scarcely been in the history of the world a more dramatic transformation. Few countries have ever grown as rapidly or shared their growth as equitably."

Vietnam's rulers know that as long as they deliver economic growth, people will be content to leave politics to the party. But they are taking no chances: the country remains a one party state in which the press is tightly controlled and dissidence not tolerated.

Party leaders watched Belgrade's recent street protests with dread. "For the politburo that is their nightmare," said one Vietnamese businessman with close links to the upper echelons of the party.

Vietnamese diplomats are resigned to the fact that Clinton is bound to raise human rights. Going by past practice, Hanoi will hit back with statements on Agent Orange, the chemical which the US sprayed over extensive areas of Vietnam to deny the communist forces cover and food.

Agent Orange contained highly poisonous dioxin. Recent research shows that some parts of Vietnam - especially former US air bases - still have dangerously high dioxin levels.

The US compensates American, but not Vietnamese, veterans who have Agent Orange-related illnesses. The two sides have agreed a major research project on the issue. That may explain why Vietnamese officials have dropped their longstanding and strident demands for reparations in favour of softer language.

Cynics, though, have another explanation. Vietnam is increasingly reliant on agricultural exports such as coffee and seafood. High profile campaigns on Agent Orange could allow international competitors to claim that Vietnamese produce contains dioxins.

Another legacy of the war left in Vietnam's soil is thousands of tonnes of unexploded bombs and mines. Since 1975 about 38,000 people have been killed by accidental detonations. Many of the victims are farmers who hit mines with their ploughs. Others are dealers who want to sell the shell casings and explosives.

Children are also vulnerable. Ten-year-old Phan Huu Lan was badly injured by a mine last year. "I was feeding a buffalo by the hill and met two friends there," he recalled. "They had found a mine and we played with it. It exploded and they died." Lan has huge scars on his legs, a limp right hand and metal lodged in his skull.

His 68-year-old grandmother, Le Thi, witnessed the war at first hand. But for her the conflict has not ended. "More people will die. There are so many bombs and mines in this area. Whenever we get heavy rain, they come to the surface," she said.

Mine clearance has begun but is painfully slow. One British mine clearer, Mark Thompson, said: "The Americans still deny they laid mines in Vietnam. We have tried quite a few avenues such as the state department and former veterans on the internet. But there is very limited information available."

US officials insist that attitudes are changing and that librarians are now trawling the Pentagon's archives to establish what mines were laid and where.

fields.headline: Israel tightens ring of control
fields.standfirst:
Barak's forces target Palestinian economy as vital roads are closed
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israeli troops rolled out barricades of concrete blocks and spiked metal strips across the West Bank yesterday, opening battle with the Palestinians for control of vital roadways.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg in Neguhot, West Bank
fields.body:
Israeli troops rolled out barricades of concrete blocks and spiked metal strips across the West Bank yesterday, opening battle with the Palestinians for control of vital roadways.

A day after four Jews were killed in drive-by shootings, Israel fears its high-security routes could become a killing zone for troops and Jewish settlers in the West Bank and Gaza. Israel's deputy prime minister, Binyamin Ben Eliezer, called it the Palestinians' "death-by-road" campaign yesterday.

New barricades were erected or fortified throughout the West Bank, squeezing shut the ring of steel imposed on Palestinian towns since the conflict began seven weeks ago.

Israel's army chief, Shaul Mofaz, admitted yesterday that the West Bank could not be hermetically sealed. Instead, the closure is designed to cripple the Palestinian economy, and there could be further pain if the army acts on a proposal for a partial curfew on cars with Palestinian number plates.

Four Palestinians were shot dead by Israeli soldiers yesterday, an almost routine casualty rate during these weeks of bloodshed. But today could bring a steep rise in violence.

The Palestinians are poised to confront the closure after Yasser Arafat's Fatah organisation urged the people to throw Israeli soldiers and settlers out of the West Bank on the 12th anniversary of a symbolic declaration of independence.

"Fatah calls on the people to prevent the occupation forces and the herds of settlers from entering Palestinian areas," a statement, published yesterday in Palestinian newspapers, said. "The day will be a day of challenge between the will of the people and the will of the heavily armed occupation."

In Neguhot, a hardline settlement west of Hebron hunkered down with Israeli soldiers behind barbed wire and electric yellow gates, 13 Jewish families have been penned in by local Palestinian hostility for months.

Earlier this year, a two-and-a-half mile stretch of the main road to the settlement was transferred to full Palestinian control, under the now comatose peace process. When the violence erupted seven weeks ago, the road, already a risky route for the settlers because of sporadic stone-throwing, became off limits.

From this hilltop at 770 metres, the settlers can see the twinkling lights of Tel Aviv. But if they want to travel to the nearest Jewish settlements a few miles away, they must follow a circuitous route that takes nearly two hours.

"The problem with the road is that the army does not rule there. It is in Palestinian hands, and the army says if we pass through there we could get shot," said Neguhot's secretary, Yigael Leibner.

A former army lieutenant, Mr Leibner was one of the founding settlers of Neguhot some three years ago, and he fervently believes the outposts manned by some 200,000 Jews in the West Bank and Gaza are vital to Israel's interests. "Where there are settlements, there is security," he said. "The army puts more into it, and the settlers help keep the roads going."

That is not how they are seen by the Palestinians, who consider the settlements a symbol of the occupation; nor is that the interpretation from Israeli liberals, who believe they remain the greatest obstacle to peace. On Monday, the Israeli movement, Peace Now, launched a high-profile campaign, calling on the prime minister, Ehud Barak, to stop the expansion of West Bank settlements.

"The building of settlements and the opening of roads leading to them is a provocative act calling unnecessarily for counter-violence," Peace Now said.

Many settlers see their presence in the West Bank as a biblical birthright; those who oppose them have drifted from the true Zionist mission.

Mr Leibner believes that the Palestinians should go - and their emigration be encouraged - and that the settlers should tough it out.

"Every Arab attack should be answered by a new Jewish settlement coming up, another Jewish house, and another Jewish kid," he said. "I do not think we can win this fight. The long-range solution is not the army, it is to put our feet deeper into the land."

webTitle: Pakistan blind to attacks on sects, say rights groups

fields.headline: Pakistan blind to attacks on sects, say rights groups
fields.trailText: Human rights groups yesterday accused Pakistan's military government of turning a blind eye to attacks on a minority religious sect which have left 10 people dead in the past fortnight.
fields.body:
Human rights groups yesterday accused Pakistan's military government of turning a blind eye to attacks on a minority religious sect which have left 10 people dead in the past fortnight.

In two separate incidents worshippers from the Ahmadi sect were attacked as they prayed in their mosques in Punjab province. The 3.5m Ahmadis in Pakistan were declared non-Muslim in 1974 and it is a criminal offence for them to practise or preach their beliefs.

Amnesty International said the killings came after months of religious tension, protests against the Ahmadis and the desecration of Ahmadi graves.

In the first attack two weeks ago, four gunmen drove up to a prayer meeting in Ghatialian, near Sialkot, viewed as a sacred site by the Ahmadis.

They fired automatic weapons into the crowd, killing five and injuring 10. The local police station, which has no telephone, was slow to respond and the gunmen escaped.

"The official silence around the religiously motivated murders on October 30 and the lack of police investigation have directly contributed to a climate in which extremists feel encouraged to harass, at tack and kill members of the country's religious minorities," Amnesty said.

On Friday, a Muslim leader held a protest march against the small Ahmadi community living in Takht Hazara, a village near Sargodha. A mob broke into the Ahmadi mosque and killed five people, including two children, mutilating their bodies with axes before burning down the mosque.

The Human Rights Commission of Pakistan said it had detected organised targetting of minorities across the country in recent weeks. In Karachi and Hyderabad, in Sind province, "literature of hatred" was being distributed in mosques, said the commission's chairman, Afrasiab Khattak. In particular, groups working in development and women's rights were being fiercely criticised.

"All across the country there appears to be a deliberate attempt to cleanse non-conformist forces. The environment of hatred and intolerance is expanding by the day," Mr Khattak said, adding that more lives could be lost.

Two days after the latest killings, Pakistan's president, Muhammad Rafiq Tarar, told Sikhs that religious minorities were living in harmony and peace. "Our religion and constitution guarantees the rights of all the minorities," he said.

webTitle: Florida's wary judges steer clear of poisoned chalice

fields.headline: Florida's wary judges steer clear of poisoned chalice
fields.standfirst:
Scapegoats: Bitter ballot disputes will damage future career hopes

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Scapegoats:  Bitter ballot disputes will damage future career hopes
fields.byline: Julian Borger in West Palm Beach
fields.body:
"How many more judges are there in town?" someone asked yesterday in West Palm Beach - not normally a town considered to be juridically-challenged. And yet with the presidential election chewing its way through the Florida courts, there was a sudden shortage of wise legal heads.

Five judges, one after the other, opted not to hear legal complaints brought by irate residents who felt they had been cheated out of their vote by Palm Beach county's famous "butterfly ballot". They were no fools. Everyone here is aware of what a poisoned chalice this bizarre election has become.

Theresa LePore shows how bad it can get at the heart of the controversy. She is the elections supervisor in Palm Beach county whose idea it was to design a supposedly easy-to-read butterfly ballot for the short-sighted pensioners among the electorate.

Now she is known in her Democratic party branch as the woman who may have lost the 2000 election, because elderly would-be Democratic voters, many of them Jews, were confused into voting for the xenophobic firebrand, Pat Buchanan.

Ms LePore now has the appearance of someone walking through the recount imbroglio like a dark-eyed zombie, muttering tentative opinions only to withdraw them hastily.

When the local electoral board appeared in public yesterday at a table set up in the patio of the local government offices, Ms LePore sat silent as colleagues agonised aloud over whether to go ahead with a hand recount of votes, even if it might end up being rejected by the Florida state authorities, and could be challenged in the courts.

"Will we go to jail? Because I'd be ready to go to jail," said a feisty Democratic councillor, Carol Roberts, raising cheers among a crowd largely in favour of the Democrats' presidential candidate, Al Gore. "Revote! Revote! Every vote counts!" chanted the crowd.

But the sharp-voiced Ms Roberts also shows the dangers of weighing in on this issue. She has received several death threats since emerging as the main supporter of a hand recount of all 425,000 of the county's votes. Now she is under protective surveillance by the police.

Yesterday, it was looking as though another woman, Katherine Harris, might emerge as the next local scapegoat for the messy election result in Florida: when Judge Terry Lewis issued a ruling that appeared to please both sides and wipe the troublesome recount issue off his hands, he also emptied it neatly into Ms Harris's lap. Now Judge Lewis is free to continue his legal career and write another legal thriller on the side. His last was called Conflict of Interest

As Florida's secretary of state, Ms Harris, 43, usually has to deal with such cultural issues as overseas trips by the state ballet.But thanks to the cleverness of Judge Lewis, she has just been given the "discretion" to decide which late recounts, if any, she would accept after the formal deadline of 5pm yesterday. In other words, she could decide who wins Florida and therefore who moves his gear into the White House in January.

The national media spotlight has already begun to light up the nooks and crannies of Ms Harris's life. Educated at Harvard, she is from one of Florida's richest families and has the reputation of bringing the high life to her relatively humble office.

She has been questioned about spending up to $500 (£340) on hotel rooms when in Washington on business. She spent $100,000 (£69,000) of taxpayers' money on trips to Barbados, Brazil and the Sydney Olympics. Her explanation was that she was drumming up business contacts for entrepreneurs in Florida.

She was also caught up in a campaign-finance scandal in 1994, in which she was forced to hand back $20,000 in irregular contributions. And she used $30,000 of public money for a political advertisement urging people in Florida to go out to vote: because it starred one of Mr Bush's prominent cheerleaders, General Norman Schwarzkopf, it had strong Republican overtones.

This hint of sleaze has caused much amusement in southern Florida, an area normally tarred with the "banana republic" brush. Ms Harris works in Tallahassee, which is more than just a time-zone away from Miami. Situated in the Florida panhandle, Tallahassee is several cultural zones away too - a prim and proper corner of the Deep South.

As each mini-scandal came and went Ms Harris protested her innocence and hinted that she was wealthy enough (listing her net worth as $6.5m) not to need to bend the spending rules.

Not everyone is convinced and her position, which is largely ceremonial, is due to be abolished in 2003, when her current term expires. By then, of course, she may be known as the woman who swung the 2000 election.

fields.headline: International news in brief
fields.trailText: Health authorities are scouring western Kenya for seven people possibly infected with the killer Ebola virus after attending a victim's funeral in Uganda.
fields.body:
Kenyan hunt for Ebola mourners

Health authorities are scouring western Kenya for seven people possibly infected with the killer Ebola virus after attending a victim's funeral in Uganda.

Health chiefs in Uganda warned its neighbour that the seven Kenyans were among 150 mourners of a woman who fled hospital in Gulu, the centre of the outbreak, to escape the virus. Four people in the woman's home district of Masindi, 75 miles from Gulu, have since died, taking the death toll in the latest outbreak of the virus to at least 110. Reuters, Kampala

Fifth Picasso found in Turkey

Police have recovered what is thought to be the fifth stolen Picasso painting found in Turkey this year.

The Naked Woman painting was retrieved in a police operation near the Turkish-Iraqi border in the southeastern province of Mardin, reports said. Four suspects were arrested.

The four other paintings recovered so far include Ugly Woman, the portrait of Picasso's mistress, Dora Maar, and the 1908 painting La Fermière (The Farmer's Wife). Police believe the pictures were stolen from a Kuwaiti palace during the 1991 Gulf war. AP, Istanbul

fields.headline: Florida votes decision in hands of Bush ally
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Florida's controversial secretary of state, Katherine Harris, emerged yesterday as the official with the potential power to determine who wins the US presidential election, after a court ordered her to use her "discretion" in accepting late manual recounts in the tightly contested state.

fields.body:
Florida's controversial secretary of state, Katherine Harris, emerged yesterday as the official with the potential power to determine who wins the US presidential election, after a court ordered her to use her "discretion" in accepting late manual recounts in the tightly contested state.

In an anxiously awaited verdict in the state capital, Tallahassee, Judge Terry Lewis upheld a deadline laid down by Ms Harris, a Republican activist, for all the state's 67 counties to certify their final tallies by 5pm local time yesterday.

However, in a two pronged ruling, Judge Lewis - a novelist in his spare time who once wrote a legal thriller called Conflict of Interest - said Ms Harris must consider late results arising from hand counts demanded by the Democrats in four counties. She would have the power to reject those results but could not do so "arbitrarily" and would have to exercise "sound discretion".

Democrats were quick to seize the political initiative in the wake of the ruling. Warren Christopher, Mr Gore's troubleshooter in Florida, said: "Under this decision we now have a vehicle for the full, fair and accurate tabulation of the votes of the citizens of Florida." Standing at his side David Boies, a high-powered Democratic lawyer, warned: "If the secretary of state refuses to accept amended returns based on the recount and violates what the court rules is her duty then we may be back in court."

In a state where George W Bush has a lead of only 338 votes in preliminary results, Ms Harris's "discretion" over the manual recount could decide who moves into the White House on January 20. Democrats have pointed out that she campaigned actively for Mr Bush and was appointed by his brother, Jeb, the governor of Florida.

A spokeswoman for Ms Harris said she would listen to reasons for late results "based on what the counties tell her" but she emphasised the legal weight of the 5pm deadline.

As the large, mainly Democratic counties of Miami-Dade and Palm Beach had not even begun a manual recount of votes by the time of the ruling, Ms Harris's 5pm ruling would have the effect of locking in Mr Bush's narrow lead in Florida, the state which is almost certain to decide the presidency.

In that case, Mr Bush's lead in Florida could only be threatened by absentee ballots by Floridians living abroad, such as the armed services and Jewish Americans living in Israel, whose votes have to be counted by midnight on Friday. Absentee ballots have historically tended to favour Republicans.

Local lawsuits continued to blossom in Florida out of the detritus of the presidential elections.

The two sides fought out a number of simultaneous legal skirmishes in the four counties, Palm Beach, Volusia, Broward and Miami-Dade.

In Volusia county, which brought the original case against Ms Harris for an extension of the deadline, officials said they might have problems in completing their 200,000 vote count by 5pm.

In Palm Beach county, meanwhile officials halted plans to begin a full manual recount of more than 400,000 votes.

In Miami-Dade county, officials agreed late yesterday morning to begin a partial recount in three precincts.

A hearing about what should be done in a fourth county, Broward, was due to begin late yesterday.

Bush 48,999,459

Gore 49,222,339

Nader 2,694,855

Electoral college

Bush 246 votes Gore 255

270 needed to win

States still not called: Florida (25 electoral college votes), New Mexico (5), Oregon (7)

Latest in Florida

Bush 2,910,299

Gore 2,909,911

Bush majority 388

fields.headline: Passnotes
fields.standfirst: No: 1761 Elvis Costello
fields.trailText: No: 1761 Elvis Costello
fields.body:
Age: 46.

Appearance: Sensitive bloke who'd like to meet a woman who's into cinema, theatre and country walks, GSOH optional.

Yes, he does have a certain mid-life fustiness about him. Fustiness! Don't you know you're not allowed to talk about our greatest living songwriter with anything but grovelling respect?

Why, when he hasn't written a hummable tune since 1979? Any Tom, Dick or Robbie can write a hummable tune, you know. But how many can compose classical scores, sing with Burt Bacharach, appear in jazz musicals, curate the Meltdown festival, etc, etc? Costello is so much more than just a worthy, slightly dour popster I keep getting confused with Bono.

The phrase "Jack of all trades, master of none" comes to mind. I wouldn't expect a pleb to appreciate the great man's artistry.

Watch who you're calling a pleb! During yesterday's Today programme on Radio 4 he railed against the middle class's favourite arts show, The Review, calling it "World Federation Wrestling for middle-class people". Ah, so we get to the point of this Passnote. Why was he so peevish?

He and Review presenter Mark Lawson have a history of mutual antipathy. It's coming back to me. It all started when Lawson slated his Burt Bacharach duets album, Painted from Memory. Costello took umbrage. So when the critics started attacking his current project, jazz musical The Keaton Bar & Grill (in which he plays the narrator - is there no end to his talents?), he was left fuming. And Lawson was a natural target for his ire.

He could have a point about The Review, actually. Inasmuch as it's mindless entertainment for people who pronounce Streatham "St Reatham", yes.

Don't say: "Hey, why can't you write another one as good as Alison, Elv?"

Do say: "They just don't understand you, your Pop Holiness."

fields.headline: Hey, big spenders
fields.standfirst: Today friends will gather for John Aspinall's memorial service. Among them will be the gamblers who bankrolled his zoos - and perhaps even the Kuwaiti who lost £93m to him
fields.trailText: Inside Story: Today friends will gather for John Aspinall's memorial service. Among them will be the gamblers who bankrolled his zoos - and perhaps even the Kuwaiti who lost £93m to him. Marcus Scriven reports
fields.body:
His recent heart attack will keep Henry Kissinger away from St John's, Smith Square, London this morning, where John Aspinall's memorial service begins at 11, but Chief Buthelezi will be there; so, too, will be Goldsmiths and Birleys, young and old, as well as an assortment of plutocrats and intellectuals, decaying roues and dispossessed aristocrats.

Aspinall, who died last June, now lies in the lime avenue at Howletts in Kent, between two graves, one for Mameena, his daughter by his second wife; the other for one of his favourite gorillas. Like Port Lympne, his other magnificent house in Kent, Howletts is home to a zoo of world renown. The zoos are funded by a charitable trust which Aspinall endowed with £18.5m - a remarkable legacy for a man who inherited no money, and who, in 74 years, never endured a single day in conventional employment.

It was made possible, of course, by the success of his casinos; more precisely, by the rich who lost their fortunes in them. Aspinall was never squeamish about this. He once reflected that his first casino, the Clermont, whose founder members included five dukes, five marquesses and 20 earls, was a place "where gentlemen could ruin themselves as elegantly and suicidally as did their ancestors 300 years ago". Aspinall was true to his word. It was routinely said that, until the crisis at Lloyd's insurance market, he was responsible for the greatest redistribution of upper-class wealth of the 20th century.

He set to work in the late 50s, holding gaming parties in Mayfair and Belgravia, making an unabashed play for the high-rollers, ensuring that they were served extravagantly expensive food and wines. After gambling was legalised, he repeated the trick at the Clermont, a superb William Kent house at 44 Berkeley Square, which had a nightclub, Annabel's - named after Lady Annabel Birley (subsequently Goldsmith) - in its basement. But it was Aspinall's presence, his untamed personality, his apparent invulnerability, which lured the rich in, as much as the lavishness of his hospitality.

As a boy, picnicking on the beach at Goring-by-Sea in Sussex, Aspinall had stayed to watch a swarm of wasps descend on a pot of honey; everyone else fled. At school at Rugby, he became the first boy in living memory to be "quad-flogged" by the head of house, infuriated by the maverick who wandered around the dormitory naked. Even at the last election, when he stood as a Referendum party candidate, the Observer described one of his speeches concerning the five English tribes - the Angles, Saxons, Jutes, Danes and Normans - as "a compelling, entrancing performance".

But, according to one former Clermont habitue, it was in the 60s that Aspinall was at the height of his powers, a blonde Rasputin who was "splendid in his own way", but also "a fairly sinister figure... He was articulate, intelligent, very good looking. He had this fatal attraction. He gave people the impression that if they didn't play they weren't up to much. Some were timid, wet, feeble and rose to the bait with disastrous consequences."

Lucky Lucan, he remembers, was invariably present, with his wife, Veronica, sitting, vacant-eyed, at his side. But Lucan's losses meant that he had assumed a different status from other gamblers. "Aspers would despatch Lucan to bring people in - it was done without disclosing that they were playing with house money. A lot of one's contemporaries came to grief. Bill Stirling [brother of David, founder of the SAS] ran out of Goyas, ran out of everything [including his Perthshire seat and 20,000 acres, which Stirling sold to Mahdi Al-Tajir, an Arab billionaire, without informing his wife]. John [the 18th Earl of] Derby had enough money. The scale of the gambling was staggering. It was a strange sort of episode."

Aspinall, who lost and remade fortunes throughout his adult life, played at his own tables for as long as the law allowed. "It added a certain tension, a certain madness," he reflected, not long before his death.

Inevitably, though, others lost far more than their host. One of them, Henry Vyner, heir to an estate which included Studley Royal and Fountains Abbey, accepted financial destruction with impeccable equanimity, greeting one disastrous evening (according to Annabel Goldsmith) by "announcing languidly at five in the morning: 'I suppose I shall have to sell some of my outlying farms.'"

In the end, Vyner lost the lot, though Aspinall's friends asserted that it was a calamitous investment - made against Aspinall's advice - which finally did for him. Whatever the truth in Vyner's case, the Clermont was so successful in allowing British gentlemen to "ruin themselves elegantly and suicidally" that, latterly, Aspinall was obliged to extend the privilege to their Arabian counterparts.

Quite how damaging the Arabs' losses were was harder to gauge, since they did not have ancient estates to sell nor Old Masters to consign to auction at Sotheby's or Christie's. But one gambler who was playing at Aspinall's second casino - established in 1978 and initially called, quite simply, Aspinall's Club, later, the Aspinall Curzon - sustained almost incomprehensible losses.

An industry insider who enjoyed a close working relationship with Aspinall during the 1980s, leading up to the sale of the Aspinall Curzon in 1987 (it was bought by Peter de Savary's leisure company, Alfred Walker, for £90m), recalls how, at a pre-sale press conference, Aspinall was asked how many high-rollers he depended on to maintain the casino's profits. Aspinall replied by holding both hands in the air, and saying that the number of high-rollers was "fewer than this" - a reference to his 10 fingers. Later, in private, he admitted that he was, in fact, dependent on just one patron, a Kuwaiti.

Aspinall's former assistant remembers: "This Kuwaiti lost £93m, his whole inheritance, in the course of one or two years. They could not take it off him quickly enough. That's what enabled Aspinall to sell it [the casino] at a mammoth profit." With the Kuwaiti a busted flush, the casino's profits sagged: the following year, de Savary sold Aspinall's to a firm called Leisure Investments; and, by 1990, Aspinall was able to buy back his old haunt - for just £6m.

Remarkably, the 50-year-old Kuwaiti feels no anger, still less, bitterness. Recently, on a visit to London, he agreed to talk to me, on condition that his identity was protected, explaining that, in the claustrophobic world of Kuwaiti business, past disclosures would damage him and his family (Muslims are forbidden to gamble).

Despite what happened, he said he had only good memories of Aspinall. Speaking in enthusiastic but imprecise English, he said: "He was a good man, a nice man, a gentleman. I sit with him in the bar, and have a nice glass with him. He was very cheering. He had a nice mother. She was also playing. It was a family club, you could say, at the time."

Unlike the Sultan of Brunei - who was another dedicated habitue of Aspinall's during the 80s - the Kuwaiti gambler said that he did not like playing in a private room, a privilege that was usually accorded to high-rollers.

The claim that he had lost more than £90m within two or three years was, he said, "exaggerated", but he acknowledged that the figure was "unbelievable. I don't have a record for it". He was, he added, now a contented man. "I have my family. My children have married, they have children. Everybody has in his life something good and bad, you see. Let's say these were good and bad days. It was fun but it was really bad, you see. Everybody who has done something bad has to put it behind him."

These days, he added, he goes to casinos only to see friends and to have dinner. And he has inculcated a simple lesson into his children: "This is the first thing to do in their life: not to gamble - to throw their money in the street, but not to gamble. To throw ten thousand in the street, but not to gamble a hundred."

Aspinall might be disappointed. "Reason is the worst possible guide to human affairs," he argued four years ago. "It is merely the undertaker that you send in after the battle to explain the logic of the affair. Instinct and prejudice are much better guides."

fields.headline: The oracle of Essex
fields.standfirst:
The Peniel Pentecostal Church has faced allegations of exploitation, complaints about the advertising of 'miracles' and unease at the extreme views of its leader. Now claims that it is trying to take control of the local Tory party have resurfaced - and Martin Bell is considering standing as MP. Sally Weale investigates

Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: The Peniel Pentecostal Church has faced allegations of exploitation, complaints about the advertising of 'miracles' and unease at the extreme views of its leader. Now claims that it is trying to take control of the local Tory party have resurfaced - and Martin Bell is considering standing as MP. Sally Weale investigates.
fields.body:
It is a quiet Sunday morning in rural Essex. There is little traffic on the roads and the sun shines weakly on the Peniel Pentecostal Church in Pilgrims Hatch, near Brentwood. At first sight there seems little out of the ordinary about the place - a plain, barn-like building that looks more like a village hall than a church. Then you notice the high metal fence and automated gates that surround the cluster of buildings. There is a large gun in the grounds fronting on to the road, pointing outwards. It was a gift, a piece of living history from the Ark Royal. And there's the car park. It's huge. Since when did churches need Tesco superstore-sized car parks?

By about 9.30am worshippers are beginning to arrive in force. An army of shiny saloons, people carriers and Jeeps, filled with well-heeled families in their Sunday best, pours into the car park, where it is directed with practised efficiency by a team of parking attendants.

Just before 10am, Michael Reid, a former policeman and insurance salesman who is the founder and leader of the Peniel, makes his way across the car park, keeping a close eye on me. I stick out like a sore thumb in my casual clothes amid the suits and matching separates. The service is about to begin.

Bishop Reid's Peniel Pentecostal Church has occupied this unremarkable corner of Essex for a quarter of a century, steadily growing from a tiny house church made up of a couple of families who used to meet in one another's living rooms to a church with 600 regular worshippers, a high-achieving school for 160 children based in a beautiful Georgian mansion purchased for £1.3m, and a college of higher education offering "accredited" American degree courses from Oral Roberts University (based in Tulsa, Oklahoma, and set up by the controversial American evangelist Oral Roberts), with which Peniel has close links.

It has attracted worshippers from all over the country, many of whom have left jobs, sold up and moved down to Pilgrims Hatch to be part of the church. Some arrive in groups, bringing friends and family. Others have come from abroad - the Peniel prides itself on including people from 37 nations among its congregation - and the rest are local, middle-class residents: doctors, dentists, teachers, nurses. Many are tithed, giving 10% of their gross income to the church and making it a wealthy organisation; its funds are also boosted by school and college fees.

But as the success and popularity of the Peniel has grown over the years, so has the controversy surrounding the church. Independent churches, particularly successful ones like Peniel, often attract suspicions from outsiders. These suspicions are usually unjustified, says the Evangelical Alliance. In the Peniel's case there have been allegations - vehemently refuted by the church - that it has some of the characteristics of a cult. A small number of former members have described what in their view was excessive control exercised by the church over its congregation; they have told how they were frightened to leave, and how they were encouraged to cut off contact with family outside.

There is also disquiet about claims of "miracles" at the Peniel. The church's website features testimonials from people who claim to have been cured of everything from eczema and endometriosis to chronic fatigue syndrome and deafness. Last year the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) upheld a complaint against the Peniel over an advertisement that claimed a man who had been bedridden and dependent on painkillers for chronic sciatica was able to walk out of church pain-free and had not taken a painkiller since. After an investigation the ASA said it had found no evidence to back the claims and told the church it was in danger of raising the hopes of vulnerable people. The Peniel appealed, but the complaint was upheld. Seven years ago the ASA upheld a complaint against a claim made on behalf of a visiting guest speaker, Archbishop Benson Idahosa, who was said to have raised eight people from the dead.

Then there are Reid's far-right views - gays are "filthy perverts"; Muslims, Hindus and Buddhists are variously described in videoed sermons as "vile" and "foul heathens". Christians who do not work, Reid said in one recording, should be allowed to starve. He believes in capital punishment, and he would pull the trigger himself; lethal injection is too good for them, he says in one church video. His teachings on the family are not to everyone's taste. Writing in the latest issue of the Peniel's newspaper, Reid says: "Parents have a tremendous responsibility when they have children; fathers have the biggest responsibility, because God has placed them as 'head' of the household, to give leadership to the family by setting the standards." He continues: "In today's society, however, many women have usurped the place that God gave to their husbands."

And there have been concerns expressed about the church's attitude toward disciplining children. "How do you drive something far from a child?" Reid asks in one video of him preaching. "Well you have a stick, and they have a rear end which God caused to be cushioned." The claim, again denied by the church, is that it infiltrated the local Tory party in order to gain political influence in the area. It is not a new story. It dates back almost three years to January 1998, when 119 members of the Peniel church joined the Pilgrims Hatch branch of the Conservative Association and were voted into key positions within the branch.

The allegation is that Reid, frustrated after a planning application for a school sports hall was turned down by the local council, called on members of his church to join the Tory party so that he might gain some influence within local government. The church dismisses the claim as "absurd". Conservative Central Office was called in to investigate, but it found nothing amiss - key complainants, however, say that they were not even interviewed when Tory officials visited. The Evangelical Alliance, of which Peniel is a member, has also found that concerns that had been raised were "groundless".

Yes, a number of people from the congregation did join the Tory party, says Brown; not as a coordinated effort to infiltrate the local association, however, but to support a fellow Peniel member, Robin Maillard, who had been active in the party for a number of years in a different constituency before moving to Pilgrims Hatch and intended to stand as a Conservative candidate in the local elections. "Mr Reid has never suggested that members of the congregation join the Conservative - or any other - party to gain influence in local politics, or for any other reason."

He has received 75 letters from Brentwood constituents, one of whom described it as "a distressed constituency", asking him to stand against the existing Tory 10,000 majority.

"There's obviously a lot of unhappiness in the area. I think that it might be a good opportunity to offer them a fresh start and take party politics out of the equation," said Bell.

The Peniel is likely to remain in the public eye due to a number of pending legal actions involving the church and the Tories. As well as the action for damages detailed above, Bishop Reid and five of his church colleagues are suing a local independent Tory councillor, Tony Galbraith, for alleged libel over a press release he put out; the independent Conservatives are suing the official Conservatives for alleged libel over an election leaflet; and the police are investigating an alleged breach of electoral practice by the independents.

One of the independent Tories expelled from the official party is its former treasurer, Tony Donnelly, who was among those who approached Bell. "The Peniel church is the single largest group in Brentwood and Ongar Conservative Association," says Donnelly. "They have the power to select and deselect the MP or any councillor. My fear is that the Peniel church is not just a church. It also has a political agenda. Their influence over the Conservative party is unhealthy and we've got to do something to stop it."

But according to the Peniel, only five of the 30 members of the executive committee of Brentwood and Ongar Conservative Association attend the church. "Hardly a ruling majority," says Brown.

On the Sunday I visit, Reid and his congregation appear utterly unperturbed by the renewed speculation surrounding their church. Political infiltration? It is so ludicrous that they find it funny. The church is almost full. Inside it is more like a television studio than a church: video cameras are trained from every corner; there are big screens and microphones suspended from the ceiling; there is a photographer on hand; and there is an impressive little band in a special two-tier studio within the church.

When I walk in, an elderly man welcomes me. He takes my hand and holds it for a long time. Then his other hand closes over the top of our two hands and he looks me directly in the eyes, asking me where I come from. Someone lends me a Bible so I can study the passages mentioned by the preachers. The 100-strong choir, resplendent in orange and pink, is awesome. Its members' faces are beatific; they even pogo with enthusiasm.

Everyone is friendly, smiley, keen to strike up conversation. The children are impeccably behaved. They sit quietly throughout the two-hour service, like mini-students in a lecture hall, making careful notes of what Reid says throughout. The only child to make any noise - a little boy of about 18 months, dressed in a waistcoat and bow tie - is carried out by his dad, his hand over his son's mouth. Reid pauses as the boy is removed; a little while later he is carried back in, perfectly happy and perfectly quiet.

In it he denies that his church has taken over the local Tory group. His church, he says, has no political agenda. "I encourage every member to be fully involved in the community. Pickles, likewise, rejects any suggestion that there is a link. "Has at any time any member of that church sought to change my views on any thing? The answer is no. Does Keith come and talk to me about the church? The answer is definitely no."

His view is that the objections of the independent Tories are nothing to do with a church taking over, but merely an extension of the political infighting that had been going on for some time in the constituency. Max Carter, who has known Reid for more than 30 years, moved his family down from Lancashire to join the church, which he left 12 years ago after five years' involvement. webTitle: Court circular: Who's up in front of the judge

fields.headline: Court circular
fields.standfirst: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.body:
Everyone's favourite pint-sized has-been, Gary Coleman, has taken to the TV to defend himself against a $1m lawsuit. Coleman, you might well recall, was involved in an altercation in 1998 with a female autograph-hunter while he was working as a security guard at a shopping mall - he punched her in the face.

The former Diff'rent Strokes star pleaded guilty to a charge of disturbing the peace and attended an anger management class. But the victim of his attack, 205-pound bus driver Tracy Fields, wouldn't let it end there. Fields admits that prior to Coleman punching her she "told him he had a bad-ass attitude", and "that was the reason he wasn't successful as an adult actor".

Her million-dollar civil case sought compensation for "pain and suffering" brought about by the incident. After appearing before TV Judge Mills Lane, Coleman was ordered to pay Fields $1,665 for medical expenses. Judge Lane, however, dismissed any further claims to compensation, telling Fields, "Don't give me that principle stuff, it's the money." Coleman simply said, "I hope to God never to run into another person like this."
