webTitle: Government has not gutted RUC reform bill says Mandelson

fields.headline: Government has not gutted RUC reform bill says Mandelson
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson yesterday vowed to press ahead with the government's controversial plans to reform the Royal Ulster Constabulary despite unionist resistance and criticism of his bill by one of the authors of Chris Patten's original blueprint.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson yesterday vowed to press ahead with the government's controversial plans to reform the Royal Ulster Constabulary despite unionist resistance and criticism of his bill by one of the authors of Chris Patten's original blueprint.

The Northern Ireland secretary dismissed claims in yesterday's Guardian by the Canadian academic, Professor Clifford Shearing, a member of the Patten commission, who complained that the government had "gutted" its proposals in its efforts to square both unionist and nationalist opinion.

"I fundamentally disagree with his analysis," Mr Mandelson declared. Everyone "had to live in the real world, and that includes former members of the Patten commission" when the threat from dissident republicans remained.

Prof Shearing's complaint of cherry-picking on crucial elements - including confidence-building accountability and local partnership - was seized upon by nationalists and Sinn Fein to vindicate their demands that the report be implemented in full.

A Downing Street spokes-man said: "We believe we are implementing the Patten report, and doing so in a way that is consistent and fair." Tony Blair had a 15-minute phone conversation with President Bill Clinton on Friday, officials revealed. Mr Clinton "stands ready to help" in his final weeks in office.

But the SDLP's police spokesman, Alex Attwood, said the Canadian criminology professor's criticism of the bill illustrates the "real fears and anxieties" about its departure from the Patten blueprint.

He added that while there had been "some ground recovered" in recent months, more needed to be done. He told reporters at Stormont that the SDLP would base any decision on whether it could endorse the police force created by the bill against the standards of Patten.

"What we require is certainty that what Patten intended will be delivered - certainty in respect of the name, the flying of the Union flag and the future badge of the police service; certainty in respect of Special Branch, full-time reserve, the recruitment of part-time reserve, closure of Gough holding centre," he said.

"We require certainty because the government say they are implementing Patten but there is uncertainty in a number of key issues that they are not implementing Patten.

"If we can get certainty, then we can get confidence and if we can get confidence, then we can get participation in the service and its structures."

Mr Mandelson faces a more imminent threat tonight when separate attempts will be launched to thwart his proposals in the Lords.

Tory peers will try to amend the bill to prevent symbolic changes to the RUC hatband while unionist peers, loyal to David Trimble, will urge postponement of the RUC reform package until the terrorist threat is finally over.

Mr Mandelson is confident that a cross-party coalition of peers will see off both threats and that he will get his Police (Northern Ireland) Bill through by the end of the month. If Liberal Democrat hostility to the principle of quotas means the government is defeated on its plans to recruit equally from both of the province's communities, ministers will restore the clause in the Commons.

Faced with unionist anger, as Mr Trimble ducks and weaves to survive pressure to pull out of the power-sharing executive, Mr Mandelson - who has been broadly supportive of his efforts to keep the peace process intact, despite his efforts to exclude Sinn Fein from cross-border meetings - said he would take the security situation into account when implementing any changes.

It is expected that he may delay nominations to the new Northern Ireland police board.

Disquiet has been further increased by weekend arrests of suspects in an apparent plot to detonate a 500lb "barrack buster" bomb in the province. It was found in County Fermanagh. Another bomb, also linked to the dissident Real IRA by the security services, was found in Belfast but believed to have been destined for London.

fields.headline: Carnival of carnage
fields.standfirst: It's that time of year again: the carpets in America's TV offices are turning red as failing shows are yanked off the networks. It can be breathtakingly ferocious - and nobody is safe.  John Patterson  has been watching the mayhem
fields.trailText: It's that time of year again: the carpets in America's TV offices are turning red as failing shows are yanked off the networks. It can be breathtakingly ferocious - and nobody is safe. John Patterson has been watching the mayhem.
fields.body:
It's autumn in America, and there's a bloodbath on television. It happens every year, and no, it's not a renewed debate about violence on TV. It's the annual slaughter of the sickly children of the fall network TV season. The new shows debut on the big networks. Everyone crosses their fingers and nervously awaits the arrival of the Nielsen ratings. If your show goes over big, you'll probably survive for a few weeks, possibly even for the entire season. You might even be back next year.

And then again, you might not. Short-term expectations are insanely high. You need to make a splash immediately. If that doesn't happen, your show takes an early bath - forget about nursing sick shows along - and something else moves into your time slot. Your show might not even last a fortnight before they axe it and start handing out the P45s.

All that creative development, all your seed capital, all those focus groups and test screenings, all those delicate negotiations with network execs, show creators, crew and talent, and all their sharky business representatives - all for nothing, as the suits take your dream TV show off to a quiet place near the freight elevators and shoot it in the back of the head. When your show debuted, you dreamed of a ten-year run, critical plaudits, a place in the national culture, perhaps, and of the millions to be made in syndicated rerun fees. But right now all you have left is a potentially trouser-filling appointment with your bank manager.

This carnival of carnage has been especially entertaining this autumn because so many other TV events have delayed the launch of the new season. First there was the Presidential candidates' refusal to set clear dates for their three debates, the conclusion of which usually marks the kick-off point for the new season in an election year. Then there were the Olympics, which got the most wretched ratings in US TV history.

The result is that the unveiling of new shows has been staggered over an unusually long period, which somewhat diminishes the coherent sense of a new generation of TV programmes.

British viewers will never even see some of these shows - and in most cases that's no great loss. Every year a few programmes are so bad that you wonder to what species the people who greenlighted them belong.

Judging by the slew of disasters foisted upon us (and then cancelled) by the NBC network, I would guess that their decision-makers belong to some obscure category of higher mollusc. "NBC", quipped one critic after a particularly brutal culling of new shows, "currently stands for 'Nothing But Catastrophes'." Among the catastrophes were the gormless family sitcom Daddio, which was placed "on indefinite hiatus" (meaning they'll execute you when no one's looking), and Tucker, a dire family comedy that was axed after critics called it a rip-off of Fox's wonderful Malcolm In The Middle.

Deadline, a newspaper series starring Oliver Platt, from Law And Order creator Dick Wolf, was spiked after five lacklustre outings. Those three programmes constitute two-thirds of the network's Monday night line-up, which now looks like the Manhattan skyline minus half the skyscrapers.

The Michael Richards Show fell on its backside in its second week despite hopes that it might benefit from some intangible "Seinfeld factor". The critics were brutal: "It has sagging letdown written all over it", said one; "a devastating bomb... it's awful", chimed in another, as cheerful as a leper's bell. Now the axe hovers above Richards's neck.

None of the other networks has been as troubled as NBC, but each one has cancelled something, and a good number of remaining shows are looking very unsteady on their feet. Fox has pulled Freakylinks, an X-Files-style mystery developed by the Blair Witch team, and replaced it with another new show, Million Dollar Mysteries. The WB Channel has already yanked its newlywed comedy For Your Love.

Even the big hitters are stumbling. Melrose Place and Sex In The City creator Darren Star took a critical drubbing for his Wall Street sex-drama The Street, which was ridiculed by, among other people, Wall Street traders. And his teen spoof soap Grosse Pointe has already been rescheduled half to death on the WB Channel. David E Kelley's new high-school drama Boston Public was roundly ridiculed in a poll of students taken by the Boston Globe.

Oddly, both Kelley (in Ally McBeal) and Star have current storylines featuring female characters blessed with penises. James Cameron meanwhile avoids chicks with dicks in his first TV venture, the action sci-fi thriller Dark Angel, choosing instead to rely on the high-kicking, chicks-in-charge formula he honed with ex-wife Linda Hamilton in The Terminator.

Each of these shows will get a long leash, given the power and influence of the men behind them. But if they come a cropper they'll still be shown the door. The networks don't just axe bad shows: last year's cancellation of NBC's Freaks And Geeks and Fox's Hollywood comedy Action only proves that quality and good writing aren't considered adequate substitutes for a 12-point market share.

webTitle: Information bill deal disowned by Lib Dem MPs

fields.headline: Information bill deal disowned by Lib Dem MPs
fields.standfirst: Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: The government's hopes for a smooth passage for its freedom of information bill were dashed last night after the Liberal Democrat leadership in the Commons disowned a deal struck by its peers.
fields.body:
The government's hopes for a smooth passage for its freedom of information bill were dashed last night after the Liberal Democrat leadership in the Commons disowned a deal struck by its peers.

The years long campaign for open government has reached its most critical stage with ministers determined to push the bill through parliament within a fortnight.

The Lib Dems hold the balance of power in the Lords and yesterday could, with Conservative support, have forced through changes to toughen the bill during its report stage. But Liberal Democrat peers led by Lord McNally held back after last week striking a deal to support the bill in return for concessions.

Faced with a torrent of criticism from the press and campaigners over the deal, the party's home affairs spokesman, Simon Hughes, and constitutional affairs spokesman, Robert Maclennan, promised to hold last minute talks with the home secretary, Jack Straw, to strengthen the bill further. The Liberal Democrats want to remove the proposed blanket exemption from disclosure of any information gathered during the course of an investigation such as the Paddington rail inquiry, or the sinking of the Marchioness. Critics claim the exemption would protect ministers and companies from public scrutiny if they had been responsible for a breakdown in health and safety.

The opposition was strengthened yesterday when freedom of information campaigners also protested at late changes tabled by ministers banning the public from obtaining any documents supplied to tribunals handling complaints on email snooping by the state.

The new ban tabled in the Lords yesterday by cabinet office minister Lord Falconer will allow the Home Office to withhold any information supplied either "directly or indirectly" to tribunals hearing complaints from those whose offices and homes have been raided by the authorities. The Liberal Democrats hope to negotiate further concessions in time for the bill's third reading in the Lords next week, but if they fail to reach agreement with the government, they will put pressure on their peers to back their tougher line.

Mr Maclennan conceded yesterday conceded there had been "a failure of communication between ourselves and our peers. The issue is, are we still negotiating with the government, or have we signed off the bill? And the answer is, we are still negotiating the bill."

The Tory leader in the Lords, Lord Strathclyde, yesterday accused Liberal Democrat peers of "double dealing and twisting in the starkest form". He claimed the original deal had been struck between Labour and the Liberal Democrats at the highest level.

The campaign group Charter 88 also rounded on the Liberal Democrat peers, saying their "collapse is deeply disturbing. The four agreed amendments do nothing to address the main areas in which the bill is defective".

The Campaign for Freedom of Information said: "We are reaching the absurd situation when the Conservatives will be able to claim the high moral ground on this issue."

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.standfirst: The Faculty • Outland • Dead Ringers • Touch
fields.trailText: The Faculty • Outland • Dead Ringers • Touch
fields.body:
The Faculty (Robert Rodriguez, 1998) 8pm, Sky MovieMax
A sharp and witty sci-fi thriller, written by Kevin (Scream) Williamson and directed by the man who brought you the bloody, marvellous vampire-gangster movie From Dusk till Dawn. Much in the style of Invasion Of The Body Snatchers, it has the teachers of an Ohio high school taken over by aliens, the fate of the town and maybe the world resting in the hands of a bunch of bickering students - fortunately, as snappy a gang of teenies as you're ever likely to meet.

Outland (Peter Hyams, 1981) 8pm, Sky Cinema
High Noon in space, with Sean Connery in the Gary Cooper role. The action shifts from the Western's Hadleyville to a mining base on Jupiter's third moon, Io (As in: Io, Io, it's off to work they go), where Marshal Connery awaits the arrival of drug-pusher Peter Boyle's killers from earth. It's a long vigil as the now digital clock counts down to a violent final confrontation.

Dead Ringers (David Cronenberg, 1988) 10pm, Carlton Cinema
Doing for gynaecology what Marathon Man did for dentistry, Cronenberg's tale of disturbed twins is sufficiently creepy in itself as to make his trademark gore effects unnecessary. Practically the only trickery required was to enable Jeremy Irons to play both the mental Mantle brothers with stomach-churning conviction. Scientists at the top of their field, they share success, apartments and, unwisely, lovers. Genevieve Bujold is unfortunate enough to fall under their surgical spell, throwing their joint identity destructively off balance.

Touch (Paul Schrader, 1996) 2.05am, Sky Premier
Based on an Elmore Leonard novel, this is the story of Skeet Ulrich's former monk, Juvenal, who is blessed with healing powers and suffers the stigmata. Christopher Walken's media-mad evangelist and Tom Arnold's fundamentalist vie for the opportunity to exploit him in a parable on religious extremism.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.standfirst: Thinking Allowed • Laboratories Of Power
fields.trailText: Thinking Allowed • Laboratories Of Power
fields.body:
Professor Tim O'Shea hopes to expand the number of international students attending major British universities. But, as he explains to Laurie Taylor in Thinking Allowed (4.0pm, Radio 4), their presence will be through the magic of the internet. There are, obviously, any number of unsolved technical issues, but the knottier problems are likely to be cultural. Even the supposedly international language of mathematics employs different notation in various parts of the world.

One of the greatest triumphs for the World Health Organisation, second of the Laboratories Of Power (9.0pm, Radio 4) profiled by Richard Black, was its campaign to rid the world of smallpox. The disease killed some 2 million people in 1967; 10 years later the only known cases were of two accidentally-infected laboratory assistants. But WHO's campaigns are not always that effective. For a time in the 1980s its officials thought they had tuberculosis on the run. Unfortunately, the mycobacterium proved a more resourceful opponent.

fields.headline: Random Views
fields.standfirst: What limo drivers are watching on TV
fields.trailText: What limo drivers are watching on TV
fields.body:
David Tead: "I don't get to see a lot of it, I spend most of my time in the car reading the paper, trying not to get parking tickets. I might see GMTV in the morning when I get up. I can't stand the Big Breakfast, I don't like all the shouting and it's so bright! Hurts my eyes first thing in the morning. I watch a bit of Trisha on my day off after I've walked the dogs. I don't like it though."

Simon Jenner: "I'm not a tremendous viewer of the television. I like the sitcoms though, I think the British sitcom is an overlooked programme, it's an institution. When I do watch it, it'll be Fawlty Towers or One Foot In The Grave. I think they're very clever, good strong characters. Perhaps Victor Meldrew has got a bit stale, you just know he's going to say 'I don't believe it!' all the time."

George Castle: "I like to watch the comedy nights, but I really am working all the time. I get my wife to record Frasier, because I like that a lot. I like the dog, Eddie. Everyone's got a personality. I also like Friends, even though it's full of young, beautiful people - perhaps that's why I like it! I watch the documentaries sometimes but it's all about people going to the supermarket or buying a house, and we've all done that, haven't we? Perhaps there's nothing left to film anymore. Just Jane McDonald? I'm not sure about her."

fields.headline: Upstairs, downstairs
fields.standfirst: Brookside • Christie's Story • Cutting Edge: Seconds To Impact
fields.trailText: Last night's TV: Brookside • Christie's Story • Cutting Edge: Seconds To Impact
fields.body:
Susannah, we hardly knew yet. Just when Ms Morrissey was beginning to make a favourable impression on us - as a lying, cheating, fine wine drinking nympho - there she goes and makes another impression entirely: a Susannah-shaped dent in her hall carpet.

Even without a Murder, She Wrote-esque silhouette of her throwing her hands in the air in shock as she got pushed down the stairs, Susannah's death was a jolly affair.

Jacqui Dixon accosted her about a hair appointment Susannah had pinched from under Jacqui's nose (oh, and it had something to do with a kid too), while Dr Darren vowed never to give Susannah another protein injection. Emily Shadwick - auditioning for a part in Child's Play 3: The Daughter Of Chuckie: Barbie Goes Bonkers - was suitably menacing, spitting out words like they weren't ecstasy tablets. And Mick didn't quite know what to do with himself, so he grumbled like a bear with a migraine and went off for a weep in the street, perhaps anticipating that if anything did happen to Susannah, he would automatically be blamed (and he does have a history of pushing women down stairs, the last one being that psycho teacher).

So now, after push came to shove, the question hanging in the air in Brookside (Channel 4) - stronger than the stench of Bernie Nolan's hormones - is, who killed Susannah? The answer is Max Farnham. Whether he actually pushed her down the stairs or not is irrelevant since he is culpable simply by having married her. Chinese water torture looks like a day at a health farm compared to being married to Max. Poor Patricia was so tired of being married to him, she ran off to France and became a lesbian with her mother. (Well, not with her mother. Accompanied by her.)

Whatever the former Mrs Farnhams have done, you have to feel sorry for them, simply because they were once Mrs Farnhams and had to put up with Max's hair, terrible dress sense and his habit of sitting in his car on the driveway. It wouldn't be surprising if Susannah threw herself down the stairs, unable to live with the shame any longer. And that would certainly explain the lack of a Murder, She Wrote homage. Susannah looked more like a Quincy fan.

Christie's Story (ITV) was both icky and uplifting, hopeful but ultimately depressing. White trash from Tennessee, Christie was 24 years old, 5ft 6in tall, and weighed over 36 stone. She felt grotesque and there was little anyone could do to persuade her otherwise, mainly because she was grotesque to a society fed on thin-equals-beautiful ideals. In a heartrending moment, she explained she was afraid to go out with Olivia, her daughter, because she didn't want her to feel ashamed of her mother.

But Christie's weight was not simply a cosmetic issue, it was killing her. So, it was off to hospital for an operation which would make her feel full after a couple of mouth fuls of food. The following year, Christie lost half her own body weight, had a tummy tuck operation (which resembled someone dismantling a circus tent) and began to feel better about herself. But just a little bit better.

As this wonderful film unfolded, it cast its gaze over poverty in America, the dysfunctionality of many families and the hopelessness and self-loathing that are some people's constant companions. We discovered the reasons for Christie's weight gain as a child (she says she was abused), the by-product of her weight loss (abandoning her church for sex, drugs and rock'n'roll in an attempt to regain her lost adolescence), and the price paid by Olivia who, as her mother's new lifestyle left her stranded, began overeating. A lesson in "Tread lightly in your dreams, they might come true for you tomorrow", Christie's Story was one to which we should all pay heed.

Cutting Edge: Seconds To Impact (Channel 4) was about base jumping, the practice of jumping off tall structures - cliffs, chimneys, pylons - for the sheer hell of it. "If I have an accident now," one of the participants said, "I won't look back in months to come and say 'Why did I do it?'" No, you won't, because you'll be in a hospital bed getting fed through a tube and you won't have a clue who or where you are.

Not surprisingly, the vast majority of base jumpers are men. And some of them are Australian.

fields.headline: Good day, bad day
fields.trailText: Yesterday
fields.body:
Yesterday

Bad day

Scottish Socialist MSP Tommy Sheridan, heading for jail following conviction for breach of the peace and resisting arrest. He was fined £250 at Helensburgh sheriff court after his arrest at an anti-nuclear protest. He refused to pay the fine and was given 28 days to pay or face 14 days in prison.

Good day

The Queen. Labour MP Kevin McNamara's attempt to remove the need for MPs to swear allegiance to the monarch was defeated after a Tory opponent accused him of wanting to admit "fifth columnists and traitors" to the Commons.

Today

Commons: PM's questions. Transport bill, Lords amendments. Lords: Police (Northern Ireland) bill, third reading. Freedom of information bill, report.

webTitle: Queen lukewarm on new prayer book

fields.headline: Queen lukewarm on new prayer book
fields.standfirst:
Monarch attends service using the controversial new Common Worship liturgy for the first time but says tradition has a 'valued place'

Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: Monarch attends service using the controversial new Common Worship liturgy for the first time but says tradition has a 'valued place'.
fields.body:
The Queen bestowed lukewarm praise on the Church of England's new Common Worship prayerbook yesterday, making it clear that she was relieved to see it contained large sections of the 451-year-old Book of Common Prayer beloved of traditionalists.

The church's supreme governor insisted that the Book of Common Prayer still had a "valued place" in the Church of England.

Royal sources said the book is used in the Queen's private chapels at services she attends.

The Queen was at a service at Westminster Abbey at which Common Worship was used for the first time. Then she addressed the first meeting of the newly elected General Synod, at Church House.

It has taken 15 years to develop Common Worship, which replaces the much derided Alternative Service book, criticised for its use of banal modern language. The new book contains a blend of modern speech and traditional prayers which priests will be able to use at the end of this year. Prayers can be downloaded from the Church of England website.

The Queen told synod members: "The aim of this revision is to provide for the diversity of worship in the Church of England's parishes within a common framework. I am pleased that Common Worship contains services from the Book of Common Prayer. Both the prayer book and modern services have a valued place in the Church of England today and are part of its future.

"I have appreciated the opportunity to meet some of those who have been involved in the design and production - their work holds to a long tradition in the church to worship God in ways both old and new which reflect the deepest strivings of our faith."

Traditionalists have tried to enlist the Prince of Wales, patron of the Prayerbook Society, to support their opposition to the new services, but yesterday his staff reiterated that he will not enter the debate.

The synod, made up of bishops, clergy and lay members, will today debate whether to wind up the church's urban fund, set up in 1987 to aid projects in the inner cities.

The fund has dispensed more than £37m but a report to the synod recognises that it is in danger of becoming too costly to administer.

A report by the archbishops' council, the church's executive decision making committee, absolves the fund's administrative staff of wrongdoing but adds: "General concern has been expressed - regarding the stewardship and administration of the fund.

"Public knowledge of this will have implications for future fundraising and collaboration. There is an urgent need for reassurance on these points."

fields.headline: £231m Portcullis House faces cost inquiry
fields.trailText: The controversy over Portcullis House, the new office block for MPs, was reopened yesterday after the national audit office launched an investigation into why it cost £231m to build.
fields.body:
The controversy over Portcullis House, the new office block for MPs, was reopened yesterday after the national audit office launched an investigation into why it cost £231m to build.

The independent spending watchdog - which last week published a damning report into the £1bn financial fiasco of the dome - said it wanted to "examine in detail" how the project was planned and built.

Areas expected to be scrutinised include the £47m cost of its burnished bronze roof, which then needed a £500,000 polish, the £2m electric blinds, and whether it was really necessary to hire 12 ornamental fig trees at the cost of £150,000. The NAO is expected to investigate why MPs who oversaw the project lost £4m in in a legal wrangle after operating a "buy British" policy when awarding contracts. A judge ruled this was illegal, while a second judge deemed the tendering process "a charade".

Last night an NAO spokesman said the building, which the watchdog had been monitoring since work began on it in 1992, was an "obvious contender" for investigation.

Last night Norman Baker, Liberal Democrat MP for Lewes, welcomed the inquiry. "The colossal spending on Portcullis House is incredible," he said. "The taxpayer has forked out more than £1m for each MP housed there. Hopefully the national audit office will get to the bottom of why the project was allowed to spend taxpayers' money so freely."

Sir Sydney Chapman, chair of the Commons accommodation and works committee, which is responsible for the running of the building, said it was "perfectly proper" that an investigation should take place.

fields.headline: The bouncer from the Tigger school of bouncing
fields.trailText: I've always thought that the health secretary, Alan Milburn, resembled a Geordie bouncer, with his truculent manner and preference for shouting people down rather than exchanging the delicate nuances of argument.
fields.body:
I've always thought that the health secretary, Alan Milburn, resembled a Geordie bouncer, with his truculent manner and preference for shouting people down rather than exchanging the delicate nuances of argument.

I see him outside some naff north-eastern club, possibly called Tropicana, all pink and blue neon palm trees. From inside you can hear the insistent bass pulse of house, or garage, or perhaps potting shed music. Wearing a tuxedo - not quite all the bloodstains have washed out yet - a baseball bat to hand, he brooks no disagreement from those whom he wishes to debar from the premises.

I consulted a friend from that part of the world about what the old Milburn would have said in his role as bouncer. He replied: "He might say 'Oi, marra! Fook off out or a'll fooking brain ya!' This is normally spoken in a soft, soothing voice, as if reading a bedtime story."

But all is changed. Perhaps he was frightened by the ghost of health secretaries past, but the new Milburn is a nicer bouncer. Yesterday he told the Commons how he was going to dish out an extra £37bn a year to health authorities in England.

This was a lovable bouncer, a bouncer from the Tigger school of bouncing. He would offer people money to go in, plus a book of vouchers good for free ready-mixed cocktails. Old persons would try to get in. "I'm not so nippy on me pins these days, Mr Milburn," they would explain, and he would reply: "You're welcome anyway. Just dance round your Zimmer frames! Have a drink on us!"

Mr Milburn dispensed money like a pantomime Buttons tossing chocolate bars to the audience. There would be an average of £29m each for health authorities. "Oooh!" said Labour MPs. There would be an extra £65m to recruit nurses and midwives. Ward sisters would be showered with gold. There would soon be a mere 30-minute wait for "life-saving clot-busting drugs" - which sounds like something the Commons could use.

"We are winning the war on waiting lists!" he went on, though this sounded less impressive later when he said waits for hospital treatment would be "wicks, rather than munz" - in 2008, that is.

Immediately afterwards Kevin McNamara made one of his periodic attempts to abolish the oath of allegiance for MPs. He believes this is an anachronism which de mands fealty to the Queen but makes no reference to the voters. Tories believe it is really an attempt by Mr McNamara, who is sympathetic to the Irish republican cause, to get Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness into the House. They won't sit because they refuse to swear loyalty to Her Maj.

Mr McNamara was perhaps lucky in that his opponent was the Conservatives' Gerald Howarth, who defended the oath by saying it was "a bulwark against Catholicism!". As Labour MPs gleefully pointed at the very Catholic Ann Widdecombe, he tried to row back: "Catholicism used to represent a challenge to the sovereignty of these islands. But it no longer is," he pleaded lamely. "Too late, too late!" yelled Dennis Skinner, as Ms Widdecombe almost laughed herself off the bench.

And too late it was. Mr Howarth may now be known as the Oaf of Allegiance.

Though he did win. Changing the Commons' ancient ways is always appallingly difficult. For example, John Maxton complained about traditional divisions, each of which takes 15 minutes and can occupy hours in any one day. "Isn't it urgent for us to introduce electronic voting?" he demanded.

"Ask the Americans!" shouted a Tory to howls of joy. Sometimes a passionate, well-expressed argument can be utterly deflated by a single phrase.

fields.headline: John Bury
fields.standfirst: Set designer whose energy brought flamboyance and originality to the theatre
fields.trailText: Set designer whose energy brought flamboyance and originality to the theatre.
fields.body:
John Bury, the Glyndebourne and Royal Shakespeare Company stage designer, who has died aged 75, was usually in the grip of a great enthusiasm. A groundbreaker, he ploughed right through the lawns of English theatrical taste and received opinion about how sets should be.

He had a good start in life. His father worked as a physicist with Nils Bohr, and his mother was a botanist; both parents expected John to try his hand at things like gardening, sketching out of doors and learning how things work.

Educated at the Cathedral school, Hereford, and University College, London, Bury came to his work with plenty of general knowledge, but a touch of the primitive. He had no opportunity to study in his chosen field, or work as apprentice to an established designer, as is normal nowadays.

Pending demobilisation from the Fleet Air Arm, in which he served from 1942-46, he simply presented himself at Joan Littlewood's Theatre Workshop, in Stratford, east London - and, being no actor, evolved from driving the van that carried the lights, to hanging the lights themselves, focusing them on the action, and pro viding the odd door or wall as required.

Littlewood's demands and Bury's aptitude led to good sets, like those for A Taste Of Honey, The Quare Fellow, Fings Ain't What They Used To Be! and Oh What A Lovely War. He transferred to the West End, then a place of formalities, coming on stage with cast-iron radiators dismaying in their reality, more interested in the kind of paint to be used on a door than in its colour.

Bury travelled abroad with Theatre Workshop, picking up a wider theatrical experience than was then to be found in Britain; and he was politically aware too, if a bit of a Stalinist, who thought leftwing ideals could do with a few rules to make them effective in action. He left the Theatre Workshop in 1963 to join the RSC.

Peter Hall understood what this attitude could bring to various Shakespeare productions he was planning, with the theme of power in society; John's sets and costumes for The Wars Of The Roses, Stratford's great cycle of history plays for the Shakespeare quatercentenary in 1964, had an unprecedented force. His periaktoi were on a heroic scale. These triple-faced structures, based on classical Greek theatre, which, when revolved simultaneously, transformed the scene and its ethos, were dressed in metal-like siege engines and other weapons. Their unprecedented weight made for unrest back stage.

His designs for David Warner's Hamlet and Paul Scofield's Government Inspector showed increasing sophistication. His Hamlet was a black formica world of elegant menace; his Government Inspector was a brilliant gaggle of characters drawn from diverse sources - Daumier crossed with Beatrix Potter.

Among Bury's very best work, in my opinion, were Pinter's double-bill, Landscape and Silence, at the Aldwych. For Landscape, he created an ocean of emotional distance with a divided rostrum. Silence had a labyrinth of forlorn memory, in which light bounced off a rippled silver floor, throwing shadows and shimmering clouds on to a plain canvas ceiling.

These were days of ascendency for Bury, and he went to Glyndebourne, initially in the face of a lingering, polite anxiety about his "lack of taste". But he refashioned the world of baroque opera as a full-bodied place. In 1970, Cavalli's Calisto scuttled away in a bearskin to her place in the stars as Ursa Minor. A year later, the gods of Il Ritorno d'Ulisse in Patria were suspended from the flies, riding the sky on bluntly mechanical rails. The Hall staging, though not the least Pythonesque, was nicknamed Monteverdi's Flying Circus.

A few years earlier, Bury had made as bold a beginning at Covent Garden, with Moses and Aaron. The opera's postbag was stuffed with anguished letters about the exploited women in the dance before the golden calf, and the nervous animals on a slope made slippery with "the blood of sacrifice". In 1973, he became Peter Hall's head of design, and associate director at the National theatre, then preparing to leave the Old Vic for its new South Bank home.

There, the standard of work was not always sustained. There was so much of it, and the demands of Bury's collaborators were diluted by their need to woo public opinion. He was chairman of the Society of British Theatre Designers, won prizes at Quadriennales of Design in Prague, and was chairman of the scenographic commission of the International Organisation of Designers and Theatre Architects. A suprising delicacy of touch was nourished by his second wife Elizabeth, who contributed much to his work. fields.bodyText: John Bury, the Glyndebourne and Royal Shakespeare Company stage designer, who has died aged 75, was usually in the grip of a great enthusiasm. A groundbreaker, he ploughed right through the lawns of English theatrical taste and received opinion about how sets should be. He had a good start in life. His father worked as a physicist with Nils Bohr, and his mother was a botanist; both parents expected John to try his hand at things like gardening, sketching out of doors and learning how things work. Educated at the Cathedral school, Hereford, and University College, London, Bury came to his work with plenty of general knowledge, but a touch of the primitive. He had no opportunity to study in his chosen field, or work as apprentice to an established designer, as is normal nowadays. fields.headline: Angela Holmes
fields.standfirst: A talented performer devoted to building a business of beauty, style and quality in fashion
fields.trailText: A talented performer devoted to building a business of beauty, style and quality in fashion.
fields.body:
Some time last year, the fashion designer Angela Holmes, who has died of cancer aged 50, was buying perfume in a London store when a celebrated fashion editor accosted her. Jabbing a finger at her unusual coat, the woman whispered: "Where did you get those clothes? I should know you. Are you in fashion?"

Many designers would have been oleaginous with opportunism at such an approach from an influential journalist, but Angela put down the perfume and made a swift exit. "It was ghastly," she said afterwards, "like coming face to face with the Wicked Witch of the West."

Angela was uncompromisingly talented. She built up Droopy and Browns, a unique family business, designing, manufacturing and retailing beautifully-made clothes. Yet she avoided the mainstream fashion industry because, like the boy in the fairy tale who knew the emperor was naked, what she saw through the hype was not a pretty sight. She was also a powerful performer and singer, described by the Financial Times in 1984 as "an unparalleled interpreter of songs by Brecht and Weill".

Out shopping, or walking her Gordon setters on York's Knavesmire, Angela aroused curiosity because, with blonde hair tumbling down her back and trailing clouds of perfume, she appeared too glamorous for mundane activities. She was depressed by drab reality and tried to exclude it from her world, filling her house with flowers and dressing as if each day was a special event.

Born in Darlington, County Durham, she was one of four children brought up on a Yorkshire farm. As a child, she put on performances about swooning princesses to entertain her mother and older sister. At 13, traumatised by her beloved mother's death from cancer, she spent hours drawing elegant ladies in beautiful dresses. At 17, she went missing for three weeks, found work as a chambermaid in Scarborough and met her future husband, Keith Wilkinson.

The couple returned to York and, with Angela's brother Jonathan, started a market stall selling her designs. In 1973, they acquired a shop in Stonegate, a building full of ghosts for Angela, who, as a little girl, had watched her mother buying couturier gowns in that very shop. Inspired by those memories, she started designing even more extravagant clothes. By 1997, Droopy and Browns had eight shops, from Edinburgh to Bath, the flagship being in St Martin's Lane, London.

Nostalgic for the days when clothes were beautifully made, and lasted, Angela disliked the disposability of contemporary fashion, and its use of cheap foreign labour to produce poor quality items. She took an arts and crafts approach, overseeing every stage from design to retail, and employing craftsmen and women to make each garment individually. She worked in natural fabrics, designed and drew many of the prints herself, and had them dyed to her own specifications.

Droopy and Browns' clothes are flamboyant and feminine, contemporary but with a historical influence, reflecting Angela's love of fantasy. Keith died in 1995, and the business will continue under Jonathan.

Angela could have taken a different path. During a brief stint in London in the 1970s, she was lead vocalist with what had been Robert Palmer's first band, the Mandrakes. In the 1980s, she toured her own shows, Songs Of Whores And Wars, and Cheap And Potent, and, bringing a fierce intelligence and dramatic presence to the works of Stephen Sondheim, Cole Porter and Kurt Weill, sold out at Edinburgh's Assembly Rooms and the Cheltenham literature festival. She directed and took the lead in a 1983 production of Bertolt Brecht's Happy End, which was invited to transfer from Edinburgh to the West End.

A member of the Prayer Book Society, which aims to encourage use of the Book of Common Prayer, and the John Clare Society, Angela loved traditional craftsmanship and Englishness, and joked that she should be "a blacksmith in a leather apron". Deeply religious and well read, she believed in equality and individuality, and railed against the culture of collective thought, political correctness and focus groups.

She is survived by Jonathan and her sister, Leone.

fields.headline: Paddy Chambers
fields.trailText: The career of guitarist Paddy Chambers, who has died of cancer aged 56, was the stuff of the 1960s rock era. A member of Paddy, Klaus and Gibson, his other bands included Faron's Flamingoes and the Big Three.
fields.body:
The career of guitarist Paddy Chambers, who has died of cancer aged 56, was the stuff of the 1960s rock era. A member of Paddy, Klaus and Gibson, his other bands included Faron's Flamingoes and the Big Three.

Born in Liverpool, he co-founded the Creoles in 1961, and soon after became lead guitarist with Steve Bennett And The Syndicate. But their diction was too northern for the Pye record label, so they joined the circuit around US air force European bases. In 1962, after a stint in Paris with a jazz group, Chambers joined Faron's Flamingoes.

At the height of the 1963 Liverpool boom, the band was a major palais attraction, but signing with an obscure record label led to two flop singles. In late 1963, Chambers was briefly with another Liverpool group, the Big Three, before passingthrough the Dominoes.

In Hamburg, the Dominoes' drummer Gibson Kemp, Lewis Collins (later of LWT's The Professionals) and Chambers set up a proto-jazz rock group, the Eyes. Collins quit, to be replaced by the German bass player Klaus Voorman. Thus was Paddy, Klaus And Gibson born.

In London, pop manager Tony Stratton-Smith was impressed. He booked the group for the then chic Pickwick club. At the urging of the Beatles, Brian Epstein, enthralled particularly by Chambers, bought out Stratton-Smith's contract in 1965, though success did not follow and, in 1966, the band split up. Chambers teamed up with Beryl Marsden, one of the best, if little recognised, female singers to emerge from Liverpool in the period. They formed Sinbad, the house band at the city's Victoriana club.

By the mid-1980s, Chambers had diversified into managing local groups. He is survived by his wife Joy, daughter and grandson.

fields.headline: Roger Peyrefitte
fields.standfirst: His novels on homosexuality scandalised France
fields.trailText: His novels on homosexuality scandalised France.
fields.body:
When British students went to Paris after the second world war, they were on the lookout for the works of Jean-Paul Sartre and Albert Camus. They already knew that these were the masters of contemporary French literature. But they heard a lot about another novelist, Roger Peyrefitte, who has died aged 93, and they soon found themselves reading his bestseller, Les Amitiés particulières, published in 1944 and translated into English as Special Friendships, in 1958.

The novel was regarded as unusual - indeed, it was considered scandalous by some - because it dealt with the love affairs of pupils at a French boarding-school for boys. That the school was a religious establishment made it all the more sensational, since the liberation of 1944 had highlighted the old question of relations between private and religious education, and state schools. It was assumed that the book was largely autobiographical, and that the events it described were drawn from life.

André Gide, who had attempted to defend homosexuality in a much earlier work, was prophetic in his congratulations to Peyrefitte. He did not think that Les Amitiés particulières would win the Goncourt prize, but did believe it would still be read a century later.

Indeed, Peyrefitte did not win the Goncourt. But the fact that the prize went to Elsa Triolet - by five votes against Peyrefitte's two - was seen as a manifestation of communist and resistance power (the decision was heavily criticised by both the Catholic and the right-wing press). So far as Gide's other prophecy is concerned, one can certainly say that Les Amitiés particulières is still read, more than 50 years later.

In the postwar years, Peyrefitte seemed likely to become prominent in the intellectual debate about the responsibility of writers. Sartre set the pace by claiming that a writer had to be committed to a cause. But, in 1945, Peyrefitte wrote that a writer had the right not to be committed to some set of principles or beliefs, conjuring up a world in which the writer was treated with indulgence. This angered many, who suggested that the attitude justified those writers who had supported Germany during the years of war.

But Peyrefitte was not interested in pursuing this type of discussion; he was not an intellectual. He was born in Castres, in the Tarn, and his parents were farmers who had become comfortably well-off as they had become successful in trade and business. He used to say that there were only two things that mattered - to have money, and, if one had not been born with a famous name, to make oneself famous.

He received a religious schooling, was expelled from philosophy classes because of bad behaviour, took a literary degree at the University of Toulouse, and attended the Ecole Libre des Sciences Politiques in Paris. He graduated in the diplomatic section and worked in the ministry for foreign affairs from 1931 to 1933. He was then secretary to the French embassy in Athens until 1938.

It has been said that it was in Greece that Peyrefitte gained confirmation of his homosexuality. It was certainly there that he developed his interest in classical history and his preoccupation with romantic scenery. In 1938, he returned to the Quai d'Orsay, to work in the ministry.

His relations with the Vichy government in 1940 are confused, but he continued to work with it and, in 1943, became assistant to Ferdinand de Brinon, the representative of the government to the German occupying authorities. In February 1945, Peyrefitte was dismissed, officially for this collaboration, but perhaps also because of a mysterious scandal. From then, he became a writer, and Les Amitiés particulières, which won the Prix Renaudot, was a remarkable beginning.

Peyrefitte never wrote another book with the same qualities, although he published more than 30. He wrote novels, essays - some of which adopted the form of novels - biographies, dramas and translations. They were all well written and the result of hard work, although Peyrefitte liked to give the impression that he spent his time attending grand receptions in high society.

But they all sought to be successful because they revealed hidden scandals and secrets. They caused great embarrassment to his distant relative Alain Peyrefitte, who was 17 years his junior (Obituary, November 29 1999) and who was just beginning his career as a serious writer and politician.

It would be tedious to list all these publications. Les Ambassades in 1951 (Diplomatic Diversions, 1953) was Peyrefitte's revenge against the diplomatic corps, showing what happens behind the official receptions and meetings. Les Clefs de Saint Pierre, in 1955 (The Keys of Saint Peter, 1957) did the same for the Vatican - which described it as lewdly libellous - and was prosecuted for obscenity in Italy, while Les Fils de la lumière (1961) took freemasonary as its target. Les Juifs (1965) sought to reveal all about certain Jews, especially the Rothschilds and Pierre Mendès France. Les Americains (1968) led to Peyrefitte being sued by Marlene Dietrich - who won.

Perhaps the most talented book was L'Exilé de Capri (1959), which depicted the unhappy drama of a man whose early success in life turned to tragedy. But even here, Peyrefitte's determination to be provocative is apparent. He did what he wanted: he was a champion at outing.

Roger Peyrefitte, writer, born August 17 1907; died November 5 2000

webTitle: Leader: Mr Bush feeds the fires

fields.headline: Mr Bush feeds the fires
fields.standfirst:
He has not come well out of this fiasco

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: As Republican efforts to fix the Florida result continue, the leadership and judgment of America's pretender-president, George W Bush, look less impressive by the day.
fields.body:
As Republican efforts to fix the Florida result continue, the leadership and judgment of America's pretender-president, George W Bush, look less impressive by the day. His aides now say that Dubya was so confident of victory on November 7 that he eased off too soon and coasted to the tape. That is contrasted unfavourably with Al Gore's energetic, all-out dash to the finishing line. Genuinely shocked by the non-result, Mr Bush began his post-election campaign by adopting a studied, nonchalant air. His down-home photo-ops, featuring muddy jeans, cute pet dogs and a languid manner, were intended to convey sang-froid - or Texan cool. But they may have had the opposite effect, suggesting that Mr Bush was not so much above the fray as totally out of his depth. Out of touch, too, as if in surreal parody of Daddy Bush in 1988, the make-believe leader of the free world "appointed" a make-believe secretary of state and a very insecure security adviser.

That impression was reinforced by the sudden emergence from the shadows, as if by murky magic, of James Baker, Bush Snr's old buddy and Mr Fixit. As the Florida follies have unfolded, it has become ever clearer that Mr Baker, and other old hands like vice-president-in-his-dreams Dick Cheney, are calling Republican shots in the Sunshine state. A stronger leader than George W might have vetoed Mr Baker's legal efforts, aided and abetted by ardent Bush-ette Katherine Harris, Florida's secretary of state, to thwart local recounts. A bigger man might have upheld the bigger democratic principle of fairness over his own claims and, for example, supported a state-wide manual recount. That would have boosted his public standing and enhanced his chances of winning (by including Republican-inclined counties). None of this - his complacency, the old gang's ascendancy, bad tactics and a lack of scruple - bodes well.

In an extraordinary week, Mr Gore's conduct has not been above reproach, either. Polls show most Americans back his insistence on a reliable tally in Florida. But as patience begins to run out, it may well be growing public exasperation, as much as recounts and courts, that finally brings this contest to closure.

That would have boosted his public standing and enhanced his chances of winning (by including Republican-inclined counties). None of this - his complacency, the old gang's ascendancy, bad tactics and a lack of scruple - bodes well. In an extraordinary week, Mr Gore's conduct has not been above reproach, either. Polls show most Americans back his insistence on a reliable tally in Florida. But as patience begins to run out, it may well be growing public exasperation, as much as recounts and courts, that finally brings this contest to closure.

webTitle: Literary Review Bad Sex in Fiction prize

fields.headline: Publisher far from sheepish over author's bad sex
fields.trailText: A small London publishing house was ecstatic last night about its star author's double whammy - after the surprise appearance on the Booker Prize short list, Brian O'Doherty has now achieved a place on the shortlist for the Literary Review Bad Sex in Fiction prize.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
A small London publishing house was ecstatic last night about its star author's double whammy. After the surprise appearance on the Booker Prize short list of Irish-American author Brian O'Doherty, his first novel The Deposition of Father McGreevy has now achieved an even more coveted literary laurel - the shortlist for the Literary Review Bad Sex in Fiction prize.

The judges were seduced by the pulsating account of his hero's encounter with a sheep: "When I passed him he turned to look at me, and I saw those fine white lashes long enough to catch flies. Strange that a beast should have such beautiful lashes around eyes with as much expression as two marbles."

Many publishers would pay good money to keep their authors off the Bad Sex list. But Gary Pulsifer, of Arcadia Books, was thrilled.

"It's great news, isn't it?" he said. "I think he'll be absolutely delighted. We've already distributed 12,000 copies in England and Ireland, and this should sell a lot more of them. You know some Kerry councillor was so outraged he has declared a sort of fatwa on him? This should really get them going."

O'Doherty - beaten to the Booker prize by Margaret Attwood - is in distinguished company.

The shortlist includes Sean Thomas, for Kissing Engla, about a lad-mag journalist specialising in travel, lifestyle criticism and sex; Wendy Perriam, for Lying, in which the heroine betrays her devout Roman Catholic husband with an unemployed barman; Candida Clark, for The Constant Eye, a Eurostar thriller described by one excitable critic as "powerfully erotic, frighteningly beautiful"; Edward St Aubyn, A Clue To The Exit, of which the Literary Review's own critic said crossly that "from the point of view of anatomy whatever is going on here is rather hard to determine, however pleasurable it may have been to write; and Wendy Holden, for her excruciatingly titled Bad Heir Day.

The Literary Review editor, Auberon Waugh, commented: "Judging is always highly amusing."

The senior figure on the shortlist was John Updike, nominated at last for his Hamlet prequel, Gertrude and Claudius.

fields.headline: Whitbread book award shortlist: children's
fields.standfirst: Harry Potter put to flight by darker forces
fields.trailText: Heaven Eyes by David Almond (Hodder)
fields.body:
Heaven Eyes by David Almond (Hodder)

"First we enter a children's home, with its cement garden, embittered staff and despairing 'circle time': then Almond takes us on a terrifying but beautiful journey. Escaping through one of the most nightmarish landscapes ever devised by man - the deserted docklands of a great northern city - three runaways meet a strange child and a mad old man." (from a review)

The judges: A beautifully written, thought-provoking story of friendship and hope that grips, with its stunning imagery and lyrical writing.

Arthur: The Seeing Stone by Kevin Crossley-Holland (Orion)

A pageant of the past, crowded with characters - Arthur's jealous older brother; the forthright village girl Gatty; Tanwen the serving girl. Life in a medieval manor, shot through with legends of King Arthur, with a thrilling climax.

The judges: A superbly researched and descriptive tapestry of medieval life with an accessible take on the legends of King Arthur

Troy by Adele Geras (Scholastic)

"The siege of Troy seen from below, from the kitchens and the stables and (a wonderful notion) the Blood Room, where the wounded are tended by the young Xanthe." (from a review).

The judges: Brings the ancient story of Troy alive and takes the reader into the heart of history. Profoundly moving and gripping.

Coram Boy by Jamila Gavin (Egmont)

"A ruthless dealer travels the drovers' roads of Georgian England purporting to carry abandoned infants to London's new hospital. In fact, he buries the babies ... while allowing older infants to starve to death." (from a review)

The judges: An engrossing historical novel with life well beyond the pages of the book and superb narrative control over complex stories.

Guardian choice: Almond. Runner up: Gavin

fields.headline: Whitbread book award shortlist: biography
fields.standfirst: Harry Potter put to flight by darker forces
fields.trailText: Fanny Burney by Claire Harman (Harper Collins)
fields.body:
Fanny Burney by Claire Harman (Harper Collins)

Life of the great diarist, letter-writer and friend of Sheridan, Madame de Stael, Dr Johnson. Focuses on Burney's constant refashioning of the past.

The judges: Hugely enjoyable study, perfectly balanced between historical sympathy and psychological insight.

John Ruskin - The Later Years by Tim Hilton (Yale University Press)

The last volume of a lifelong project for the Guardian's former art critic. The first biography of Ruskin to return to original source material.

The judges: An outstanding biography of perhaps the most influential cultural force of the late 19th century.

Hitler - 1936-1945: Nemesis by Ian Kershaw (Allen Lane Penguin Press)

Third volume of biography showing how Hitler's acolytes "worked towards" his darker aims without explicit guidance.

The judges: Extraordinary scholarship. Chronicles the downfall in unsparing detail, with cool precision.

Bad Blood - A Memoir by Lorna Sage (Fourth Estate)

An academic's upbringing in a Flintshire council house. One review notes that her grandpa, a disgruntled vicar ... "had a scar down his hollow cheek ... which grandma had done with the carving knife".

The judges: A tragi-comic autobiography, unforgettable story with poignancy, and humour and courage.

Guardian choice: Sage Runner up: Kershaw

fields.headline: Teenagers reject abortion
fields.trailText: Family pressures and inadequate sex education stop most pregnant teenagers from even considering the possibility of an abortion, according to a report today from the Joseph Rowntree Foundation.
fields.body:
Family pressures and inadequate sex education stop most pregnant teenagers from even considering the possibility of an abortion, according to a report today from the Joseph Rowntree Foundation.

As the government wrestles with policies to reduce the highest rate of teenage births in western Europe, researchers from York university found a lack of support for young women having to make quick decisions when faced with an unplanned pregnancy.

They interviewed 41 young women in Doncaster, a town with one of the highest teenage pregnancy rates in England. Almost all were shocked to discover they were pregnant. There was no evidence that any deliberately became pregnant to secure economic independence or housing. By the time pregnancy was confirmed, the women had seven to 14 weeks to decide on an abortion.

They were primarily influenced by attitudes and experiences they had before they became pregnant and by the experiences of those around them.

"Anti-abortion views were prevalent and families had not discussed abortion as an option. In contrast, young motherhood was highly visible and had been discussed within families," the report said.

One young mother reported that her boyfriend's parents said an abortion would amount to "murdering their grandchild". Another said she would have been hit and abused if she returned to school after terminating her pregnancy.

The few who chose abortion said a big influence was knowing someone who had made the same decision. For some the result was isolation from their peers and open hostility. "I told a woman I worked with and she called me a murderer," said one.

Latest figures show almost 90,000 teenagers became pregnant in England in 1997, of whom 56,000 gave birth. Almost 7,700 were under 16, of whom 3,700 gave birth.

The government has set a target of halving the rate of teenage conceptions within 10 years.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Women appear more vulnerable to the effects of smoking than men, according to new research.
fields.body:
Smoking risk to women

Women appear more vulnerable to the effects of smoking than men, according to new research.

The more they smoked, the more likely women were to report symptoms such as wheezing, persistent breathlessness, coughing and asthma, the study of 65,700 smokers and non-smokers in the Nord-Trondelag county, Norway, revealed.
James Meikle

Website youth 'world leader'

An 18-year-old who founded a football website and then sold 60% to Disney for £15m has been named one of the 100 "global leaders of tomorrow". Tom Hadfield who is at a sixth form college in Brighton is among 11 Britons under the age of 40 chosen by the World Economic Forum along with the Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy and the public health minister Yvette Cooper.

Ninth man on dome charge

A ninth man charged after the attempted diamond robbery of the De Beers millennium jewels at the Millennium Dome last week was remanded in custody yesterday. Wayne Taylor, 35, a horse dealer from Tonbridge, Kent, appeared at Belmarsh magistrates court in south east London.

Officer accused after inquiry

An unnamed superintendent with Cleveland police faces four charges of alleged neglect of duty as a result of an inquiry into alleged malpractice at Middlesbrough CID. Superintendent Ray Mallon, the pioneer of zero tolerance policing, already faces 14 disciplinary offences.

fields.headline: Whitbread book award shortlist: poetry
fields.standfirst: Harry Potter put to flight by darker forces
fields.trailText: The Asylum Dance by John Burnside (Cape Poetry)
fields.body:
The Asylum Dance by John Burnside (Cape Poetry)

The sanctuary of home versus the lure of escape. A world of myth, beyond which lies a "somewhere in-between" of mists or sudden light.

The judges: A collection with stunning unity of tone, style and purpose ... an epiphany on every page.

Conjure by Michael Donaghy (Picador)

Elegies and disappearing acts, love songs and tortuous journeys, written with elegance and philosophical wit.

The judges: Donaghy draws you in with the skill of a conjuror to reveal something more profound and dangerous.

Granny Scarecrow by Anne Stevenson (Bloodaxe Books)

The title poem starts as a tale about two farm girls putting their granny's dress on a scarecrow, then becomes more of an elegy for the passing of a way of life.

The judges: Full of wisdom and music, Stevenson has a conversational tone of voice which conceals formidable technical gifts and a deep engagement with the complexities of modern life.

Collected Poems by R F Langley (Carcanet)

A first collection of long and short poems, many of which are often inspired by the landscapes of Suffolk.

The judges Langley is one of poetry's best kept secrets. This is a wonderfully inventive collection, bursting with linguistic exuberance.

Floods by Maurice Riordan (Faber & Faber)

The theme is instability and flux, with more personal memories rooted in rural Ireland and poems of loss that are nuanced with hope.

The judges: With its enormous range of references and obsession with love, cosmology and hunting, Riordan's omnivorous curiosity in these poems is haunting.

Guardian choice: Riordan Runner-up: Burnside

fields.headline: Muslims want Pooh, not Piglet
fields.trailText: The usually inseparable literary duo of Winnie the Pooh and Piglet may spend this Christmas apart in a number of children's stores, to respect the sensitivities of devout Muslim parents.
fields.body:
The usually inseparable literary duo of Winnie the Pooh and Piglet may spend this Christmas apart in a number of children's stores, to respect the sensitivities of devout Muslim parents.

Mothercare outlets in West Yorkshire have reported a number of polite requests for Pooh products - which range from games to bathmats - to be sold without the bear's small friend to avoid problems over pigs' unclean status in Islam.

The chain is now investigating the legal niceties of licensing agreements, which almost invariably cover products showing Pooh trekking about with Piglet in tow. Although occasionally twinned with Eeyore the donkey or Owl, A A Milne's bear spends most of his time rescuing the pig from fixes.

"It could be that we are unable to divorce Winnie the Pooh from Piglet," said a Mothercare spokeswoman, whose colleagues in West Yorkshire have been keen to find a solution. Staff at one branch said that mothers had been coming back, slightly embarrassed, and asking if Piglet-free products were available, but "it had taken a bit of time for the penny to drop."

Nissar Ahmed from the Leeds Muslim community said that most pictures in a Muslim house would have a religious significance. He said: "I would think that no Muslim would want pictures of pigs, even the harmless character Piglet."

fields.headline: Meningitis child died after misdiagnosis
fields.trailText: The parents of a toddler who died from meningitis spoke yesterday of their "vision of hell" in a hospital's overstretched accident and emergency department which failed to diagnose his condition.
fields.body:
The parents of a toddler who died from meningitis spoke yesterday of their "vision of hell" in a hospital's overstretched accident and emergency department which failed to diagnose his condition.

Jacob Fogg, 22 months, died on the same day that doctors at the Whittington hospital in Highgate, north London, said tests did not indicate a life-threatening condition.

Edward Fogg, his father, said the family spent seven hours prior to the misdiagnosis on a Sunday night last month in an area with dirty floors, exhausted doctors and rude nurses. Several of his allegations are disputed by the hospital.

The parents said they took their son to the A&E department on the evening of October 15 after he became feverish and drowsy at their home in Crouch End, north London. His condition was worsening and the couple were concerned he could have meningitis.

They said the A&E area was dirty, with drunks and drug addicts roaming around and a long queue to be assessed by a nurse. The family said they were told to wait in a room which had blood on the floor and urine samples in the sink while they waited for a doctor.

Mr Fogg, 29, a fashion model, told the Evening Standard: "We were disgusted. The place was unhygienic and we didn't want Jacob to come into contact with anything."

Emma, his partner of five years, said: "It was like being in a self-service hospital. We had to instigate everything." One nurse allegedly told them: "If you don't like it, go to another hospital."

A paediatrician saw their son three hours after they arrived. The doctor was "blinking to stay awake and had big red tiredness blotches under his eyes," Mr Fogg said.

At 3am doctors said a blood test had showed no evidence of meningitis and that the boy was exhibiting symptoms of flu. The parents took Jacob home, but later that morning he had large numbers of spots and seemed weaker.

Doctors then diagnosed meningitis and Jacob was taken to Great Ormond Street hospital. He died at 4pm.

Mr Fogg said: "If the hospital had reacted differently our precious, beautiful little boy would in all probability still be with us today."

In a statement the Whittington hospital said: "The symptoms of meningococcal disease are notoriously non-specific in the early stages of the illness. Tests were carried out on Jacob and did not indicate that he had a life-threatening infection."

Doctors wanted to keep Jacob in overnight but his parents decided to take him home, the hospital said.

It added that cleaning staff were managed by the nurses, which "enabled the hospital to greatly improve the cleanliness of the [A&E] department".

fields.headline: Whitbread book award shortlist: novel
fields.standfirst: Harry Potter put to flight by darker forces
fields.trailText: Fred & Edie by Jill Dawson (Sceptre)
fields.body:
Fred & Edie by Jill Dawson (Sceptre)

Based on the hanging of Edith Thompson and her lover Fred Bywaters in 1923 for allegedly murdering her husband.

The judges: A woman's novel in the best sense of the word ... provocative, exquisitely written.

What Are You Like? by Anne Enright (Cape)

About the splitting and dislocation of twins, threading their separated, dislocated lives in Dublin and New York.

The judges: An original, wholly convincing new voice ... artfully reworks the literary trope of twins separated by circumstance to create an electrifying narrative, searing with emotional intensity from beginning to end.

When We Were Orphans by Kazuo Ishiguro (Faber & Faber)

Christopher Banks, brought to England as an orphan, now a celebrated detective but still a misfit, seeks his lost parents in Old Shanghai.

The judges: A wonderfully compelling tale of the construction - and deconstruction - of personal identity, Ishiguro shanghais the classic detective story, turning it on its head.

English Passengers by Matthew Kneale (Hamish Hamilton)

A ship of zealots and greedy fools sails to Tasmania in 1857, led by an anti-Darwinian vicar eager to prove it is the biblical paradise.

The judges: A technical marvel. Matthew Kneale orchestrates an astonishing cast of conflicting voices without ever losing the momentum of a wonderful adventure story.

How the Dead Live by Will Self (Bloomsbury)

"A full-length account of necropolitan London. In the satiric geography of Will Self (right), the young dead - the 'morbidly mobile' - go to find work in the States or the Gulf, but the older dead simply live on either north of the river in Dulston or south of the river in Dulburb". (a review)

The judges: A dark, terrifying, wildly funny book written with extraordinary verve and daring. Unapologetically individualistic as it laughs in the face of death.

Guardian choice: Enright. Runner up: Ishiguro

webTitle: New doubts on cause of Mull of Kintyre helicopter crash

fields.headline: New doubts on cause of Mull of Kintyre helicopter crash
fields.trailText: Fresh doubts have emerged over the hotly disputed decision by senior RAF officers to blame the pilots for the crash of a Chinook helicopter into the Mull of Kintyre in 1994, killing all 29 people on board.
fields.body:
Fresh doubts have emerged over the hotly disputed decision by senior RAF officers to blame the pilots for the crash of a Chinook helicopter into the Mull of Kintyre in 1994, killing all 29 people on board.

New evidence shows the Ministry of Defence withheld potentially crucial information about computer software problems from Air Chief Marshal Sir William Wratten and Air Marshal Sir John Day who overruled the verdict of an RAF board of inquiry.

The board found there was insufficient evidence to blame the pilots.

The new evidence, given in parliamentary answers to Frank Field, Labour MP for Birkenhead, will be presented today to Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, by an all-party group, led by Lord Chalfont, a former Labour defence minister campaigning to get the verdict quashed.

Twenty-five MI5, army, and RUC intelligence officers from Northern Ireland and the four crew died when the Chinook crashed into the Mull of Kintyre in June 1994. The two air marshals found the pilots, Jonathan Tapper and Rick Cook, guilty of gross negligence.

The MoD has now admitted that at the time of the inquiry, Sir William Wratten "did not recall" an incident five years earlier when an RAF Chinook was nearly destroyed by a software problem during tests in the US.

It also admitted that Sir William was not aware of the subsequent legal dispute between the MoD and Textron Lycoming, makers of the Fadec software.

It has told Mr Field that while Sir John Day was aware of the incident he was "not aware of the detail".

Papers leaked to Computer Weekly magazine show that in a legal action in the US, the MoD itself said the Fadec software was "unsafe".

An RAF officer told the board of inquiry that problems with the Chinook's software had resulted in uncontrolled engine acceleration and cutouts and misleading instrument readings in the cockpit.

The day before the crash on the Mull of Kintyre, the RAF stopped all test flying of its Chinooks because of concerns about the Fadec software.

Under RAF rules in place at the time of the accident, crew could be blamed only when there was "absolutely no doubt whatsoever" that they were at fault.

Lord Chalfont said yesterday that he would press Mr Hoon to exercise his prerogative and overturn the verdict of the two air marshals.

Failing that, the MoD should reopen the inquiry, he said.

Lord Chalfont has tabled a motion to set up a House of Lords committee to investigate the affair.
