webTitle: Hope of freedom after 27 years in jail

fields.headline: Hope of freedom after 27 years in jail
fields.standfirst: Miscarriage of justice suspected in 'Bakewell Tart Murder' as doubts raised over police who charged man with learning difficulties
fields.trailText: Miscarriage of justice suspected in 'Bakewell Tart Murder' as doubts raised over police who charged man with learning difficulties
fields.body:
Stephen Downing was 17 when he was convicted of murdering Wendy Sewell, a secretary, in a village cemetery. He said he was innocent when he was first jailed and has been saying it ever since.

Now, after 27 years in prison his claims of an appalling miscarriage of justice are finally being heard. His case - which became known as the Bakewell Tart Murder - has been referred to the court of appeal after an inquiry by the criminal cases review commission.

There are strong grounds for believing Downing, 44, will be freed soon, and that the conviction will be quashed. The CCRC decision trained a spotlight not only on the inconsistencies and alleged failings of the original murder investigation, but also on Bakewell, the small Peak District town where Downing grew up and where his parents, Ray and Juanita, still live.

A campaign launched by the local newspaper, the Matlock Mercury, uncovered evidence that many townspeople knew that Downing was not the murderer, but had been too scared to say so. Don Hale, the paper's editor, claims that as he dug for further information, someone tried to kill him.

Yesterday, Mr Hale said he was "thrilled" the court of appeal had been asked to rule on the safety of the conviction.

Ray Downing said: "We have lived with this pressure for almost 30 years. We knew that [Stephen] hadn't done it. He was such a gentle boy. So much of his life has been wasted, but I am so proud of him for telling the truth and sticking to it. I stand by him."

Ms Sewell died in Chesterfield royal hospital from head injuries two days after she was attacked in Bakewell cemetery during September 1973.

Downing, a gardener, found her half-naked body on the cemetery path during a short lunchbreak. He raised the alarm, showed the police where the body was, and pointed out the murder weapon, a pickaxe handle, which had been discarded in the grass. Agitated and nervous, Downing was taken to Bakewell police station for questioning.

He did not get the chance to speak to a solicitor, a care worker, or his parents.

Nine hours later, he signed a confession - which was written out for him in pencil by a police officer - claiming he had hit Ms Sewell over the head with the pickaxe handle and sexually assaulted her.

He retracted his statement a few days later, claiming he was cold, tired and in pain from a spinal injury. Nevertheless, the statement was the main prosecution evidence during a three day trial at Nottingham crown court.

The judge, Mr Justice Nield, made constant references to the statement during the trial, but not to Downing's learning difficulties. The jury took just an hour to reach a unanimous guilty verdict. The judge recommended a tariff of 17 years.

If Downing had pleaded guilty to manslaughter - which was offered before trial - he would have been released within 10 years. If he had admitted murder after conviction, he would have been released on parole 10 years ago. But he has always refused to accept guilt, and has therefore been classified by the Home Office as an IDOM (In denial of murder) which means he cannot be freed.

The CCRC's decision to refer the case is understood to have been based on disquiet with the way the police interrogated Downing. There is other evidence, though, to suggest the conviction was unsafe. When Mr Hale began to investigate the case six years ago, he uncovered inconsistencies that were not acknowledged during the trial.

In his retracted confession, Downing said he hit Ms Sewell twice. Yet the pathologist's report indicated she had been battered seven or eight times. The confession also spoke of a sexual assault, but there was no forensic evidence to suggest one had taken place.

Mr Hale also received anonymous letters which cast doubt on the prosecution story that Ms Sewell was in the cemetery on her own before she was attacked. One writer said she heard a couple having an argument, then saw a man running away from the scene moments before Downing walked through the cemetery gates and discovered the body.

Mr Hale also uncovered evidence showing Ms Sewell had had a string of affairs with married men in the village. Friends of Ms Sewell suspected she had gone to the cemetery to meet someone, almost certainly a lover. A schoolgirl saw Ms Sewell embracing a man in the cemetery, but she did not contact the police until months after Downing was convicted. Mr Hale gathered 70 new witness statements, and several named the same man as the likely killer.

Mr Hale's campaign, however, was not welcomed by everyone in the village. Anonymous callers told him to stop investigating the case and he was almost knocked over by the driver of a sports car in an attempted hit and run.

Ray Downing, a taxi driver, believes Ms Sewell's killer still lives in the village and has urged Derbyshire police to reopen the investigation. The force has said it will only do so if ordered by the court.

"Stephen is bitter, but he tries not to show it. He has educated himself since he has been in prison and passed every exam he has taken, but what can he do after all this time? He can hardly start again because all those years have been lost. Mr Hale has the name of someone who may or may not have committed this crime, and I think the police have a duty to check.

"I can't understand why the police can't accept that a mistake might have been made. They owe it to Stephen to find out. I don't think they would have ever looked at this case again if we hadn't campaigned."

Tim Reeves, Downing's lawyer, said last night his client, who is at Littlehey prison in Cambridgeshire, was "very pleased" with the CCRC decision. Mr Hale added: "The result is brilliant and I just hope Stephen can be released as soon as possible."

If Downing is released, it is possible he could receive more than £1m in compensation.

webTitle: Captive big cat died from feline form of BSE

fields.headline: Captive big cat died from feline form of BSE
fields.trailText: A lion from a west country zoo was suffering from the feline version of mad cow disease when it was put down this year.
fields.body:
A lion from a west country zoo was suffering from the feline version of mad cow disease when it was put down this year.

Staff at Newquay zoo in Cornwall disclosed yesterday how Major, a 12-year-old male, was put to sleep in August after failing to recover from injuries sustained in a fight with another lion several years ago. But results of a post mortem showed he was suffering from feline spongiform encephalopathy (FSE), the cat equivalent of BSE.

Officials at the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food in London were told of the case after samples from its brain were tested.

But a Maff spokeswoman said the case was not felt to be a concern. "These animals don't go into the food chain. You are more at risk of getting mauled by a lion than getting BSE from one."

The zoo's managing director, Mike Thomas, said staff had had no idea that the animal had the disease. "I expect it would have had to come from Major eating part of a whole carcass as it is the brain and spinal cord which carry the disease."

Although cases of FSE in big cats in Britain are not unprecedented, Major is only the third lion confirmed to have suffered the disease. Official figures show a variety of exotic species have succumbed to BSE-type illnesses since the first recorded death of a zoo animal from such a disease in June 1986.

Most of the deaths have occurred among the species, with tigers, ocelot, puma and cheetah all falling victim. Isolated cases have also been reported among ruminants.

Major arrived at Newquay after fights with an older male at the safari park. When conventional treatment failed to work staff called in a local faith healer to try to cure the spinal problems Major had been left with as a result of the fighting. But the lion's health continued to deteriorate and he was put to sleep three months ago.

Keith Harris, head warden at Longleat, which boasts 25 lions, said the park had not had any problems with FSE.

webTitle: Fertility clinic sued for unwanted third baby

fields.headline: Fertility clinic sued for unwanted third baby
fields.standfirst: Couple may get £100,000 after 'shock' of having triplets
fields.trailText: Couple may get £100,000 after 'shock' of having triplets.
fields.body:
A couple who underwent fertility treatment will go to the high court today in an unprecedented compensation claim against a clinic for giving them three babies instead of two.

Peter and Patricia Thompson, who say they felt "shocked" to learn they were expecting triplets, are claiming damages for breach of contract by the Sheffield fertility centre.

The three day hearing at Sheffield, starting today, will decide whether the clinic is legally liable to compensate Mr and Mrs Thompson for the cost of bringing up the third baby. If the couple succeed, a later hearing will determine the damages, which could be about £100,000 to cover the cost of raising a child from birth to adulthood.

The notes of the couple's consultation with the clinic record that they wanted only two embryos inserted in Mrs Thompson's uterus. But the clinic claims that in a later conversation, not recorded in writing, Mrs Thompson was advised to have three to give her a better chance of a baby, and that she agreed.

The Thompsons, from Thrybergh, Yorkshire, say they love their girl and two boys. They had refused to have one foetus aborted when they learned there would be three, but they argue that the clinic breached the agreement with them not to put inmore than two embryos. They believe they should be compensated for the extra expense of a third child.

The couple are represented by Irwin Mitchell, the law firm which has just won compensation from the government for the victims of vCJD and their families.

The Thompsons are suing mainly for breach of contract rather than medical negligence - a course open to them because they paid for private treatment at the clinic, a registered charity. Had they had free treatment on the NHS, they would be barred from claiming the cost of bringing up a healthy child because of a House of Lords ruling last year. The law lords left open the question of whether compensation could be claimed where the birth resulted from a breach of a contract between a clinic and parents who paid for its services.

Mrs Thompson, 34, said she and her husband, 57, had been trying to conceive a child for five or six years without success when they decided to try in vitro fertilisation, or IVF.

"The clinic told us, if you go for three it's higher risk and you might not carry to full term so it's better to go for two. We opted for two hoping to conceive one and then to have another later."

Her husband was "very, very shocked" to learn that she was expecting three babies. "He went very white when they told him we'd got triplets."

The babies were born in March 1997. Mrs Thompson said: "Fortunately they all fed together. We had to take 12 bottles to bed just to get us through the night."

Twelve weeks after their birth Mr Thompson, a former engineer, had a heart attack and then a bypass operation. The couple now have four children under four because Mrs Thompson unexpectedly fell pregnant with a daughter, who has just turned two.

She said looking after the children left her no time even to read a newspaper. But she added: "It could have been a lot worse. They could have been poorly but they're not."

Elizabeth Lenton, director of the Sheffield fertility centre, said: "The Thompsons stated their wishes, which were that they only wanted two embryos at the consultation at the beginning." But she said that Mrs Thompson was later advised to have three embryos inserted in her womb and that she had agreed, although this was not recorded in writing. "I understand from my staff that they were quite comfortable that Mrs Thompson understood that they proposed to replace three embryos and that she agreed to that."

Mrs Thompson disputes this version of events and insists she only learned after the event that three embryos had been inserted. "I felt numb, but the shock didn't sink in until they said you've conceived triplets. They did suggest I consider having one terminated but I said no. When it's in there, it's a baby."

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Lord Archer was yesterday committed to stand trial at the Old Bailey when he appeared at Bow Street magistrates court, central London, accused of asking a friend to lie for him during a libel case against the Daily Star in 1987.
fields.body:
Old Bailey stage for Archer

Lord Archer was yesterday committed to stand trial at the Old Bailey when he appeared at Bow Street magistrates court, central London, accused of asking a friend to lie for him during a libel case against the Daily Star in 1987.

Channel 5 axes news anchor

Andrea Catherwood, who replaced Kirsty Young as the main anchor of Channel 5's news bulletins, has been axed after a year. She will return to ITV's news team

Old Beatles outsell Oasis

The Beatles album, 1, a set of songs released 30 years ago, is outselling the live album Familiar to Millions by their biggest imitators, Oasis, by four to one. It sold more than 58,000 copies on its first day

Railtrack halts Xmas parties

Railtrack has cancelled all official Christmas parties because it was in "corporate mourning" in the wake of the Hatfield disaster. An internal newsletter warned that staff could not be seen to be "whooping it up" when victims and families had so little to look forward to.

Rugby player's father dies

Peter Cohen, 58, the father of England international rugby player Ben, has died in Northampton general hospital after suffering serious head injuries during a nightclub attack last month, police said yesterday. Four men from Northampton were arrested in relation to the incident.

Doctor's errors led to outbreak

A 70-year-old doctor yesterday admitted causing an outbreak of acute hepatitis B after failing to dispose of needles and clinical waste at his alternative medical centre. Madhusudan Shivadikar denied that the mistakes amounted to serious professional misconduct when he appeared before the General Medical Council yesterday. The hearing continues today.

Worker died from wasp sting

A Coventry council worker died after an allergic reaction to a sting after disturbing a nest of about 30 wasps while clearing rubbish from a garden, an inquest heard yesterday. A jury returned a verdict of accidental death on John Roche, 47.

webTitle: Judges' lodgings costing taxpayers £4.7m a year

fields.headline: Judges' lodgings costing taxpayers £4.7m a year
fields.trailText: The taxpayer is forking out up to £2,030 a night so that high court judges hearing cases away from home will have somewhere congenial to hang up their wigs.
fields.body:
The taxpayer is forking out up to £2,030 a night so that high court judges hearing cases away from home will have somewhere congenial to hang up their wigs.

The 32 historic lodgings for judges in England and Wales cost more than £4.785m in 1999-00.

The average cost of their lordships' bed and board came to £901 a night. The most expensive hit £2,030 - the Ritz charges £1,750 plus VAT for its priciest suite of two bedrooms with study, dining room and kitchenette.

The figures, released in a parliamentary answer, will put pressure on the lord chancellor, who has been monitoring the cost since 1997, to close the most expensive.

Much of the cost arises because some properties are occupied for only a few weeks a year but have to be maintained year round. Lord Irvine is expecting a report from officials with cost-cutting recommendations early next year.

In the meantime he has pledged to "look hard" at lodgings which fail to bring costs below £2,500 a week. So far only two meet the benchmark.

The lodgings range from historic listed houses, some in extensive grounds, to a penthouse flat in Mold, in Wales, overlooking the Clywd hills. About two thirds are owned by the lord chancellor's department; the rest are rented, many from local authorities.

Among the most expensive is Carr Manor in Leeds, which cost £402,000 to maintain in 1998. The penthouse flat was occupied for only five weeks, costing £1,800 a night. Telscombe Manor, in Lewes, costs around £6,000 a week.

Andrew Dismore, Labour MP for Hendon, who asked the parliamentary question, said: "It's an awful lot of money. I can't see why judges can't make do with a five star luxury hotel like everybody else."

The lord chancellor's department claims the judges need somewhere to keep their case papers private. But circuit judges, the next tier down, have to make do with modest hotel rooms when they sit at courts away from home.

The high court judges are waited on by butlers, cooks and housekeepers, and are expected to entertain local dignitaries. The cost includes cars to take them to court.

Judges sitting in courts near London, at St Albans and Reading, are expected to stay in lodgings even though they could easily commute home each night. The house in Reading, used by judges for 23 weeks a year, cost £1,062 a night last year. The 100-year-old mock Tudor house in St Albans, cost £1,074 a night for the 21 nights it was used.

Many judges heartily dislike the circuit system, which requires them to spend half their time away from home. QCs say the requirement to go out on circuit is a big deterrent to joining the high court bench. In 1995 another internal review into the lodgings recommended stringent cost controls. The cost of the lodgings then was £3.9m a year - nearly £1m less than last year's bill.

Savoy or Blackpool?

For £901 a night, a high court judge could stay...

One night at the Savoy in the river bedroom suite, separate living room with views over the Thames. £895 a night

Two nights at the Ritz in London, in a junior suite, twice the size of standard double room. £450 a night

Six nights at the Swallow, Bristol, in standard double, includes use of leisure club. £129 a night

10 nights at the Post House, Birmingham, in standard double. £89 a night

18 nights at the Express Holiday Inn, Manchester, in a standard double room. £49 a night

23 nights at the Fairway Hotel, Blackpool, in standard double, breakfast included. £38 a night

webTitle: Palestinian tells Lockerbie trial he quit terrorism

fields.headline: Palestinian tells Lockerbie trial he quit terrorism
fields.standfirst: Special report: Libya and the Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: A Palestinian terrorist alleged to have been involved in the Lockerbie bombing yesterday insisted he had ended all paramilitary activity years before the 1988 atrocity.
fields.body:
A Palestinian terrorist alleged to have been involved in the Lockerbie bombing yesterday insisted he had ended all paramilitary activity years before the 1988 atrocity.

Defence counsel for the two Libyans accused of the bombing, Abdelbaset Al Megrahi and Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah, claim Abu Talb and other Palestinian terrorists were responsible for the destruction of Pan Am flight 103.

But although Talb admitted being a member of a terrorist group, he said he had given up his fight to free Palestine in 1982. However, he was jailed for life in 1989 for the bombing of a Danish synagogue in 1983.

Yesterday he told the Scottish court in the Netherlands he was not responsible for the attack. "I was convicted although I was not there and did not admit the crime. I ended my work and all activities relating to Palestine at the end of 1982," he said.

The Libyan accused have lodged a special defence of incrimination. They blame Talb, a member of the Palestinian Popular Struggle Front, and members of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command for the biggest act of mass murder in UK history.

Questioned about his long activity in terrorist organisations, Egyptian-born Talb admitted he had used many aliases, one of which translates in English as "He who takes revenge". He said this had no significance. "It's just a name."

Talb said he sought asylum in Sweden in 1983, where he survived on sickness benefit and income from jobs in a snack bar and video rental shop.

In 1988, however, he travelled to Cyprus to recover from a stabbing inflicted in a bar owned by a member of the PFLP-GC. Meanwhile, his brother-in-law visited another PFLP-GC member in Germany.

When Talb returned to Sweden he contacted this brother-in-law immediately. Within two days he had met up with three men who had links with the PFLP-GC. "People might think there is a collection of circumstances here that requires some explanation," said William Taylor QC, counsel for Megrahi.

There was an ill-tempered exchange between Talb and Richard Keen QC, counsel for Fhimah. Talb denied admitting to investigators a year after the bombing that he "retrieved and passed to another person a bomb that had been hidden in a building in West Germany, used by members of the PFLP-GC".

He also denied spitting in the face of an American investigator. "Mr Talb, you are not only a murderer, you are a liar, is that not correct?" said Mr Keen.

The defence lawyer demanded to know whether Talb had undergone training in the use of surface to air missiles in the former Soviet Union, a question he had earlier refused to answer. He again refused and the court was adjourned for legal argument.

Mr Keen said it was imperative he was forced to answer. "As will become apparent, he took part in a series of terrorist outrages in 1985 and 1986 and arranged for friends to undergo training for such atrocities. He was involved in a series of moves in 1988 which cast considerable light on what was going in regard to the bombing of Pan Am 103," said Mr Keen.

The trial was adjourned until today to allow the judges to consider whether to compel Talb to answer defence questions.

webTitle: Whitbread book award shortlist: first novel

fields.headline: Whitbread book award shorlist: first novel
fields.standfirst: Harry Potter put to flight by dark forces
fields.trailText: Under the Skin, by Michel Faber (Canongate Books)
fields.body:
Under the Skin, by Michel Faber (Canongate Books)

A woman motorist's quest for the perfect male hitch-hiker - single, well-muscled, good bone structure and no dependents. But nothing is quite what it seems.

The judges: A parable by a writer with a breathtaking gift for language, pace and subtlety. A disturbing and challenging book.

Danny Boy by Jo-Ann Goodwin (Bantam Press)

Danny, Doncaster's streetwise gang leader, is suspected of murdering local grass Teapot. With his mates Deka and Chica Latino, he heads for London.

The judges: Subverts the gritty, post-Trainspotting genre with genuine humanity and an unexpected, magical sub-plot.

Born Free by Laura Hird (Canongate Books)

An ordinary Edinburgh family, Jake, Joni, Angie and Vic, battle to overcome teenage and midlife crises, sibling rivalry and marital problems.

The judges: A heartbreaking and hilarious snapshot of a doomed, self-destructive Edinburgh family. The novel's brutality is eclipsed by its humour and sensitivity.

White Teeth by Zadie Smith (Hamish Hamilton)

On different sides of the unforgotten colonial fence, generations of Joneses, Iqbals and Chalfens live in a London borough where extremism is the order of the day.

The judges: An extraordinarily confident debut, exploding with energy, it is a landmark novel for multicultural Britain.

Guardian choice: Smith. Runner up: Faber

webTitle: The night George Harrison thought he was dying

fields.headline: The night George Harrison thought he was dying
fields.standfirst: Ex-Beatle shouted 'Hare Krishna' to distract psychotic intruder from trying to murder him and his wife, court is told
fields.trailText: Former Beatle George Harrison thought he had been fatally wounded by a psychotic intruder who believed he was on a mission from God to kill the pop star, an Oxford court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
Former Beatle George Harrison thought he had been fatally wounded by a psychotic intruder who believed he was on a mission from God to kill the pop star, an Oxford court heard yesterday.

The jury was told how Harrison and his wife Olivia fought with Michael Abrams who was armed with a knife and part of a stone sword broken from a statue of St George and the Dragon at the couple's Oxfordshire mansion.

In a statement read to the court, Harrison described tasting blood in his mouth as he lay on his back upstairs in his home, and hearing his lung deflate when Abrams plunged the knife into his chest. "There was a time during this violent struggle that I truly believed I was dying," he said.

He said he chanted "Hare Krishna, Hare Krishna" at the man, in a vain effort to distract him.

Oxford crown court heard that three psychiatrists who have examined Abrams concluded that he intended to kill Harri son because he believed the star had possessed him. But they also decided that he did not realise he was doing wrong because of these "delusional" beliefs.

There was no dispute, the prosecution said, that Abrams, who is from Liverpool, carried out the attack on December 30 last year. But it was up to the jury to decide if his plea that he was not guilty of attempting to kill Harrison and his wife "by reason of insanity" should be accepted. According to the prosecution, the defendant believed God had sent him on the murder mission.

Abrams, 34, who wore a pinstriped suit in court, showed no emotion as a vivid statement which Harrison gave to police after the attack was read out in court.

Harrison, 57, said that he had locked up and joined his wife in bed at around 2.10am. He had spent the previous evening visiting his brother and had watched a film at his mansion at Henley-on-Thames, which is surrounded by a high security fence.

At about 3.20am Olivia Harrison awakened her husband to say she had heard smashing glass. Her first thought was that a chandelier had fallen but she soon realised that someone must be in the house. Harrison said in his police statement that he put a jacket over his pyjamas and slipped on a pair of boots.

While Mrs Harrison phoned staff and the police he went down to the kitchen and found a window broken. Lying nearby was a stone wing which Harrison recognised from the statute of St George.

He smelled cigarette smoke and shouted to his wife that someone was in the house. He went back upstairs but then came back out on to a gallery that overlooks the ground floor. Glancing down, he saw an intruder in the main hall.

Harrison said: "He stopped in the centre of the room and looked towards me. He started shouting and screaming." The man was yelling: "You get down here." Harrison asked who he was. The man replied: "You know, get down here."

Harrison spotted the knife and the stone sword; a "personal memory" of another incident - which he did not specify - flashed through his mind. He said: "I made the decision to shout back at him to distract him. I looked down and shouted Hare Krishna, Hare Krishna."

The tactic did not work and the intruder advanced up the stairs. Knowing that his wife and mother-in-law were in the house Harrison decided to fight back. Armed only with the "element of surprise" he lunged at Abrams.

"My first instinct was to grab for the knife," Harrison said.

"We fell to the floor," he continued. "I was fending off blows with my hands. He was on top of me and stabbing down at my upper body."

Mrs Harrison came out and began hitting Abrams with a small brass poker. The intruder chased her and grabbed her by the throat.

Harrison said he staggered after his wife and Abrams, and at one point the three of them fell into a "meditation area" with cushions scattered on the floor.

Harrison said: "I felt exhausted and could feel the strength draining from me. I vividly remember a deliberate thrust to my chest. I could hear my lung exhaling and had blood in my mouth. I believed I had been fatally stabbed." The wound, one of five, caused the lung to collapse and left Harrison with breathing difficulties. His wife suffered head cuts and bruises.

Giving evidence from the witness box Mrs Harrison, 54, said: "There was blood on the walls and on the carpet. There was a moment when I realised we were going to be murdered - I realised that this man was succeeding."

Watched by the couple's son Dhani, 22, Mrs Harrison told how she grabbed a heavy table lamp and began swinging it at Abrams, who gripped the cord of the lamp and began pulling it towards him. Mrs Harrison threw the lamp at him and ran downstairs to find the police had arrived.

A police officer said that as Abrams was taken away he said: "You should have heard the spooky things he was saying, the bastard."

Prosecuting, Simon Mayo said the case was unusual. There was no dispute about what had happened but the trial was focusing on the defendant's mental condition. The trial continues.

Attacker believed he was on God's mission

Michael Abrams was described by Olivia Harrison as being "crazed and frenzied" on the night of the attack, writes Steven Morris . His hair was long, "straw-like" and unkempt, and he wore a black leather jacket. She was struck by his eyes which were "wild and staring". Throughout the attack he did not say a word - which she described as "odd".

After Abrams was arrested a police doctor examined him and concluded immediately that he was likely to be suffering from a psychotic condition and could be a paranoid schizophrenic.

The court was told that Abrams believed he was being possessed by George Harrison and had been sent on a mission by God to kill him.

Three psychiatrists were unanimous in their conclusion that he had a "complex delusional system".

He had travelled from his home in Liverpool on occasions prior to the attack and had asked local people about Harrison. On the night of the assault he was found with a cord some 100cm (40in) long on him.

Simon Mayo, prosecuting, said there was no dispute about Abrams' mental state but English law demanded that a jury makes findings on "issues of in sanity". He said that the jury may be directed to find not guilty verdicts "by reason of insanity".

Abrams, the court was told, has since expressed "considerable remorse" at his actions. He realised now how terrified the Harrisons must have been and had told doctors that he wanted to apologise to them.

In the dock Abrams looked very different to the figure who had confronted the pop star and his wife on that night.

His blond hair was cut short and he wore a smart black pinstripe suit, white shirt, pink tie and round spectacles.

fields.headline: Britain's divorce capital
fields.trailText: Skelmersdale emerged yesterday as the divorce capital of Britain after a study by market researchers who logged the marital status of more than 200,000 people replying to consumer surveys.
fields.body:
Skelmersdale emerged yesterday as the divorce capital of Britain after a study by market researchers who logged the marital status of more than 200,000 people replying to consumer surveys.

The Lancashire town has a per head rate of divorcees and separated singletons five times greater than that in Biggleswade, Bedfordshire, which was found to be the top town for marital stability.

According to the report by Claritas, a consumer information company, 32.4% of adults in Skelmersdale are divorced or separated, compared with 6% in Biggleswade.

Other towns with high concentrations of divorcees are Hove, East Sussex, with 29.1%, Barking, Essex, with 26.2%, Southsea, Hampshire with 25.9% and Bransholme, East Yorkshire with 25.9%.

Areas with low concentrations include Altrincham, Lancashire, with 6.3%, Beverley, East Yorkshire, with 6.5% and Kingswinford, West Midlands, with 8.5%.

A spokeswoman acknowledged that the figures showed where divorcees and separated people have ended up living, not where they were when their relationships broke up.

But Bernard Briars, mayor of Biggleswade, said: "It is fantastic news. I'm not absolutely sure why the divorce rate is so low here, but we're a fast growing town with a particularly low level of unemployment. Factors like that can have a big impact on family stability."

webTitle: Fingerprint trail pinpoints killer after six years

fields.headline: Fingerprint trail pinpoints killer after six years
fields.trailText: Dogged police attempts to match a fingerprint fragment eventually trapped a shoe fetishist who was jailed for life yesterday for the rape and murder of a woman picked at random off the street.
fields.body:
Dogged police attempts to match a fingerprint fragment eventually trapped a shoe fetishist who was jailed for life yesterday for the rape and murder of a woman picked at random off the street.

Christopher Farrow, a father of three, was arrested last year six years after the killing of Wendy Speakes, a 51-year-old divorcee whom he subjected to a prolonged sexual attack before stabbing her in the face and neck and killing her.

After the trial, in which the 39-year-old printer admitted the murder, rape and buggery of Mrs Speakes, police said they would question him about other serious offences.

Police believe Farrow would have become a serial rapist or killer if he had not been caught.

Paul Johnston, a detective chief superintendent, said: "Our investigations do not stop here. Even though Farrow has been sentenced to life imprisonment, it is vital that we identify any other crimes he may have been involved in. It is possible there are other serious crimes, probably committed before Wendy's murder."

A charge of trying to break into another woman's house in Huddersfield was left on file.

Leeds crown court also heard that Farrow, who forced his victim to wear an old pair of shoes and tied her up with black stockings, had stalked a 24-year-old woman for days before the killing on March 15 1994. Angry when she refused to answer her door, he then saw Mrs Speakes get off a bus and followed her home instead.

Farrow, of Cookridge, Leeds, was caught after his fingerprints were taken following a drink-driving offence in June 1996 and compared with part of a print left on the handle of Mrs Speakes's front door. Apparent similarities led the police to attempt a match, which they did inconclusively three times using a computer system based in the US. However, a final, fourth attempt left little doubt that the print had been left by Farrow. Bloodstains at the scene were matched with Farrow's blood and he admitted the murder.

Robert Smith QC, prosecuting, said that Farrow had told detectives: "I just saw her get off a bus as I was getting off another bus. I had been... thinking how crap my life was. My sex life... was absolute zero and I had a lot of upset and anger towards my girlfriend. I decided to do something that day to someone. But you then located a second victim - another complete stranger - and you forced your way into her house."

The judge said he would recommend to the home secretary that Farrow should not be released from prison for "very many years".

Tracey Millington-Jones, 36, a daughter of Mrs Speakes, said: "Our mother had everything to live for. If she had not been so kind in trying to help Farrow out when he called at her home, she would probably still be alive today."

fields.headline: We have nothing to hide on freedom of information
fields.trailText: Your dismissive and curmudgeonly comments about the freedom of information bill are as misplaced as they are predictable (Leader, November13).
fields.body:
Your dismissive and curmudgeonly comments about the freedom of information bill are as misplaced as they are predictable (Leader, November13). The bill currently before parliament shares exactly the same principles as the white paper - to achieve for the first time a statutory right to know. That right is balanced with the equally important rights to privacy and confidentiality and to ensure the effective conduct of public administration.

You claim that information gathered by the health and safety executive would be kept secret under the provisions of the bill - this is simply not the case. Of course the government believes that such information in most circumstances should be available to the public but that cannot be done if it would jeopardise criminal prosecutions. The public would be rightly outraged if actions to disclose information meant that individuals who were guilty of jeopardising the lives of others would walk free.

Far from losing its way the government has from the start made it clear that we were listening to others on FoI but that we would not accept weak, woolly and emotive arguments of the sort we often hear on FoI. We have had a serious debate in parliament and outside and changes have been made to improve the legislation as a result

The Guardian has asserted "betrayal" all the way through this bill. The time has now come to acknowledge that if passed this legislation will lead to a massive culture change in the public sector and more transparent and open government - which I am sure Guardian readers will support.
Mike O'Brien MP
Home Office minister

Hugo Young rightly upbraids the Liberal Democrats for the squalid deal they have struck with the government over the freedom of information bill in the House of Lords (Comment, November 14). Not surprisingly, however, few press reports since the story broke at the weekend took this line. The Home Office did its job of spinning the lobby correspondents well. All except the Guardian's David Hencke reported the deal as a significant concession on the part of Jack Straw.

We think not. The minor concessions given by the government will have a marginal effect on the bill, even in the areas affected by the deal. Lib Dem lawyers have mistaken fine legal detail for wider political context. To make matters worse, their political leaders in the Lords did not even realise when they had the government cornered.

It is a bit of a cheek now to accuse the Tories of untrustworthiness, when that was not even put to the test, nor the resistance of Labour backbenchers. While Charter88 supports the politics of compromise it should be conducted more intelligently than this, and not sacrificing principles held dearly for many decades.
Pam Giddy
Director, Charter88

webTitle: Letters: The debate is hotting up

fields.headline: The debate is hotting up
fields.trailText: Climate change is a threat to many environments world-wide, but Rosetta's problems in Egypt are largely self-inflicted (Confronting the perils of global warming in a vanishing landscape, November 14).
fields.body:
Climate change is a threat to many environments world-wide, but Rosetta's problems in Egypt are largely self-inflicted (Confronting the perils of global warming in a vanishing landscape, November 14). Visiting the town last week - part of pan-African climate-change research - we saw how the Nile delta has indeed receded several kilometres towards Rosetta in the last 100 years.

But why? Because the Aswan dams have prevented silt reaching the delta, leaving the coastline vulnerable to erosion. And the flood defences in Alexandria are now essential because the city is deliberately encroaching into the sea, not least to build the coastal highway along the beach.

The key point is that increased human vulnerability has local and well as global origins. Often it is the former that dominate, and global excuses should not be allowed to paper-over misguided local practices.
Prof Edmund Penning-Rowsell
Flood hazard research centre, Middlesex University E.Penning-Rowsell@mdx.ac.uk

Global warming will induce not only environmental change, but also the most rapid and profound cultural changes in the history of humanity. In the face of rising English nationalism and current discussion on the nature of "Britishness", the cultural dimension has been so far absent from the debate.

Changing weather means changing crops, changing food, changing clothes and changing homes. Behaviours and styles we now recognise as foreign will have to be co-opted into mainstream British culture. Flood defences may mean Mekong delta-style stilt houses on the Ouse estury. It will mean a profound shift in national and individual identities.

As well as cuts in emissions we should be calling for a greater understanding of world cultural diversity.
Oliver Maxwell
University of Durham o.c.maxwell@durham.ac.uk

I am glad that Peter Smith raised the possibility that the Gulf Stream might switch off because of global warming (Letters, November 14). There was some publicity last year, but not much, and it does not seem to be taken very seriously. Your report on climate change in Britain (Welcome to the new world, November 14) does not mention it. Please could we have more information about th likelihood and possible consequences, for us and the rest of western Europe.

And your material on global warming this week has little about the political and economic pressures that are likely to grow as warming intensifies, in particular population movements. Please, more on this too - it warrants much greater attention than our media is prepared to give it.
Peter Churley
Leeds peter-churley@supanet.com

This climate change is worse than I thought. If you are to be believed, Morecambe and Blackpool will lie in the northwest of Britain in 50 years. What's going to happen to places like Ullapool, Gairloch and Durness which are there now?
Ken Chew
Geneva kenneth.chew@ihsenergy.com

Surely the reason the "advanced" nations are making such heavy weather of the Kyoto review is that they are pursuing two incompatible aims - to curtail CO2 emissions and to maintain economic growth.
RD Harrison
Oxford

When you refer to "the Hague" instead of "The Hague" (as on yesterday's front page), I am not sure whether you mean the place or the politician.
Adrian Russell
Poole, Dorset russell@sarjpartners.co.uk

fields.headline: America fights back
fields.trailText: I have been fascinated by the editorial opinion in your paper over the internet. The consensus seems to be that American democracy is in a fragile and unhealthy state and that the electoral college is an outdated monstrosity.
fields.body:
I have been fascinated by the editorial opinion in your paper over the internet. The consensus seems to be that American democracy is in a fragile and unhealthy state and that the electoral college is an outdated monstrosity. Despite the shenanigans going on in the banana republic of Florida and the media-created crisis, the rest of the US has remained calm. It may be a slow process but many seem to forget that the election in Florida will not be officially over until November 17 when all the absentee ballots are counted.

There also seems to be agreement on your pages that our new Congress will be more evenly split and thus dysfunctional. Frankly, when European states are brought to a halt by striking farmers (France) or blockaded oil refineries (UK) or terrorists (Spain) or a paedophilia ring (Belgium), things don't look so good on your side of the Atlantic either.

Your condemnation of the electoral college reveals a serious ignorance of American governance. One complication of governing a federal union is how to make the institutions democratic while still respecting the sovereignty of the member states. How do you ensure that the interests of small states are not trampled by large states? Our framers of the constitution answered that with the compromise known as the electoral college. I find it ironic that your writers are so quick to preach a "remedy" for the American union when the European Union is struggling to come up with an answer to this same question. If the uncertainty in Florida continues, the election will simply be decided without Florida having any say. Life will go on.
Ryan Oyama
Cambridge, Massachusetts royamahi@earthlink.net

fields.headline: Shopping John
fields.trailText: For the benefit of Bernard Jenkin (Sketch, November 14) John Prescott's absence in the Commons on Monday could not be explained by his "skulking in his den". He could in fact be seen smiling and waving in a shopping centre in Preston, Lancashire.
fields.body:
For the benefit of Bernard Jenkin (Sketch, November 14) John Prescott's absence in the Commons on Monday could not be explained by his "skulking in his den". He could in fact be seen smiling and waving in a shopping centre in Preston, Lancashire, encouraging a high Labour turnout in the forthcoming byelection.
Laura Field
Clitheroe, Lancs

Do the London millennium projects provide us with a metaphor for the Englishman's sexual anxiety? First, you can't get it up (the Eye). When you've got it up, it wobbles too much to be functional (the bridge). When you've got it up and stopped it wobbling, people have lost interest in it (the dome).
Ian Conolly
Nottingham

In 1945 I was working in the physics lab at Porton Down (The guinea pigs, November 8) and took part in the first test of nerve gases brought back from Germany. Rob Evans says all those who took part were service personnel. In fact, equal numbers of civilians and servicemen were involved . It was a ghastly experience.
VS Dodd
Cuffley, Herts

I wholeheartedly agree with Frances Mossop (Letters, November 14). I have been trying to persuade supermarket check-out staff for years that bananas come with their own packaging.
Tessa Kingsley
Leamington Spa, Warks

Unfortunately, in Jerusalem, neighbours are but a stone's throw away from each other!
Daniel Roberts
London

How nice of the Queen to send a message of sympathy at long last to the flood victims. Where has she been for the past month?
Steve Dey
Dousland, Devon

fields.headline: Gossip makes us dumb
fields.trailText: Madeleine Bunting's faith in gossip as a cultural glue is misconceived (Rewiring our brains, November 13).
fields.body:
Madeleine Bunting's faith in gossip as a cultural glue is misconceived (Rewiring our brains, November 13).

Gossip has always inherently defined a community by excluding those who "aren't in the know", and so aren't "one of us"; while narrowing and focusing the talk of those "on the inside". It excludes and normalises. And that's why the tabloids and tabloid media love it.

Who cares about the gossip of other EU countries or "what's hot" outside the English-speaking world?

And at home, why should democratic debate be allowed to upset tribal certainties? For instance, why should the introverted indignation of the fuel protest be challenged by "chattering class" diversions about the environment or the nature of democracy?

Gossip is not popular culture, but populist bullying; the very antithesis of the concerns of theorists of culture like Hall or Hoggart or Raymond Williams. It's dumbing down, big time.
Nigel Blake
Institute of educational technology, Open University n.p.blake@open.ac.uk

fields.headline: Whose life is it anyway?
fields.standfirst:
The knowledge economy should be for all

Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Patents are pending on over half a million gene sequences. Today the Guardian reveals the extraordinary scale and pace of the rush to patent the blueprint for life in all its forms - from the tiniest microbe to an entire mouse. Never has such a dramatic shift in the ownership of knowledge occurred with so little attention or comment.
fields.body:
Nine patents have been applied for on the genes which determine your eyeball, 40 on those for your heart, and no fewer than 152 on a single grain of rice. Everytime you sit down to eat, there are patents pending on most of the contents of your dinner plate. Patents are pending on over half a million gene sequences. Today the Guardian reveals the extraordinary scale and pace of the rush to patent the blueprint for life in all its forms - from the tiniest microbe to an entire mouse. This process has picked up with breathtaking speed: our research of the 9,364 patent applications lodged in 40 countries shows that over 60% had been made in the last three years. And all of this has happened without either governments or the media showing any urgent interest. Never has such a dramatic shift in the ownership of knowledge occurred with so little attention or comment.

The reason for this is not hard to see. Gene patenting involves two areas of enormous complexity - the fast developing genetic sciences and patent law. Few parliamentarians have the time to master the details, and it is the sort of subject on which environmental groups find it difficult to mobilise activists. The European Patent Office (EPO), whose convention meets next week, is used to conducting its affairs with little public scrutiny. And it hopes to keep things that way; gene patenting has been relegated to "basket two" in its agenda in a bid to avoid controversy. All of that may change, and just as another international body, the World Trade Organisation, found itself at the eye of a global protest storm, so the EPO could move centre stage in the battle over knowledge.

When the extent of the gene patent rush is explained, there is an instinctive unease. How can the the genetic codes which stimulate and codify the make-up of every cell of a living organism be bought and sold? The realisation is slowly growing that something has gone seriously awry. That something is the interpretation of US patent law. The rot started 20 years ago when the first patent was granted on a bacteria. At that point, a vital principle of patent law was fatally undermined, and the distinction between what was a discovery (which has never been patentable) and what was an invention was blurred. The US has lobbied and secured the implementation of similarly liberal patent regimes around the world - through the trade related intellectual property agreement (TRIPs) - and in Europe. In the resulting patent rush, there are thousands of absurd applications which are so speculative or vague that they are very unlikely to be granted. Companies and public laboratories have been applying for patents on genes of which they do not even understand the function. There are anomalies such as different patents being granted on the same gene sequence for different purposes. Only one thing is certain in this chaos: what lies ahead is years of lucrative work for patent lawyers to sort out the mess. It costs hundreds of thousands of pounds to defend or challenge a patent.

There are two main reasons for worry about the gene patent rush. First, patents could increase the cost of medical research or even inhibit it. While patents clearly have a role in protecting investment in research, researchers could be deterred by the pile of patents they will have to negotiate before any drug they have developed can come to market. Given how little understanding we now have about how our genes work, slapping patents on them can only slow down the advance of publicly available scientific knowledge. Secondly, there are several issues raised by developing countries which argue that the knowledge economy is being stitched up for decades to come to their gross detriment, reinforcing a pattern of technological inequality. For example, western bio-prospectors are raiding the rich bio-diversity of developing countries to patent genes and the properties of plants which have long been part of indigenous knowledge. Another concern is that patents are gathering on staple food crops such as maize, rice and wheat which could disrupt centuries of farmers' own crossbreeding. They are justifiably worried at the threat of crop substitution to economies which are heavily dependent on the export of raw commodities. Most famously, the US company RiceTec has developed a copy of basmati rice.

Given the scale of the issues in terms of human wellbeing and development, it is a scandal that the subject of gene patenting is unlikely to be discussed at the EPO's convention next week. Debate is exactly what this issue most needs. As the knowledge economy gathers pace, it is vital that considerations of public interest are built into its regulation through patent law. The time has come to check this revolution by stealth and to call to account the officials who have presided over it.

Given the scale of the issues in terms of human wellbeing and development, it is a scandal that the subject of gene patenting is unlikely to be discussed at the EPO's convention next week. Debate is exactly what this issue most needs. As the knowledge economy gathers pace, it is vital that considerations of public interest are built into its regulation through patent law. The time has come to check this revolution by stealth and to call to account the officials who have presided over it.

webTitle: First sight of Tolkien films draws 'oohs'

fields.headline: First sight of Tolkien films draws 'oohs'
fields.trailText: Online spy reports register a cautiously enthusiastic response after the first major screening of footage from Peter Jackson's eagerly awaited film adaptation of The Lord of the Rings trilogy
fields.body:
Reports are seeping in across the web of the first major screening of footage from Peter Jackson's eagerly awaited film adaptation of The Lord of the Rings (watch the trailer here). The screenings, of 10 scenes from the first two movies in the series, took place at Fox Studios in Sydney for an assembled marketing audience, and was introduced by the film's executive producer, Mark Odesky.

Online spy reports register a cautiously enthusiastic response. "Even without a film grade and finished effects the footage sent a shiver up my spine," says the scooper 'Vermont' on the Dark Horizons website. "To say I can't wait for Boxing Day 2001 is a slight understatement."

According to one critic at Ain't It Cool News, "what was really cool was the film seemed REAL - the landscape felt genuine and naturalistic, even in a medieval-type context. The real thing that stood out for me was how well Elijah Wood [who plays Frodo Baggins] seemed to TAKE the screen so confidently. He didn't seem like a kid. He had a sense of dignity and awe that made me feel like, 'Yup, I want to see this guy through this story'."

Ian McKellen's Gandalf, meanwhile, was described as having "majesty and dignity but also a weariness... he's obviously seen a lot in his time. Looks like a real wizard, not a guy in a cape with a funny hat."

Director Peter Jackson, meanwhile, has held a press conference to herald the anniversary of production work on the film, at which the New Zealand director again assured fans of his project's loyalty to the books of JRR Tolkien.

"Way back at the beginning," he said, "we thought there was quite a bit of this we are going to have to alter or change. But the more we got into it and the more we started to know the books in great detail, [the more] we've gone further and further back to the books. A lot of our so-called clever ideas at the beginning we've long since abandoned and Tolkien hopefully has a fairly clear voice in the film."

The first film in the saga is released in December 2001.

fields.headline: Home truths
fields.standfirst: How we can all help to clean up the environment
fields.trailText: How we can all help to clean up the environment.
fields.body:
You may not know it, but if you buy a new fridge or freezer, you can be assured improved efficiency. Since September last year, Europe has forced manufacturers to raise minimum energy efficiency standards, and so use less electricity and cause less pollution. It has taken more than seven years to achieve and started with a report to the European Commission in 1993.

What the efficiency improvements have shown is that when the market is competitive, as in this case, the price can be lower, too. In comparison with a year ago, the average fridge or freezer bought in Britain uses 15% less electricity and costs £25 less.

The result for the 2.8m Britons who bought a new fridge or freezer this year is that they will be saving £100 over the life of the appliance, by comparison with someone who bought a similar, but less efficient machine, the year before. Definitely a win-win situation, for consumers and the environment.

Consumers can be more actively involved when buying products that carry an EU energy label, which identifies the most and the least efficient in the colourful A-G scale. There is still a wide range of efficient machines on the market: the best cold appliances in the shops use two-thirds of the electricity of the worst and new models will soon reduce this to half.

These labels are on many of the major pieces of equipment and will include all light bulbs by the end of the year. I recommended similar labels for cars in a recent report to the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions and this should also be extended to houses.

There is a factor of two in the fuel consumption of cars of the same size, between those that use the most and the least petrol. With rising fuel prices, new car buyers could halve their petrol or diesel bill by choosing an efficient vehicle. If the DETR introduces comparative labels and guides, the choice will be made easier.

Helping the environment requires the active involvement of manufacturers, others depend more on consumers. Educating people to choose a more environmentally-friendly lifestyle is ultimately the best guarantee of a cleaner world with less extreme weather.

 Brenda Boardman leads the energy and environment programme at the Environmental Change Institute, University of Oxford. Further information: www.eci.ox.ac.uk

webTitle: Ambitious bid to end child poverty

fields.headline: Ambitious bid to end child poverty
fields.standfirst: The government has launched a strategy to stop poverty ruining children's lives
fields.trailText: More than 4m children in the UK live in poverty. Look again. Four. Million. It's nigh-on impossible to take in. And what is almost as difficult to comprehend is how we can be one of the richest economies on the planet and yet condemn so many young lives to misery and disadvantage.
fields.body:
More than 4m children in the UK live in poverty. Look again. Four. Million. It's nigh-on impossible to take in. And what is almost as difficult to comprehend is how we can be one of the richest economies on the planet and yet condemn so many young lives to misery and disadvantage.

The Labour government has pledged to end child poverty within 20 years and halve it within 10. Chancellor Gordon Brown has made that pledge one of his priorities. The strategy melds fiscal and social policy. It includes a number of tax and benefit measures, including the new deal for lone parents, working families tax credit and the new (as of November) children's tax credit. It also includes several initiatives aimed at preventing poverty from ruining the lives of children and young people.

Brown had been impressed by the US Head Start programme, which aims to prevent deprived children being held back at school. Head Start became the model for Sure Start, New Labour's programme to promote the physical, intellectual and social development of children under five. Under Sure Start, around a third of pre-school children in deprived families should benefit through a wide variety of projects run by local voluntary and statutory partnerships.

Sure Start has been followed by initiatives aimed at older children. There's Connexions, a personal adviser service to help keep 13- to 19-year-olds stay in education. And then there's the new children and young people's unit for 5- to 13-year-olds. The unit's genesis was in the social exclusion unit proposals for a "youth unit" to co-ordinate preventative strategies. It would drive forward cross-government objectives, amass research findings and evidence about effective projects and draw together a yearly strategy for parliamentary debate.

The result is a prime example of joined-up - or maybe jumbled-up - working, if ever a government came up with one. The new unit is overseen by a Cabinet committee, chaired by Brown and including vice-chair and education secretary David Blunkett, young people's minister and home office secretary Paul Boateng, health secretary Alan Milburn, culture secretary Chris Smith, Treasury minister Alastair Darling, defence secretary Geoff Hoon and Cabinet Office minister Mo Mowlam. On a day-to-day basis, Boateng heads the unit, which is based in the Department for Education and Employment. "Material poverty, poverty of aspiration, is the number one enemy," says Boateng, envisaging the task ahead.

The children's and young people's unit will have at its disposal a new children's fund, worth £450m over its first three years. Of that, £70m will go directly to voluntary organisations. For Family Welfare Association chief executive Helen Dent, it's a chance to do some important work with a "neglected" group. "The voluntary sector is in a good position to pass on the money to other voluntary organisations and it's welcome," she says. "I hope there will be the flexibility to work where there are small pockets of deprivation." Even relatively small grants to, for example, summer playschemes, can "improve the quality of children's lives". But hackles rose when minister for young people Paul Boateng hinted that local authority social services departments could be kept out of the loop. The reality is that it would be hard to administer a national fund efficiently without the involvement of councils, even if it were done on a local partnership basis. Local authorities are obliged to know their catchment areas and how to respond to them, as outlined in children's services plans. Councils also have a duty to assess and arrange services for children in need and their families, under the Children Act 1989.

Along with other children's charities, Barnardo's is very positive about the new unit and its fund. "We're totally behind the government's initiative to abolish child poverty," says chief executive Roger Singleton. But, welcome though the new money will be, he argues that child poverty cannot be eradicated without changes in society's infrastructure. He steadfastly refuses to be partisan and says that local government will need to be involved.

"If some or all of the money goes to the statutory sector, so be it. It must be better for children to get a good education from local schools than for them to get help from the voluntary sector when the public sector louses up," he says. "The criteria ought to be ensuring basic services, such as transport, education and health, so that what's available to children in very poor families is at least as good as those for children living in competent and secure families." However, he adds: "You may not need large amounts of money to make the services that are there work. For example, inducements to help encourage teachers to work in poor areas."

There's a sneaking suspicion in the child care field that the absence of a template such as Sure Start had, coupled with political prejudices, has made the job of sorting out who will do quite what with which bits of cash that much tougher.

But Boateng has made one thing clear. The unit - and projects it funds - will need to "be brave and courageous" and inclusive. The unit's advisory committee will "involve the great and the good", academia and the voluntary sector, "and young voices around the table". The minister for young people says that: "We will need to take the risk of involving children and young people."

fields.headline: Cooperation reaps rewards
fields.standfirst: The new children and young person's unit needs to "break through Whitehall's bunkers".
fields.trailText: Malcolm Dean welcomes the launch of the new children and young person's unit but wonders how smoothly it will be allowed to do its job.
fields.body:
The children and young person's unit (CYPU) is launched today. It will be easy for the Tories to mock. On top of Sure Start partnerships, youth offending teams, children services planning groups, and early years and childcare development partnerships, a new joined-up service is being planned. It's aimed at five to 13-year-olds. No one should be in any doubt of its need - or the difficulties it will face.

Like Sure Start, it is another Treasury initiative. It was announced by Gordon Brown in his second comprehensive spending review in July. Beginning next April, it will spend £450m over three years to help prevent children falling into drug abuse, truancy, or crime. It will fill the hole between Sure Start, which supports vulnerable families with children under four living in deprived areas, and Connexions, the new career and youth service for 13 to 19-year-olds.

It's needed because poor families have been let down by mainstream services. Labour's goal of abolishing child poverty within 20 years has to include better access to public services as well as work and more financial support. Sure Start, fizzing with new initiatives, has led the way.

But the CYPU's boss - still to be appointed - will face a more difficult task. Unlike the policy-free zone of under-fours, much of the new unit's territory is already staked out. It will need some unpicking. Social services, for example, are also supposed to be concentrating on vulnerable children. CYPU's remit runs wider, embracing eight departments serving children, but turf wars look inevitable.

Paul Boateng, minister with day-to-day responsibility, did not help with last month's verbal assault on social services. Ironically, it came in the same week as the Lord Chief Justice's judgment on James Bulger's killers, praising social service secure units but condemning youth offender institutions under none other than . . . Mr Boateng.

Like Sure Start, responsibility for CYPU is spread round Whitehall: main unit in Department for Education; day-to-day minister at the Home Office; big boss in the Treasury. The idea is to break through Whitehall's notorious bunkers - get people out of their boxes on to a different viewing plain. The old co-ordinating system of a lead department, meant other departments paid no attention. The new spread-out approach risks confusion, but works with Sure Start. Eight committed women ministers have shown admirable cooperation.

One unanswered question: can Paul Boateng do the same? Macho abrasiveness is the wrong approach. Gordon and Jack - his two bosses - need to keep an eye on him.

webTitle: Lara smashes second century in a row

fields.headline: Lara smashes second century in a row
fields.trailText: Brian Lara has had plenty of hassle since he arrived in Australia, but yesterday he hit his second hundred in two innings against a Northern Territory invitation X to confirm he is still a force to be reckoned with.
fields.body:
Brian Lara has been in Australia only 11 days, but already he has fitted in a year's worth of peaks and troughs. Badgered about match-fixing allegations before he stepped on the plane, then taunted for being overweight upon his arrival, yesterday he hit his second hundred in two innings to confirm he is still a force to be reckoned with.

Lara's blazing 106 against a Northern Territory invitation XI in Alice Springs means he has now faced 218 balls on tour, scored 214 runs, hitting 13 fours and seven sixes. But it is still unclear just what shape Lara, still battling a hamstring injury, is in for next week's first Test in Brisbane.

The NT attack boasted only two first-class bowlers, Colin Miller and Daniel Marsh, while Lara's first-up hundred was plundered off an ACB chairman's XI led by two old-timers in Mike Whitney and Jo Angel. Courtney Walsh began his tour yesterday where he left off in England, taking none for four from six overs as the tourists won by 57 runs.

Sri Lanka, meanwhile, have left Aravinda de Silva out of next month's Test tour of South Africa, but the move has nothing to do with his inclusion in the Indian match-fixing report.

fields.headline: England step into the unknown
fields.standfirst: First Test in Pakistan for 13 years is greatest challenge yet, admits Hussain
fields.trailText: Mike Selvey hears Nasser Hussain admit that England's First Test in Pakistan for 13 years is his greatest challenge yet.
fields.body:
Today, Nasser Hussain admits, brings the biggest test yet to confront his side since he joined forces with Duncan Fletcher a little over a year ago. Test with a lower-case "t" or a capital, it does not much matter: the sentiment holds good just the same.

The past 12 months have brought mixed fortunes but a steady upward movement on the learning curve. A loss but no disgrace to South Africa, followed by series wins over Zimbabwe and West Indies, neither of them providing more than modest opposition in the prevailing seam-orientated conditions, but worthy successes for all that.

This, though, is different. England's sole excursion to the subcontinent to play Test cricket in the 13 years since last they contested a series in Pakistan was a disastrous, ill-conceived trip to India, and briefly but pertinently to Sri Lanka, eight years ago.

Of that side only Alec Stewart, Graeme Hick, Mike Atherton and Ian Salisbury are in Pakistan now. The coach has never been here. So to undergo a three-Test series now, against one of the hottest sides in the game in their own environment, with a massive lack of experience in those conditions, represents a great challenge. On paper England have not got a prayer.

Yesterday, however, Hussain outlined almost with relish what faces his side over the next four weeks. "The first day will be a huge one for us," he said. "But however it goes, whether it is in our favour or theirs, we will live in the present. There will be a long way to go. We lost the first day of the West Indies series and came out on top.

"I do regard it as our biggest challenge, however. This is completely different from anything we have had before, even on this tour where the pitches in the two warm-up games and especially that in Peshawar have been excellent. We have enough experience in our side to be able to adapt to whatever conditions there are but it will still be interesting to see how people cope with it."

Hussain took another look at the Test pitch yesterday and it was already as dry as it could get, devoid of grass except for clippings rolled in cosmetically, cracked into a mosaic, and with no real solidity. There is no question that the ball will turn but the pace bowlers might also get some uneven bounce as the match wears on. The side that wins the toss will want to bat first.

So balance will have been the key when England selected their final XI earlier this morning. The intention had been to play two spinners, with a batsman light from the seven who played last summer (Michael Vaughan's injury made a difficult choice unnecessary) and Darren Gough and Andy Caddick backed by Craig White, whose hamstring is still niggling but no more than it has done for the past five weeks.

Andy Flintoff temporarily joined the injury list yesterday when he was hit on the nose after mistiming a hook in the nets, causing blood to stream down his face. X-rays showed he had sustained only bruising and the plan was that he would play if White, or any other batsman, proved unfit.

Pakistan's intentions are clear. They had a vigorous workout in the morning (all, that is, except Inzamam-ul-Haq, who watched from an armchair for an hour before donning pads, batting like a prince for 15 minutes and resuming his seat) but well as the seamers ran in, they know this is for the twirlers.

Pakistan may well play the side that contested the one-day series but with a batsman, Qaiser Abbas, who made 71 against England for the Patron's XI at Rawalpindi and took wickets with his left-arm spin, coming in for Azhar Mahmood. With Saqlain Mushtaq, Mushtaq Ahmed and Shahid Afridi, that might be seen as over-insurance, with the only pacemen intended to be Wasim Akram and Abdur Razzaq.

"It is a formidable side," Hussain admits. "Just think of the questions they pose, when you first go in with men round the bat, or when Wasim is coming at you with the new ball. Think of their batsmen when they get in on a flat one and hit through the line of the ball.

"This is about our technique against the spinners and reverse swing, it's about having bottle when you are under the cosh and you don't know where the next run is coming from, or when you bowl a perfectly good ball and it goes for four. It is about technique and it is about character. We'll find out a lot."

fields.bodyText: Today, Nasser Hussain admits, brings the biggest test yet to confront his side since he joined forces with Duncan Fletcher a little over a year ago. Test with a lower-case "t" or a capital, it does not much matter: the sentiment holds good just the same. The past 12 months have brought mixed fortunes but a steady upward movement on the learning curve. A loss but no disgrace to South Africa, followed by series wins over Zimbabwe and West Indies, neither of them providing more than modest opposition in the prevailing seam-orientated conditions, but worthy successes for all that. This, though, is different. England's sole excursion to the subcontinent to play Test cricket in the 13 years since last they contested a series in Pakistan was a disastrous, ill-conceived trip to India, and briefly but pertinently to Sri Lanka, eight years ago. Of that side only Alec Stewart, Graeme Hick, Mike Atherton and Ian Salisbury are in Pakistan now. The coach has never been here. So to undergo a three-Test series now, against one of the hottest sides in the game in their own environment, with a massive lack of experience in those conditions, represents a great challenge. On paper England have not got a prayer. Yesterday, however, Hussain outlined almost with relish what faces his side over the next four weeks. "The first day will be a huge one for us," he said. "But however it goes, whether it is in our favour or theirs, we will live in the present. There will be a long way to go. We lost the first day of the West Indies series and came out on top. "I do regard it as our biggest challenge, however. This is completely different from anything we have had before, even on this tour where the pitches in the two warm-up games and especially that in Peshawar have been excellent. We have enough experience in our side to be able to adapt to whatever conditions there are but it will still be interesting to see how people cope with it." Hussain took another look at the Test pitch yesterday and it was already as dry as it could get, devoid of grass except for clippings rolled in cosmetically, cracked into a mosaic, and with no real solidity. There is no question that the ball will turn but the pace bowlers might also get some uneven bounce as the match wears on. The side that wins the toss will want to bat first. So balance will have been the key when England selected their final XI earlier this morning. The intention had been to play two spinners, with a batsman light from the seven who played last summer (Michael Vaughan's injury made a difficult choice unnecessary) and Darren Gough and Andy Caddick backed by Craig White, whose hamstring is still niggling but no more than it has done for the past five weeks. Andy Flintoff temporarily joined the injury list yesterday when he was hit on the nose after mistiming a hook in the nets, causing blood to stream down his face. X-rays showed he had sustained only bruising and the plan was that he would play if White, or any other batsman, proved unfit. Pakistan's intentions are clear. They had a vigorous workout in the morning (all, that is, except Inzamam-ul-Haq, who watched from an armchair for an hour before donning pads, batting like a prince for 15 minutes and resuming his seat) but well as the seamers ran in, they know this is for the twirlers. Pakistan may well play the side that contested the one-day series but with a batsman, Qaiser Abbas, who made 71 against England for the Patron's XI at Rawalpindi and took wickets with his left-arm spin, coming in for Azhar Mahmood. With Saqlain Mushtaq, Mushtaq Ahmed and Shahid Afridi, that might be seen as over-insurance, with the only pacemen intended to be Wasim Akram and Abdur Razzaq. "It is a formidable side," Hussain admits. "Just think of the questions they pose, when you first go in with men round the bat, or when Wasim is coming at you with the new ball. Think of their batsmen when they get in on a flat one and hit through the line of the ball. "This is about our technique against the spinners and reverse swing, it's about having bottle when you are under the cosh and you don't know where the next run is coming from, or when you bowl a perfectly good ball and it goes for four. It is about technique and it is about character. We'll find out a lot." fields.standfirst: George Best, the last United player to win the coveted European player of the year award, casts his eye over the six Old Trafford men up for this season's prize
fields.trailText: George Best, the last United player to win the coveted European player of the year award, casts his eye over the six Old Trafford men up for this season's prize
fields.body:
Ryan Giggs
He's having a brilliant season and what I am most delighted about is that he is going at people as soon as he gets the ball, which I've always said should be the first thing on his mind. When he is in that mode, defenders are absolutely terrified of him Rating: 8

David Beckham
The greatest thing about David is that he never seems to miss a game, not even for England, which is saying a lot for a Man United player. It's the third time he has been nominated for a major award and now that he is scoring more goals, he must be among the favourites. Rating: 9/10

Jaap Stam
His size is enough to put off strikers. You'd need a ladder to challenge him in the air and half a day to walk round him. He had a few Gary Pallister moments when he first signed but now he is rated among other players as one of the best in the world. But because of injury, he probably hasn't played enough games to win the award. Rating: 8

Fabien Barthez
For me, he is the best goalkeeper in the world, though not many keepers win gongs like this. He may give his own defence a few shaky moments but his distribution is brilliant and his kicking awesome. He can smack the ball 80 or 90 yards without blinking. Rating: 8

Roy Keane
Beckham may be the most famous United player but Roy is the most influential. He is one of those marvellous players who makes it look easy and the beauty of him is that he makes other people play. The prawn sandwich remark aside, he also seems to have got a grip on his temper. Rating: 9

Paul Scholes
I always fancied Nicky Butt to come through in the midfield anchor role but Scholes has shown such consistency that Alex Ferguson's been unable to leave him out. But I'm a bit surprised to see him in the list because I think he's been a bit off the boil lately, missing chances he would normally stick away blindfolded. Rating: 7
