fields.headline: United dominate top European award
fields.standfirst: George Best on the United's six nominees
fields.trailText: An unprecedented six Old Trafford players have been named in the list of 50 nominees for the European footballer of the year award while four players from Arsenal make the list.
fields.body:
As if Manchester United had not won enough silverware to fill the Millennium Dome in the past few years, an unprecedented six Old Trafford players have been named in the list of 50 nominees for the coveted Ballon d'Or, the European footballer of the year award.

Their six of the best are inevitably headed by the new England captain David Beckham, who was runner-up to the Brazilian Rivaldo last year in the poll organised by the magazine France Football. Ryan Giggs, Jaap Stam, Fabien Barthez, Roy Keane and Paul Scholes make up the United numbers. But they may again find Arsenal, their main Premiership rivals, challenging them with four nominated players of their own, though none of them are English. They are the Frenchmen Thierry Henry, Sylvain Wiltord and Patrick Vieira, all members of France's Euro 2000 winning side, and the Dutchman Dennis Bergkamp.

Chelsea's Marcel Desailly, the newly appointed captain of the world and European champions, is also nominated.

United have more players nominated than any other club. The top league on this showing, however, is Italy's. Twenty-one of the 50 nominees ply their trade in Serie A. The Premiership is the next best represented, while Spain's Liga is third with 11 players nominated. The top nationalities are Italian and Argentine, each having six nominees.

The last British player to win the title was Kevin Keegan, who picked up back-to-back awards in 1978 and 1979 when he was playing for Hamburg.

George Best was the last Manchester United player to be named European footballer of the year. He won in 1968, following in the footsteps of Bobby Charlton and his close friend, Denis Law, both team-mates. Here he casts his eye over the six Old Trafford men up for this season's prize.

fields.headline: Tricks of the trade
fields.standfirst:
35. How I got my own back

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: 35. How I got my own back
fields.body:
Sarah Ashford, 31 PR executive

My boss's deputy was very unpleasant. She was snide, made personal comments about how I dressed, organised meetings without me and was generally difficult. I didn't have the confidence to confront her because I didn't think it was professional and thought she would win any arguments. I got my revenge when I got a new job. At my leaving bash I started taking the mickey out of her. I always thought she intimidated everyone, but because we had all had a few drinks, my colleagues started laughing. I spent the entire evening making her look ridiculous. She eventually flounced out and went home. It was pure joy.

Rachel Riley, 29 management consultant

A married male colleague was convinced I was having an affair and was hostile to me personally and professionally, even though I wasn't guilty of anything. There was nothing I could do. At the next Christmas party he was snogging one of the female members of staff. Everyone but me was very drunk, so when I took a photo, nobody remembered. I stuck it on the offiice noticeboard. He was on holiday for a week, so it stayed up until he came back. He was furious, but after that left me alone.

Alison Parker, 39 chief executive

I used to have a boss who made inappropriate advances to my colleague and me. We decided to send him and the managing director a Valentine card each, except we deliberately put them in the wrong envelopes. We worked in an open-plan office so we watched them open their cards. The smarmy boss got a raunchier one than the happily married MD, so when they swapped cards our boss was visibly embarrassed. I don't think the MD was very impressed either and I'm sure our victim guessed what was going on. He never confronted us but he stopped giving us unwelcome attention.

Suzanne Hume, 38 marketing director

I used to have a boss who was a nasty piece of work. If you were new to the job, she would pick holes in everything you did and attack your confidence, which is what she did to me. I eventually got promoted and, ironically, had to oversee a complaint made about her by an employee years later. Because I had been in the same situation, I knew exactly what was going on. In the end, my report was so damning that she took early retirement.

Ian Thomas, 45 company director

I was in charge of a department and had trouble with one of my bosses. He rang me at 7pm one Thursday and said he wanted to inspect my department next day. I had booked the day off so I apologised and said I wouldn't be in. He went anyway and really picked holes in the operation. Then he wrote a snotty letter to me which he copied to my immediate boss and the MD. He really tried to stitch me up. So I sat down with the MD and my boss, explained what had happened and they saw my point of view. I let the facts speak for themselves. Eventually I was promoted and this guy was sidelined because of his attitude.

webTitle: Brief encounters: An employment tribunal lawyer writes

fields.headline: Brief encounters
fields.standfirst:
An employment tribunal lawyer writes

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: An employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.body:
Sometimes, in the thick of the ongoing battle to define what is and isn't sexual harassment in the workplace, I think it would just be easier if basic rules were issued to everyone at school. (Maybe there could be a GCSE in workplace behaviour?) Any infringement would be sexual harassment. At a stroke, ambiguity would be eradicated.

Here are my proposed rules:

 No one shall mention anything to do with sex or gender in the workplace.

 No one shall comment on the personal appearance of any other person.

 No one shall make romantic overtures to any other person (or perhaps, to avoid misunderstanding, there should be no social overtures either).

 No one shall have any physical contact with any other person.

I have come up with this desperate proposal after meeting four female clients who claimed to have been sexually harassed by a colleague, a young man who was always talking to them about sex. They complained to management and nothing was done. That could easily be sexual harassment. Or not.

Me: "So, what kind of things was he saying to you?"

Client 1: "Well, he was always talking about stuff which had happened to him. Like he met this girl in a pub and she asked him back to her place and they were snogging but then he took his shirt off and she looked at him and said 'Actually I don't think I fancy it after all'."

Client 2: "Yeah, there were lots of stories about him getting the knockback from women."

Client 3: "Or he would just try and start conversations with you about what film stars you fancied or whether you fancied anyone at work. It was kind of sad."

Me: "But did he ever make any sexual advances to anyone at work? Did he say anything that made you feel uncomfortable or threatened at all?"

Client 4: "Not really."

Me: "So why do you think he would tell you these things?"

Client 4: "Dunno. To make us like him? I guess we were a lot older than him and there were no other blokes in our section."

All the women look uncomfortable at this stage as we ponder Mr Alleged Harasser offering up his sad tales of sexual humiliation in exchange, he hopes, for a bit of workplace friendship. I am overwhelmed, not for the first time in my career, by the sense that somehow the point has been missed.

But maybe my rules go too far: people in dull jobs would die in their thousands from boredom if they were enforced.

Maybe what is needed is some kind of GCSE in distinguishing the pitiful from the culpable, the inappropriate from the wicked?

fields.headline: Classical  Copland Centenary
fields.standfirst:
Wigmore Hall, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText: Hard on the heels of the BBC's Copland Weekend at the Barbican, the Nash Ensemble offered its own anniversary tribute to Aaron Copland on Tuesday, his 100th birthday. The Nash's programme managed to include two major Copland achievements: the 12 Emily Dickinson Songs of 1950, sung by Barbara Bonney, and the suite from the ballet score Appalachian Spring, conducted by Lionel Friend in its original 13-instrument scoring.
fields.body:
Hard on the heels of the BBC's Copland Weekend at the Barbican, the Nash Ensemble offered its own anniversary tribute to Aaron Copland on Tuesday, his 100th birthday. The Nash's programme managed to include two major Copland achievements: the 12 Emily Dickinson Songs of 1950, sung by Barbara Bonney, and the suite from the ballet score Appalachian Spring, conducted by Lionel Friend in its original 13-instrument scoring.

Musical anniversaries, particularly one as copiously celebrated as Copland's centenary, can either enhance our perspective on a composer by revealing new facets of his creative personality, or confirm prejudices. In this case, it has done the latter, for Copland's finest achievements are his best-known works.

Neither the late Duo for flute and piano, which Philippa Davies and John Lenehan played so elegantly at the start of the Nash programme, nor the meditative Quiet City, with its long-limbed but rather characterless solos for trumpet and cor anglais, really stay in the memory.

Aside from the raking melody with which the 1971 Duo begins, the rest of the work falls back on to the well-mannered neo-classicism that would have won the approval of Copland's teacher Nadia Boulanger 40 years earlier.

That tactful neutrality suits the Dickinson settings, however; the piano part, beautifully judged by Malcolm Martineau in this performance, is there to cushion and reinforce the vocal line, so that every word of these extraordinary poems can blossom. Bonney ensured that too; the few occasions when she darkened her tone, just a word here and there, was always appropriate.

Copland made himself the master of the simple gesture; there are never too many notes in his best works. In Appalachian Spring (the suite rather than the full ballet this time), it is impossible to imagine any chord and any tune existing in a way other than the one he devised. With careful attention to rhythmic detail, the Nash's performance had that nice balance of clarity and dynamism.

fields.headline: Bill Frisell
fields.standfirst: Queen Elizabeth Hall, London ****
fields.trailText: Queen Elizabeth Hall, London ****
fields.body:
"Things aren't always what they seem," Bill Frisell once wrote about his music. "What I love about music is what cannot be explained." Who can disagree? Frisell interprets melodies and improvises solos with fire, grace and virtuosity, but sometimes the best moments come from somewhere else altogether. They are in the strange and beautiful transitions, or in the spaces between beats (in one of those achingly slow grooves he specialises in) or in the smiling interplay he generates with his fellow musicians.

You might not expect the rhythm section from a band called Sex Mob - Kenny Wollesen (drums) and Tony Scherr (double bass and acoustic guitar) - to be masters of restraint and sensitivity, but in Frisell's company they play in all the right places, while adding a baggy, offbeat sensibility all of their own.

The band began their set with John McLaughlin's gloriously asymmetric Follow Your Heart ("one of the most thrilling reworkings of the blues in the entire history of jazz", as Ian Carr said), which has become a standard for adventurous guitarists and numerate drummers everywhere. This morphed into a reading of Bacharach and David's What the World Needs Now as a jazz waltz which in turn became Frisell's own That Was Then (from the Good Dog Happy Man album), a subtle, rocking groove.

Then Frisell and Scherr switched to acoustic guitars and Wollesen drummed an empty case with brushes for a good-natured arrangement of John Hardy.

Robin Holcomb, who had opened the show with her idiosyncratic pieces for piano and voice, appeared again to sing Stephen Foster's Hard Times. Then the trio went back to their usual instruments for a swinging blow based loosely on Henry Mancini's Days of Wine and Roses. Someone yelled "bebop" in delight. (This was a jazz festival, after all.)

When he played What's Going On he delivered a crystal-clear rendition of Marvin Gaye's original phrasing that made the song as moving and beautiful as ever. Yet it sounded like nobody but Bill Frisell, driving a 30-year-old tune into the 21st century. Frisell interprets melodies and improvises solos with fire, grace and virtuosity, but sometimes the best moments come from somewhere else altogether. They are in the strange and beautiful transitions, or in the spaces between beats (in one of those achingly slow grooves he specialises in) or in the smiling interplay he generates with his fellow musicians. You might not expect the rhythm section from a band called Sex Mob - Kenny Wollesen (drums) and Tony Scherr (double bass and acoustic guitar) - to be masters of restraint and sensitivity, but in Frisell's company they play in all the right places, while adding a baggy, offbeat sensibility all of their own. The band began their set with John McLaughlin's gloriously asymmetric Follow Your Heart ("one of the most thrilling reworkings of the blues in the entire history of jazz", as Ian Carr said), which has become a standard for adventurous guitarists and numerate drummers everywhere. fields.headline: Kimmo Pohjonen
fields.standfirst: Purcell Room, London ****
fields.trailText: Purcell Room, London ****
fields.body:
There is an old gag that a gentleman is somebody who can play the accordion yet doesn't, but this gig deserves to bury the joke once and for all. The audience spent half of Kimmo Pohjonen's single-set gig poleaxed and the other half in raptures. The Finn played three encores, and his fans would have been happy for him to carry on all night.

Some people might question whether Pohjonen technically belongs in a jazz festival. Yet he is a boundlessly ambitious improvisor - the kind of freewheeling performer who could easily have slotted alongside John Zorn and Han Bennink into Derek Bailey's late-lamented Company Weeks - who adds to his virtuosity a great sense of theatre.

The impact of Pohjonen's solo show was substantially reinforced by lighting effects, the wild, churning music sometimes coming at you out of pitch darkness, sometimes from a glimpsed figure bathed in blue light or set against back-projected images of starscapes or earthrises.

Pohjonen bugs an orthodox accordion with pickups and pedals, beats it to make conga-drum sounds, or mimics the noise of avalanches of pebbles with his nails on the buttons. He sets loops of earlier effects going behind subsequent improvisations, as Eberhard Weber does with the bass.

Folksy melodies and wistful tangos were swept into ever more balefully insistent ostinatos, sometimes gathering velocity and volume to turn into hurricanes of sheer noise, mingled with Pohjonen's amplified suckings and chewings into a head-microphone.

Dolorous scat effects repeated like darkly lamenting north-European versions of the kind of vocal chants that Pat Metheny uses. Echoing, churchy incantations became playful, almost jazzy melodies; hoarse and increasingly frantic hollerings were accompanied by Pohjonen pacing restlessly around the stage, as if trying to evade psychosis.

He eventually achieved the unusual effect of making the accordion eat him. A battle with its aggressively pounding chords and whirling counter-rhythms left him thrashing around on his back, then slowly expanding the squeezebox in the half-light until it resembled a noisy giant caterpillar. He slowly retreated behind the instrument until only his legs were visible. Extraordinary.

fields.headline: National's Peer Gynt shambles into life
fields.standfirst:
Peer Gynt
Olivier Theatre, London ***
fields.trailText:
Peer Gynt
Olivier Theatre, London ***
fields.body:
I expected the worst: when one reads that a director has abused the actors at a public preview one assumes a disaster is in the offing. But, compared to such previous Olivier stinkers as The Villains' Opera and Antony and Cleopatra, Conall Morrison's production is perfectly tolerable and even momentarily moving.

There are many approaches to Ibsen's echoing theatrical poem. To some, it is a pre-Freudian study of the unconscious. In Peter Stein's production it became a Marxist assault on unbridled capitalism. In John Barton's Stratford version - much the best - it was a Shakespearean meditation on time.

Here, in Frank McGuinness's translation and Morrison's production, it becomes a mixture of Irish folk tale and plangent melodrama, almost literally since a six-strong band provides constant musical accompaniment.

There are many problems with Morrison's approach. The abundance of jigs, reels and jaunty songs grates; when the aged Peer, confronting the vanity of his self-absorbed life, compares himself to a falling star the last thing one wants is a little riff from the flutes and pipes. Morrison's device of having three actors play Peer - two black and one white in a multi-racial cast - also raises difficulties. It gets over the age problem but it undermines Ibsen's key point that Peer, whether a boy fantasist or a middle-aged adventurer, remains locked in the tyranny of self. Three into one will go but at some cost.

But although there is much in this production to dislike -including Francis O'Connor's set assembled out of the usual supply of old trunks and packing cases - there are moments when Ibsen's play still grabs one by the throat.

In a somewhat shambolic first half, the death of Peer's mother, Ase, comes across strongly because of Chiwetel Ejiofor's graceful tenderness as he thanks his mum for her "beatings and babysongs".

This version also whisks us quickly through the hero's often interminable African adventures, allowing Patrick O'Kane as Peer two to register a resilient irony as he constantly makes and loses fortunes. But in the last third, with Joseph Marcell as the grizzled, homebound Peer, Ibsen comes into his own and you begin to forget Morrison's musicalised softening.

Ronald Pickup is a fine, craggy Button-Moulder, making the most of that extraordinary injunction - "to be oneself is to lose oneself" - and Olwen Fouere's austerely patient Solveig removes any hint of sentimentality from the idea of redemption through love. It may not be a peerless Gynt and it has much to infuriate one. But it is not a disgrace. And there is something so moving in Ibsen's notion of a man journeying through life in order to discover the need to abandon the egotistic self, that one surrenders to the dramatist's vision if not to the production as a whole.

In repertory. Box office: 020-7452 3000. This review appeared in some editions of yesterday's paper.

fields.headline: The Farewell
fields.standfirst: London film festival **
fields.trailText: London film festival **
fields.body:
Having agonised at length over the logistics of filming the life of playwright Bertold Brecht, screenwriter Klaus Pohl and director Jan Schutte eventually opted for a novel approach. Subtitled Brecht's Last Summer, The Farewell shelves the life and cuts straight to the death.

It unfolds through one dawn-till-dusk day in the August of 1956, Schutte's camera ambling leisurely around a lakeside summer house in Brandenburg. The result is part-Ulysses, part- portrait of the artist as an ageing stud.

Nestled at the film's centre sits Josef Bierbichler's effective portrayal of the Brecht of popular myth, hunched in his work clothes over a typewriter as he pops his heart pills, cuts a fart and scowls behind thick-framed specs like a bulldog chewing a wasp. Orbiting him are Brecht's women: his wife, his daughter, an adoring young assistant, the neurotic ex-mistress and the philosopher's wife he is banging on the side.

To all intents and purposes, the setting is that of a bucolic summer idyll. But storm-clouds are gathering in the shape of secret police who have set up checkpoints in order to snare a political dissident. Mrs Brecht knows of the impending crisis but has kept him in the dark, mindful of her husband's failing health.

The basic plot furniture of The Farewell is that of a drawing-room comedy, full of incessant comings and goings, romantic misunderstandings and heated squabbles around the luncheon table. What's different is the tone and tempo.

Perhaps mindful of the fatal finale up ahead, Schutte's film appears in no rush to get there. On the contrary, it fairly luxuriates in its sombre ambience, trailing its hero as he shuffles between his ladies, now more a sexual voyeur than a participant. So Brecht sits in his armchair and watches as his assistant goes skinny-dipping in the lake. The cinema- tography is a wash of amber; the soundtrack a hum of lapping waves and distantly barking dogs, all underpinned by a tinkling, minor-key piano score from John Cale.

Like Brecht, you find yourself drifting slowly towards an eternal sleep.

At the Odeon West End 2, London WC2 (020-7928 3232), tonight.

fields.headline: Retail therapy
fields.standfirst:
Staff morale is at rock bottom. Waiting lists never end. The food is absolutely ghastly. And the complaints keep rolling in... So what can the NHS learn from a supermarket? Esther Addley on the health trust that has called in Asda

Special report: The Future of the NHS
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Staff morale is at rock bottom. Waiting lists never end. The food is absolutely ghastly. And the complaints keep rolling in... So what can the NHS learn from a supermarket? Esther Addley on the health trust that has called in Asda
fields.body:
Imagine a National Health Service in which there is unlimited, free parking for every in-patient. In which the corridors are sparkling, the drug cupboard shelves groaning with every product imaginable. In which patients are greeted at the door with a smile and a "how may I help you?" from a worker exuding happiness. In which waiting lists are a thing of the past: as soon as there are more than two people queueing for an operation, the powers-that-be simply open another facility.

Fantasy? The "health service with a smile" may not be as far away as you think. Managers of a Leeds NHS trust have this week launched an unlikely collaboration which they hope will improve the working conditions of staff while making a hospital visit a considerably more pleasant experience for patients. And the model of corporate life they want to emulate is the supermarket group Asda.

It's a long time since we started thinking of ourselves as consumers rather than "patients", "passengers" or "users", but there seems something particularly incongruous about an association between the hyper-competitive supermarket industry and the lumbering NHS.

It's all very well telling the public that they are are health service customers, but most of its habitual shoppers are not in a position to change brands if they don't like the product. But it is the health service workers - especially the non-medical staff, such as porters and receptionists, who are being targeted by the Leeds scheme - who may feel they have most cause for complaint. As if it weren't enough to push sick people around crowded hospitals all day on broken trolleys for low wages, they will have to do it sporting a smile and a "happy to help" badge.

The NHS certainly seems to be taking seriously the fashionable exhortation to find new ways to work. It has recently appointed the gastronome Loyd Grossman to sort out hospital food, which may see canteen staff more accustomed to slopping out grey cabbage retraining in the skills of cordon bleu. And last week managers at Great Ormond Street hospital in London invited engineers from the McLaren Formula One team to teach its orderlies the methods it uses to shave seconds off a pit stop, thus saving valuable seconds during heart surgery. But can a supermarket's working practices really play a role in transforming the morale of NHS employees?

The NHS is looking closely at Asda's working models, which include a daily "huddle" to exchange information about the company: an NHS delegation to one of the company's stores was yesterday involved in a huddle in the fresh fruit and veg area, according to a spokeswoman. The company has also outlawed the term "staff", referring to employees as "colleagues". This has nothing to do with the company's takeover by the US group WalMart, she hastens to add. There, shelf-stackers are known as "associates".

She does not mention whether NHS managers will be encouraged to adopt Asda's curiously motivational approach to hygiene - a system of yellow "Archie bins" introduced into stores some years ago when Archie Norman, now shadow environment secretary, was at the helm. Similarly, the prospect of hospital car parks being turned into drive-in cinemas and ice rinks (as the supermarket has done in the past two months) is a tantalising one. Either way, the NHS visitors will achieve a great deal, says Asda's spokeswoman, "if they can empower their staff and make them feel as important as our colleagues feel."

Perhaps it is too easy to scoff at the notion of aspiring to the job satisfac tion felt by someone who operates a till for a living. Asda is, after all, a member of the government-endorsed group Employers for Work-Life Balance, and was judged "employer of the year" in 1998 by the campaiging group Parents At Work. It offers child-care leave during school holidays, study leave for students going away to college, career breaks for "colleagues" who want to extend maternity leave, and up to three months off for full-time carers over 50, regardless of position or length of service.

Steve McGuire, manager of support services for the Leeds Teaching Hospitals Trust, talks evangelistically about embracing the "Asda philosophy" in his hospital trust and throughout the NHS. "The average rate of pay of our ancillary staff is equal-ish to the rate of pay that the Asda staff get. The type of staff we employ in terms of conditions are broadly comparable to the Asda staff. We still have a largely female domestic cleaning staff, for instance. I want to create a situation where the issues that are not tolerable in a supermarket are no longer tolerated in a hospital. If there's a queue, or something is broken, that should not be tolerated."

At this point the hearts of hardworking public sector staff plummet, as they detect yet another exhortation to work harder and be happier and provide better services. "If a new philosophy is imposed in a hamfisted and inappropriate way it's enormously demoralising for staff to embrace," says Andy Westwood, senior policy specialist at the Industrial Society. "But anything that demonstrates the value of looking at people as users rather than statistics is to be welcomed. It doesn't matter if you are a supermarket or a provider of health care. It's about realising that individual people make a difference to your business. It doesn't matter if they are staff or consumer."

This is straightforward stuff. McGuire thinks it could not be more straightforward. In fact, he can't think why the NHS hasn't been run on supermarket-style levels of customer service for years. But isn't his vision of a hospital where nothing is broken, nothing is lacking, where the staff are always satisfied and the consumer always leaves happy impossible? "Nothing is impossible!" he booms. Then, smilingly: "It would be fair to say that my background is not in the public sector."

fields.headline: Auke de Vries
fields.standfirst: Yorkshire Sculpture Park, West Bretton ***
fields.trailText: Yorkshire Sculpture Park, West Bretton ***
fields.body:
There are some artists who like to play at being kids. Charles Baudelaire saw creativity as childhood recovered at will. Andy Goldsworthy arranges leaf circles in the artistic equivalent of children building sand castles.

The tree house sculptor Auke de Vries has none of the exquisite decadence of Baudelaire. Yet when he thinks big, his grown-up experience achieves a viewpoint from which innocent wonderment seems again almost within reach. His Watchtower stands 11 metres high on the sloping hillside of the Yorkshire Sculpture Park. A skeletal metal tree leans precariously, topped by a little yellow house that stood out in perfect compliment to the drifting clouds. Crows flew by to check it out. I wondered whether one of them might set up home there. It was one of those moments when fancy goes to work, uninhibited by the self-consciousness of art appreciation.

There is not much here to appeal to those who presume profundity is automatically aligned with misery. De Vries takes his cue from the motley-coloured semi-abstract surrealism of Miro. His sculptures are joyfully twisted. In the Pavilion Gallery he has set up a forest of model tree houses inhabited by the occasional lone cardboard cut-out figure. The houses have been brightly daubed and furnished with an assortment of tiny windows, chairs, ladders and bird cages. One is decorated with what, true to scale, would be a giant carnival mask. Many are equipped with bizarre funnel contraptions that look as if they have been installed for listening in to heavenly white noise.

From one dangles a tail that quivers in the draft from the park. The insectile oddness of their construction is unfortunately contradicted by their being elevated on a series of white plinths. It must be said that the plinths are a big mistake. Just when you begin to be taken in by de Vries's miniature world, they isolate the individual pieces to make one think of them as proper sculptures.

As I escape the gallery, the towering outdoor piece charms me back into seeing the surrounding countryside as part of the dream.

Until February. Details: 01924 830579.

His sculptures are joyfully twisted. In the Pavilion Gallery he has set up a forest of model tree houses inhabited by the occasional lone cardboard cut-out figure. The houses have been brightly daubed and furnished with an assortment of tiny windows, chairs, ladders and bird cages. One is decorated with what, true to scale, would be a giant carnival mask. Many are equipped with bizarre funnel contraptions that look as if they have been installed for listening in to heavenly white noise. From one dangles a tail that quivers in the draft from the park. The insectile oddness of their construction is unfortunately contradicted by their being elevated on a series of white plinths. It must be said that the plinths are a big mistake. Just when you begin to be taken in by de Vries's miniature world, they isolate the individual pieces to make one think of them as proper sculptures. As I escape the gallery, the towering outdoor piece charms me back into seeing the surrounding countryside as part of the dream. Until February. Details: 01924 830579.
